grasped in the ambient room translate into activity outside the rave. So if

Hello everyone,

	This is Greg from Harmony. At Friday night's Harmony party 
someone intentionally/unintentionally made off with one of our most 
meaningful, important props! At the party we had a stuffed animal room, 
where you were free to keep whichever animal you wanted as a companion 
for the night and the rest of your life. However, there were two stuffed 
animals that were not part of this adoption policy. If you noticed on 
the stage above the dj table, there were two Sesame Street charactors. 
Elmo was one and Ernie was the other. At the end of the party while I 
was spinning, I guess some people found their way up to the stage and 
adopted Ernie. Ernie and Elmo were not up for adoption that night, 
infact we tied them to the stage so they would get to cought up in the 
party and disappear!
	The owner of Ernie is very upset that someone has adopted her 
Ernie without her permision. Ernie was a birthday present given to her 
from her fiance. This gift meant a lot to her and him! Ernie was and 
still is a tremendous influence on both their lives! Ernie means a lot 
to these people, please help find him!!! If you know anyone who was at 
Harmony who might know where Ernie is please write back or call the 
Harmony voicemail @ (408)486.9591
	Ernie is about two and a half feet tall, he has orange 
complection, black hair, big eyes, blue sneakers, a stripped shirt, and 
a big smile!!!!! Last reported sight of Ernie was on the stage at 
Harmony, kicking back with his good buddy Elmo. 
	Please, if you have any info. on this incident respond 
immediatly!!!!!! We need all the help we can get in finding little 
Ernie. 

Peace, love and harmony to all,

Shroomy

- There are NO cuts in the school lunch program, despite endless Democrat

lunch program, Clinton's budget proposed a 3.1% increase...

- A majority of "poor" people - using the government's definition - own a TV
and a microwave oven.  A sizeable plurality own cars as well.

- I've seen truly poor people in India - hardly anyone here is that poor.

Recently , Greg from Harmony posted about how Harmony went -
> Hello all you beautiful sfravers,
> 
> 	This is Greg from Harmony. I would like to first thank everybody 
> who helped make last night a dream come true!!!!!! Mostly everything 
> worked out great, (one problem with one of the locals.) I really send my 
> extra special thanks to all of you who showed up, and brought love to 
> the party!!! 

 Well ,you're welcome! I brought my wife Mary ( we were the older couple -
asain male in big sun/moon tshirt and large white gal with the tshirt with 
the black celtic design on it ). We both had a good time , for the short time
we were there. ( I had to work on Saturday , so we left during Ethan's set ).
My wife usually doesn't get out to dance as much as I do , so it was great
to have her with me! We were the folks who brought the bananas , the chocolate,
and the date bits. Did they get eaten?

> You guys/girls were amazing!!! I had a beautiful time, 
> (after dealing with the stress!)
 I felt a little bit guilty about not telling your parking lot guides
about the complaint I had received from onee of the apartment tenants
earlier. She asked me to move my truck out of the tenants' parking,
which was the very area your parking lot guides were telling people to
park! 

> We did loose a good bit of money, but that's what makes it fun!!!

 Just don't get into the habit of such economics for future events!

> 
> ps. How did you like the river of life?!!  
> 
 My wife thinks the water is circulated , and there is a Disneyland 
aspect to it. Is it real mountain water , or what? Looked nice!

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

Hello everyone:

We at Orbitrecords have some extra inventory on our first single, so if
you haven't heard it yet, here's your chance.  The record is the first
Induction 12", featuring the songs "Attempt" and "Electrostatic". 
Though they're hard to classify, both songs can be considered melodic
acid breakbeat.

Also still available from us is Induction's GONE album, on cassette
only.  This album was recorded about a year ago, and though we initially
decided to stop producing the tape, requests for more of them have
prompted us to produce more.

I know people on the list have both of these things, so if you like what
you heard, let us know!

Also, if you have a WWW browser, you can listen to the tracks before
deciding whether or not to purchase.  Here's the URL:

    http://hyperreal.com/music/label/orbitrecords

Here's how to get the stuff:

    o The OR001 12" is $4 plus $2.50 shipping
    o The Gone cassette is $5 plus $2.00 shipping.

    o make checks payable to Sami Khoury

    o send to:

        Orbitrecords
        1600 Walnut Street, Apt B
	Berkeley, CA 94709

If you have any questions, please feel free to call us at our voicemail
box: 412.392.1505

Thanks for all the support so far, and look for our new record in the
month of May.

	Sami

sunset, actually.  Got shut down while the sun still had a good 2.5
hours before hitting the sea.  The space was pretty amazing--a random
park in Richmond, a big bay-level open space of thick soft thistles
and grass.  MANY people there by the time the police showed, which
was a good six hours after things began.  It couldn't have been a more
beautiful day, no way, not possible, and the many smiling moving 
ravers were digging it completely... the beats generated some great
surrounding energy fields that some of us noticed while feeling the
rhythm flow through.

Now it's getting towards dusk and I'm back home, and wanted to share
some of this springtime vibe with you all while it's still fresh. We
will keep it going, no matter what, and have the time of our lives
doing it.

Rob Jellinghaus		robj@netcom.com

I didn't say at all that there's very little hope for the planet;  indeed
if I'm accused of anything in the Uk and here it's that I'm far too
*positive* about it.  realistically I'd say we have a 50/50 chance at tbis
point, perhaps a little better. 

what I also say, however, is that we can't rely on truisms like "Truth 
must ultimately prevail".  How does lee or anyone know that?  it hasn't 
happened up till now, so why assume it will happen?  it *can* happen if 
wisdom prevails in time.  I actually believe that we, WoMankind, has 
been on the wrong competitive track for a very long time and we ar now 
running out of time and space, and that's why there is a hope, for the 
first time in history and the last time, that we can raise our voices and 
our banners and actually *change* the system. in our lifetimes, even mine.

what lee says about RC is almost the same as I'm saying - only I'm giving
it all a much shorter time context because that's what I see and believe. 
hence all the news about system collapse that zippies seem to revel in
sometimes.  for the system to be actually changed an increasing number of
people have to see clearly that it is not working, is collapsing (whatever
our opinion about that may be) and that there's actually HERE AND NOW and
worldwide a new culture, RC, which is already spreading at warp speed that
is largely and fundamentalyy about another wqay of living and relating.
and can help to establish the positive cooperative fun-loving
compassionate cultural attitude that needs to become :fashionable" for the
main cultural establishment behind the system to bring about or at least 
accept the necessary change. 

in other words the culture that we need to change the old system is around 
us.  in the Uk it's a national affair and virtually the dominant social 
meme among a new generation.  australia too, as captain crunch has been 
telling us.  etc.  and it's going national here too - and, I repeat, 
america is both the greatest threat to and the best hope for ... the planet.

what happens with RC here is crucial in the world picture. also because 
from here the new meme gets broadcast around the planet.  do we really 
want america to spead a culture of beavis and meathead?  does that please 
and reassure the goddess that all is well?

see you on evolution's barricades. (actually everyone on sfraaes is 
already there - not all realise it fully yet is all.)

fraser.

Subject: House Party in the Hinterlands
Date: 02 Apr 1995 19:00:20 GMT
Message-Id: <152235998.67088@macshasta.snowcrest.net>
Organization: Rich Renouf
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello,

The further away you get from a major metropolitan area, the less "rave" and
more "party" you get.

I went to an odd little house party last night out here in the boondocks.

Seems that someone who's parents were away knew the local promoter, and a
party was created by simply getting a few DJs and posting the info on the
hotline.

This house was like one in Pacific Heights (except that out here, what would
be $3 million in S.F. is probably ~$600,00), ie 3 stories on a hill with a
room on the bottom floor half built into the hillside and half facing out
over the pool.  The result being that, when the door to the patio was shut,
you could barely hear the sound system (full volume) outside.  Ideal.

Also ideal were clean restrooms and free water (in fact some people helped
themselves to the refrigerator contents :-(  ) and  ( the Captn would like
this) clear air - everyone took their smoking outside.

And the party was free - in honor of someone's birthday who hardly anyone
knew. :-)

Everyone was very friendly (no one was treated as a stranger), but not much
ravey hugging and "significant eye contact" (actually too dark for that -
usually not much in the way of dance lighting out here).  Plenty of beer and
patio conversations...

Over the past year, the house music around here has gotten significantly
better/ more advanced.  It used to be strictly happy house discoey divas,
lots of vocals.  Last night had few vocals, lots of aceeed and tribal
rhythms.  Still mostly 120-125 bpm.
The best DJ was Paul J.  Unfortunately most of the best stuff had very
cryptic labels (I'm dreaming of a "scratchable" CD turntable with an LCD
screen with artist and track names), but a few tracks that I did notice were:

The Love Tribe - Together   (this did have some vocals)
Marco Polo - A Prayer to the Music  ( I like that name )
Speedy J - [label said "7" but that might be the label name - anyone know?]

Anyone familiar with any of the above?   Are these ancient history in S.F.? 
Cheese Wiz? :-)

Ken
ken@macshasta.com
send bounces to ken.stuart@tigerteam.org

Precedence: bulk

WOW, what a beautiful first sunset party.  Couldn't ask for better 
wheather, the vibe was great.  Friendly smiles everywhere and a nice new 
spot.
The high lights of the party was the spontaneous cheering and shouting 
when the sun set, increasing everyone's energy causing people to jump up 
and down in rythmic joy.  Another beautiful high light was the forming of a 
big circle as people first joined hands, then danced in the circle.  As 
the energy of all the togetherness and sharing mounted, everyone rushed 
to the center jumping and hooting with extatic pleasure. 
Another great thing I like about the sunset parties is that people also 
get to know one another a little more intimately.  Very nice atmosphere 
for friendly conversation, which I find very difficult in clubs where 
there isn't any quiet spots and you have to shout in someones ear to be 
heard.
Springtime is definitely here, there's that special feeling in the air.

peter

Yeah, yeah yeah. Sunset is Baaaaack!!!  So am I.  I hadn't been out in
months, with the exception of my trip to Frankfurt a month ago which left me
with a near-pneumonia case of bronchitis which means no party, definately no
smoke, just rest -- very boring, but  I can go to....Sunset was beautiful in
every way (though I wished the sound system was facing the other way and
further out in the park so that everyone was facing the sunset.)  Those big,
happy cheering moments sent chills up my spine and over the top of my head
and up -- told ya I hadven't been out in a while :-)  I'll write something up
on my Frankfurt experience one of these days too.
C-ya next sunday!

     As WICKED flyers always have a neat or witty little quote to enhance 
     the visuals, I thought I'd add my 0.02 cents in the review of this 
     month's party...
     
     
     "Amazing were the beats played on the menu
      But sorely lacking once again was the venue "
     
     :)
     
     
     Sy

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Apr  3 13:42:51 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id NAA21861; Mon, 3 Apr 1995 13:42:51 -0700
Received: from ns.PacBell.COM by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with SMTP id NAA21854; Mon, 3 Apr 1995 13:42:48 -0700

Received: from lizard.srv.PacBell.COM by pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA02405; Mon, 3 Apr 95 13:42:43 PDT
Date: Mon, 3 Apr 95 13:42:43 PDT
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9504032042.AA02405@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Ravers United to Save the Earth
Cc: jlf3@mofo.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Recent dicussions about Rave Culture's (RC)* role in improving the global 
situation have inspired us to form an organization whose purpose will be to 
propose specific RC-based solutions to the many problems that now plague us.
Seeing how little time there is to affect change and save this planet, we 
feel that it is no longer satisfactory to simply sit back and wait for 
our "meme" to spread or for PLUR to become fashionably mainstream.  This 
memorandum will be the first in a series of concrete proposals that will
force humanity to take better care of itself and its environment. 

Proposal I: Mandatory Bean Bag Laws
-----------------------------------

1.a. Starting in 1997, all new cars will be required to use bean bag chairs 
for all seating.  The added cushioning should help reduce injury in case of 
accident while maintining (if not improvng) comfort to passengers.  This 
measure should also help drive down insurance rates and the resultant 
lighter weighted cars should see a boost in fuel efficiency.

1.b. All airline carriers to be completely retrofitted with bean bag chairs.  
In addition to the increased safety padding, bean bag chairs with Styrofoam 
beans make excellent floatation devices.  As an added benefit, airplanes 
completely laden with bean bag chairs will no longer need seatbelts, 
eliminating wasteful seatbelt instruction time during takeoff.

1.c.0. All schools, stadiums, restaurants and workplaces in earthquake-prone
areas will be required to have all seating converted to bean bag chairs
by the end of 1998.  Our government's ineptitude in making our buildings
quake-proof can no longer be tolerated!

1.c.1.0. Other mass transit seating - as per section 1.c.0

1.d. The government will finance the free replacement of all wheelchairs 
for the handicapped with new, high quality, *wheelbags* (patent pending).

1.e. The resulting demand for bean bag chairs that will result from these
laws will create much economic opportunity.  Economically deprived areas
will be given the exclusive rights to establish bean bag chair manufacturing
plants, creating a multitude of jobs and capital influx for these troubled
neighborhoods.

1.e. Realizing that imposing one style of furniture on an entire population
conflicts with an individual's right to free expression, bean bag chair
manufacturers will be required to offer bean bag chairs in a variety of
colors and patterns, to be voted upon by local community representatives
who will be selected in special bi-yearly elections.  Airlines will be
exempted from this, since bean bag floatation devices will have to be a
bright orange or pink in order to be easily spotted at sea.

Next: Proposal II - Mandatory Hugging Laws.  

Brought to you by Ravers United to Save the Earth (RUSE); fighting, with
luv, for a Rave New World.

*RC is a copyrighted symbol of RUSE Inc. not to be confused with the "RC"
of RC Cola fame.


ObSFRavesContent - Sunset was good.  Music was so-so.  Police seemed
amused, dog walkers confused, tow truck operators enthused.  Cyril played 
a Richard Kirk song.

I just wanted to thank everyone for an absolutely BEAUTIFUL weekend.  A 
sunny Saturday afternoon with Mother Earth Sound System and a great group 
of friendly smiling people.... A great time at Wicked (although I heard 
horror stories about the length of time some people waited in line...also 
too crowded until late in the night).  A bigger space for an anniversary 
party would have been more appropriate (but I did appreciate them 
kepping it going until about 8:15).  Back home to chill for a few hours 
and off to Sunset.  What a wonderful way to top off an already great 
weekend.  These parties made my summer last year and I'm so glad they 
will be happening again this year.  Summer is here!! 

Keep smilin'

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Apr  4 01:17:31 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id BAA08631; Tue, 4 Apr 1995 01:17:31 -0700
Received: from well.sf.ca.us by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with ESMTP id BAA08617; Tue, 4 Apr 1995 01:17:28 -0700
Received: (from phred@localhost) by well.sf.ca.us (8.6.10/8.6.9) id BAA10952 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Tue, 4 Apr 1995 01:17:30 -0700
Date: Tue, 4 Apr 1995 01:17:30 -0700
From: Fred Heutte <phred@well.sf.ca.us>
Message-Id: <199504040817.BAA10952@well.sf.ca.us>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Another Wild Weekend!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I flew in Friday morning from Portland and arrived in so-so weather,
which was kind of disappointing after the nice weather at home all week.
But no matter (and actually the weather was quite nice all weekend!).
Did a little spinning at Ameba in the afternoon, chatted with Markie,
Jeno and Terrence Toy (who is producing a new house release called 
"Everybody Is a Star" featuring an excellent "OOBE Astral" remix by
Ameba's own OOBE/Andrew, I got to give Andrew a pleasant surprise by
playing it as he was walking back in after a break :).  Gavin Hardkiss
came by with copies of *his* new CD which also looks really good.

But the big news at Ameba, I have-ta-tell-ya, is ELECTRO.  Yes friends,
the Electro Revival is now in full swing, dust off those old Herbie
Hancock disks and catch the new ones from artists like the Jedi Knights
and Deluxe.  Allen Ameba says (perhaps only half in jest) that he wants
Ameba to be the West Coast's electro headquarters.  I told him why stop
there?! 

I went down to the lower Haight to help gather materials for the New Moon
party and stopped in briefly at Zebra Records, an interesting shop which
has good hip hop and acid jazz and, over in one of the bins, the *only*
West African 12" singles I've ever seen in the States.  I snagged two
Francos, a Pepe Kalle and a Zaiko Langa Langa, ah soukous!!

Michelle drove Mona and me up to the New Moon location up in the hills
of West Marin, the area of Inverness to be exact, north of Olema which
in turn is north of Bolinas, out on the coast.  The location was a house
at the top of a narrow drive up in secondary growth redwoods, a really
nice area.  Greg and Ann also were there and soon we had boxes of
decorations into the house and began setting up around 11.  

I know there were problems finding the party, but many people did manage.
The only difficulty then was that the sound system was late showing up.
Someone brought in an amp and I started playing tapes from the January
New Moon to fill in, and finally the real system arrived around 2.  I kicked
off with about a two and a half hour set that I thought went over very well.
All over the musical map as usual, a little ambient at the beginning, some
trancey house and housey trance, and a half-hour of dub which went over
amazingly well.  There were two main party rooms with sound from the DJ
setup, so it was kind of a guess as to how things were going in the other
room.  In addition, due to the late start it seemed like the party vibe
had a very hard time getting going.  But no matter . . . anyway, DJ relief
arrived at 5 am and I went outside for some fresh air.

Shortly thereafter we were faced with one of those situations where we have
to stop paying attention to what we are enjoying and instead deal with what
happening in real life.  And what was happening was two different and
particularly difficult to deal with bad acid trips.  It freaked out a lot
of people and put a damper on the vibe, to be sure, but . . .

But what happened was in itself quite amazing.  It took a long time, and
we were clumsy and somewhat uncoordinated in our efforts, but eventually
an amazing gathering of people and energy occurred, with many people
offering help and suggestions in a *positive* fashion, and the crisis
eventually passed with, at least in the case I'm most familiar with, no
bad effects.  I want to offer my sincere and deepest thanks to all who
helped us through this struggle to help our friends.  The situation called
on all of us to push our envelopes of reaching out and caring and working
for a good solution in a situation that was difficult to comprehend and
even frightening at moments.  The sight of two dozen people gathered in
a circle and offering their hands and hearts and voices has to be one of
the most powerful things I've ever experienced.  We need to take care of
each other in many ways, and sometimes in ways that are hard to imagine.
I am so thankful that, regardless of our uncertainty and inefficiency,
the most important thing of all happened, which is that many people 
gathered together and *stuck with it* for as long as it was needed.
And when it was over we went out into a beautiful and sunny if suddenly
windy and chilly morning (the wind having shifted right around sunrise).

I know for myself it's important to learn a bit more about the right way
to deal with the personal emergencies that can happen at our events or
really at any time.  What happened that night was not really anyone's
fault, but it can happen to anyone who alters their consciousness knowingly
or, as in the case with those who are unfortunate enough to have innate
chemical imbalances or other problems (epilepsy, for example), who are
simply subject to the changes that their bodies go through regardless.
We all have our physical and mental frailties and incompleteness to deal
with, and it is so important to remember that we all need help with those
sooner or later.  So, as the I Ching so often instructs, No Blame, and
move on to those actions which the Superior Person should follow to move
forward . . .

The remainder of the party was actually very enjoyable, I especially enjoyed
the sets by Charlotte and Manny, who brought us excellent hip hop and
'70s funk flavas.  The New Moon continues to chart its unpredictable and
ever-rewarding course!

We drove down to Bolinas and spent the day just hanging about and had
a couple of trips to the Bolinas Bakery, which I'd never visited but is
run by a couple of longtime Deadhead friends of mine.  The drive from
Olema to Bolinas was just amazing, running right through earthquake
country with all these little jumbled hillocks and curvy roads and the
greenest Oregon-green foliage thanks to the excess of rain over the
winter.  Finally we drove back to the City around sunset with a
spectacular view from the spine of Mt. Tam.

Saturday evening I was pretty worn so not into the expected heat and
smoke and crowding in the DV8 basement for Wicked (besides they are
coming to visit *me*, er, Portland in a couple of weeks :).  Instead 
I went to a very cool little gathering at the Cafe Bastille down in
the financial district, put together by Sunshine and Moonbeam of Dub Tribe
and Corey Black.  It's a nice place with an upstairs bar and a downstairs
dining area where the DJs were set up, including Sunshine (whose old skool
deep house set I missed) and Corey and others.  A nice house/discoey kind
of thing without the usual club attitude and the nice price of $2 . . .
I think they'll do another one like this (it was called Vanilla Fudge)
every so often.  

Sunday we made our way over to Richmond to a new site for Sunset at
Point Isabel Park, right off the Central Ave exit of 880.  What a *place*!
I liked it even more than the Marina (although the Marina has nice
features too).  It's right next to the Bay Area post office bulk mailk
center where all the mail going in and out of the area is processed.
The park itself is basically designated as a dogs-run-free thing, so
all the local dog owners were out with their canine pals running around.
Sunset was set up basically in the center of a several-acre CLOVER field.
Those who don't know, lissen up!  Clover is the BEST outdoor dancing
and hanging-out surface ever.  And this *particular* clover field faces
the Golden Gate Bridge, with a perfect view of San Francisco to the 
southwest, Marin to the Northwest and the Berkeley Hills behind.
The cops came around 5, mostly concerned about cars in the no-parking
areas around the BMC.  I won't steal Ronan's story about this from him,
but suffice it to say they talked for some time, checked out the scene
and then left once it was clear that cars would be moved where needed.
In the meantime we had beautiful sun and cool breezes and, finally, thje
sun set directly over Mt. Tam, slipping behind the peak as a great shout
went up from the massive, and then the thinnest sliver of the new moon
with the rest of the darkened disk still visible high above in the western
sky.  And Galen, Solar, John Howard (who played 'Mobilize', yay!) spinning
the good ole groovy SF zoundz.  I don't know how often this site will be
usable, there must have been 500 people and this is only the first Sunset
of the year, so handling what is inevitably going to be a bigger and 
bigger crowd is a serious issue.  I'd hate to burn out this site, perhaps
the Pacific crewe will use it sparingly this year because it's a great one!

To round out a great day, of course, the ever-reliable Libo Lounge at 
Il Pirata, it's a great way to relax and just hang out informally and
enjoy good music and dance a bit.  Don't forget to ask the bartenders
for something good to drink, you never know what they might suggest but
they're all good (both alcoholic and non-alcoholic drinks).

Don't know when I'll be back in town, sometime soon I hope.  But it was
an eventful (sometimes amazingly so) weekend!

c u
phred

Fraser (fraser@megatripolis.org) replied:
>I didn't say at all that there's very little hope for the planet;  indeed
>if I'm accused of anything in the Uk and here it's that I'm far too
>*positive* about it.  realistically I'd say we have a 50/50 chance at tbis
>point, perhaps a little better
>what I also say, however, is that we can't rely on truisms like "Truth 
>must ultimately prevail".  How does lee or anyone know that?  it hasn't 
>happened up till now, so why assume it will happen?  it *can* happen if 
>wisdom prevails in time.  I actually believe that we, WoMankind, has 
>been on the wrong competitive track for a very long time and we ar now 
>running out of time and space, and that's why there is a hope, for the 
>first time in history and the last time, that we can raise our voices and 
>our banners and actually *change* the system. in our lifetimes, even mine.

I think that the only point I disagree with you on is "we are running out of 
time and space".  (And I think giving us a "50/50" chance is just being less
negative than others :-) rather than being positive).

To me any attitude or action taken because "we are running out of time
and space" is thereby happening out of fear, rather than a positive
celebration of life.  Even if only 400 people (rather than 4 billion) were
living
in negativity, the feeling of compassion would still dictate the same desire
to extend the "vibe" to them.

In the Vedas (the world's oldest known writings/sayings), time is said to
be a cycle of 4 eras or "yugas".   These eras run thousands of years.
The current one, "Kali Yuga", is the spiritually darkest era and began about
5,000 years ago or so.

I think that if one believes that mind/spirit is an accident in a material
world,
then fear always exists that it can be eliminated.
But, if one discovers that matter is just the playground of mind/spirit,
then,
as Zero the Hero says in the Planet Gong trilogy "You never blow your
trip forever".    (although you can really mess it up temporarily :-) ).

>and can help to establish the positive cooperative fun-loving
>compassionate cultural attitude that needs to become :fashionable" for the
>main cultural establishment behind the system to bring about or at least 
>accept the necessary change. 

If you like I can private e-mail you some paragraphs from Newt about how he
is
trying to help establish a positive cooperative compassionate cultural 
attitude in society (he feels that the bureaucratic dispensing of compassion
in the form of money (eg the "dole") whereby the compassion is supposed
to come from people who are only interested in how long it is until 5 PM, 
doesn't work, and needs to be replaced by private volunteer action by 
people who are really interested in the disadvantaged in society).

respect to all,

Ken
ken@macshasta.com
send bounces to ken.stuart@tigerteam.org

All of this may be true but bear in mind that if your car stalls on
the train crossing, all the positivity in the world won't eave you
if you don't move the car or yourselves before the train comes, being confident
that the engineer will see you in thime (or can stop the train in time is
clearly irresponsible on your part)  Basically I think fraser is being 
optimistic when he gives us a 50/50 chance, I guess the place that we differ
is in the ultimate outcome, I believe that the planet and most of it's life 
forms WILL survive but homo sapiens may be gone. (those pesky hairless monkeys)
We humans actually believe our own bullshit and think that because we are at
the top of the food chain, that gives us some form of divinity.

Well lets be realistic, no every human will not die but we may loose 25% - 50%
of the population, It may not be so bad here in the industrialized countries
(although white folks won't be able to go outside anymore :) but in Africa
and other parts of the world it will be a living hell, where so many dead
bodies lying around that diseases will multiply and make it _very_ uncomfortable
for the people who do survive.

I think Fraser is try to get people to realize that we need more than
"good time dancing" if we want to save the planet.  Thew Dance is definitely
a ralleying point and out of that strong bonding and aliances are formed.
I think for many it was a wake up call and Gaia's last ditch effort to reach
here children before she let's her sister Kali have a go.

> Is there now a standard format for audio in WWW?  If so, do you know what it
> is?

Umm, I don't believe so, but the most universal formats are probably 
.wav, .au, and MPEG.  These, incidentally, are the format our samples and 
most others in hyperreal's music archives are in.

> (It would be a help to me in selecting a sound card...)

This should not have too much to do with it, actually.  If you are 
worried about which formats you will be able to play/record, the software 
is the most important thing (assuming, of course, that you do not get 
shitty hardware ;), but most cards today can handle stereo/16, anyway).

	Sami

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Apr  4 11:05:18 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id LAA10507; Tue, 4 Apr 1995 11:05:18 -0700

	id LAA07459; Tue, 4 Apr 1995 11:02:28 -0700
Message-Id: <199504041802.LAA07459@netcom5.netcom.com>
To: ken_stuart@macshasta.snowcrest.net, red@hyperreal.com
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: :: orbitrecords 
In-reply-to: Your message of "03 Apr 95 18:05:50 GMT."
             <855048158.53852@macshasta.snowcrest.net> 
Date: Tue, 04 Apr 95 11:02:27 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> Is there now a standard format for audio in WWW?  If so, do you know what it
> is?

The "de facto" standard audio format on the web is Sun/NeXT 8k format
(*.au). This gives pretty crappy audio quality, but it's the most 
widely used format out there on the web; most of the web browsers I've
used support this format by default... Be careful about using other
rates, since many older workstations can't support 16k, 22.05, 32k, or
44.1k sample per second sound files.

Sites like IUMA are trying to use MPEG2, but there aren't that many 
browsers set up to use this (or rather few people have the MPEG2
decoder nor have they set up their MIME types to run this decoder). I
occasionally see *.wav format "out there", but then you lose out on all
the unix boxes out there.

Your best bet is to support multiple formats for each sound byte.
Support 8k *.au format for the Unix weenies out there, *.wav for the
unwashed masses, and MPEG2 for those that want better sound quality. In
the future, we may even get the ability to automatically have the
server negotiate the kind of sound file it sends over based on  sound
playback capability information your browser sends to the server (see
also Simon Spero's MDMA web server -- Hi Simon!).... For now, you might
have something like
		Richie Hawtin's Expectorations in A-minor
			[click here to hear 8k Sun/NeXT format]
			[click here to hear WAV format]
			[click here to hear MPEG2 format]

Unfortunately, some of the better compression techniques out there,
e.g. Aware's Wavelet compression, aren't available for free, but can be
purchased for SGI workstations (with SGI's patented
shoot-yerself-in-the-foot-before-you-even-get-the-product-out-the-door
pricing structure added on to ensure that all SGI's cool software
remains out of the hands of the masses and destined for instantaneous
obscurity and obsolescense).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==     Niels Mayer -- http://cyborganic.com/~niels -- mayer@netcom.com     ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

a young man overdosed and died from taking two hits of Ecstasy at
a rave in SOMA on Friday night. His friend took one hit and was okay, but
after they returned home on Saturday morning, after a night of raving
the guy had a heart attack or something.

Does anyone know anything about this? It concerned me that one of
the few public mentions of a rave had to do with an overdose and
a death.

>I got a call from a friend of mine in the SF Bay area this morning.  A
>friend of his went to a rave last night where he bought and took a hit of
>X. An hour later he wasn't feeling much, so he bought and took another.
>Effects hit him shortly thereafter. Early this morning, he walked into
>his kitchen and passed out. His roommate came to find him puking blood
>all over the place. He called an ambulance, and then when he found that
>he had no more pulse, he tried resuscitation. By the time the ambulance
>arrived, he was dead.

A friend forwarded this to me yesterday. We were both taken rather aback 
by it, given the repeated assurances of safety one hears in the scene. I'm 
pretty reluctant to take it at face value given the very general nature of 
the facts, but of course, names and places aren't necessarily likely to 
come out. I'm no pharmacologist, but it seems likely it was something 
other than E that was ingested.

Yes, it is very unfortunate that the public's knowledge of the scene is 
often limited to these sorts of incidents, often taken from very 
inaccurate reports. For that same reason, if anyone 
has any other - preferably more concrete - details, please post (with the 
sort of discretion Milton and Joe discussed recently).

take care!
-nate

Subject: X fatality
Date: Tue, 04 Apr 95 15:29:00 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Finally, more reasons why I've been saying "don't do X"  for the last
few years... too bad people have to die to provide us with evidence....

Don't believe the hype (from the religious-X-as-panacea fanatics). X
won't get rid of your colds (RE a previous ridiculous thread on this
list), it'll nuke your immune system just like any other amphetamine,
and just like coke. X won't make the world a better place -- better
people will make the world a better place... and it's hard to be better
when you're dead or ill. Amphetamines are amphetamines no matter which
way you slice them... Wanna find out how wonderful these speedy things
are for you -- read David Crosby's autobiography, or take a look at his
liver...

Your momma,
	-- Niels.

I got a call from a friend of mine in the SF Bay area this morning.  A 
friend of his went to a rave last night where he bought and took a hit of 
X. An hour later he wasn't feeling much, so he bought and took another. 
Effects hit him shortly thereafter. Early this morning, he walked into 
his kitchen and passed out. His roommate came to find him puking blood 
all over the place. He called an ambulance, and then when he found that 
he had no more pulse, he tried resuscitation. By the time the ambulance 
arrived, he was dead.

In article <zillaD6FG8I.GoA@netcom.com>,
zilla@netcom.com (Jay Majer) wrote:

>I got a call from a friend of mine in the SF Bay area this morning.  A 
>friend of his went to a rave last night where he bought and took a hit of 
>X. An hour later he wasn't feeling much, so he bought and took another. 
>Effects hit him shortly thereafter. Early this morning, he walked into 
>his kitchen and passed out. His roommate came to find him puking blood 
>all over the place. He called an ambulance, and then when he found that 
>he had no more pulse, he tried resuscitation. By the time the ambulance 
>arrived, he was dead.

Sorry to hear about the loss of your friend, Jay. For a long time,
people thought that these deaths were a strictly British phenonenon,
and were related to heatstroke. Personally, I've always doubted that
thesis, and suspect that it was simply that more people were doing 
more of it here than anywhere else.

There just doesn't seem any way of predicting who might fall foul of
this horrible phenomenon. People who are going to take MDMA had better
be aware that this outcome is always a possibility, and is much less 
rare than people like to imagine.

- --
peter@petermc.demon.co.uk                                   Cool as fuck!

           OSA: Sack Milne and Stone. Reinstate Jet and Vera!

Message-ID: <zillaD6HCDz.K11@netcom.com>

References: <zillaD6FG8I.GoA@netcom.com> <040395091426Rnf0.78@weeds.xs4all.nl>
Date: Mon, 3 Apr 1995 22:13:11 GMT
Lines: 30
Sender: zilla@netcom10.netcom.com

In article <040395091426Rnf0.78@weeds.xs4all.nl> rich@weeds.xs4all.nl (Richard v.d. Horst) writes:
>Puking blood? Never heard anything like this. Did he also take other drugs
>(alcohol, or smoked coke or speed, or something else)? Can you give a
>medical reference for this? (Name of doctor in charge, his name)?

Since many people asked about this, let me clarify some things. First of 
all, I did not personally know the person that died last weekend. He was 
a close friend of one of my close friends. 

Now why is it important who the doctor was. By the time the ambulance 
arrived at the guy's place, he was already dead. BTW, this story made the 
news in San Francisco (and California), so anyone who wants "official" 
information, check the library. But he did not take anything else other 
than those two tablets, and six or seven hours later he was puking blood 
and died. 

Some people on here seem to take it for granted that drugs can be safe if 
taken responsibly. But remember that the people who make these outside 
the law don't have the same responsibilities. Perhaps the tablets he took 
weren't really MDMA. (I hear that most of the stuff that shows up at 
raves as "X" is actually speed or heroin.) Or maybe they were MDMA, and 
he unfortunately ODed or had an allergic reaction. I'm sure he wasn't the 
only one at the rave who took one of those particular tablets.

The point is that one shouldn't trust something they aquired from a 
stranger at a rave. I would never buy any drugs at a rave, but then 
again, I tend to stay away from synthetic drugs these days. Nothing but 
greens, mushrooms, and yeast-piss for me.

Puking blood might be from disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) which
is a documented problem with MDMA, although very rare.

Lamont Granquist (lamontg@u.washington.edu)

zilla@netcom.com (Jay Majer) writes:


Okay, lets get one thing straight.......
There is no heroine in tabs passed as E, it doesn't make sense to put 
heroine in e tabs, as the amount to smack you'd have to put in orally 
would make the tabs very very expensive to produce, so you'd be much 
better off just selling the smack, you'd make much more money....

The possiblity of this guy death being related to an alergic reaction is 
very possible. about 250,000 people die each year from perscription and 
OTC drugs in the US each year, MDMA is a very safe drug, very few ppl are 
actually allergic to it but it does happen, shit I've heard of death from 
asprin. So with out the death certificate or medical report ther're is no 
way of knowing what really happened but don't jump to the conclusion MDMA 
is a bad drug.... it's not....
There is an inherent risk with taking any drug, from asprin to heroine. 
know these risks....

>Some people on here seem to take it for granted that drugs can be safe if

I bet it _was_ MDMA. It sounds like a classic example of death from
Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation -- ie, your body overheats and
you start suffering from massive internal haemmoraging. I would also
bet that if someone was taken to a US hospital in this state, the A & E
crews wouldn't have the first idea how to respond.

If somebody that you know has a convulsion or passes out on MDMA, it is
vital that you try to keep their body temperature down. Call an 
ambulance immediately, and keep the body cool by sponging them with
iced water till the ambulance arrives, and tell them that you suspect
DIC from MDMA. It could save someone's life (and most people who get
this have died)

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Apr  4 16:09:03 1995

In-Reply-To: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
        "X fatality" (Apr  4,  3:29pm)
References: <199504042229.PAA13838@netcom22.netcom.com>
X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.2.0 06sep94)
To: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>,
        "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Re: X fatality
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

As the thread Neils posted indicates, this is a case where many people are
jumping to conclusions despite the lack of a full set of facts.  This is
certainly a tragedy, and I don't want to minimize that, but it seems most
unlikely that E was directly responsible for this person's death, although
it could have been a contributing factor.  The disseminated intravascular
coagulation effect seems more likely to occur when ventilation conditions
are poor and a person has overheated by dancing or other movement and not
drinking enough fluids.  But from the limited details reported here, it
appears that this person collapsed well after taking the E, probably well
after it had mostly metabolized, and at home rather than in a crowded,
hot club or warehouse.

Having seen some medical emergencies at events recently, it is important
to me anyway to be very careful about speculating as to causes and effects
without knowing the full story.  The characteristics of E and other drugs
are well established and documentation is widely available.  Not everyone
responds to any given substance or dosage level the same, not at all. 
And some people suffer dangerous reactions to things that don't affect
others.  This isn't just true of psychoactive drugs; I have a friend who
is so allergic to peanuts and other legumes that she could die if she ate
too many.  But one of the widely reported characteristics of E is that
it is considered relatively safe because the level at which unpleasant
but not dangerous reactions occur is well below the toxicity level.  

This is *not* to say that E or any other such drug is *safe*.  But the
particulars of the situation and contributing factors are at least as
important as the drug itself in the reported medical problems and 
fatalities that have occurred in conjunction with its use.

We owe it to ourselves to learn the facts about these matters so we can
recognize the danger signs when they occur in ourselves or our friends,
and know how to respond.

c u
phred

Precedence: bulk


>>I got a call from a friend of mine in the SF Bay area this morning.  A
>>friend of his went to a rave last night where he bought and took a hit of
>>X. An hour later he wasn't feeling much, so he bought and took another.
>>Effects hit him shortly thereafter. Early this morning, he walked into
>>his kitchen and passed out. His roommate came to find him puking blood
>>all over the place. He called an ambulance, and then when he found that
>>he had no more pulse, he tried resuscitation. By the time the ambulance
>>arrived, he was dead.
>
>A friend forwarded this to me yesterday. We were both taken rather aback
>by it, given the repeated assurances of safety one hears in the scene. I'm
>pretty reluctant to take it at face value given the very general nature of
>the facts, but of course, names and places aren't necessarily likely to
>come out. I'm no pharmacologist, but it seems likely it was something
>other than E that was ingested.
>
>Yes, it is very unfortunate that the public's knowledge of the scene is
>often limited to these sorts of incidents, often taken from very
>inaccurate reports. For that same reason, if anyone
>has any other - preferably more concrete - details, please post (with the
>sort of discretion Milton and Joe discussed recently).

I was wondering if anyone knew if this person had tried e before.  It is
possible that he had an allergic reaction to it.  Ecstasy may be illegal,
but it is almost as safe a drug as Tylenol, or milk for that matter.
Nobody knows what they are allergic to until they actually try a substance.
A friend of mine almost died when he was younger because he had a similar
reaction to milk.

What does make ecstasy from the black market unsafe are the extras that
manufacturers put into the tablets.  It could be adulterated with multiple
products.  However, it does not make sense for people to put shit like
heroin or a whole lot of speed into it.  Or crushed glass.  Who the hell
would take the time to crush glass so finely that he could make pills out
of it?  Why waste the effort?  And why drive up the cost of manufacture
with other expensive drugs like heroin, when a good starch filler will take
up the same space for a lot less money?

Anyway, getting off track.  This is one of the FEW ecstasy related deaths.
Unfortunately, media tends to focus on all that is bad in this world.  All
we will ever see on tv are the deaths from the drugs.  Never will the faces
of thousands of happy raving people be displayed on tv, for that would be
promoting the lifestyle of a censored subculture.  It is no of use for us
to create a mass scare about ecstacy.  You have as high a chance of dying
due to allergic reactions to prescription or OTC drugs.

We are constantly being fed biased information by society and government
like this every day.  Another example is with HIV(which doesn't really
pertain to ecstasy, but proves my point).  the Centers for Disease Control
have chosen not to publicize that the chance of getting HIV in heterosexual
males having unprotected sex is roughly 1 in 700, while in women it is 1 in
500.  A lot lower than the media would like you to believe, although still
a dangerous level. What would happen if the truth were known?  A lot more
unprotected sex.  This is the same reason we are not given a full
description of effects of ecstacy on users.

Well, i think that's enough for me.  Just remember to treat information
from the media as a viewpoint from a biased source.  If you want a more
impartial view, go to the library and check out a *bunch* of the latest
articles on the subjects of your choice.  Listen to the hype, but use your
head and the resources around you to check things out.

Luv y'all,



Rob McCord (BR '98)
mcrobt@minerva.cis.yale.edu

At 15:29 4/4/95, Niels P. Mayer wrote:

>Finally, more reasons why I've been saying "don't do X"  for the last
>few years... too bad people have to die to provide us with evidence....
>
>Don't believe the hype (from the religious-X-as-panacea fanatics). X
>won't get rid of your colds (RE a previous ridiculous thread on this
>list), it'll nuke your immune system just like any other amphetamine,
>and just like coke. X won't make the world a better place -- better
>people will make the world a better place... and it's hard to be better
>when you're dead or ill. Amphetamines are amphetamines no matter which
>way you slice them... Wanna find out how wonderful these speedy things
>are for you -- read David Crosby's autobiography, or take a look at his
>liver...
>
>Your momma,
>        -- Niels.
>

This might become non-SFR relevant soon, but I think any interested parties
should look at the MDMA FAQ on hyperreal. While MDMA is in the amphetamine
family, it's methods of action are quite different than those of plain
amphetamine, methamphetamine, and other stimulants and has different
physical effects on your body. Indeed, MDMA affects different
neurotransmitters and receptors than most other amphetamines. (serotonin as
opposed to dopamine) I know of no studies that indicate that MDMA is as
toxic as amphetamines and it is generally not used in the same patterns as
other amphetamines (i.e. increasing dosages and frequency of use leading to
heightened physical and mental stress) due to tolerence to it's
empathogenic effects.

A decision to use any drug needs to be made responsibly, however,
generalizations may only confuse the issue.

As far as the tragedy this past weekend goes, to much information is
missing for any of us to come to any conclusions just yet. Until the
specific drug(s) he ingested has been identified and any pre-existing
conditions have been ruled out, it might be wise to hold off on making
judgements.

Joe

Hate to revive a long dead thread, but a while back we were talking about
using noise cancelling technology (i.e., speakers using negative phasing) to
block the thump heard on the street generated by a rave.  It seemed too
difficult to use outdoors at the time.  Now I see that BART is using this
technology to silence the noise made by its cars on portion of track.  So
maybe someday...

Yes, one of the few, but nonetheless a tremendous tragedy for the
person and his family and friends (I'm starting to gather this story is
correct in the outcome, if not the cause). Phred's post brought that back 
into perspective for me. Even one avoidable death is too many.

Yes, the mainstream media distorts and promotes the negative. However, 
most of the supposedly objective literature I've read would have you 
believe that the only side-effects you'll ever experience are a sore jaw 
from E and an upset stomach from 'shrooms. I'd hate to find myself 
parroting this in a moment of hightened enthusiasm to a first-timer 
friend.

Now that summer's arriving and things are getting underway, would
some "knowlegable" person care to post a list of reasonable dangers 
and how to watch out for or react to them? Or perhaps a just pointer to a
WWW/FTP source?

Thanks!

On Mon, 3 Apr 1995, Rob McCord wrote:

> promoting the lifestyle of a censored subculture.  It is no of use for us
> to create a mass scare about ecstacy.  You have as high a chance of dying
> due to allergic reactions to prescription or OTC drugs.

Disclaimer: What follows is a bit off point from the E thread and you may 
already know this but...

Please please be careful out there, no matter what drug you're taking. 
Even if you're prescribed something, don't assume that the doctor knows 
what s/he is doing. I was prescribed Inderal (a beta-blocker) a few years 
ago. Twenty minutes after I had taken it, I had a full-on convulsion on a bus. 
I'll skip the gory details, but suffice to say my doctor had made a huge 
mistake - one that cost me a transfusion and four days in the hospital 
and nearly my life.  In hindsight, I wish I had asked more questions, 
read up on the drug and trusted my own intuition about what was going on 
with my body. I'm not standing on a soapbox here, nor am I castigating 
all doctors. I just hope sharing my experience can be helpful.  

You're all precious. Please take care of yourselves.

Love,
Kathryn

Precedence: bulk

While it may be true that MDMA is unlikely to cause toxic effects directly,
the book E is for Ecstasy (the entire text is available at hyperreal) has
extensive discussion of the medical problems associated with its use.
Generally, it appears to be quite safe (safer, for example, than skiing,
in terms of mortality-per-million uses), and while the toxicity (LD50)
level is fairly low, cases of people taking the equivalent of several
dozen doses with no lasting effects have been recorded.  Generally, taking
more than a couple times the typical dosage level, according to the
literature, produces enough uncomfortable "speedy" effects that people
aren't tempted to severely overdose in any event.  

The biggest problem area is the question of overheating (or probably much
more rarely, overchilling).  Both lab studies and general observation
indicate that people react less strongly to heat or cold while on E, and
that can be dangerous in cases where strenuous exercise and lack of fluid
intake can trigger collapses or even death.  The following excerpt from
E is for Ecstasy gives a synopsis of this:

E Is for Ecstasy, Appendix 1, Reference 51
 
Toxicity and deaths from MDMA from The Lancet by John Henry et al. August 1992
 
...
 
Reports from the USA suggested MDMA was only mildly toxic. The main cause
of death was cardiac arrhythmias; rhabdomyolysis and disseminated
intravascular coagulation (DIC). Most cases the authors were consulted
about had mild symptoms. There was a clear pattern of toxicity in the most
severe cases. Death was probably due to heatstroke "in which severe
hypothermia was accompanied by DIC". There was no evidence of drug impurity
being responsible for toxicity. All fatalities occurred after the user had
been at a crowded party or club. Sustained physical activity, high ambient
temp, inadequate fluid replacement could all reduce heat loss and the
direct effect of the drug may upset the thermoregulatory mechanism.
The authors conclude that MDMA is capable of causing severe toxicity and
that the pattern of acute toxicity witnessed in the series of cases studied
may be due mainly to the circumstances in which it is misused.

------

I really suggest looking at the entire section on MDMA
effects on the body in the E is for Ecstasy text.  Although people often
report that the MDMA in a supposed E dose has been "cut" with other
substances, the very limited reports in the literature indicate this is
probably rare, and it would be much more frequent to get a completely
different drug such as MDA being sold as E -- and then you could have
some serious side effects and health problems, especially if the person
is not prepared for that prospect.

The only "rave" happening in SOMA on Saturday night that I know about was
Wicked in the basement of DV8, so I don't know if this was the event
referred to, but regardless of that, it is surely a warning once again
to all of us to "be careful out there" and watch for the warning signs
in ourselves or others and be prepared to help when needed.

see ya
phred

> What you just posted just chewed up bandwidth on the net.

No, sounds more like you're grasping at straws for reasons to dismiss
my posting. I figured those w/o news access might be interested in a
summary of the posts that have transpired on this case. Yes, I
editorialized, as I often like to do... Don't like it? Hit delete now!

IMHO, the subject seems alot more relevant to raving than the 500
messages of mostly bullshit, that I had to wade through after I got
back from vacation. (And too much of that bullshit was people posting
about what people shouldn't post about -- the bandwidth wasted on
people getting all huffy about that dwarfed the bandwidth of any
off-topic posts...)

> Has little to no facts.  There was no actual cause of death attached to
> those facts.

What the hell is a fact? People used to think that it was a "fact" that
X rays, ultraviolet radiation, nuclear radiation, or pregnancy hormones
like DES were harmless. Facts are only as deep as our understanding,
and our understanding, pro-X or con-X are very very limited. Yes, we
may know the minutiae of how X affects us at a neuronal level
(serotonin this versus dopamine that). But, I  maintain, such minutiae
are irrevelvant when looking at the overall systemic, immune, or
hormonal effects of X. We still understand very little about that. So
don't blow "facts" at me.... Just cuz the facts don't fit your belief
doesn't mean the info was irrelevant.

Also, what of the "facts" of all the X related deaths (admittedly from
overheating) in the UK. What of the "facts" presented in the postings
mentioning DIC? Seems like those are good "facts" for people to know.

And whose facts are you believing? I've read parts of various pro-X
books like "E is for Ecstacy" and much of it reads like a bunch of spew
from a religious tractate (selective quoting from scientific articles).
Much of the "literature" that people point to in claiming that X is
100% safe seems to lack objectivity. It's easy to preach to the
converted, but that shit don't pass for "science"... It's bad science
to just look for the positives suporting your point, and skip,
gloss-over, or minimize any negatives.

> I respect your personal conviction that E is not a good drug for you for X and
> Y reasons.  But respect others convictions that it is an enhancing drug for
> them.  There is absolutely no reason for you to sit up on your pedestal and
> preach to the masses.

Since when does expressing an opinion equate to lack of respect?  Or is
it somehow uncool to post opinions that are politically incorrect here?
Is "respect" to you making me your "yes man" -- if so, I politely
request your permission to diss-respect you. 

I, for one, am getting real sick of hearing about "respect" because,
IMHO, it is often just a code word for "don't rock my boat"... But it's
not like I'm calling you a worthless slob or anything, I'm just
expressing an opinion about a topic, intellectually. If you disagree,
then fine, you disagree, tell me why. But don't lay this "respect" crap
on me cuz I'll just laugh back.... The day we can't express opinions 
for fear of "lack of respect" is the day we might as well roll up and
die, because that's a big part of being intelligent and human.
 
I know lots of people that do X and I sometimes tell them what I think
and many still do X (and many are still friends). My opinion is that
people get a bit too dreamy in the shorts when describing how wonderful
X is, and they seem to lose objectivity. Yeah, and I was totally
dissing that stupid thread a while back about how people were claiming
that X had cured them of their colds, because I think that's a big load
of hooey, in my not so humble opinion (IMNSHO).

--------------------

I first did X back when it was legal, it was real, it was interesting.
But for me, I have a been there, done that attitude (aka learning,
experience) about my past experiences that lead me to believe it isn't
a very good enchancer. For the following reasons:

(0) X is too expensive. Fuck designer fashions.
(1) The effects wear out over time, your 100th trip won't be anything
    like the first, or even the tenth. (So you end up upping the dosage
    and eventually incur the risk of ODing...).
(2) The crap that passes for X nowadays is a joke. It's much like playing
    russian roulette.
(3) X makes me depressed and emotionally listless afterwards, and you're 
    wading into dangerous addiction territory if you need to do more X to
    make yourself feel ok...  (i've spoken to a handful of people that feel
    the same way).
(4) I have seen empirical evidence indicating that X fucks w/ your immune 
    system, leaving you susceptible to colds, flu, bronchitis/pneumonia, 
    and making recovery a lot slower than normal. (Why is it that so many
    X users are perpetually sick or recovering from "nasty colds")...
(5) I watched some heavy users in college lose much of their emotional affect
    for an extended period of time (like 1 year). They eventually became
    fun to be around (aka normal) again once they stopped using/abusing X.
(6) Emotional hallucinogens are a bad way to fall in love/like. Because when
    you're down, you may still think you're in love/like, but the reasons for
    feeling that way turn out to be nothing but a mirage. I'd rather be
    a bit more objective and sober when investigating love/sex/friendship.

These are opinions, and you are free to ignore them, or whatever. I
really don't care. The only facts I ever write are programmatic source
code. Everything else is by definition an opinion, because facts are
slippery business.

-- Niels "dropping science like gallileo dropped an orange" Mayer.

Some information I came across:

E - is well known for having a low LD-50 (lethal dose 50) which means that
the dose at which its effective is pretty close to the dose at which 50% of
the rats in your control group die.

Two tabs of pure MDMA could probably kill you, which is why they say its a
good idea to administer E in the following way:

Instead of swallowing a whole lot of the substance, snort a small amount
thereby administering the substance directly to the right place, and
avoiding high dosage.

Always wait a while to monitor effects.

Never take another E, just because you're having a great time on the first dose.

Try to keep the dosage as low as possible.

Charlie Grof, one of the few people doing MDMA research reccomends that you
take an antioxidant as well, like betacaratene, vit e, to minimise dentrite
collapse. (yes, you can flatten dentrites with high doses)

- also be very careful of taking anything from a stranger, or ingesting any
substance you're not sure of.

Just say KNOW.

- david dei

To: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>, "Ron Nikel" <ren@nin.engr.sgi.com>
Subject: Re: X Fatality (was Re: The sky is falling - And that is only your opinion - chicken little )
Cc: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I like a lot of what Neils has to say on this.  I'd only point out a
couple of things.  First, MDMA is not merely anecdotally an immune
suppressant, this has been widely reported in the literature and again
anecdotally from my friends and FOAFs who get "raver flu" sometimes
after doing it.  But it happens also with pot and alcohol and lots of
other things.  

I also disagree somewhat with the characterization of E Is for Ecstasy
as merely a pro-X "spew" selectively quoting the literature.  This may
be true of certain other well-known books about this substance, but my
reading of it is that it is very fair and reasonably complete in its
coverage and conclusions.  This book certainly does *not* claim that
MDMA is 100% safe (as the excerpt I posted just now indicates).

The point is, we are not dealing with an unknown here.  There is plenty
of readily-available documentation on the benefits, drawbacks and even
dangers of this substance, as there are with many others we may encounter
directly or indirectly through the experiences of our friends and
acquaintances.  

I don't happen to agree with Neils' essentially negative opinion of MDMA,
but I greatly respect that opinion and I think he laid out some clear
reasons for why he holds it.  All of these things are worth considering
when deciding what we are going to do in regard to this whole issue.

Ob:rave, MDMA has been and continues to be a part of this scene, but it
is not the defining characteristic that the media seem to want it to be,
nor was it ever, even back in the day of 1991 (or 1987 if you were in
the UK).  And this is not surprising -- not all Deadheads have taken
acid, despite what you'd think from what is said in the media.  I'm
Exhibit No. 1 in that regard.  But there's no question that acid put its
stamp on the Dead as a musical outfit and on the Deadhead scene in
general, just as X has done with the house/techno/rave/underground.
So, regardless of whether we do this particular substance ourselves,
it is something we have to deal with for our own understanding of what
it is we're involved with, and to respond appropriately when the media
comes calling as it did with Ameba this weekend.

And every so often we are faced with a true tragedy within our scene.
At times like these, for surely one or more of the people on this list
knew the person who died this weekend, knowing about these things makes
it much easier to comprehend their meaning and to take the necessary
steps to minimize the loss of health or even life that can happen, so
ironically and arbitrarily, in a scene devoted to the proposition that
we support *life*.

nice letter.
one tip for dealing with people on bad trips that' I've picked up over 
the years:  try to sit the person down (not totally necessary) and 
looking in the general direction of something nice, a mountain, a painting 
etc (but a boring wall can do as well) and then say:  look at that [?].  
did you ever see such an interesting [?]  isn't it beautiful, amazing 
whatever.  the point is to get themoff their negative track and into a 
more positive one.  doesn't always work but often does.
fraser

ken, to take the only point on which you disagree (2 actually):
we *are* running out of time.  and space.  in the old days ( at least 
till all your foremothers came out here to america) there was enough 
space that if things got bad enough in this valley with all the greed and 
powerheads the intelligent sensitive and cooperative could always move to 
the next valley.  now there are no valleys left.  ipso we have run out of 
time and space.  now our species has to change or die. 
I think we have a slightly better than even chance of changing.  and I'm 
not doing it out of fear.  before Rc spontaneously combusted, during the 
"wildereness years" of the '80s when the world was just quietly 
disappearing down the plughole and nobody seemed to give a fuck) I was 
(more or less) content to live gracefully on little funds and just write 
privately. (except that I started the Encyclopaedia Psychedelica 
Internztional a few years before it erupted, prediciting that a "new wave 
of consciousness is about o break out among youth" - this is all well 
documented)  now I'm full of *hope*.
the reason I say the odds are about even is because so-called "spiritual 
types will often tell you that it's all outside our control, that the 
goddess (or Truth or Spirit or Rhythm or  whatever) will sort it all out 
and all we have to do is polish our inner mirror or whatever.  I don't 
believe that.  nobody knows any of this for sure but I judge a 
pilosophical viewpoint by its likely effect on people.  telling folks 
that they don't have to do anything doesn't strike me as healthy.  and 
besides, I believe we *are* the goddess - her finest blossoms. and *we* 
the goddess in each of us is gonna sort things out now, having learned 
only too well the folly of competitiveness.
ok?  >:-)
fraser
PS  just beause I don't use the word spiritual etc don't get the idea k'm 
an atheist or I see matter as primary because I'm not and I don't. in 
mahayana buddhism (which was a reaction to the long-established but 
mostly then corrupt hindu "religion") there comes a stage where you have 
to "get rid of the stench of enlightenbment".  >:-)))))

I'll make it easy for people. I'll write responses to all topics in one
message.

RE:x-overdose

two views x is bad-there have not been enough studies done on the
psycological aspects of x-ing. All drugs are bad. Even too much vitamin
C can cause a urinary tract infection. To much salt causes premature
high blood pressure.

x is ok- like any other substance our bodies are designed to handle
abuse from drugs such as x. But these things are best taken in
moderation. Besides if you wait a long time before each dose (more than
2 months) I've heard that only one dose is more than enough to get you
going all night. Someone posted something about MDMA is not the same as
MD with MA (the whole is not as bad as the sum of its parts)wrong. I
talked to my uncle(a pharmasict and instructor) and he said that
whenever you have an accelerator with a mind altering drug, It has the
same effects to the body(raising temp., high blood press.........) but
it does something worse. It increses the amount of brain damage. even
candy can cause brain damamge though. BE SAFE. USE IN MODERATION. DRINK
LOTSA WATER.(Even if you dont take drugs)


RE: SUNSET

It was a lot of fun and I just liked being there for the sunset itsself.
It looks like all of you would agree. This is a start to a great summer.
I didn't see one frown the whole day. I met Bryce, Andrew Lawson,
Ethan..... and someothers whos names I have written down but they are in
my car.(SORRY) but anyways. Time for bed

I'd *guess* that the black propaganda has begun. it started in the UK 3
years ago and the govt started publishing the number of deaths thru
ecstasy.  Zippy Times did a study of the first 8 deaths and we found that
*none* of them were caused by ecstasy - car crashes, loadsa booze & other
drugs, falling off rooves etc.  I actually appeared on a tv program in
Manchester with the mother of a boy who had supposedly died on e. a
difficult appearance, I'll tell you, but the truth was her son was doing
*lots* of different drugs, most of them more dangerous than e. 

not to say that ecstasy is not quite toxic on the body - it is. and then
there's the thing about dehydration, no water available at raves etc

fraser

PS  I don't know what kind of radio station KCBS is but it might be a good 
idea for someone to give them a call and see where they got their story 
from.  a hospital?  a govt agency?  a "dodgy" press company?  the bloke 
he was with?  if the facts turn out to be inconclusive it *might* be a 
good idea to let the station know that hundreds of thousands of young 
people don't need BAD unresearched information, especially on a saturday 
night.
these are all just off-the-hip reactions, of course, maybe it *is* 
genuine, in which case we thank the station for its good work.

started off the weekend at freaky at komotion.  weird crowd.  it's sposed 
to be a queer space but a possibly confused straight guy came up to a 
(queer) friend of mine and exclaimed, "Where are all the girls?!"  back 
pain was bad so i was cranky, but i wound up having fun hanging out 
behind the bar and then working the bar (and i even got a tip!)  left 
when bryce was done with his set - he had played some bizarre DJAX 
techno, and then lots of latin house and somewhat poppish stuff.  have to 
congratulate him for getting the mostly standing-around-smoking crowd 
dancing for a bit, tho'.  

saturday i hadn't planned to go out but i heard about a small event 
starting at 4:00 byt he beach so i went to check it out.  gorgeous 
sunset, but no soundsystem, and then no speaker cables.  the organizers 
did a ritual for shiva, tho', with lots and lots of flowers.  it was nice 
to be at a party starting with a ritual.  but it was cold, so we left.

sunday was sunset, but first a VICIOUS attack of pms, so i didn't feel 
very social (an understatement - at one point i wanted to sacrifice the 
most annoyingly perky raver), but i went.  and again i remembered that 
marijuana IS medicinal :).  nice site (point isabel in richmond).  i 
found the music pretty boring, tho', but this is IMHO (i like a basic 
house groove, but not for more than half an hour.)  thought i heard some 
acid as we were leaving (just after sunset), but i wasn't sure.  nice to 
watch the cops come and go :).  

but one complaint: i thought sunset was s'posed to be a park clean-up.  
the site certainly looked a bit trashed as we were leaving.  (and it's 
frustating to be a virgo and not be able to bend down and pick up trash!  
i DID pick up a diazepan (valium) wrapper as we were leaving.  thought it 
was really tacky that it was there in the first place.)  anyway, maybe 
the message needs to be made more clear to some kids - like, if it's a 
park clean-up the least one could do is not trash the place!  hope it 
wasn't just ann and the sunset people left dealing with it at the end...

monicat 
looking forward to bleeding

Dear All;

	Offering 1st Aid Services at raves, and when I saw this
immediately called the E/R at John Muir Trauma Center, Walnut Creek and
Posion Control at the 800 number and this is what these two conservative,
but very reliable sources told me, contraindications for amphetamines: 

	1. Anyone with a known or unknown cirrulaorty system defect.
		Heart Attack
		Stroke
		Heart Defect
		Hypertension....etc

	2. People cuurently, or recently taking MAO-Innibitors

	3. People with a known or unknown allergenic reaction to amphetamines

	Amphetamine overdoses is usually chacracterized by hot dry, skin, 
rapid pulse, dehydration ..etc, and can lead to heart attack, stroke, 
hypertension, tack-a-car-di-a, kidney/renal failaure due to rapid muscle 
fiber breakdown. These symtoms mentioned above can happen in a subject 
who has ingested amphetamine for up to 24 hours after inital ingestion. 
An overdose is consituted by/as anyone using the drug for recreational 
use. This means they consider one E pill an overdose, or one line no 
matter how small.

	AS far as vomiting blood, don't believe the hype, only if the 
subject ingested a lot, grams, and grams.

	I strongly encourage hot and heavy debate on this topic and how 
it effects us, ravers, users of a lot of amphetamines. Please do detailed 
research siting your sources as I have done here, get the facts as they 
pertain to you, PLEASE!!!!!!! 

	I want to meet you all with a smile on you face, not in tears, and 
scared that your gonna die. THanks

		Peace & LOve From Across Cyberspace
		 aka Brian Darkness, LMT/BSEE/CET

		Internet:	brianv@liberty.com
		Alt. Internet:	brianvan@liberty.com


ps If you are gonna trash me on this one make sure you site your source, 
I will more than happy to admit I made a mistake when it comes to peoples 
lives.

From: Kevin Keiper <keiper@itsa.ucsf.EDU>
Subject: Re: X-Overdos
To: Nathan Moser <nathan_moser@manual3.com>

        Michael Kellner <mkellner@netcom.netcom.com>

Yes X does cause epolepcy which is why if you are a known epoleptic you 
should NEVER take X.  But the problem is that a lot more people have some 
form of epolepcy then they realize because they think that all fit's 
consist of a person rithing around on the floor with white foam coming out 
of their mouth's.  This is only in extreame cases usually you just feel 
a bit giddy for a while.  But this is when you are not on X; because when 
you do have a fit on X it is as above but you are bleeding instead.  This 
is what obviously happened to the man in question.
I know this from my own personal experience too.  When I used to live in 
London I used to sell X for a living.  Once I was at a festival where I 
sold some X and forty minutes later I looked over on the dance floor and 
noticed that he was rithing around on floor in pain and week blood was 
coming out of his mouth.  All the other raver's stood around not knowing 
what to do but I went in their, turned him on back, pinned his arms be 
hind him and sat on him in such a way that he could not move; this way 
he could not injure himself and there was no danger of him chocking on his 
own blood.  I kept the person in that position for the duration of the 
fit and told somebody else to go and call for an ambulance.  This is the 
correct thing to do when some body is having an epololeptic fit and every 
raver should know what to do.  
Remember: epoleptivc fit's can be easilly tested for by a doctor and I 
urge anyone who is taking lots of X to go and get themselves checked 
out.  Because you may have always been epoleptic but it was to minute for 
you to notice until you started taking X which puts a great strain on 
one's nurological system which will agrivate your epolepcy.  Also: watch 
about for strobe lights because they too can bring on fits, especially when 
you are on X because UV lights are that more intense.
Remember: this info about epolepcy is important because this, together 
with de-hydration, are two main thing's that people die of when they are 
on X.  Dispite the media telling you otherwise none has ever died from 
taking X or overdosing on it (and by X I mean pure MDMA).  Providing you 
take precautions and educate and regulate yourself X can be one of the 
most amazing experiences going.
Tristan.

A DESCRIPTION OF THE BOOK
========================================================================
Better Sex Through Chemistry - A Guide to the New Prosexual Drugs.
Authors:  John Morgenthaler and Dan Joy 
Publisher:  Smart Publications.  $14.95. 
(available from Megatripolis, Box 12, 3288 21st, San Francisco, CA 94110
for $14.95 + $3 handling.  cheques to Megatripolis)
======================================================================== 
 ** a book of real, modern-day, pharmaceutical breakthroughs for enhancing
 sexual health.  
 ** a practical, scientific approach for people in good sexual health or
 with specific sexual dysfunctions.  No other book covers sexual health
 from this angle, making "Better Sex Through Chemistry" the first in its
 category.  
 ** detailed information on the new "prosexual" drugs and nutrients that
 can enhance: sex drive, firmness and duration of erection, vaginal
 lubrication, skin sensitivity, intensity of orgasm, enjoyment of sex,
 stamina, length of sex, and intimacy and emoional connection.  
 ** explains how making use of the new prosexual drugs and nutrients can
 also improve overall health.  Many of these substances have a wide range
 of health benefits and have been shown in scientific studies to: enhance
 immune function, slow aging, alleviate depression, assist fat loss, 
 improve memory and cognition, and more.  All feature a high level of 
 safety.  
 ** explains how each drug or nutrient works, how it can be obtained, and
 how to use it - including complete information on dosage, precautions and
 other safety issues. 
 
 ** features many true stories of people who have used these prosexual
 substances to dramatically improve their sex lives, often as told in
 their own words.

**************************************************************************

from dehydration and eating things that weren't mdma. It's a fact. There

When someone is having an epileptic seizure, it is very important to 
protect their head so they don't end up with a concussion or worse.  This 
is more important then pinning their arms behind them.  One should also 
be careful when sitting on someone, which can make it difficult to 
breath.  Never put your finger in their mouth to try and keep them from 
swallowing their tongue, because you may only have nine left when its over.

peter
