return of Liquid Air this saturday.  Liquid Air is a smallish, friendly

together to play some records and dance outdoors.  Always free, always

At 19:50 4/4/95, David Dei wrote
:
>Some information I came across:
>
>E - is well known for having a low LD-50 (lethal dose 50) which means that
>the dose at which its effective is pretty close to the dose at which 50% of
>the rats in your control group die.
>
>Two tabs of pure MDMA could probably kill you, which is why they say its a
>good idea to administer E in the following way:
>
>Instead of swallowing a whole lot of the substance, snort a small amount
>thereby administering the substance directly to the right place, and
>avoiding high dosage.
>


Uh, would you mind citing your sources? I've never heard MDMA has a
particularly low LD50. And saying "two tabs...could probably kill you" is
totally subjective. The effects are based on dosage in relation to body
weight, so a mg/kg ratio would be preferred if giving such info. All
quantitative and qualitative reports I've heard regard snorting indicate
it's not the most desirable way to administer the drug. Absorbtion by the
mucuos membrane occurs more quickly than abbsorbtion through the stomach,
but the effects are much shorter in duration. I don't see how the mucuos
membrane is the "right place." Its effects take place in the brain, not the
nose.

Joe

Okay everyone--we all know that DIC is a potential danger involved for
anyone who uses e, and to pretend that it doesn't exist--no matter to what
extent--is naive.  I'm new to this scene; I've been to 2 raves and just 
subscribed to this list, but it still amazes me how rabidly people 
dismiss associated dangers.  Does "The government" (isn't it funny how 
people assume the government is a single entity?) dispense misleading 
information on drugs' effects?  Of course it does, and for understandable
reason--more drugs mean more hassles for the government to deal with: car 
crashes, emergency room visits, etc.  Even if the percentage of users 
experiencing problems is small, if the number of users increases, so too must
the number (in strictly raw terms) of accidents.  On the other extreme stands
the drug enthusiast, whose information is also often biased, but this time
in the opposite direction: "ecstasy is like aspirin" and "too much water 
will kill you if you drink enough" as well as other absurdities.
My point is that knowledge is power.  Don't dismiss the weekend's 
tragedy; ask as many questions as you can think of and don't belittle others
for asking irrelevant questions.  My question, then, is this--does anyone
know of anti-coagulants that ravers can take to minimize risk?  Will water
act as an effective combattant against DIC, or are there better solutions
(pun intended :) ) out there?  If anyone is a biologist or a med student, 
please post... I'm just a dumb english major! :) 
Peace and love and eternal grooving,
starbursts and pacifiers to all,
timothy


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Apr  5 13:50:19 1995

Neils sed:


> (0) X is too expensive. Fuck designer fashions.

	This is purely a case of "perceived value"...
	you perceive it as expensive.. you don't buy it.
	Some others dont see it that way.
		
> (1) The effects wear out over time, your 100th trip won't be anything
>     like the first, or even the tenth. (So you end up upping the dosage
>     and eventually incur the risk of ODing...).

True. But it`s up to *you* to increase the the dose.. With a little discipline
you won't. You'll ease up. Or settle for less of a "high". Most people I
know do this.

> (2) The crap that passes for X nowadays is a joke. It's much like playing
>     russian roulette.

In some cases .. not all. Be a "smart shopper" if u need to.

> (3) X makes me depressed and emotionally listless afterwards, and you're 
>     wading into dangerous addiction territory if you need to do more X to
>     make yourself feel ok...  (i've spoken to a handful of people that feel
>     the same way).

Maybe true for you. But the only person that I know that had that effect
was someone who was depressed before taking the drug.. and found the
difference between the "high" and his "depression" to be excessive, therefore
making him feel even more depressed after taking the drug. You do raise
the interesting point of "psychological addiction" in that we may be 
un-interested in doing things, e.g., going to raves, *without* the drug..
because we may believe it's a hell of a lot more fun with it than without it.
But that's not much different that any drug like pot and alcohol.

> (4) I have seen empirical evidence indicating that X fucks w/ your immune 
>     system, leaving you susceptible to colds, flu, bronchitis/pneumonia, 
>     and making recovery a lot slower than normal. (Why is it that so many
>     X users are perpetually sick or recovering from "nasty colds")...

Could be true. But, think about what ravers are doing. Staying up all nite,
missing sleep. Dancing in a germ-filled sweatbox for 8 hours. Sharing water
bottles... can you separate the ill-effects of the drug from those other
possible causes?

 

> (6) Emotional hallucinogens are a bad way to fall in love/like. Because when
>     you're down, you may still think you're in love/like, but the reasons for
>     feeling that way turn out to be nothing but a mirage. I'd rather be
>     a bit more objective and sober when investigating love/sex/friendship.

Certainly. But you are emphasizing the negative side of that coin. 
There is a positive side also, i.e., breaking down inhibitions.. etc.
Of course this can get u in trouble, as you mentioned.


>Yeah, and I was totally
>dissing that stupid thread a while back about how people were claiming
>that X had cured them of their colds, because I think that's a big load
>of hooey, in my not so humble opinion (IMNSHO).

Could be a dumb idea. However, the drug raises the body temperature,
like a fever does when the body wishes to counteract againt infection.
Now that is one *possible* reason why some people may report this effect. 
Can you provide any reason why it would *not* have a curing effect besides
an attitude of healthy cynicism?


hugz

brian

Hey All,

Been doing some thinking (yeah, I know... ;)

I don't know how everyone on this list feels, but I definitely believe 
we're at a crossroads in our evolution.  

With our movement, we CAN facilitate change in others. The question is, 
how far do we take it.

First, we need to ask ourselves: 

Can we significantly affect the conciousness of others so as to bring about a 
fundamental change in human behavior?

I beleive the answer is yes.

Next:	Do we want to accept the responsibiltiy of our understanding and 
	be the facilitators of this change?

	I don't think we have a choice on this one.

Next: 	Do we take an active or passive stance in encouraging the 
	participation of others in our movement?

	A passive stance would mean we continue with the way we 
	celebrate. This implies that our parties are separate from the 
	manner in which "conventional" people spend their free time.

	Most people at our parties aren't conventional. We're all very 
	progressively minded people.

	Further, passivness implies that we realize that the world is 
	crumbling anyway, and we just enjoy ourselves while we can, 
	perhaps creating the tribal environment that we will live in 
	after societies crash.

	The question arises:	Should we even bother trying to change 
				and just let nature takes its course? Perhaps 
				humanity has had its chance in the natural 
				cycle, and it's time for another species to 
				dominate.	

	An active stance would imply that we find a method of encouraging 
	"conventional" people to attend our celebrations.

	(Fraser is already trying to do this. I'm not sure how effective 
	his methods will be).
	
	It seems to me that most "conventional" people are the ones who 
	are in positions to affect immediate change. These are the teachers, 
	local politians, community leaders, etc.

	With their particiaption at our celebrations, they can come to 
	the same understanding as ourselves. They can then go back to work with 
	these new insights and work to affect change in their respective 
	areas.   

Next:	How do we encourage participation?

	First, we have to lose the word RAVE. I'm sorry if any of you are 
	offended, but there are already so many  stigmas and negative 
	connotations with the word RAVE that, from my experience, it is the 
	primary deterrent to people's participation. I try to encourage others
	to come to these celebrations, but as soon as the word RAVE is seen or
	heard, they bolt. 

	We find some other name that is more "accpetable" (or less likely to 
	be perverted) by "conventional" people, then they won't be so mislead 
	as to the nature of our celebrations. Perhaps we focus more on 
	multicultural celebrations, pagan "holidays" or events, etc.
	
	We need more outdoor parties. The very fact we're outdoors is a 
	celebration in itself. I find outdoor parties to be much more powerful.
	This will help convey a more positive image of our celebrations to  
	"conventional" people.
	
	With the outdoor celebrations, we need to be responsible with our 
	behavior. Not delapitating the site, picking up trash, being 
	respectful to the people who stumble across our celebrations 
	accidentally, or those that might live in the vicinity. We've already
	started this. We need to be diligent and encourage it to continue.

With regard to the above, we can do two things:

	1).	Have our own private, intimate celebrations to renew our 
		energy and encourage ourselves to continue our 
		responsibilities.

	2).	Have integrated celebrations with both the "conventional" 
		and "non-conventional" people to help conciously affect the 
		ones who can help to affect immediate change in our world.
	
Some points to consider:

-	How do we prevent any exploitation if we begin "integrated" 
	celebrations. There's no doubt that some will see our movement as 
	an opportunity to satisfy their greed.

-	How do we prevent or resist persecution of our movement by "Authority"
	much like the tribes of our past.

If we want to affect change and we stay underground, it will take a long 
time-perhaps too long.

If we slowly go "above", we need to insure others don't pervert our 
intentions and destroy our movement.  

That's all for now.

-Jonas

      mattster says:                re: sunset yippee!                    4/5/95
                                                                         2:52 PM
ann asked:
>who were those folks who showed up wearing big masks and were blowing 
>a cardboard tube?  they said it was a "didgeridon't."

just thought i'd reply to this. I read sfraves, but don't have much time to
post, but "those folks" were me and my housemates, peter and lissie. we like to make
masks for Halloween and work for weeks before every year. I love Sunset so much
and everything the Pacific Crew does for us, that I like to bring some energy to
that party. I've always had a vision of our frogs coming over the hills at the
Berkeley Marina and finally that vision was realized with just a little pleading
to my housemates to bring their masks along. It was great to do it, and
gratifying to see all these people waving goodbye when we left. I LOVE THIS
SCENE! The cops sure got a kick out us when we left around 7, kind of milling
around and smiling and poking each other. I'll never forget that. 

We want to do more, make more masks and set up cool wind toys and maybe get
together a drumming contingent. Anyone out there interested in gathering for
mask making and other creative events? I'm leaving my job in June and will have
a lot of time on my hands. My housemates are moving to a big warehouse in
Oakland, so we've got a space to work. Let me know - chocMalt@aol.com - or wait
we'll post to this list when we announce that we're ready to do it.

The "digeridon't" is just that - a  cardboard tube that my roommate plays very
well, and that I'm learning to play, as a digeridoo. we also throat sing
together and have been interested in doing an ambient room gig together as a
live performance. Can anyone offer us about a half-hour in their ambient set to
show everyone what we do? It's quite ethereal, trippy and beautiful and we'd
like to make it participatory, too. We just need some time and contacts. Thanks!

Matthew
The Frog Prince

on Wed, 5 Apr 95 bmcgonig@pacific.abbotthpd.com (Brian McGonigle) wrote:

>True. But it`s up to *you* to increase the the dose.. With a little discipline
>you won't. You'll ease up. Or settle for less of a "high". Most people I
>know do this.

Unless you're an addict or potential addict, in which case you simply would
not have any discipline where getting loaded is concerned, and you would
keep upping the dose and taking cheaper drugs, having less fun and more
problems...  Nearly everyone I ever used drugs (including alcohol) with did
this. Addicts often try, with little sucsess, to control/discipline their
using and will swear that they can control it. That's just the nature of
the beast.

8< snip
> You do raise
>the interesting point of "psychological addiction" in that we may be
>un-interested in doing things, e.g., going to raves, *without* the drug..
>because we may believe it's a hell of a lot more fun with it than without it.
>But that's not much different that any drug like pot and alcohol.

Psychological addiction is the only addiction that matters. Physical
addiction, after a period of withdrawal, generaly painful and awful, goes
away. It is Psychological addiction that remains a lurking deamon, even in
recovery, for the rest of an addicts life. You're right E is no different
than any other drug in this respect. Anything that gets you loaded, no
matter how nontoxic, has the potential to be very destructive. Therefore it
is impossible for E to be as safe as Tylonol, as someone said in another
post.

(Although it apears that what I've said here is in response to what Brian
said, a lot of it is not. Much is in response to bits and pieces of many
other posts)




Michael Standish  DoD#732  standish@c2.org  (510)849-4511

Here's my little story from the weekend.

I attempted to go to the New Moon party in Pt. Reyes where I was supposed 
to DJ. I went with a couple of friends from Bolinas and we weren't able 
to find the party. We called the voice mail & it said that the sound system 
hadn't shown up yet. We decided to go back to Bolinas to sleep. Around 
6:30 am a friend called and asked us to come up to the party to help 
bring healing energy to a person suffering an acid freak out. Someone 
came and picked us up and took us to the party. We arrived around 8am and 
things were mellow and our ill friend was sleeping. It was a totally 
amazing morning. Charlotte was playing some trip hop / acid jazz and 
there were still 20 or thirty people. I was really glad that I finally 
made it to the party and saw my close friends (Morgan,Mona,Greg,Ann et 
al) who had been through an intense experience and showed what it means 
to be real friends in community seeking healing. I played the last set 
which ended around 10:30 or so. It was great fun , there were still a 
group of people dancing. After this we did a closing ritual with everyone 
who was still there. It was very nice!

I arrived at Sunset on Sun around 2:30 at the same time as Matt and his 
masked friends. It was a beautiful day and I saw alot of people I know. I 
thought Cyril played a nice set. It was different and more trancey. There 
were alot of people there by 4pm and I was hoping that the cops wouldn't 
show. At 5:30pm I walked out to the parking area to see if things were 
cool. There were three cop cars and three cops and Galen was talking to 
them. I walked up and started talking to them also. They were pretty 
mellow but one of them was older and less cool. He was intent on shutting 
the party down. His main excuse was that there were cars parked illegally 
and that the party was unpermitted and could be potentially unsafe. Galen 
and I were trying to be cordial while also trying to hint at the 
possibilty of letting the party continue. The uptight cop  made some 
calls back to the station and then told us that we'd have to turn the 
soundsystem off and leave. Me , Galen and the cops walked out to the park 
and the soundsystem was briefly turned off. As we were walking out I 
talked with the uptight cop and Galen talked with the more mellow younger 
ones. The uptight one was relatively cool and was asking me questions 
about what was going on. I was very nice to him and explained. He said he 
hadn't seen anything like this since the 60's. I told him to get used to 
it cuz it wasn't stopping anytime soon. As we approached the party you could 
tell that the cops were feeling the positive peacful vibration. Everyone 
was smiling and offered them candy. After some more smooth talkiing by 
Galen the uptight cop said "Well, everything looks okay here. We'll just 
check things out and leave you in peace." That's the best thing I've 
heard from a cop. We had actually had a real communication and they even 
stayed for awhile and _enjoyed_ themselves.

All in all it was a beautiful day and great party. I thought the music 
could have been a bit more diverse and more people could have picked up 
there own trash, though by the time I left the place looked pretty clean.
This was a good start to a new season but we have alot of work to do to 
raise our consciousness and overcome the ills of ignorance and addiction 
to destructive habits (be it speed, x, or habitual disregard for others 
and our surroundings). Hope we can continue to experiment with new forms 
of celebration which can invoke healing and positivity.

Yours in Transformation,
ronan

i just read jonas' post, and i really dug it.  i think we all understand 
the desire to change consciousness through "rave" (i like the idea of 
calling it holiday instead), but we're not entirely sure or consolidated 
on how to go about doing it.  many an ear has heard me talk about the 
hundredth monkey concept, and it is a concept by which i firmly stand.  
i *highly* recomend that everybody on this list (and a whole mess of 
people not an the list) read the book the hundredth monkey, by ken keyes 
jr.  it's rather short with nifty drawings, and its very, very well 
writen and fun to read.  at least just read the first chapter.   rocks 
my world...


             lovelovelove,
                  sig





From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Apr  6 13:29:51 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id NAA07331; Thu, 6 Apr 1995 13:29:51 -0700
Received: from mail02.mail.aol.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with ESMTP id NAA07298; Thu, 6 Apr 1995 13:29:34 -0700
From: SOrmsby@aol.com
Received: by mail02.mail.aol.com
	(1.37.109.11/16.2) id AA125230143; Thu, 6 Apr 1995 16:29:03 -0400
Date: Thu, 6 Apr 1995 16:29:03 -0400
Message-Id: <950406162901_74165861@aol.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: the two c's 
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

fellow travellers,

i'm new to the rave world, new to the experience of X, and new to this list.
the new moon last week X'ed virginity and left something expansive and
wonderful in its place. then on sunday, i went to the point isabel gathering,
danced with all the spirit i had, smiled at strangers, felt the sun and music
wash through me, swam through the wet  music with gyrating hips, webbed toes
and a sober but ecstatic mind. 

i write you collectively to share with you the perspective of this beginner's
mind. what i've recently found at the new moon, at the park, and at
sfraves@hyperreal.com is community and consciousness - two of the most
important things in my life. what i seek is a marraige of  community and
consciousness. there's clearer way to say this:  wholesome, functioning
community creates and supports increased consciousness and increased
consciousness in turn nourishes and adds life to the community.  some people
speak of an enduring tribe that will survive the ravishes of consumerism,
militarism, the contract with america, & etc. we're talking about the same
thing, using different images.  

i'm aware that i'm writing of ideals, abstractions. what is important and
real is the energy and enthusiasm we bring to the events. whether we call
them "raves," "happenings," "be-ins," or "joints," they are created entirely
by the people who attend them. we create the feeling, the tone, the mood. we
have the power to create experiences in ways that they meet our deepest
needs. no, we are that creative power. 

an earlier posting spoke about trying to bring the "common people" into the
rave-fold, to educate them about the spirit of our gatherings, and so, change
the world. i agree that we should welcome any people interested in our
sub-culture, that we should welcome them as new friends as i was welcomed -
but i think that our emphasis ought to remain on developing our consciousness
and our community. if we are successful in this respect, if we treat
ourselves and each other with love and respect, if we develop our minds while
opening our hearts and freely expressing our creativity (through music,
dance, writing, poetry, painting, sculpture - through simple intimacy,
honesty, and compassion), we won't be able to keep the interested people away
from our gatherings. 

we live in a culture of radical separation and disaffection. my hunch is that
nearly everyone from california to new york craves a supportive community of
fun-loving people and the consciousness to know how to best interact with
those people - but they don't know how to find it. so instead, they stop
listening to voice of their inner needs and instead they watch homer simpson
slap his forehead and say "doOOH!" for the upteenth time.   

we're a sad group of people, we americans. we have every luxury of the world
at our disposal and yet so many of us are in the depths of our selves lonely,
isolated, and anxious about our lives. we've convinced ourselves that we're
unable to follow our dreams, so we grab for whatever sensual pleasures there
are on the shelf. 

for me, X is not just another sensual pleasure. it is a powerful tool with
which to explore the mystery of my own mind, and to connect with like minds. 

disclaimer: i'm not speaking for anyone other than myself. these are my
observations, not universal truths. and they are the observations of a
newcomer.

why am i writing this? to give thanks to the community, to share my vision of
what we could be with you, and to stick my neck out and emphasize the
transfomational and  artistic aspect of the experience over and above the
escapist or purely recreational aspect. in other words, let's heal, nourish
and develop ourselves first and foremost, both as individuals and as a
community. and goddamn: let's enjoy it every step of the way...  

shalom  
sormsby@aol.com

   Jive Samba - DJ's Roman & Chris Playing Latin Licks, Rock Steady Hits,
   and Jazz Picks. Live music with Josh Jones and Guests the Up&Down Club
   1151 Folsom
   
   a little more - DJs Mark Farina, Suiki, Julius Papp, Terrence Toy &
   live acid jazz. 9:30pm-2am @ Eleven, 374 11th St.
   
   the Spot - house, reggae, hiphop? - every other Weds. $3, 21+, 502
   Auzerais, San Jose
   
   Live it Up - House DJs Aaron O, Safar, Noble, Sean Bronski - Savages @
   Pier 33
   
   Re-Groove-A-Nation - 10PM to 5AM, 18+, $5. 511 Tyler (off Fremont),
   Monterey. DJs Taylor Made (Santa Cruz), Juni, Lonnie, Greg Dean, &
   guests.
   
   BluePrint - 2nd Wed of every month - Quality Time dj's: Jason Boyd,
   Corey Black, YT, Crunch. 10p-6a, $5, 1015 Folsom, 21+
   
   Smorgasbord - Spun Miquel Josh Galen 21+, 278 11th St. 415.773.8841
   
   Blinc - Pleasure Man, O.S.T., Alex, Jason - 111 Minna St @ 2nd -
   415.974.1719
   
   Touch - soulful house - Julius Papp and guests - Club 181, 181 Eddy
   St, SF. 415.673.8181
   
   Showcase Live - DJs Kevin & Nadeeah plus live performances - $5
   w/invite. DNA Lounge, 375 11th St, SF. 21+
   
   Happy House - DJs Aaron O, Jan Cooley, Jamie J, Blackstone. 9pm-4am,
   174 King st. 415.765.7676
   
Info Lines

   Be-At Info Line - 415-626-4087. Usually has 5-10 listings, updated
   daily.
   Clubline - 415.979.8686
   Fatline - 415.207.3668
   the Global Party Network - 415.568.1338
   Pre-Rave Warmup Line - Wondering what to do before the music starts?
   Events can happen at any time. Suggestions welcome. Call 415-522-3848
   The Gruv Line - (415) 331-1583 Ext. GRUV(4788)
   
Radio/TV Shows

   Sunday night 12mid-3am - Ambience w/Michael Hayes & David X KWOD 106.5
   (Sac)
   Sunday night 9pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 47 - Progressive
   house, acid jazz and "alternative" music views. (415) 281-3377.
   Sunday night mid-3am - "No UFO's" w/Adam from Silent Records KZSU 90.1
   Stanford
   Monday night/Tuesday morning midnight-3am - "On the Astral Plane"
   ambient w/Galaxy Girl and guests, KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
   Wednesday night mid-3am - "Cataklyzmol Pixel" ambient, experimental &
   noize - w/DJ Unknown, KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
   Thursday evening 9:30pm-12mid - Minor Minor KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
   Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF 90.3
   (SF)
   Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix with
   Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
   Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Deserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
   10pm-2am Ambient, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, Acid Jazz and
   noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
   Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from SF
   and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
   weeknights ~9pm - the Modern Mix w/Steve Masters KITS 105.3 (SF)
   
Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, submit them! I can't possibly
   hope to get all the info every week.
   
   To subscribe or unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

well, there IS techno in sf, but sometimes it's pretty hard to find...

you might want to check out AMP at 201 9th at howard on fridays (9-2:00, $5).
i think it's a pretty queer male cruisy space, but don't quote me on 
this.  also, the flyer says "tribal acid and trip house" so i'm not 
POSITIVE it's techno, but susan has usually been on the harder side.

also, DEFINITELY check out ethan and alex whenever they're spinning 
(usually one-off parties, and friends and family).  oh, and chizura - she 
plays rad, hard techno, but doesn't seem to have many gigs.  and 
sometimes bryce (he MOSTLY plays techno at large parties, but not 
necessarily all the time.)

but if it's BREAKBEAT techno you're after, then i have no clue where to 
look, as i try to avoid that as much as possible.

good luck,
monicat the tekno slut

well, despite the fact that i absolutely despise the new sf weekly, i 
have to recommend this week's issue for the article on hip hop.  there's 
a lot of info. about police pressure on clubs to keep them from having 
hip hop shows, and it's definitely relevant to ravers (and our new year's 
eve buddy capt. yalon is interviewed!  my hero!  he kept me from hurting 
myself having too much fun!)

monicat

I'm a reporter at the Marin IJ, working on a story about raves and esctasy,
truth vs. myth. I've read some pretty erronous information in the media and
want to hear from people who actually go to these parties. If you feel like
letting me know what raves are like, please respond to the above address.

or have attended raves in the county. I will not print your name, but I
need to know your age and what town or school you attend. Thanks

Dear Sfravers;

	With all due respects to Brian at Hyperreal, and Wired magaizne
and the responsible, honest press. Don't trust just any reporter, unless
you get what their going to say in writing, they will say and do anything
for a story, and as far as being on our side they have no good reason to
support us, they have very good reasons for making sensational hype about
the negative aspects of raves.  Because that sells papers, not how
wonderful and beautiful our scene is.  Just me two cents, BUT I FEEL THEY
ARE NOT ON OUR SIDE, AS WE HAVE SEEN ALL TO WELL IN THE PAST!!!!!!!! 

	Also, don't believe them when they say they won't print your 
name, friends of mine have been told that one, and not only did they 
print their names, but misquoted them, and I'm being kind when I say 
misquoted. 

	We don't need the main stream press, WE HAVE THE INTERNET, the 
main stream press needs us, If you talk to them, get everything in writing.

		PERSONAL DISCLAIMER!!!!!@!

	Note my opinions EXPRESSED in this post do not represent the views
or opinions of Hyperreal, and I'm not assoicated with Hyperreal or Wired
magaize, These opinions are mine alone, Thanks

Sincerely
Brian Darkness

Precedence: bulk

I came up with a different application of the 100th Monkey some time back 
which you all might find relevant as it helps to explain what otherwise 
looks unexplainable.

consider that one's inner psychological makeup is built on the 100th 
Monkey Principle.  thus, the first time we see something that brings up 
in us the natural reaction:  "Jeeesuz, that has no place on this here 
planet, I GOTTA DO SOMETHING!" that's Monkey One.  The feeling passes, so 
does time.  then something else pops up and it's Monkey Two.  etc. only 
when you reach Monkey 100 does a sudden change come about in your 
behavior.    so, now, when it looks like people never seem to change, 
that, despite all the terrible things going on, people just never seem to 
GET IT - don't worry nor get depressed too much.  it could be that 
practically the entire popultion is on Monkey 99

KABOOM!  >:-)   fraser

Received: from macshasta.snowcrest.net (macshast@localhost) by mtshasta.snowcrest.net (8.6.5/8.6.5) with UUCP id FAA20227; Fri, 7 Apr 1995 05:56:21 -0700
From: ken_stuart@macshasta.snowcrest.net (ken stuart)
Reply-To: ken_stuart@macshasta.snowcrest.net
To: jjudd@mercury.sfsu.edu
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Our Destiny
Date: 06 Apr 1995 16:47:07 GMT

Organization: Rich Renouf
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Jonas Judd (jjudd@mercury.sfsu.edu) writes:

	An active stance would imply that we find a method of encouraging 
	"conventional" people to attend our celebrations.

	(Fraser is already trying to do this. I'm not sure how effective 
	his methods will be).
	
	It seems to me that most "conventional" people are the ones who 
	are in positions to affect immediate change. These are the teachers, 
	local politians, community leaders, etc.

	With their particiaption at our celebrations, they can come to 
	the same understanding as ourselves. They can then go back to work with 
	these new insights and work to affect change in their respective 
	areas.   

I've been thinking about this for a long time (and am still discussing
aspects of it with the Captn, especially since he can now see how it works in
.au land)...

I keep coming back to Kurt Cobain, and whether $200 grunge shirts at Macy's
affected his state of mind...

The flaw in the above reasoning is assuming that you can keep the same
character of Vibe after opening up the participation to the larger public. 
This has failed everywhere else - for example, most of us have experienced
reading a newsgroup or mailing list that was great until it became popular. 
Or how about just within raves themselves?  How many times have I read "at
Blah event, don't even arrive until 4 am when the club types have left"?  My
impression is that many local raves have map points mostly to exclude the
sort of people we're contemplating including!

SO, it is not sufficient just to create a marketing scheme for popularizing
rave culture.

It is crucial to come up with some way of doing this WITHOUT losing the Vibe
and just ending up with the format.

Otherwise,  Our Destiny is  the Michael Jackson/Tony Bennett House Party
Album....

respect to all,

Ken
ken@macshasta.com
send bounces to ken.stuart@tigerteam.org

David Dei said:

> Two tabs of pure MDMA could probably kill you, which is why they say its a
> good idea to administer E in the following way:

Two tabs of E could kill you if you swallowed them both at the same time
and choked.  Other than that, its going to be the Amount that you are
taking that will cause the damage, and amount is not in anyway
solidly linked with the word "pill."  I have seen pills that have 100 mg
and others that had around 250 mg.

> Instead of swallowing a whole lot of the substance, snort a small amount
> thereby administering the substance directly to the right place, and
> avoiding high dosage.

Insuflation/snorting drugs tends to makes their effects more powerful
for a shorter duration of time.  This would simply mean that the
lower dosage is going to hit you harder, and the side effects will too.

This seems like a more sure way to end up in trouble if you dont
pay attention to what you are doing.

But then again.  Snorting even 100 mg of something is such a pain in the
ass to do, i guess you could rely on the "people will just give up" theory.

> Charlie Grof, one of the few people doing MDMA research reccomends that you
> take an antioxidant as well, like betacaratene, vit e, to minimise dentrite
> collapse. (yes, you can flatten dentrites with high doses)

Just to be really anal.  It's Grob.  Charles Grob, he's the only
one doing legal MDMA research on people, (well him and his assistants)
and he is doing it out of UCLA/Harbor Medical Center, just FYI.

 ,
dana

hey, all.  i've been missing the Bay area lately, but this list has
been helping me feel in touch.  boy, all the great parties i've been
missing...  you all have something very special, and i hope you
appreciate it enough.  i sure thought i did, but i find myself wishing
i had made more of an effort when i was there.

the startup company i work for has recently released two interesting
WWW products.  MultiHost (http://www.nfic.com/multihost.html) is a
httpd server which allows for a single physical machine to return
different pages and behave differently for http://foo.bar.com and
http://yow.zap.com.  PageAlert (http://www.nfic.com/pagealert.html) is
a service which lets you know when your web pages are inaccessible or
have changed for any reason.  make sure to sign up for a free trial
account --- most of the functionality is not apparent until you add
some pages and run it for a bit.

just thought a) some of you might like to know what i've been up to
and b) there seems to be a bit of WWW talk on this list.  apologies if
not interested...

i barely managed to keep myself from jumping in during the anti-frat
discussion which seems to flare up every once in a while on this list.
keep in mind that fraternities *are* different, especially region to
region and school to school.  fraternity experiences therefore can be
very different as well.  people who follow this list know that i feel
i wouldn't have survived school without my house.  'nuff said.

i miss you guys!

-- Bob

From: Kevin Keiper <keiper@itsa.ucsf.EDU>
Subject: Weekly Report; the angry old man speaks!
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9504070923.A72304-0100000@itsa.ucsf.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0

Precedence: bulk

So what happened this week?  Well it was quite hectic.  For a start some 
body died from taking X or, more to the point, died from some thing that 
was brought on by the X like epolepcy.  ANGRY OLD MAN SAYS: Anybody that 
dies from X has some thing already that is dangerious and, therefore, they 
should not be doing X.  X is a serious drug and people should be more 
responsible.  In other word's, anybody who is stupid enough not to find 
the full facts of a drug that one is taking (including facts about it's 
source and medical danger's) deserves everything they get.
Then there was Whicked last Saturday.  A good party; the tv's in the 
chill-out room were inspired and the dj's in that room were also 
excellent.  To bad that it was sweat box and that all the bouncer's their 
are wanker's.  ANGRY OLD MAN SAYS: Get another venue now because if you 
don't everyone is going to stop going to your parties because they are 
fed-up with the venue.
Then there was Sunset (Sunset, NOT Pacific).  While not in quite a nice a 
venue as Berkeley Marina it was never-the-less a beautiful spot, with 
beautiful weather, with BEAUTIFUL PEOPLE.  Sunset is with out a doubt the 
best party in the bay area with a totally mixed crowd and no 
cops/bouncer's telling you what to do; and it's free!  ANGRY OLD MAN 
SAYS:  Fuck nightclubs (except maybe 1015) lets get back to nature and 
freedom.
Then there was Community on Wednesday.  I did not go but Comunity it is the 
best party at a night club in SF partly because Christophe (one of the 
very best dj's around) play's their.  (check out his tape called The 
Pressure; a masterpiece of mixing).  This is also because it is at 1015 
Fulsome which is the best nightclub in SF.  ANGRY OLD MAN SAYS: In 
the Summer, nightclub parties once a month and outdoor parties once or 
twice a week
And, on the whole, Angry Old Man feels that their is a good vibe around 
at the moment; Summer is here.  He was saddended by some of the recent 
ignorant comments on SF raves especially to with Xenophobia and F&F 
particually those by some one called Tristan and phred and Brian 
Darkness; but other's said some silly thing's too.  ANGRY OLD MAN SAYS: 
Despite local belief, anger is not a negative vibe and at least Tristan 
was causing people to think about what they were saying so that they 
really thought about it and then were in a position to lend a worthwhile 
voice in the debate.  Remember: it is only when some body pisses you off 
or is obnoxious that you start to really think about what you are saying 
because all Humans feel insecure so they do not want to be seen as 
arseholes.  Tristan succeeded in doing this and therefore he should not be 
thought to badly of.

I was going to have a new music spot as well but I think that I'll leave 
this up the readers.  Also every week their we be a big shout.  This week 
a big shout goes out to all at Sunset, the possie from Bolder Colerado, 
Whicked on Tour, and, as always, to Frazer Clark and all at the 
parrallel university.
Until next week, this is Angry Old Man telling you to stop being angry.

a few cool heads (dana and david, to be exact) wrote: 

>
>> Instead of swallowing a whole lot of the substance, snort a small amount
>> thereby administering the substance directly to the right place, and
>> avoiding high dosage.
>
>Insuflation/snorting drugs tends to makes their effects more powerful
>for a shorter duration of time.  This would simply mean that the
>lower dosage is going to hit you harder, and the side effects will too.
>

because of the high volume of responces to this topic, i've been keeping my 
opinions to myself.  i really have to mention, though, that we ought not 
forget that snorting anything other than clean air will wreck your sinuses. 
as anyone who's ever snorted e can attest, it hurts like the devil's up 
your nose, more than meth or any of that stuff.  and it hurts because it's 
destroying membrane.  that's not to say that i am totally opposed to 
snorting e or any other drug (that's another topic entirely).  just 
remember, if you do snort anything, snort a bit of water up after taking a 
line.  it clears any powder out that my be lodged within the membrain. 
otherwise it can rot (yes, ROT! bleech!) after being left up there for too 
long.

and always eat your vegatables...


lovelove,
sig


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Apr  7 11:40:41 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id LAA01703; Fri, 7 Apr 1995 11:40:41 -0700
Received: from ultima.org by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with SMTP id LAA01679; Fri, 7 Apr 1995 11:40:28 -0700
Message-Id: <199504071840.LAA01679@taz.hyperreal.com>
Subject: Greetings!
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Fri, 7 Apr 1995 11:53:53 -0700 (PDT)
From: "Friends and Family" <fandf@ultima.org>
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 4635
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Greetings from all of us at Friends and Family :)

As you may have noticed, our last party got busted. Rather than letting the
party end on what might be an angry, sad, or ambiguous note, we wanted to
take this opportunity to tell you a little bit ourselves, why we're doing
what we're doing, what happened that night and, last but not least, what
our plans for the future are and how you might fit into those plans.

First off our sincerest thanks for coming to the party and bringing with
you the positive energy, love and respect that make these celebrations what
they are. It remains a truly amazing experience for us to join with you in
helping to facilitate the release of this energy. May it continue to spread
with all of our help, love, and support.

Friends & Family, well beyond being just a party, is a group of people
committed to facilitating ultra-low cost, not-for-profit, all ages,
community celebrations that feature and encourage the amazing diversity of
talent and energy that we have here in the bay area. We open ourselves to
anyone and everyone that cares to join us in these endeavors. If you'd like
to be involved, please contact us. You can look for the smiley faces on
laminates or T-shirts when you're out dancing or email us at the address
provided below.

At our last party we had a few problems. Most noteable among these was
rather severe overcrowding. We wish to state emphatically that this was not
our intention and we did not oversell what we took to be the capacity of
the space. However a variety of circumstances, some within and some beyond
our control -- forged tickets and duplicated maps for instance -- resulted
in hundreds more people than we expected finding out where the party was
and attempting to get in, creating a massive problem at the door and
inside. We did our best to deal appropriately with the situation which,
unfortunately, resulted in very long waits at the door.

Ultimately an alram was triggered on the building next door, the police
responded to it, noticed we were having a party and shut us down. We
greatly appreciate your peaceful, happy cooperation in helping us safely
clear the building at that time and offer our sincerest apologies that our
evening together ended so abruptly. Thank you for the many comments and
criticisms you've given us, we will strive to incorporate them into future
events.

In regards to the police, we would also like to emphasize what we take to
be the real importance of immediate, peaceful cooperation with the police
when we do encounter them. The police generally do what they want when they
set their minds to it and we have learned over and over again that, whether
they are right or wrong, getting in their way does absolutely no good.

Unfortunately we learned this lesson yet again at this party. Two of our
members had a less than pleasant confrontation with the police at the door,
one of them was arrested and faces two criminal misdemanor charges while a
third member of our group was ultimatley issued five criminal misdemeanor
citations for throwing the party in general. If you witnessed any of
these events, or if you have any useful information that bears on these
events, please contact us, court dates for these "offenses" are pending.

As you may or may not also know, Friends and Family parties are always
benefits; all of our members including DJs, visual artists, staff, etc. all
work strictly for free; no one has ever been paid for being part of a
Friends & Family.

So we wish also to thank you for donating so generously at the recent
party. Your contributions will benefit Komotion, an arts collective that
has been supporting independent and underground music in the Bay Area for
almost ten years, entirely through volunteer efforts, and will also help
defray the costs, legal and otherwise, resulting from the busting of the
Other New Year's Eve Bash at 938 Harrison Street this year. Some of your
contributions will also help defray some of our legal costs. We sincerely
appreciate your willingness to support the underground and hope you feel
your contribution was well placed. We will be back :)

Finally, and most importantly, we want you to know that we take your
safety and comfort very seriously. We would never, will never,
intentionally place anyone at risk. We hope also that you will view our
parties as your parties, and treat the people you meet there and elsewhere
as friends, as family, lending a hand where needed, helping those in need
where needed. Together, we can do it.

Lots of love,
Friends & Family.

-- 
=========== Friends and Family   eddress: fandf@ultima.org ==============

>>Yellow Devil.

>>mascots. ERNIE is the Orange Devil, The Profit has spoken!

Um, this looks serious, folks, and they don't look like they're fooling
with us, Ernie's ear was found wrapped in the above note, with fresh
stuffing leaking from it[Bad scene, my neighbor wept for 2 hours]. They
claim Ernie is well, but tired and feeling abandoned. The E-Bee, who was
lost at New Years spent 2 weeks in captivity before rescue by the elite
forces of Cloud Factory. I was very relieved at the reunion, and can only
offer my sympathy and hope to Ernie's loved ones. BURT, hang in there,
buddy, Ernie's gonna make it, he's a lover, not a fighter.

Police forensics were incapable of finding clues. My phone line is
monitored, in case the terrorists return my calls. If you see the Sendero
Depressoso, please, do no attempt to animate them. They are EXTREMELY
UNHAPPY and will react with attitude.
 Report them to the authorities (your friends) and gradually try to make
them feel at ease. They are easily unarmed by acceptance, and if they break
into a smile, they have been vanquished and may defect and join the Rave
Corps. More details to follow.

Lotsa love,
 Milton and the "never again" E-Bee.....

April, 1995 Fellow Debtor: This is going to sound like a con, but in
fact IT WORKS!  The person whois now #8 on the list was #9 when I got
it, which was only a few daysago.  Five dollars is a small investment
in your future.  Forget the lottery for a week, and give this a try.
 It can work for ALL of us.You can edit this list with a word
processor or text editor and then convert it to a text file.
Good Luck!!
Dear Friend: My name is Dave Rhodes.  In September 1988 my car was
repossessed and the bill collectors were hounding me like you
wouldn't believe.  I was laidoff and my unemployment checks had run
out.  The only escape I had from the pressures of failure was my
computer and my modem.  I longed to turnmy advocation into my
vocation.In January 1989 my family and I went on a ten day cruise to
the tropics. I bought a brand new Lincoln Town Car with CASH in
February 1989.  I amcurrently building a new home on the west coast
of Florida, with aprivate pool, boat slip, an a beautiful view of the
bay from my breakfastroom table and patio.  I will never have to work
again.  Today I am RICH! I have earned over $400,000.00 (Four Hundred
Thousand Dollars) to dateand will become a millionaire within 4 or 5
months.  Anyone can do thesame.  This money making program w orks
perfectly every time, 100% of thetime.  I have NEVER failed to earn
$50,000.00 or more whenever I wanted. Best of all, you never have to
leave home except to go to your mailbox orpost office.In October
1988, I received a letter in the mail telli ng me how I couldearn
$50,000.00 or more whenever I wanted.  I was naturally veryskeptical
and threw the letter on the desk next to my computer.  It'sfunny
though, when you are desparate, backed into a corner, your minddoes
crazy things.  I spent a f rustrating day looking through the wantads
for a job with a future.  The pickings were sparse at best.
Thatnight I tried to unwind by booting up my computer and calling
severalbulletin boards.  I read several of the messages posted and
then glanceda t the letter laying next to the computer.  All at once
it became clearto me.  I now had the key tomy dreams.I realized that
with the power of the computer I could expand and enhancethis money
making formula into the most unbelievable cash flow genera torthat
has ever been created.  I substituted the computer bulletin boardsin
place of the post office and electronically did by computer
whatothers were doing by mail.  Now only a few letters are mailed
manually. Most of the hard work is speedily downloaded to other
bulletin boardsthroughout the world.  If you believe that someday you
deserve that luckybreak that you have waited for all of your life,
simply follow the easyinstructions below.  Your dreams WILL come
true.     Sincerely yours,
     Dave Rhodes

Follow these instructions EXACTLY, and in 20 to 60 days you will
havereceivedwell over $50,000.00 cash, all yours.  This program has
remained successful because of the HONESTY and integrety of the
participants. Please continue its success by CAREFULLY ADHERING to
the instructions.Welcome to the world of Mail Order!  This little
business is some whatdifferent than most mail order houses.  Your
product is not solid andtangible, but rather a service.  You are in
the business of developingMailing Lists.  Many large corporations are
happy to pay big bucks forquality lists.  (The money made from the
mailing lists is secondary tothe income which is made from people
like yourself requesting that theybe included in that list.)

starting atnumber 1   through number 5.  SEND CASH ONLY.  (Total
investment: $5.00) Enclose a   note with each letter stating: "Please
add my name to yourmailing list".     Include your name and mailing
address.  (This is alegitimate service that you are requesting and
you are paying $1.00 forthis service.)
[2]   Remove the name that appears as number 1 on the list.  Move
the other 9 names up one position (Number 2 becomes number 1, number
3 becomes number 2, and so on).  Place your name, address, and zip
code in the number 10 position.
[3]   With your name in the number 10 position, upload this ENTIRE
fileto 10 (ten) different bulletin boards.  You may post it to the
BBS'smessage base or to the file section.  Name it FASTCASH.TXT, and
use the file description comments to draw attention to this file and
its great potential for all of us.

copy of this file for yourself so that you can use it again andagain
whenever you need money.  As soon as you mail out these letters
youare automatically in the mail order business.  People will be
sending YOU$1.00 to be place d on your mailing list.This list can
then be rented to a broker that can be found in your local yellow
pages listings for additional income on a regular basis.  The
listwill become more valuable as it grows in size.This is a service.

legality of this service, please referto Title 18, Sections 1302 and

*****To those with the COMMON sense to participate in this easy
moneyopportunity:About six months ago I received the enclosed post in

convinced it was justanother gimmick and could not possibly work.I
was wrong!  About three w eeks later I saw this same letter posted on
alocal bulletin board in Montreal.  I liked the idea of giving it a
trywith my computer.  I didn't expect much because I figured, if
otherpeople were as skeptical as I, they would not be too quick to
part w ith$5.00.  But, I BUY LOTTERY TICKETS WEEKLY IN MY PROVINCE
AND HAVE NOTHINGTO SHOW FOR IT BUT TICKET STUBS!  This week I decided
to look at this asmy weekly lottery purchase.  I addressed the
envelopes and mailed out$1.00 in each as directed.  Two w eeks went
by and I didn't receiveanything in the mail.  The fourth week rolled
around and I couldn'tbelieve what happened!  I can not say that I
received $50,000.00, but itwas definitely well over $35,000.00!  For
the first time in 10 years Igot out of debt.  It was great.  Of
course, it did not take me long to gothrough my earnings, so I am
using this excellent money makingopportunity once again.  FOLLOW THE
INSTRUCTIONS AND GET READY TO ENJOY!Please send a copy of this letter
along with the en

that this really doeswork!
Good Luck,
Charles Kust

in my opinion.  Personally, I don't like most house, so this is the kind 
of music I try to seek out.

	-->>     Jesus Chrysler -- jchryslr@catch22.com      <<--
	-->> Try our BBS: 415-865-2550 or telnet:catch22.com <<--


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Apr  7 16:38:29 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id QAA26725; Fri, 7 Apr 1995 16:38:29 -0700
Received: from harp.aix.calpoly.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with SMTP id QAA26707; Fri, 7 Apr 1995 16:38:23 -0700
Received: by harp.aix.calpoly.edu (AIX 3.2/UCB 5.64/4.03)
          id AA108565; Fri, 7 Apr 1995 16:38:30 -0700
Date: Fri, 7 Apr 1995 16:38:30 -0700 (PDT)
From: Daniel Alexander Robinson <drobinso@harp.aix.calpoly.edu>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: US...(as in we,everyone) (fwd)

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Fri, 7 Apr 1995 15:45:56 -0700 (PDT)
From: Morgan Jay Roberts (CyberGod) <mjrobert@oboe.aix.calpoly.edu>
To: Daniel Alexander Robinson <drobinso@oboe.aix.calpoly.edu>
Subject: Some more Thoughts..

OKAY! so this letter is GARGANTUAN! 

But with all the talk about everything on this list(rave integration etc.) 
this letter seems to express how I and  many of us feel.  And it is 
really worth reading...So please read it..

I met up with the local college radio station Dj that is working very 
hard on making a difference... I took an initiative to meet him...he sent 
me this letter he has found...somewhere on the net...Maybe you have read 
it maybe not but its a real confirmation ....So check it out! :)
                    T H E  I M A G I N A L  R A V E

This is not so much about what raves are or aren't, than 
about what they MIGHT be.

So don't bother looking here for a rehash of the obvious: that raves 
are the latest thing in underground dance parties/about having 
fun/feeling good/Peace/Energy/Unity ... all of which IS true, 
needless to say, but there remains so much more to be said, so much 
more to BE!

CUT through the clouds of trendism and commercialization that 
attach themselves to any major new mutation in culture. What wants 
to be invoked (what I want to invoke--what I hope YOU want to 
invoke) is that imaginal, incandescent core out of which all the 
smoke & noise is generated; what a rave truly can be, for some 
people in some situations--what it could BECOME; and then, peeling 
away at the sides, ... falling off one by one, duller, flatter, greyer ... 
and ever so much more TAME ... all those would-be and almost-raves, 
unavoidable byproducts of anything too real.

An old Sufi saying has it that: "where there's counterfeit, there's 
true gold."

So next time you go to something that calls itself a rave but isn't, 
don't just write it all off; the real ones do exist, and why SHOULD 
they be so easy to find? And, after all, it's up to YOU to make them 
real.

Allright, we already know that raves are THE space-age tribal youth 
ritual, the return of the dionysian energy that first emerged in 50's 
rock 'n' roll and erupted in full force in the late 60's with the 
intertwining of music and psychedelic drugs. But the rave-current is 
itself only the more visible crest of something broader and 
deeper.It's no coincidence that it hits the States at the same time as 
a major resurgence of psychedelic usage.

You can take the toying with neo'60's motifs--day-glo, flowers, 
smiley faces, flares--as mere fashion recycling by a generation born 
largely post-Summer of Love. Or you can see these themes as the 
instinctual recovery of a project left hanging, next breath after a 
two decade-long lull. Or you can go ever furthur--and why not!?--and 
see "the 60's" as only one recent intrusion within the Flatland of 
(take a deep breath now) Gravity-Bound-Domesticated-Humanoid-
Industrial Civilization (got that?) of a future that is already 
happening, a future that beckons us towards itself and sends its 
echoes spiralling back through the dark and narrow tunnels of 
terrestrial time to make itself come true...

But only with your help, of course!

Picture a wave forming on the horizon, a big one (talking late 50's, 
early 60's): the psychick surfers coasting out there, beatniks, non-
conformists, oddball academics bored with the small town life at 
the shore and all its dismal soap-opera games, looking for something 
to carry them away into a wilder, richer world; the first swells of 
energy carry with them a tide of psycho-active algaes...

HOFFMAN/HUXLEY/BURROUGHS/GINSBURG/WATTS/LEARY/ALPERT/KE
SEY & CO., issue their first reports and manifestoes; munching on the 
junk food of the gods, our proto-mutants are initiated into the 
mysteries of the Vortex; they come back to the cardboard facades of 
Main Street with their evocations of kaleidoscopic infinity, eyes lit 
with the light of alien suns. Their news answers a gnawing hunger 
among so many trapped within the greypastelboxroutines of the 
industrial-consumer-democratic hive; More, they activate dormant 
circuits of the hive's nervous system, and spawn a burst of deviance: 
forms of rebellion less interested in disputing what varieties of 
greypastelboxroutines are preferable and what's right and wrong for 
everybody, than in setting up scouting parties for heading out to 
sea...

Underline the word parties.

Dosed to the gills, beatniks in existential black mutate into 
rainbow-hued hippiedom. Up with the Flower Children, hedonistic and 
'escapist'--so called because they withdrew from the arena of 
domesticated primate aggro-sports known as 'politics' in favor of 
actually learning about the infinite kingdoms within their own body 
and nervous system. Drop into the Haight, turn off powertrips, tune 
out conformism and competition. 

Meltdown ensues. All the accelerated bondings through Be-Ins, Love-
Ins, communes. Awash in the incense of oriental exoticism and 
occultist bric-a-brac, a renaissance of the spirit decks itself out in 
raiments of psychic kitsch. And how much can we fault them, really, 
if their Love&Peace trip undercut itself by becoming a denial of the 
Darkness; after all, they are there for us to learn from.

But just as everyone is tumbling about in the cosmic froth, 
anticipating revolution or millenium tomorrow afternoon at the 
latest, the Wave suddenly evaporates beneath them. No, the Earth Egg 
didn't quite hatch yet, ...just some initial stirrings. And so the 
children of the Vortex find themselves hurtling through the air like 
Wil E. Coyote, wrapped up in all their newfound lifestyles, but the 
vital juice is gone, and it all becomes so tame and lame so quickly, 
and in any case, a lot of people couldn't handle the intensity so it 
comes time to settle back into a safe routine, in some cases lay the 
ground for those who come after; & all around are the Mr. Jones' of 
many guises, panicked at the imminent collapse of Normalville; some 
however take their chance to cash in on what they can of it, a lot of 
others are wholly freaked, and thus begins a Counter-Reformation. 
One the one hand, a retreat from direct encounter with the Abyss 
crystallizes into the New Age, and on the other, it's back to the 
Bible, dumb drugs, white-bread, and Family Values. And all the 
hipsters left posing without a clue, all the 
burnouts/fuckups/addicts & victims of some invisible multi-
dimensional boogeying elephant; over there in the ivy towers, the 
blind men scribble their learned tomes, dissecting some stray 
paisley footprints; but something far stranger has happened, and its 
awfully hard to make out just what till the next, bigger cousin of 
that wave starts to surface offshore.

Meanwhile even many devotees of the Vortex ascribe it to the 
decline in quality of their psychoactive goodies, mistaking the 
portal for the vista beyond (but how do you enter the vista without 
the portal? hmmm...BE THY VISION! a distant curl of the Vortex 
whispers back).

Credit it all to upsurges of the Gaian mind, long-schemed scams of 
the giggling DNA-consciousness, or the flotsam & jetsam cast down 
by That Transcendental Novelty Item at the End of Time; choose your 
metapors--the more the merrier; but there's a mystery-in-process 
that all the nice rationalistic analyses will never get at: here I'll 
echo a point once made by Mr. Leary: the most subtle form of 
conservatism is that which views the present only through the prism 
of the past!

And yes, (to those for whom it's not patently obvious), IT'S 
HAPPENING AGAIN.

***

At the heart of the rave is a modern, technologically clad 
form of non-verbal, ecstatic communion. The ethos of 
openness, sharing, intimacy, touch and empathy--not to mention the 
pure intensities of trance itself--facilitated by the use of LSD & 
MDMA (hey, the fact that you have to take these things to loosen up 
is a sign of just how far down & lost we all are!!), in tandem with 
the all-night long pulsation of bodies to the same sound source, can 
and does create a context where layers of armoring and conditioning 
are shed, where those willing can find the joyful and mysterious 
realm of their bodies free of oh-so many enculturated ego-trips and 
bullshit, ... while also opening the "post-terrestrial" circuits of their 
psyches. (Whew! Pause, return to beginning of paragraph, read again 
slowly.)

In other words, a safe space where we can be as weird as we want 
to be.

A collective molting ritual for the new species.

***

Or take it from another angle: compare the rave-thing to a chemical 
reaction: a half-dozen ingredients (make your own list), inert & 
ordinary in the normal course of things; but combine them in right 
proportions, at the right time and place, apply the CATALYST (& 
what what THAT be?) and BOOM!, you've set off an explosion, a chain 
reaction producing ENERGY, LOTS OF IT, and in that process a 
dynamic that continues to transform many of the starting 
ingredients into new & unknown qualities. No question, of course, 
that bystanders can look in from the skeptically, and reduce it all 
back to something familiar: escapism, consumerism, fashion parade, 
whatever. But we'll leave them to their nervous calculations...
 

***

OK, so you want a schoolbook definition of TECHNO-SHAMANISM, that 
catchphrase everybody likes to invoke but no one seems to be able to 
actually explain?
Prepare to jump levels: As the individual shaman/ess evicts demons 
and excises magical darts from the sick person through a mixture of 
magickal sound & motion, so on the level of the diseased and crisis-
ridden 'global village' raves aim to heal the collective body by 
shaking it loose of its neurotic fixations and death-fetishes. 

EXORCISM THROUGH DANCE.

Unhooking the talons and shadowy webs of control. A physical 
unlearning of a few thousand years worth of BAD HABITS.

Learning to be at once a little more human and a little more alien.

Healer, leader, visionary, outcast: the shaman/ess' role is multi-
faceted, both at the center but also relegated to the margins of the 
community; the use of sound and/or psychoactive compounds are 
central to shamanism. The shaman/ess chants, hums, drums and 
dances as a way of programming hir voyage into the "spirit realms" 
(aka hyperspace), as well as of healing the mind and body of others, 
... all on a more face-to-face, way lo-tech scale, of course.

So there, chew on that for a while.

***

It's a pretty sad but predictable fact that self-professed "radicals" 
have been oblivious to this phenomenon, just because it seems to 
emanate out of NITEKLUBLAND; too bad--when will they figure out 
that all social alienation is ultimately grounded in an alienation 
from the body--that realm of nature closest to us but oh-so far 
away. Their heroine Emma Goldman once proclaimed to the grim 
socialist militants of her day: "If I can't dance in your revolution I 
want no part of it."

And what if dance could be a modality of social change?

A heretical thought, no doubt. "Free your ass and your mind will 
follow," so said George Clinton. But hey, he was just another crass 
capitalistic rock star, right?

Not to rescusitate, however, that burdensome word, Revolution. 
Scratch the R, hilite the E. Quote an obscure graffito from a wall in 
Paris, May 1968: "This is not a Revolution but a Mutation." And say 
rather, TAZ. Temporary Autonomous Zone.

Like the TAZ, the rave is wild, nomadic, outside the maps of Power. 
At its best, the rave opens onto a realm of free-form behavior and 
perception, one in which there is no hierarchy, no leaders or 
followers, at most the dj and the light-show artists. (Hopefully 
benign--be careful who you leave your sensorium with!)

...Not unlike the Situationist International's notion of the "situation" 
(sorry, I just had to drag them in here!), a space of liberated 
interactions... but where the participants are the art and the show, 
the synergy between them all the event (or event horizon?). If the 
insurrection was supposed to realize itself in a festival, we might 
ask, why shouldn't the festival turn into an insurrection--an 
insurrection of Love?

Anyone who has been part of a REAL rave, if only once, briefly, 
knows that its insane, insanely beautiful ferocity is something that 
exceeds all the contrived parlour-games that pass for alternatives, 
social or political. The mere fact of this ferocious hedonism is, 
without words or slogans, A REFUTATION OF DOMESTICATED 
EXISTENCE.

So FUCK IT if most of this California rave-scene is still ensnared in 
niteklubbism. Invade the pseudo-raves, instigate roving micro-raves. 
Doesn't take more than a ghetto blaster and a handful of courageous 
revellers to start a rave on any streetcorner or park, see how long it 
takes to catch..., or to be shut down...

THIS is OUR form of protest--our style of dance is angry and 
combative as well as loving and celebratory; to free our bodies first 
from the rotting carcass of history,,,

...and from there, ... who knows where we'll go?

***

Prediction: a few years down the road, the rave-scene will be looked 
back on as the primary networking mechanism for the tribes of star-
farers. 

But if ravers can't clean up after themselves, how are they going to 
clean up the planet?

***

DANCE

If you had to have JUST ONE metaphor for it all to live by and 
through, wouldn't that just be it. The spiral dance of life...so it 
sounds cliched, but cliched only in words, in words...

DANCE

but (& rave-friends can detour here for a sec, these are words for 
those who've never raved and long stopped going out to 

DANCE

DANCE, --this kind of dance--is FREEING MOTION. Not just moving 
to the beat but letting the beat help you throw off all the 
constricted robotic movements that have been imprinted into your 
heart, your eyes, your ears, your arms, your ass, your dreams, by all 
the tricks, traumas & seductions of society; and find the REAL YOU; 
dancing with the world, but dancing off the consensus-trance, that 
narrow greyout rightangle robotic updown freezeframe pseudo-
reality.

Raves signal the return to Western culture of sacred dance. A dance 
that balances discipline with excess, ecstasy with focus. Look at the 
three great Monotheisms that have pretty much defined our psycho-
somatic matrix: Judaism, Christianity, Islam: none of them possess 
any tradition of Sacred movement; they have all been scared shitless 
of the Body, and have instituted its repression in a thousand and one 
subtle ways. How appropriate that the advent of a spiritualized form 
of movement to the center of Civilization should present itself in a 
totally decadent, seemingly profane form. And people wonder why 
raves are actively suppressed back in the UK? Raves represent the 
primal life-force suppressed so long ago it remains only a dim but 
real memory.

And let's get this out of the way too: dancing on a decent dose of a 
psychedelic is something else again: communing with the animal 
spirits encoded into the depths of your skin, letting them out of 
their millenial cages. Learning how you can be each of them when 
you need to be; and its also about learning how to fly, how to turn 
yourself inside out into a spinning glowing disc, though that's a 
little harder ... and then, once we've got that under our belts, we can 
do it TOGETHER.

It's been said before, but not clearly enough: UFOS R US.

***

So what if all this prepacked ravitis costs too much. Don't leave it 
to them and whine about how commercialized it all is: THROW YOUR 
OWN! AND MUTATE IT WHILE YOU'RE AT IT! 

So some of the dinosaurs may not be happy seeing their way of life 
superseded and want to stamp out those noisy critters scampering 
between their feet; more intelligence and greater manoueverability 
will be our response. Haven't we gotten sick enough of the Enemy-
Production Line?

Social transmutation can be fun too, right? There's fun, safe vapid 
alcoholic-nicoteine hedonism, letting off steam so you can return to 
Monday; and then there's fun that aims high, fun allied with Will. The 
path of disciplined excess (??).

But watch this--all those scouting parties of the future will be 
known by their capacity to throw great parties--and pioneer 
partying as a way of throwing off the legacy of the miserable 
Dominator culture we've all had to grow up in.

***

RAVERS, look a little ways forward: have you wondered yet what 
happens once you're burnt out after a year or two of intensive raving, 
once you've lost half your hearing, the beats become stale, and the 
Energy has leaked away. Where, what then?

Define the rave for me.

What does the verb TO RAVE really mean to you?

But first let's list all the stuff that seems to go with it: 
Acid/techno/deep house music; dancing from dusk to dawn; hi-tech 
light shows; lollipops, floppyhats, dayglo pendants, smart drinks; 
$15-20 tickets; zillion gigagawatts sound-systems; X,a cid, nitrous 
and 2CB; goofy outfits, sexy bodies; so many inane and beatific 
smiles...

SHALL we ask together: just what is the essence of a rave?

Suppose, just for a second that we subtract one by one each of the 
above accessories. Stretch your imagination to the limit, and take 
away even, yes, even THE MUSIC; till all we have left are the people, 
all those people who have found each other in this beat, in these 
hidden gatherings, but without the beat, just heartbeat, pulserate, 
breath, ... AND THE EXCHANGE OF LOVE-ENERGIES (isn't that what sex 
is, ultimately?) and each other's presence ... Radiant and revelling in 
our unearthly beauty ... so here we are: much as we adore it, do we 
really need the dance music to affirm our commonality, the patent 
fact that we are siblings of the the same spiritual family who 
through the raves have managed to find one another and in that 
finding remember who each of us truly is, orphan child of eternity. 
Do we need to confuse the rave with the quality of our common 
presence, our moving-loving together; can't we take the essence of 
the rave, freed of all the externals we associate with it, transfer 
and apply that energy elsehwere, to just about anything...?

It comes down to a challenge, a challenge posed in that leap from 
normal space to hyperspace that kicks in when the 'rave' really 
starts to rave: those altered moments when each of us in being 
truest to our uniqueness enters into a harmonious whole; elusive as 
this may be, it calls out, and asks to be realized in every moment of 
our lives; it asks for creation, CREATION OF LIFE, for the nurturing 
of real communities that last deeper & longer than a few hours on 
the dancefloor.

That creative energy, apply it not just to your style of dress but to 
your style of BEING. Free eros & intimacy from the shackles 
socially-inherited sexualities (gay vs, straight, male vs. female), 
from monogamy and the neurotic fixation on genital sexuality: 

YES, CELEBRATE your arrival here at last after a long trek, but don't 
forget, this is only the point of departure. These parties are our 
loading docks and shipyards. (And there is Work to be done: enough 
healing & cleaning for us all.) Here is where we will build not just a 
House, but a ship of dreams, a starship. Woven out of LOVE. CHAOS. 
LAUGHTER.IMAGINATION. WILL. 

And embark; post-nuclear families setting sail out along the 
unwinding multi-dimensional origami strands of alternity...

Our motto:

UTOPIA OR BUST.

        Reply to:   RE>>Our Destiny
I don't think Jonas was comtemplating a marketing scheme.
Good raves don't have anything to sell.
Vibe is not a commodity, and it's no one's personal property.
I've never seen anyone turned away from a map point except cops, and
they weren't there to get directions.

--------------------------------------
Date: 4/7/95 7:47 AM
To: Nathan Moser
From: ken_stuart@macshasta.snowcrest
Jonas Judd (jjudd@mercury.sfsu.edu) writes:

	An active stance would imply that we find a method of encouraging 
	"conventional" people to attend our celebrations.

	(Fraser is already trying to do this. I'm not sure how effective 
	his methods will be).
	
	It seems to me that most "conventional" people are the ones who 
	are in positions to affect immediate change. These are the teachers, 
	local politians, community leaders, etc.

	With their particiaption at our celebrations, they can come to 
	the same understanding as ourselves. They can then go back to work with 
	these new insights and work to affect change in their respective 
	areas.   

I've been thinking about this for a long time (and am still discussing
aspects of it with the Captn, especially since he can now see how it works in
.au land)...

I keep coming back to Kurt Cobain, and whether $200 grunge shirts at Macy's
affected his state of mind...

The flaw in the above reasoning is assuming that you can keep the same
character of Vibe after opening up the participation to the larger public. 
This has failed everywhere else - for example, most of us have experienced
reading a newsgroup or mailing list that was great until it became popular. 
Or how about just within raves themselves?  How many times have I read "at
Blah event, don't even arrive until 4 am when the club types have left"?  My
impression is that many local raves have map points mostly to exclude the
sort of people we're contemplating including!

SO, it is not sufficient just to create a marketing scheme for popularizing
rave culture.

It is crucial to come up with some way of doing this WITHOUT losing the Vibe
and just ending up with the format.

Otherwise,  Our Destiny is  the Michael Jackson/Tony Bennett House Party
Album....

respect to all,

Ken
ken@macshasta.com
send bounces to ken.stuart@tigerteam.org




From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Apr  7 17:20:55 1995

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Apr  7 17:31:13 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id RAA01654; Fri, 7 Apr 1995 17:31:13 -0700
Received: from shell1.best.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with ESMTP id RAA01643; Fri, 7 Apr 1995 17:31:10 -0700
Received: (fraser@localhost) by shell1.best.com (8.6.11/8.6.5) id RAA19301; Fri, 7 Apr 1995 17:30:51 -0701
Date: Fri, 7 Apr 1995 17:30:50 -0701 (PDT)
From: Fraser Clark <fraser@megatripolis.org>
X-Sender: fraser@shell1.best.com
To: Daniel Alexander Robinson <drobinso@harp.aix.calpoly.edu>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: USWEYOUTHEM!
In-Reply-To: <Pine.A32.3.91.950407162559.36946A-100000@harp.aix.calpoly.edu>
Message-ID: <Pine.BSD.3.91.950407172452.17772A-100000@shell1.best.com>
