thanksyou, thankyou daniel!  yes, this is a great piece - actually written
a few years ago by Jason Keene in his Tribal Doughnut zine.  he's visited
me in london and interviewed me a coupla months ago here in SF for
something (I forget) he now lives in LA and is often seen at the full
moon raves there. he's reminded us, I hope, that we are less talking about
what raves *are* than about what they *can* be.  or, rather, what they
*are* whether we exactly realise it yet or not. fraser

On Fri, 7 Apr 1995, 
Daniel Alexander Robinson wrote: 

> OKAY! so this letter is GARGANTUAN! 
> 
> But with all the talk about everything on this list(rave integration etc.) 
> this letter seems to express how I and  many of us feel.  And it is 
> really worth reading...So please read it..
> 
> This is not so much about what raves are or aren't, than 
> about what they MIGHT be.
> 
> So don't bother looking here for a rehash of the obvious: that raves 
> are the latest thing in underground dance parties/about having 
> fun/feeling good/Peace/Energy/Unity ... all of which IS true, 
> needless to say, but there remains so much more to be said, so much 
> more to BE!
> 
> CUT through the clouds of trendism and commercialization that 
> attach themselves to any major new mutation in culture. What wants 
> to be invoked (what I want to invoke--what I hope YOU want to 
> invoke) is that imaginal, incandescent core out of which all the 
> smoke & noise is generated; what a rave truly can be, for some 
> people in some situations--what it could BECOME; and then, peeling 
> away at the sides, ... falling off one by one, duller, flatter, greyer ... 
> and ever so much more TAME ... all those would-be and almost-raves, 
> unavoidable byproducts of anything too real.
> 
> An old Sufi saying has it that: "where there's counterfeit, there's 
> true gold."
> 
> So next time you go to something that calls itself a rave but isn't, 
> don't just write it all off; the real ones do exist, and why SHOULD 
> they be so easy to find? And, after all, it's up to YOU to make them 
> real.
> 
> Allright, we already know that raves are THE space-age tribal youth 
> ritual, the return of the dionysian energy that first emerged in 50's 
> rock 'n' roll and erupted in full force in the late 60's with the 
> intertwining of music and psychedelic drugs. But the rave-current is 
> itself only the more visible crest of something broader and 
> deeper.It's no coincidence that it hits the States at the same time as 
> a major resurgence of psychedelic usage.
> 
> You can take the toying with neo'60's motifs--day-glo, flowers, 
> smiley faces, flares--as mere fashion recycling by a generation born 
> largely post-Summer of Love. Or you can see these themes as the 
> instinctual recovery of a project left hanging, next breath after a 
> two decade-long lull. Or you can go ever furthur--and why not!?--and 
> see "the 60's" as only one recent intrusion within the Flatland of 
> (take a deep breath now) Gravity-Bound-Domesticated-Humanoid-
> Industrial Civilization (got that?) of a future that is already 
> happening, a future that beckons us towards itself and sends its 
> echoes spiralling back through the dark and narrow tunnels of 
> terrestrial time to make itself come true...
> 
> But only with your help, of course!
> 
> Picture a wave forming on the horizon, a big one (talking late 50's, 
> early 60's): the psychick surfers coasting out there, beatniks, non-
> conformists, oddball academics bored with the small town life at 
> the shore and all its dismal soap-opera games, looking for something 
> to carry them away into a wilder, richer world; the first swells of 
> energy carry with them a tide of psycho-active algaes...
> 
> HOFFMAN/HUXLEY/BURROUGHS/GINSBURG/WATTS/LEARY/ALPERT/KE
> SEY & CO., issue their first reports and manifestoes; munching on the 
> junk food of the gods, our proto-mutants are initiated into the 
> mysteries of the Vortex; they come back to the cardboard facades of 
> Main Street with their evocations of kaleidoscopic infinity, eyes lit 
> with the light of alien suns. Their news answers a gnawing hunger 
> among so many trapped within the greypastelboxroutines of the 
> industrial-consumer-democratic hive; More, they activate dormant 
> circuits of the hive's nervous system, and spawn a burst of deviance: 
> forms of rebellion less interested in disputing what varieties of 
> greypastelboxroutines are preferable and what's right and wrong for 
> everybody, than in setting up scouting parties for heading out to 
> sea...
> 
> Underline the word parties.
> 
> Dosed to the gills, beatniks in existential black mutate into 
> rainbow-hued hippiedom. Up with the Flower Children, hedonistic and 
> 'escapist'--so called because they withdrew from the arena of 
> domesticated primate aggro-sports known as 'politics' in favor of 
> actually learning about the infinite kingdoms within their own body 
> and nervous system. Drop into the Haight, turn off powertrips, tune 
> out conformism and competition. 
> 
> Meltdown ensues. All the accelerated bondings through Be-Ins, Love-
> Ins, communes. Awash in the incense of oriental exoticism and 
> occultist bric-a-brac, a renaissance of the spirit decks itself out in 
> raiments of psychic kitsch. And how much can we fault them, really, 
> if their Love&Peace trip undercut itself by becoming a denial of the 
> Darkness; after all, they are there for us to learn from.
> 
> But just as everyone is tumbling about in the cosmic froth, 
> anticipating revolution or millenium tomorrow afternoon at the 
> latest, the Wave suddenly evaporates beneath them. No, the Earth Egg 
> didn't quite hatch yet, ...just some initial stirrings. And so the 
> children of the Vortex find themselves hurtling through the air like 
> Wil E. Coyote, wrapped up in all their newfound lifestyles, but the 
> vital juice is gone, and it all becomes so tame and lame so quickly, 
> and in any case, a lot of people couldn't handle the intensity so it 
> comes time to settle back into a safe routine, in some cases lay the 
> ground for those who come after; & all around are the Mr. Jones' of 
> many guises, panicked at the imminent collapse of Normalville; some 
> however take their chance to cash in on what they can of it, a lot of 
> others are wholly freaked, and thus begins a Counter-Reformation. 
> One the one hand, a retreat from direct encounter with the Abyss 
> crystallizes into the New Age, and on the other, it's back to the 
> Bible, dumb drugs, white-bread, and Family Values. And all the 
> hipsters left posing without a clue, all the 
> burnouts/fuckups/addicts & victims of some invisible multi-
> dimensional boogeying elephant; over there in the ivy towers, the 
> blind men scribble their learned tomes, dissecting some stray 
> paisley footprints; but something far stranger has happened, and its 
> awfully hard to make out just what till the next, bigger cousin of 
> that wave starts to surface offshore.
> 
> Meanwhile even many devotees of the Vortex ascribe it to the 
> decline in quality of their psychoactive goodies, mistaking the 
> portal for the vista beyond (but how do you enter the vista without 
> the portal? hmmm...BE THY VISION! a distant curl of the Vortex 
> whispers back).
> 
> Credit it all to upsurges of the Gaian mind, long-schemed scams of 
> the giggling DNA-consciousness, or the flotsam & jetsam cast down 
> by That Transcendental Novelty Item at the End of Time; choose your 
> metapors--the more the merrier; but there's a mystery-in-process 
> that all the nice rationalistic analyses will never get at: here I'll 
> echo a point once made by Mr. Leary: the most subtle form of 
> conservatism is that which views the present only through the prism 
> of the past!
> 
> And yes, (to those for whom it's not patently obvious), IT'S 
> HAPPENING AGAIN.
> 
> ***
> 
> At the heart of the rave is a modern, technologically clad 
> form of non-verbal, ecstatic communion. The ethos of 
> openness, sharing, intimacy, touch and empathy--not to mention the 
> pure intensities of trance itself--facilitated by the use of LSD & 
> MDMA (hey, the fact that you have to take these things to loosen up 
> is a sign of just how far down & lost we all are!!), in tandem with 
> the all-night long pulsation of bodies to the same sound source, can 
> and does create a context where layers of armoring and conditioning 
> are shed, where those willing can find the joyful and mysterious 
> realm of their bodies free of oh-so many enculturated ego-trips and 
> bullshit, ... while also opening the "post-terrestrial" circuits of their 
> psyches. (Whew! Pause, return to beginning of paragraph, read again 
> slowly.)
> 
> In other words, a safe space where we can be as weird as we want 
> to be.
> 
> A collective molting ritual for the new species.
> 
> ***
> 
> Or take it from another angle: compare the rave-thing to a chemical 
> reaction: a half-dozen ingredients (make your own list), inert & 
> ordinary in the normal course of things; but combine them in right 
> proportions, at the right time and place, apply the CATALYST (& 
> what what THAT be?) and BOOM!, you've set off an explosion, a chain 
> reaction producing ENERGY, LOTS OF IT, and in that process a 
> dynamic that continues to transform many of the starting 
> ingredients into new & unknown qualities. No question, of course, 
> that bystanders can look in from the skeptically, and reduce it all 
> back to something familiar: escapism, consumerism, fashion parade, 
> whatever. But we'll leave them to their nervous calculations...
>  
> 
> ***
> 
> OK, so you want a schoolbook definition of TECHNO-SHAMANISM, that 
> catchphrase everybody likes to invoke but no one seems to be able to 
> actually explain?
> Prepare to jump levels: As the individual shaman/ess evicts demons 
> and excises magical darts from the sick person through a mixture of 
> magickal sound & motion, so on the level of the diseased and crisis-
> ridden 'global village' raves aim to heal the collective body by 
> shaking it loose of its neurotic fixations and death-fetishes. 
> 
> EXORCISM THROUGH DANCE.
> 
> Unhooking the talons and shadowy webs of control. A physical 
> unlearning of a few thousand years worth of BAD HABITS.
> 
> Learning to be at once a little more human and a little more alien.
> 
> Healer, leader, visionary, outcast: the shaman/ess' role is multi-
> faceted, both at the center but also relegated to the margins of the 
> community; the use of sound and/or psychoactive compounds are 
> central to shamanism. The shaman/ess chants, hums, drums and 
> dances as a way of programming hir voyage into the "spirit realms" 
> (aka hyperspace), as well as of healing the mind and body of others, 
> ... all on a more face-to-face, way lo-tech scale, of course.
> 
> So there, chew on that for a while.
> 
> ***
> 
> It's a pretty sad but predictable fact that self-professed "radicals" 
> have been oblivious to this phenomenon, just because it seems to 
> emanate out of NITEKLUBLAND; too bad--when will they figure out 
> that all social alienation is ultimately grounded in an alienation 
> from the body--that realm of nature closest to us but oh-so far 
> away. Their heroine Emma Goldman once proclaimed to the grim 
> socialist militants of her day: "If I can't dance in your revolution I 
> want no part of it."
> 
> And what if dance could be a modality of social change?
> 
> A heretical thought, no doubt. "Free your ass and your mind will 
> follow," so said George Clinton. But hey, he was just another crass 
> capitalistic rock star, right?
> 
> Not to rescusitate, however, that burdensome word, Revolution. 
> Scratch the R, hilite the E. Quote an obscure graffito from a wall in 
> Paris, May 1968: "This is not a Revolution but a Mutation." And say 
> rather, TAZ. Temporary Autonomous Zone.
> 
> Like the TAZ, the rave is wild, nomadic, outside the maps of Power. 
> At its best, the rave opens onto a realm of free-form behavior and 
> perception, one in which there is no hierarchy, no leaders or 
> followers, at most the dj and the light-show artists. (Hopefully 
> benign--be careful who you leave your sensorium with!)
> 
> ...Not unlike the Situationist International's notion of the "situation" 
> (sorry, I just had to drag them in here!), a space of liberated 
> interactions... but where the participants are the art and the show, 
> the synergy between them all the event (or event horizon?). If the 
> insurrection was supposed to realize itself in a festival, we might 
> ask, why shouldn't the festival turn into an insurrection--an 
> insurrection of Love?
> 
> Anyone who has been part of a REAL rave, if only once, briefly, 
> knows that its insane, insanely beautiful ferocity is something that 
> exceeds all the contrived parlour-games that pass for alternatives, 
> social or political. The mere fact of this ferocious hedonism is, 
> without words or slogans, A REFUTATION OF DOMESTICATED 
> EXISTENCE.
> 
> So FUCK IT if most of this California rave-scene is still ensnared in 
> niteklubbism. Invade the pseudo-raves, instigate roving micro-raves. 
> Doesn't take more than a ghetto blaster and a handful of courageous 
> revellers to start a rave on any streetcorner or park, see how long it 
> takes to catch..., or to be shut down...
> 
> THIS is OUR form of protest--our style of dance is angry and 
> combative as well as loving and celebratory; to free our bodies first 
> from the rotting carcass of history,,,
> 
> ...and from there, ... who knows where we'll go?
> 
> ***
> 
> Prediction: a few years down the road, the rave-scene will be looked 
> back on as the primary networking mechanism for the tribes of star-
> farers. 
> 
> But if ravers can't clean up after themselves, how are they going to 
> clean up the planet?
> 
> ***
> 
> DANCE
> 
> If you had to have JUST ONE metaphor for it all to live by and 
> through, wouldn't that just be it. The spiral dance of life...so it 
> sounds cliched, but cliched only in words, in words...
> 
> DANCE
> 
> but (& rave-friends can detour here for a sec, these are words for 
> those who've never raved and long stopped going out to 
> 
> DANCE
> 
> DANCE, --this kind of dance--is FREEING MOTION. Not just moving 
> to the beat but letting the beat help you throw off all the 
> constricted robotic movements that have been imprinted into your 
> heart, your eyes, your ears, your arms, your ass, your dreams, by all 
> the tricks, traumas & seductions of society; and find the REAL YOU; 
> dancing with the world, but dancing off the consensus-trance, that 
> narrow greyout rightangle robotic updown freezeframe pseudo-
> reality.
> 
> Raves signal the return to Western culture of sacred dance. A dance 
> that balances discipline with excess, ecstasy with focus. Look at the 
> three great Monotheisms that have pretty much defined our psycho-
> somatic matrix: Judaism, Christianity, Islam: none of them possess 
> any tradition of Sacred movement; they have all been scared shitless 
> of the Body, and have instituted its repression in a thousand and one 
> subtle ways. How appropriate that the advent of a spiritualized form 
> of movement to the center of Civilization should present itself in a 
> totally decadent, seemingly profane form. And people wonder why 
> raves are actively suppressed back in the UK? Raves represent the 
> primal life-force suppressed so long ago it remains only a dim but 
> real memory.
> 
> And let's get this out of the way too: dancing on a decent dose of a 
> psychedelic is something else again: communing with the animal 
> spirits encoded into the depths of your skin, letting them out of 
> their millenial cages. Learning how you can be each of them when 
> you need to be; and its also about learning how to fly, how to turn 
> yourself inside out into a spinning glowing disc, though that's a 
> little harder ... and then, once we've got that under our belts, we can 
> do it TOGETHER.
> 
> It's been said before, but not clearly enough: UFOS R US.
> 
> ***
> 
> So what if all this prepacked ravitis costs too much. Don't leave it 
> to them and whine about how commercialized it all is: THROW YOUR 
> OWN! AND MUTATE IT WHILE YOU'RE AT IT! 
> 
> So some of the dinosaurs may not be happy seeing their way of life 
> superseded and want to stamp out those noisy critters scampering 
> between their feet; more intelligence and greater manoueverability 
> will be our response. Haven't we gotten sick enough of the Enemy-
> Production Line?
> 
> Social transmutation can be fun too, right? There's fun, safe vapid 
> alcoholic-nicoteine hedonism, letting off steam so you can return to 
> Monday; and then there's fun that aims high, fun allied with Will. The 
> path of disciplined excess (??).
> 
> But watch this--all those scouting parties of the future will be 
> known by their capacity to throw great parties--and pioneer 
> partying as a way of throwing off the legacy of the miserable 
> Dominator culture we've all had to grow up in.
> 
> ***
> 
> RAVERS, look a little ways forward: have you wondered yet what 
> happens once you're burnt out after a year or two of intensive raving, 
> once you've lost half your hearing, the beats become stale, and the 
> Energy has leaked away. Where, what then?
> 
> Define the rave for me.
> 
> What does the verb TO RAVE really mean to you?
> 
> But first let's list all the stuff that seems to go with it: 
> Acid/techno/deep house music; dancing from dusk to dawn; hi-tech 
> light shows; lollipops, floppyhats, dayglo pendants, smart drinks; 
> $15-20 tickets; zillion gigagawatts sound-systems; X,a cid, nitrous 
> and 2CB; goofy outfits, sexy bodies; so many inane and beatific 
> smiles...
> 
> SHALL we ask together: just what is the essence of a rave?
> 
> Suppose, just for a second that we subtract one by one each of the 
> above accessories. Stretch your imagination to the limit, and take 
> away even, yes, even THE MUSIC; till all we have left are the people, 
> all those people who have found each other in this beat, in these 
> hidden gatherings, but without the beat, just heartbeat, pulserate, 
> breath, ... AND THE EXCHANGE OF LOVE-ENERGIES (isn't that what sex 
> is, ultimately?) and each other's presence ... Radiant and revelling in 
> our unearthly beauty ... so here we are: much as we adore it, do we 
> really need the dance music to affirm our commonality, the patent 
> fact that we are siblings of the the same spiritual family who 
> through the raves have managed to find one another and in that 
> finding remember who each of us truly is, orphan child of eternity. 
> Do we need to confuse the rave with the quality of our common 
> presence, our moving-loving together; can't we take the essence of 
> the rave, freed of all the externals we associate with it, transfer 
> and apply that energy elsehwere, to just about anything...?
> 
> It comes down to a challenge, a challenge posed in that leap from 
> normal space to hyperspace that kicks in when the 'rave' really 
> starts to rave: those altered moments when each of us in being 
> truest to our uniqueness enters into a harmonious whole; elusive as 
> this may be, it calls out, and asks to be realized in every moment of 
> our lives; it asks for creation, CREATION OF LIFE, for the nurturing 
> of real communities that last deeper & longer than a few hours on 
> the dancefloor.
> 
> That creative energy, apply it not just to your style of dress but to 
> your style of BEING. Free eros & intimacy from the shackles 
> socially-inherited sexualities (gay vs, straight, male vs. female), 
> from monogamy and the neurotic fixation on genital sexuality: 
> 
> YES, CELEBRATE your arrival here at last after a long trek, but don't 
> forget, this is only the point of departure. These parties are our 
> loading docks and shipyards. (And there is Work to be done: enough 
> healing & cleaning for us all.) Here is where we will build not just a 
> House, but a ship of dreams, a starship. Woven out of LOVE. CHAOS. 
> LAUGHTER.IMAGINATION. WILL. 
> 
> And embark; post-nuclear families setting sail out along the 
> unwinding multi-dimensional origami strands of alternity...
> 
> Our motto:
> 
> UTOPIA OR BUST.
> 
> 
>

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Apr  7 20:45:41 1995

Received: from suffix.cs.ucdavis.edu by toadflax.cs.ucdavis.edu (4.1/UCD.CS.2.6)
	id AA24586; Fri, 7 Apr 95 20:45:36 PDT
Received: by suffix.cs.ucdavis.edu (5.65/UCD.CS.2.6)
	id AA11915; Fri, 7 Apr 1995 20:45:36 -0700
From: murphyk@cs.ucdavis.edu (Kevin P. Murphy)
Message-Id: <9504080345.AA11915@suffix.cs.ucdavis.edu>

Mime-Version: 1.0

Date: Sat, 8 Apr 1995 11:04:58 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: jsl@netcom.com (John S. Lee)
Subject: radio, raves, drugs, weekend...
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well this week was interesting.  I HAD to sit in my car (no car phone while
taking my wife & son to their destination), and endure Michael Krasne
making a concerted effort to link drug use & raves as mututally exclusive
activities.  The show was all about the death on X and raves.  They kept on
citing England and some other nonsense not realted to the American scene.
Some high school senior was one of the guests along with the only "e"
researcher in the USA.  I am glad that they had a, for lack of a better
word, youth, talk about the scene, but her age showed just how limited her
access was to most of the events.  Yes, she had gone to the large Cow
Palace parties, but  really didn;t talk about any other experiences.

Bright spots, several parents called in to say it was no big deal.  About
the X death and all.  A mother of a deceased girl (e related death) called
in and gave the green light to e, despite Krasnes attempts at demonizing
the drug.  What was notcieably absent werfe ANY of the REAL playerrs here
in SF.  Noticeably lacking wwas any of the larger promoters (Preston,
Wicked, Kevin, & Jerry, or Martin), much less any of the people who are
active in the dance culture (DJ's, promoters, SFRaves, etc.).  In other
words it was a kangaroo court on E, raves, and dance culture, with NONE of
it's active participants as part of the conversation.  What a sucky pice of
crap media alert hysteria.  As only KQED can do (is it ANY wonder the left
suffers so miserably in the U.S.).

It's really not suprising though.  With some respect due to KQED for
finding ANYBODY who would step up to the plate, I would say that the
majority of the promoters, etc. are so busy being dodgy, and trying to stay
as anon as possible, that there was little hope of getting any of them to
get on the air and say squat, much less any of the dj's.  A little
organization some years back could have remedieid this, but alas, egos rule
SF, along with great music.

I am sure that the rave community will continue to be misrepresented as
necessary by the media.  Organization would rememedy this mirepresentation,
but there seems to be little will for all involved with dance culture to
unite at this time.  But as I have said before, the tribes MUST eventaully
gather.
++++

The UG I was supposed to be spinning @ is ON this evening.  I will be
spinning this eve.  Write me for details as I do not want this posted to
the list.  The guests include a Mr. Munsen, The Baroness, and PollyWog to
name a few.  The best that can be said is that there should be all kinds of
music played this evening.  I'm looking forward to it!

Bust factor: 0

++++
To all going to Vision, have FUN!  Martin always manages to put on a show,
and is one of the few people responsible for introducing large numbers of
the "youth" to dance culture.  Right on Martin!

Im out.
++++

Late,
John

                "Prejudice is the reason of fools." - Voltaire
              jsl@netcom.com - public key available upon request

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Apr  8 13:09:08 1995

A further thought on The Imaginal Rave (the "gargantuan letter" posted 
once again [thanks] yesterday):


I love the incoming wave analogy, which sees the rave scene as another 
wave emanating from the same source as the late-60s wave. But there were 
other waves before that, and you might find their timing interesting: 


1910-1914 (with echoes into the '20s): An entirely new lifestyle "for the 
20th century" introduced, with a new prototype for relationships, both 
temporary and lasting, which finally loosened (didn't quite break) the 
repressive Victorian mold. This was accompanied by a HUGE dance craze.

1844-1850s: The flowering (and public acceptance) of the Romantic Era, 
introduced by a few free thinking pioneers in the 1830s. This was 
accompanied by a huge dance craze.


Note: I happen to think of the 50s beat-to-rock era as an early form of 
the late-60s counterculture, but together comprising one era. You might 
disagree.


So this is what you see when you plot all of this over time:


      xXXXxx                   xxXXxxxx          xXXxxXXx     xxXX 
|   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |
30  40  50  60  70  80    1900  10  20  30  40  50  60  70  80  90  


... more or less.  Increasing frequency of the oncoming waves.


Probably not a full generation 'till the next one. When they finally 
connect, seque together, without the droughts in between, is this the 
Hundredth Monkey?


Richard Powers

vintage@leland.stanford.edu

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Apr  8 15:02:36 1995

Subject: Re: Rave history
In-Reply-To: <Pine.SUN.3.91.950408124353.18171C-100000@elaine5.Stanford.EDU>
Message-ID: <Pine.SUN.3.91.950408143548.14520A-100000@elaine38.Stanford.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Thanks to those sending feedback to my rave history posting. For those 
speculating on the next wave, let me offer my two cents worth here.

If you have no interest in rave history/future speculation, that's fine 
with me. Simply skip on to the next posting.


My original posting (repeated at the end of this one) proposed that the 
positive energy of the current rave scene just might be part of an ongoing 
series of new waves. IF this pattern continues for another cycle, it is 
due in 2010-15. 

The future cannot be extrapolated from any ongoing patterns, of course. 
But this MIGHT just happen in a BIG way in 2010 because of a
concurrence with another, unrelated, dynamic:

This is the pattern is found in the years 1410, 1510, (skips once to 1750 
for sociopolitical reasons), 1810, 1910, and...?

(1810 was not the major change of the century, not compared to 
1844, but the Regency Era was nevertheless a significant ripple of 
fresh energy, accompanied by, yes, a new dance craze that included 
the introduction of the waltz to many countries.)

This pattern is that of a Coming New Century, with accompanying 
expectations for Great Change. Of course, the expectations are not 
based on anything more real than an arbitrary calendar, and thus 
should carry no real influence, UNLESS you have an entire population 
BELIEVING that a change is due. Then it becomes real.

The changes do not occur on the exact century mark, because a numeral
is not a true catalyst for change. But after a few years, people become 
disappointed that the expected changes did not occur, restless for some-
thing fresh, and much more open (or less resistant) to new ideas. 
This delayed fuse usually takes about one decade to ignite change.

You might say that people will accept ANY change ten years into a 
century, not necessarily because it has great merit, but simply because 
the time is right. Ragtime-music-to-early-jazz, tango, blues, etc. became 
mainstream for this century because they happened to be the newest
music and dance in 1910? Some of us think they were great, others say it 
was just the timing.


Back to the first pattern, the lifestyle-change waves that hit in the 
1840s-50s, 1910s-20s, 1950s-60s and now:

If these waves of positive, creative, transcendental energy are
indeed arriving in a regular, accelerating pattern, with the next one 
due in 2010, I think there is a very good chance that it will catch and 
ride on the OTHER 2010 wave, the new-century one. 

Resulting in a tsunami? 

We'll soon see.


Richard

I like the idea david and I have been discussing this last fortnight: a 
questionnaire that measures you attitudes to change and the future and 
tells you what year you are living in.  elvis fans would be living in the 
'50s, say, or punks in the middle '80s.  some of us would be living in 
the future.
great to meet you guys today, and phred DJing when we came in with the 
dutch tv crew.  and the historical backporch and we got the producer to 
dance for a moment though not captured on film, and a scotsman DJs next.
on the way to the shop they did this amazing thing where tom and I walked 
the whole length of a block of haight st5reet on a busy saturday with the 
camera crew GOING BACKWARDS filming us - obviously a technique they've 
worked out, with holds of the elbow, and the director waalking forwards 
ahead etc.  anyway it should be a great long shot.  it'll be out in 2 
weeks. we'll forward you a copy.

incidentally I wanted to comment on our attiudes to the press.  what you 
said about nevertrusting the press is still true today for the daily 
newspapers.  they only want sensationalism and I am quite sure they will 
be starting to demonise RC this summer.  word is coming down from the top 
and from the Subconscious that RC is getting powerful.

but magazines are a whole other matter.  only once a month they deal in  
dif3errent level, and level of readers.  they want some more depth.  and 
my finding last year with the tour was that the people who work for the 
monthlies are pretty much ravers themselves.  and so it becomes a conspiracy 
between them and us to get some truth past the owners.
fraser.

a party and an evolutionary experiment and etc

shit in the toilet am I to be acused of trying to introduce SF to it? 
actually the music Paul Q plays is happy, witty stuff, a pe4sonal choice
and not very trancey at all - though we will start introducing trance at
the Cyberlab7Safari

one last thing.  the Parallel University tries to explore evolutionary
frontier areas in as subversively edutaining a manner possible.  we happen
to be dealing with SEX because we were invited to do a book rave launch
for the new book Better Sex Through Chemistry and made that our first
topic of the year.

it, with ties to the book which I am perfectly cerain will sell a million
and a half coplies wordlwide.  good luck to them say I.  whether it's
exactly what the planet is waziting for it's one of the technologies we
should know about, that's for sure.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Apr  9 05:13:13 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id FAA03111; Sun, 9 Apr 1995 05:13:13 -0700
Received: from ultima.org by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with SMTP id FAA03106; Sun, 9 Apr 1995 05:13:06 -0700
Message-Id: <199504091213.FAA03106@taz.hyperreal.com>
Subject: Liquid Air
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Sun, 9 Apr 1995 05:09:44 -0700 (PDT)
From: "Bryce Ryan" <brycer@ultima.org>
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 8935
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hi, all!

Liquid Air was a blast (of cool air :-), and many thanks for your thoughts,
and to those who came out.  Things got rolling a bit late, since the bulk
of folks came by later.  But when we reached critical mass, we
set up in a hurry, and got down to some fun music.  Phred and a friend
(sorry, i can't remember his name) tag teamed for almost two hours...some
really wonderful stuff.  Joe followed, then Alex, then Phred closed us off
for the evening.  We did get visited by the police, and this part is the
real message.  I had a long conversation with two of the police, and there
was a lot of information that was exchanged that may be of benefit to
others considering events at our chosen location.  (send me email if you
need to know where we had the event).

When we noticed that we were being observed, I immediately began walking
toward the parking area.  They had shined their light on us (which clued
us in that we had visitors from the police).  As i walked toward the 
parking area, they turned off their light, stopped the motor in their
vehicle, and got out of the cruiser.  I asked them if i could help them.
They asked me what i could help them with, and i said i wasn't sure, but
thought i should come over and talk with them to see if they had any concerns.
they asked me if i was responsible for this, and i said yes, since it was
my sound system and invitation that had gotten this rolling.  it also gave
them one person to talk with (and possibly cite) instead of several.

They reported their location, saying that it was an illegal rave, and began
walking toward the dance area (which was about 100 yards away).  They asked
me why i thought we could do this at that location.  I said that i believed
that we were at a public park.  they asked me why i thought that, and i 
said that it was marked as such on the maps i had seen, and that there
seemed to be publicly maintained structures at the site.  They asked me
if i was aware that public parks in san francisco were closed after 10PM.
i said no, that i wasn't aware of any such thing, and thanked them for
telling me so.  They then speculated that if this were private property,
and we had the permission of the owner, that would be our best move.  i
thanked the officer who informed me of that.

First and foremost on their minds was to know if we were charging admission
or taking money.  This was easy to answer, since it was advertised,
intended and executed as a free party.  They were quite skeptical on this
point, so i explained how I owned the sound system, rented a very small
generator, and invited a few friends to come listen to some music in a 
place where noise wasn't going to be a problem.  All the complete truth.
I also explained that the generator was one of the quietest ones made.
They said they'd have to take a look at that, which we did, later on.

We were walking towards the dance area (and the music had been turned
down somewhat), and they looked around at folks.  They then asked their
question again about asking for money.  They also asked if people were
drinking alcohol.  Again, i said that i had seen a few bottles, but had
asked folks to cap it and take it back to their cars if i had seen it.
They asked if there were minors present, and said how minors and alcohol could
be a problem.  I said that some of the folks seemed like they might be
minors, but i had no way of knowing.  

We then talked about the sound system, and how we could not be charging
admission.  since i owned the soundsystem and had a receipt for the
generator (they looked at the marking on the generator), the answer
was quite simply that it cost next to nothing to put on, and was just
a way for us to play some music without bothering anyone. one officer
asked me "you aren't receiving any remuneration for your sound system,
the person playing the music isn't getting paid, you're not getting
any money at all for this?"  i said no, i owned the sound system, and
there was absolutely no money exchanged for anything, no goods, no
services, no use fees, no money at all.

They started asking me questions about safety.  i informed them that i
had friends looking out for mischief on a regular basis, and that we
had set up in such an obvious place so we could have clear lines of sight
all around us, to help us be aware of trouble well before things got
difficult.  They asked me what we would do if some of the neighbors
("White kids!" they said, with a touch of disbelief in their voices)
drove by and just shot into the park.  how can one answer a question
like that?  i just reiterated that we were keeping an eye on the parking
area, and hoped to be able to avoid a situation like that.

An officer took me aside and shone his flashlight on the ground, and said,
"Look at that!"  i had a hard time distinguishing what he was pointing
at, and asked him "look at what?"  He then looked me right in the eye,
making his displeasure and disbelief very clear and said that he didn't
care about me or my sound system, and that he thought i was bullshitting.
since i had no reason to assume he cared about either me or my sound
system, that didn't phase me.  since i wasn't bullshitting him at all,
i just took this as information about his attitude about what i was
saying...again, no surprises.  He pointed out some charred wood, and
said, "One thing we *don't* like out here is fires.  That looks like
you guys were having a fire out here.  We don't like fires.  What does
that look like to you?"  I said, "it looks as if someone had a fire
and it's out now."  The officer then asked me if we had made a fire,
and i answered, truthfully, that no, we had not made a fire.  The
officer reiterated that he thought i was bullshitting him, and said
he would make me a deal:  "if i go over there and it's warm, that
means you guys made a fire.  if it's warm, i'm going to throw you and
your sound system into the bay.  how's that for a deal?"  i said that
was fine, since i *knew* that i had been on the spot for at least
four hours, and no one had made a fire.  i was also betting on the man's
integrity, that if he went over, and felt cold ashes, that he would
report them as cold and not throw me and my sound system into the bay
(and a yukky spot on the bay it was, believe me...i prolly would have
gotten sick just from the water :-( ).  He put his hand into the ashes,
and said, OK, went back to his posse (now grown to four officers),
greeted the newcomers, and asked them if they wanted to stay and dance.
they laughed and said it wasn't their kind of music.  the officers
turned to me and told me to keep it under control, and then left. i
then realized there was another cruiser (probably a sergeant's or
lieutenants, since it was all white) in the parking area.  they went 
over and talked with the officer(s) in that car, and all left shortly
thereafter.

i think the officers and i covered a lot of ground that all people
considering outdoor and nightime events should be aware of. of course,
this is my personal take on the lessons learned, YMMV, and all that. 

it is
necessary for whoever is talking with them to be sober, responsible,
and believable, probably also well over 18.  the person(s) should be
willing to take responsibility for the entire event.  it is best to
meet the police as soon as they are recognized, and well away from
the main area that people are hanging out.  the person talking with
them should keep them engaged as much as possible...as we were walking
toward the dance area, several people passed us, and were paid no
heed.  The person(s) should believe that what they are doing is 
perfectly legal, and as safe as possible.  the person should recognize
the limits of the safety they can provide to people, and be willing
and able to discuss *in detail* what measures are being taken to ensure
the safety of the people there. the person shouldn't be naive, nor try
to persuade the police that there are neither minors nor alcohol present,
and should have a detailed account of what they personally have done to
prevent public consumption of alcohol, and promote safety.  the
person must be able to deal with any good cop/bad cop behavior.  the
person should be as truthful as possible, and able to deal with police
telling them that they and their possessions are of no concern.  the
person must also be willing to deal with a factual test of some kind.
courtesy, coolness, and a willingness to take the rap (if necessary)
are also required...it's a big, bad world, and the cops make the rules
when they come into contact with you. it is best to simply accept
that and answer their questions carefully and thoughtfully, saying no
more or less than you *know* to be a fact.

i hope this anecdote may be of use to you or one of your friends.
-- 
=== Bryce Ryan ===== AMBIANCE ========= e-dress: brycer@ultima.org =========
=== Internet services, education, and Toaster Net construction :-) =========

Dear All;

	I'm glad things worked out with the police, I personnally wish that
people would just keep there alcoholic beverages in there cars. If you are
at an outdoor event, there's just no reason to bring them into the event
area. Is it that much to ask of someone to keep them in their cars, and
when their thiristy go back and drink by your car to your hearts content.

	I just think its sooo selfish of people who don't want to have the
minor inconvience of walking back to their cars to get their drinks.
Instead they risk having the party busted, a major inconvience for
everyone, it just doesn't make sense to me. People at our events need to
me more responsible, and think a lot more, we could minize negative police
interaction by just doing a few simple things. I have never been busted
for drugs or alcohol in 20 years of partying(knock on wood), I have a
simple expression that I say to myself when I start to get a little lazy,
or careless, "better safe than sorry", once something happens you can't
change it, but a little precaution a head of time can save you a lifetime
of hassle.  Just something to think about, because its to late when your
in jail and the party's busted.

Dear Timothy;

	There's being stereotyped, and then there's out and out dishonest 
press. The press we have been refering to comes to us with often a hidden 
agenda, under the guise of helping our scene. This is no more that lieing 
to people, they aren't very honest about what they are printing, its just 
lies.

	Again I feel we don't need the mainstream press, we have the 
internet, I would be interested in you indicating to me a mainstream 
factual rave press source. Life is not black and white, it is always a 
shade of grey, and often, but not always, the press doesn't print things 
that are life affirming, just bad news. I challedge you to pick up any 
printed news source and count the - and the + articles, and I guarentee 
you that the - ones will out number the + ones by at least 10 to 1, and 
I'm sorry but I believe that there are more + things going on in our 
world today than are given credit for by the press.

	Carlos Santana was involved in a project for creating a TV 
channel dedicated to the dignity of man, as opposed to what going on out 
there today, things like OJ.

Hi Allen:

Thanks for the note >> I love your time wave posts...>>
 

> It comes down to facination is more important than fact.


Yeah, and I have a concern along that line about these speculations (the 
2010 vision). 

Remember Jose Arguelles' _Transformative_ Vision_? 
He came up with a prediction of a different kind, published it, and found 
that it was picked up bigtime by the new age set, who almost turned it 
into some sort of spiritual Second Coming, which they called the Harmonic 
Convergence. Right?

Arguelles played along with it as it mutated through the pre-HC hype, 
as the prediction date neared, then it turned out to be a fizzle. A FUN 
fizzle for those who gathered on mountaintops at sunrise, but it 
knocked the credibility of the new age movement down half a notch.

So did Arguelles place fascination over fact, or did his readers? 
Or did he let his following draw himself into the hype?


Fascination is fine. The possibility of these incoming waves of 
enlightenment finally taking root before dissolving is more than 
fascinating! ...which makes me all the more careful about the tendency to 
believe what we want to believe, replacing our simply (and directly) being 
right with what is happening now and nourishing it on to the next step
...the direct nonanalylitical experience that is an essence of raving.


Hope to cross paths some day.

Richard

Dear All;

	I would just like to give love, praise, a million little smiley
faces and thanks to all the wonderful womyn on our list who continue to
lead by example(the true & most effective form of leadership), resisting
this negative example set by some of the men here, by not flaming and not
participating in, what I'm sorry to say is "male ego bullshit", that has
been dominateing our list as of late. I would pick and personnally deliver
to you all a big bunch of wild flowers if I knew where you all lived :). I 
pray that the womyn of the world today, lead us all to a better way of 
respectful, affirming communication. 

	Personnally I have never received a flame from a womyn, just their
private honest feelings about what I've had to say. Please continue this
example, because I, if no one else does, appreciate and recogizes the
amount of real courage it takes to put your heart, soul and feelings on the 
line. 

	Any idiot can flame you, this is not courage or mach-cizmo, just
incredible misery & insecurity, and to all our flamers, everyone on this
list knows it. So do us and most important yourselfs a favor, and don't
insert your keyboard in your mouth, I promise you'll feel a lot better.

	     Peace, Love & Thanks From Across Cyberspace

 Well , I just bought my first Jungle mix tape today at Ameba. It's by a 
DJ Ocean - the insert graphic is a bunch of gigantic chrome orbs floating
over the ocean. I really like it! They had another Jungle tape that I
didn't like so much , as there was a lot of Jamacian "toasting" on it,
which I'm not much of a fan of. So far , as I'm listening to it, the
DJ Ocean tape keeps the "toasting" to a minimum - much more cool instrumental
stuff in crazy syncopation. 

 This style of music may be the final trigger to get me to update my 
pathetic car stereo system to something that actually has clean(er)
bass below 100HZ. The deep bass is "sane" enough to move your feet 
to , while the crazy syncopation of the midrange/treble tweaks the 
arms and the brain. I can't imagine dancing to this stuff without
the support of a dancable bass pattern.

 I hope more DJs incorporate Jungle into the music played in the main dance
rooms at raves , instead of keeping it seperate or absent.   

 Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

Hi Fraser,

Glad to see you're back.

> I say smart drinks will be replacing Java House within a couple of
> years. not that I'd bet on it or anything.

Hmm, I don't know.  There is a certain amount of ritual associated with
coffee drinking that has been amassed over the last few millenia that would
be hard to overcome.   Have you ever made your own cup of expresso?  For me
its become an elaborate ritual in the morning that serves to focus me and
bring a smile to my face.  Smart drinks because they are not as accessible
may not lend themselves to ritualization and java houses.

Looking forward to the next Chemica Sutra,

PT

Precedence: bulk

[ Broadcast to sfraves ]
This is the list of musical "bass test" recordings that folks recommended to 
me. ( I had asked for recordings that had low frequency content down to 30HZ , 
and where also enjoyable to listen to .) Thanks for the hints!
                                          Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

PS - In addition to the recordings listed below - Pink Floyd's "Dark Side Of 
 The Moon" has a good deep heartbeat at the beginning of one of the cuts. Also
 a nice section where all sorts of mechanical clock alarms and chimes are
 going off simultaneously  - a nice high frequency test.
-------------------------
 808 State "Excel", or LFO "Frequencies" which has a bass warning on the label.
-------------------------
...  my favorite low (frequency) test tracks consist of pipe organ music. 
Try BACH BUSTERS...
-------------------------
Symphony of the Planets 1: NASA Voyager Recordings
This will knock you on your ass, if I may be so blunt :)
-------------------------
Exist Dance "Transmitting from Heaven" CD compilation - "we're go: stage one"
by (if i remember correctly) High Lonesome Sound System.
-------------------------
The one that comes to mind is
"BASS 305: DIGITAL BASS (by DM Records) contains fundamentals close to 20 Hz.
If you want to go below that, the 1812 Overture by TELARC contains one of
the lowest recorded fundamentals (10 Hz at -120 dB ref 20uPa).
-------------------------
 Basshead disks, and very few classical selections featuring
Contra-Oboes(?). Most of the lowest bass you find in regular disks is
about 50-60 hz, and that is the heavy rap. Most of the stuff I have heard
(Bass 305, Bass to the Future, Techno-Bass) are very one-dimentional and
aren't very musical. I know you say no test disks, but I have one from
Carver that I use with my system. It features a full-range of test tones,
including pink and white noise, in and out of phase freqs AND 4 songs
that range from swing to new-age to jazz, which covers the full range.
-------------------------
DJ Magic Mike:  Bass, the Final Frontier...
>From Miami of course
Go to Rasputins, they have a "bass" section!
-------------------------
try THIS IS ACID JAZZ.
either the second or third track is FANTASTIC>>>>>>>>>>>
-------------------------
... Track 9, "Ketamine Entity", off of "Colourform" by the Higher Intelligence 
Agency has some crazy low bass. For something a little more analog 
(real drums), "Dafos", by Mickey Hart, Airto, and Flora Purim has some good, 
low kettle drums in it. Heres a more formal listing:

LFO - Frequencies , Tommy Boy TBCD1048
Higher Intelligence Agenciy - Colourform , Waveform 84102-2 (esp. Track 9)
Dafos - Mickey Hart, Airto, Flora Purim , Ryko RCD 10108
-------------------------
Try the first Tracy Chapman record or _The Nightfly_ by Donald Fagan.

Or one of those Bassomatic records you'll find in mass quantities in
the "used" bin at Wherehouse.

Or anything by dub dudes Scientist or Prince Far I.
-------------------------
i picked up this used cd in a pawn shop called "Bass Cube" which
is hip-hoppish, miami techno with lots of really low bass, probably
atleast 30hz.  th cd is on Pandisc records out of miami.
-------------------------
Young American Primitive's self titled album.
Ambient/trance type stuff with a purply-pink cover with satellite dishes on
it.  Perhaps you already have it.  Anyway there's a song on there called
Monolith that's in 2 parts.  The first part has this incredible throbbing
bass that swells up and down the lower frequency range from about 250hz down
to sub-audible frequencies (i.e. less than 20 hz).  If you want to test bass
response, I can't think of anything better.  I have some pretty decent
speakers, but I can hear their minor flaws when I play this track.
-------------------------
A little late, and a little old, but try Drugs Work from the original
tresor comp on novamute nmcd3002. 
------- End of list --------

Precedence: bulk

Vibe tribe report
=================

Well,  time once again for yet another report on the rave scene here
in Sydney.

This weekend was the VIbe Trib outdoor party in Sydney park.   We heard
on the radio that the location was fairly easy to get to,   so we headed
out there to check it out.

The location is at an old industrial park,  at the St Peters train station.
Sure enough as we got off the train,  we heard the music.   The party
was much bigger than I expected,   but it was certainly underground.

The soud system was set up against an old brick wall or building,   decorated
by black light posters.   Out away from the dance area was the grassy part,
where people were hanging out and chilling.

Almost immediatly I started dancing,   but the DJ was changing the beats
around with almost every song.   Certainly wasn't continious.   But when
the other DJ went on,   the energy picked up considerably.   Sometime later,
they were making an anouncement asking the crowd to not let the police get
anywhere near the turn tables.   But as I looked around,   I couldn't see
anything,  so I continued dancing.    The vibe was amazing,   a lot like
the Sunset parties in SF.    Eventually,   sometime around 2 am,  the cops
tried to charge into the group of people dancing near the front,   but
the crowd defiently deflected most of them back towards the edge.    A
person was up there asking people to stand form,  saying "We have a right
to be here,  just like anyone else" ..   Finally the cops backed off,  and
the dancing continued.   It was short lived though,  as the cops were staying
back to re-group.   This time,   they charged into the group of happy dancing
folks,   getting mean and violent,  literally knocking down anyone in their
way.    They dragged off several people,  one of which was the promoters,
without regard for the groups safety.   One of the vibe tribe members was
injured badly in the fracus,  but the ravers stood their ground and chanted
"We just want to dance...!".   Then other people were yelling "Go out and
stop the muggers and leave us alone"... Others were saying "Look,  they
are vndelizing your car,  go and stop them...".

Eventually the cops found the generator,  shut it down,  and carted it out.
Immediatly the group carted out the bongo drums and started drumming and
defying the cops in any way possible.   WoW!!  would have to say,  these
Aussies got balls,  because the group just refused to leave.   More cops
arrived,   as the promoters were negotiating with the supervisor,  and the
cops were also being especially nasty.   They eventually backed off,  and
allowed the drumming to continue.

All in all,  I'm told that 17 people were arrested,   and a half hour later,
the media showed up,   but we left after that,   and I headed over to another
party called MORPH,  but at about 5 am,  things looked pretty dead,  but I met
one of the vibe tribe members that got injured,   who later asked if I
would join in a game of billiards,   afterwards,  I finally left and headed
over to Recovery.    Recovery was practically dead most of the afternoon,
then eventually went home for a while.

Later on,  towards the evening,  I headed back to recovery,  when things started
to get hopping,  and "Shade", this new DJ was just getting on.   Some people
came up to me and said "This DJ is the best in Sydney".   Shade started off
with some slower tunes (around 140 bpm),   but gradually,  the beats started
to pick up.    WOW!  This guy was amazing,  scratching to 160 BPM beats,
literalyy tearing my head to schreds,  as he gradually worked from trance to
hard core.   At the end of his set,  he was somewhere around 220 BPM's,
literally taking off.  WOW!!  Now I see why this dude is so good.

After his set,  Akira went on,  and kept the "Doof Doof" sounds going for the
remainder of his set as well.   I eventually left,   after that,  visited
some friends until late in the early hours of Monday morning.

WOW!!  Another crazy weekend in Sydney...

Crunchman

I have inclosed some additional comments from some of the other AusRavers
on the insanity that happened in Sydney last Sat evening.  It appears
there is  GLOBAL crackdown on raving world wide,  with the Criminal
Justice bill,   San Franciso SOMA crackdowns,   and now Sydney Australia.

>From Rosie Cross <rosiex@jolt.mpx.com.au>
-----------------------------------------

Ravers do they now have to hide in parks?
by RosieX


About 2.30am Sunday, April 9. "Freequency" a rave organised by vibe
tribe and other peace lovin' party goers, experienced the wrath of
Sydney police.

It was horrific to witness the brutality of police toward ravers at this
community event held at Sydney Park, and I urge those who attended
to document the event, make official complaints and call for
an inquiry.

Reminiscent of the riots one hears and reads about..in connection
with the Criminal Justice Act, in England..Sydney Park has by default
become a "terrain of terror" for party goers and what is inevitably to
become an embarrassing blot for police records and accountability.

And be accountable they should be!

With well over 40 cops in attendance; 18 police cars, paddy wagons and
a contingency of police rescue, the situation escalated well out - of -
control and lasted for approx 45 minutes.

Many of the 300 ravers who attended the party were either intimidated,
arrested, muzzled, beaten and restrained for refusing to turn off the
music and allow police access to the generator.

To try and close the party and impound the cleverly hidden and buried
generator, (which allowed the dj's to defiantly play on)..the police
arrived for a showdown and what can only be best described as looking
for trouble.

Frustrated by their inability to locate the power source and unsuccessfully
arrest leaders and party organisers the police lost it, and lost it
completely.

Being more stoopid than brave, I tried to find out exactly who was in
charge of the cops. Like a Monty Python skit and thinking themselves
rather funny..more than 12 cops turned to me and synchronistically said
"WE ALL ARE"! A kind of honest joke, anarchist and rave organisers often
say that no one single person is in charge, everyone is and its true..

"Ha Ha Ha Ha Anarchist cops" someone said.

With smugness and truncheons on their side, the cops continued to make
smart arse remarks about The Young Ones and ape the crowd.

I didn't find it amusing, nor do I ever find it acceptable that cops
somehow always believe they are above reproach or accountability. Have
you ever noticed at a rave how when dealing with people, cops think
working class feral scum have no brains and can be booted around like a
footie ball.

Standing in scrum like fashion for at least an hour before deciding to
"attack" not one police person as far as I witnessed tried to be
reasonable or indeed communicate why on earth the party should be closed
down. Why public assembly with relatively hard core techno beats with not
a residential house in sight for miles is so threatening to societal
stability is anyone's guess.

With toffy nosed middle class muscle I said.."well thats not acceptable
who's in charge"..The senior officer then sheepishly stepped forward
& not introducing himself said "I am".

"Well, its completely out of control", I said. "People have every right
to gather in a public space and you are not only causing trouble,
you're escalating it"!  "And btw, (empowered by the moral agency of being
right)..I continued, why don't your officers have their badges on, whats
going on that no one is prepared to identify themselves!"

With shouts of support and ravers wanting to know if tax payers (including
our own tax $) were indulging this "park de theatre" and picking up the
tab for the night's fiasco; the officer in charge agreed that under the
circumstances yes things had gotten a bit "out of hand"..

"If you know who is organising the party and what time it will finish
perhaps I can do something" he said. "Well you better do something
quickly (I said) you've got officers beating up on people and I just
witnessed a woman who was about to get her skulled cracked for protecting
a friend, I doubt this is the sort of publicity you want and its not
doing much for police public relations is it."  "Hell its a party in a
park not a war"..

With that he turned and walked away to discuss the situation with some
plain clothes dudes who all similarly had stunned mullet expressions and
mobile phones.

At this stage I was thrown aside so more ravers could be loaded in the
back of paddy wagons and with shouts from inside of "anyone remember
Nuremberg" I felt anxious about my friends having to spend the night in
jail and having to succumb to the intimidatory tactics of a seemingly
inhuman group of people bent on asserting the one true goal of a
totalitarian state *power*!..

Ravers need to educate themselves about their rights, we need to know
and exercise our legal rights in order that the police do not exceed
theirs.

Footnote..

A lot of the ravers were released from the paddy wagons before they
arrived at Newtown police station. In defiance some people played music
on acoustic instruments and stayed behind in the park, public land, to
exercise their rights. The generator was finally discovered and impounded
and the chai tea flowed on til dawn.

from Christopher Mountford <cjmount@extro.ucc.su.OZ.AU>
-------------------------------------------------------

                Police Crash Party and Smash Heads.


Marrickville and Newtown police stations emptied themselves last night,
Saturday 8th April 1995, and 40 police complete with attack dogs,
Police_Rescue vans (obviously the'd been watching too much TV ;-) and
eager truncheons crashed a beautiful Vibe Tribe party in Sydney park. The
site of the old brickworks looked apocalyptic, hung with luminescent
mandalas and ultra-violet tubes, the ominous old smoke stacks flashed with
light against a night sky ripped with deep velvet-blue and pearl clouds,
backlit with a silver moon. The fabric of the sky looked dipped in gold
dust as people coalesced for the good vibe. "The music was new black
polished chrome, and came over the summer like liquid night...".
Firedancers entranced us, the rhythms resonated with something deep,
people wailed with delight. And after several failed attempts to shut
down the sound, the cops truncheoned their way in to the heated core of
dance, ripping out the two generators powering the music. Suddenly the
whole thing came a lot closer to apocalypse. Music equipment was pulled
from the tables onto the ground and to my knowledge to attempt  was made
by the police to explain their actions or give reason for the attack.

Obviously with police who do not only fail to question their individual
actions, who substitute a personal grasp of right and wrong for the
robotic programming of an attack dog, it is futile to even attempt to
communicate. But to those cops whom I told "tonight you are doing the wrong
thing", nothing but barked abuse and baton-butts came in reply. I would
have expected a little more at a party. What was this? The only thing I can
think that could be construed as a problem would be the noise level, and
even that idea was ridiculous given that in the courtyard of the brickworks,
surrounded by walls and a huge hill, and situated right next door to an
industrial complex, and not to mention the absolute absence of all
reference to residential complaints (if there had been any  residents
near enough to complain), this didn't seem to be the issue.

Indeed it is not the issue. The police were subjected to utter ridicule
from the moment they arrived, they were informed quite accurately of
their anal-retentive incapacities and sarcastically congratulated for
fucking up an otherwise harmless and primal celebration. They did not all
wear their identity badges (surprise surprise) and I saw them drag a
number of party-goers out by the throat into the waiting paddy-wagons
which were stacked across the footpath, looking like a car lot. It's no
wonder when faced by such bitter opposition, and an opposition who so
easily laid plain the utter stupidity of their jobs and lives, the cops
acted in violence out of sheer frustration at the intense freedom
lived and danced by everyone else who was there. The sad thing is that
our society, that's us, pays for these people to be fucked up to the
stage where they can't negotiate, can't communicate and can't accomplish
any meaningful thing without resorting to force and violence.

This police fuck-up will count as a large black mark against the image
of the police, their perceived ability to act like human beings and to in
some way justify their number and power. It is a sad, sad fact that in Sydney
Australia, people cannot gather in a public park to play music and dance
without being pounced upon by the cops. It's also sad that 40 fully
paid, trained, armed and uniformed police and their dogs and vehicles have
nothing better to do than to spend hours on saturday night jostling with
free and happy people to stop them acting on their natural inclination to
have a party.

I'm not going to presume to suggest anything for anyone else to think or
do about this. Do whatever you want, I will. I'll only say this:

Nothing changes by itself.

------------------------------------------------------------------------
Chris Mountford
________________________________________________________________________

From: ascend@ix.netcom.com (Gregory Sandler)
Subject: I NEED RECORDS

Hello you wonderful sfravers,

Dear All;

	First a tone statement for clarities sake. I'm just really upset
with what's been going on, and what still is, The trigger, is the most
recent unwarrented attack on my person. This post should not be read as a
flame, my sarcassum is an expression of my frustration with feeling
helpless, and is not meant as a personal attack against anyone mentioned in
this letter. We all have our point, tonight I just reached mine, as others 
have as well, and posted how they felt, this is the most healthy thing I 
know I can do, it happened in this forum with people here, so here it 
must be addressed. If these responses had not been made public, and 
someone had not infered publically that I was discrimating against men on 
the list, this post wouldn't be in your mailbox right now. If you need to 
respond, please do it privately, your feeling and thoughts are always 
welcome.

	I wasn't drawing gender conclusions or stating facts, just my
observations/experience, a place I usually speak from, thats all!!!!. As
far as not directly including the wonderful, loving, soft, men on this
list in my statement, please look up the word "some"  in a dictionary, it
means; 1) certain, but unspecified; 2) of indefinite quantity; 3) about;
-pron. indefinite quantity -adv. 1) approximate; 2) [Col.] somewhat; 3)
[Col.] to a great extent -some suf. tending to be. In other words not all,
not all men, SOME, sheezze!!!!!! & sorry. 

	Please do not read more into my posts that is displayed on the
screen in front of you, I have no trouble saying what I think and feel,
and believe me I will communicate it to you with the speed of a USR 14.4 Fax
Modem. I callem like I see em, thats all. If we men don't call each other
on our own shit, theres no hope for any us. Men need to confront men on
these issues, a womyn's voice though always helpful & welcome is not
enough, with reference to "men's issues/shit". Kathryn as a feminist,
which I'm sure you are, I know you have to agree with me on at least this. 

	As far as most of the men on this list, and here in the bay area,
I find them to be much more emotionally intouch, communicative, and into
non-violent non-hurtful conflict resolution than other places I've lived
in this country, again, just my personal observation/experience. I met 
some of the most fantastic father and father fiqures here, men dedicated 
to being against, and unlike the status quo patriarchacal society. So please 
to not infer that I hate or don't like men, or discrimate against them. 
If you felt like I was doing that, I would have liked it if you would have 
privately asked me to clarify. 

	What happened on this list, and what's still happening is nothing
more than a fest of personified male testosterone, that sickenly reminds
of Junior High School, again just MY observation. I'm sick of the personal
attacks, especially unwarrented ones, against me. I may also point out
Kathyrn & Lyle, your not the one being attacked, but to clarify, your
comments, thoughts and feeling are always sincerely welcome, in my box.

in others, and just hurt!!

building, 450 golden gate.  i urge everyone who is able to attend.

and needs our support.

lest some who are following this thread think we're merely talking about
some kind of cyclical renaissance thing I'd like to wipe that one off the
board. I've realised for some time now that it's not a cyclical thing. 
it's not even a spiral, which I thought for a decade and a half. these
social waves are in fact fractals.  by that I mean that not only do they
get bigger each time, with similarities inside (a dance craze, a new
positive attitude etc), but the nature of a fractal is that it goes on
growing and growing until suddenly it falls under the influence of what's
called in Chaos Sience a "Strange Attractor" (wrongly named IMHO) WHICH
FINALLY PULLS IT INTO A NEW ORDER ALLTOGETHER. 
in other words these "ante-raising" soial movements are not different 
things.  they're the same thing approaching critical mass.
nor is time something "that goes on and on like bread that you can cut 
anywhere" as McKenna puts it.  Time heads to a point where it moves into 
its next evolutionary dimension.
now you can argue that we can't prove it will happen this time.  but I 
say: if it's not this time it won't be ever.  because, if a wave doen't 
reach critical mass it falls back alltogether.  which admirably sums up 
our position today.  IT HAS TO BE THIS TIME.
fraser

Hello,

Over the past year, the house music around here (up North near Oregon) has
gotten significantly better/ more advanced.  It used to be strictly happy
house discoey divas, lots of vocals. However, at the most recent party there
were few vocals, lots of aceeed and tribal rhythms.  Still mostly 120-125
bpm.
 Unfortunately most of the best stuff had very cryptic labels (I'm dreaming
of a "scratchable" CD turntable with an LCD screen with artist and track
names :-) ), but a few tracks that I did notice were:

The Love Tribe - Together   (this did have some vocals)
Marco Polo - A Prayer to the Music  ( I like that name )
Speedy J - [label said "7" but that might be the label name - anyone know?]

Anyone familiar with any of the above?   Are these ancient history in S.F.? 
Cheese Wiz? :-)

Ken
ken@macshasta.com
send bounces to ken.stuart@tigerteam.org

 Well , I just bought my first Jungle mix tape today at Ameba. It's by a 
DJ Ocean - the insert graphic is a bunch of gigantic chrome orbs floating
over the ocean. I really like it! They had another Jungle tape that I
didn't like so much , as there was a lot of Jamacian "toasting" on it,
which I'm not much of a fan of. So far , as I'm listening to it, the
DJ Ocean tape keeps the "toasting" to a minimum - much more cool instrumental
stuff in crazy syncopation. 

 This style of music may be the final trigger to get me to update my 
pathetic car stereo system to something that actually has clean(er)
bass below 100HZ. The deep bass is "sane" enough to move your feet 
to , while the crazy syncopation of the midrange/treble tweaks the 
arms and the brain. I can't imagine dancing to this stuff without
the support of a dancable bass pattern.

 I hope more DJs incorporate Jungle into the music played in the main dance
rooms at raves , instead of keeping it seperate or absent.   

 Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

Yeah! verily! A quite good fish, rot rot rot!
A pink tutu and a fishy-a naughty one, rot rot rot- lemme tell you, I had
so much fun with myself at Vision that I can't say it all, but my lesson
was watching "the cool" be they the older, euro-cool or the 18
yr.snowboarder studs, those who had attitude were severely disturbed by the
fish. Smack it, I say! It's been a naughty little one, rot rot rot! The
rest seemed to -er- handle it well. Or smack it. Some wanted to kiss it,
but it's been SOOOO naughty! Ahh! Smack it!

A marine saw it, and "fished" for it in my tutu, and exclaimed "I'm gonna
quit the marines an' go to college!" I'm a role model! Or, at
Sushi-a-go-go, I'm a Roll model! Yuk yuk, smack it, bow to my lodcodd! It's
been bad, I tell you, whack 'em again! Rot rot rot!

Which proves that if you don't take yerself seriously, you can STILL have a
good time, since the poses and wrinkled brows don't take yer time up, and
there's no need for wasting energy with social status fears. I preferred
the peakers, shamelessly gone, exclaiming" I must think good thoughts!
You're so special! Let's go meet people!"
   Ah, imagine the CIA's despair when they tested this shit on soldiers in
some fox-hole in Georgia: 2 hours later, the sarge returns and the
test-subject privates are in a massage train, shirtless, rolling "hey
sarge, climb on in. You know guys, Sarge really yells at us, but it's cause
he wants us to be good soldiers, man, you really look out for us. Want some
water sarge?" 

I met a record number of military personell, all wanting out. Now I
understand how free thinking pisses off THE MAN.  If ennough people really
feel this, experience the opened doors, whew! We might all have to get
along. Hmm...

But not to thinik this makes a perfect world. At the same party of peace,
jealous friends became miffed when I entered their circle an made friends
with some of them, "well, now our circle is larger! I must make more
firends now, learn new names, relate to more people and consider their
emotions! Oh, the humanity! Stay away from him!" Oh, pish! 

Well, maybe our family has some bickering memebers, not all doors that open
go outdoors, some just go into the loo of the soul. You pick your doors,
folks!

To all those who have made it outside, thanks for the warmth! Let's try an'
leave the doors open open for the rest, they might just come out for a
cig...:)

Lotsa love,
   Milton and the E-Bee....
                        "we're thru being cool"-DEVO

>From the LA times:
       (The following text was smile-captioned for the humor-impaired :)
  Ernie, the popular sessame st. heart-throb, was reported missing from
Santa Cruz, Ca., after a nite of drug-laden hedonism in an all-nite
dance-orgy popularly referred to as a "rave" by those in the know.
  Wearing his  striped shirt of fame, Ernie dispelled beliefs of his
alleged affair with roomie Bert, through excessive womanizing and  intake
of record amounts of the notorious rave drug, "Ecstacy", leading him into
convulsions that resulted in organizer Greg Sandler having to restrain the
celebrity, tying him to the balcony, shortly before his dissaperance.
  Members of the international terrorist group "Sendero Depressoso" claimed
to have Ernie as their hostage, but the rave "scene", a comune of social
miscreants, has yet to reveal what demands they must meet to have Ernie
returned. A freshly severed ear was found in the mail of one reveler,
Milton, but it has yet to be determined if it truly pertains to the Sesame
st. resident. The E-Bee declined any statements as to the case, but Milton
was interviewed at Vision. The exclusive follows:
  LAT: Milton, when did you find Ernie's ear?
  M: "wow, can I touch that microphone?"
  LAT: Yes,uhm, when did you-
  M:"It's so round! Mark, come touch this! It records sound!Cool, no?"
  LAT: Are you conserned for the safety of Ernie?
  M: "Hmm? Did you see Ernie?"
  LAT: Yes, he was kidnapped last-
  M: "Do you know Ernie? He's real cool.."
  LAT: Have you been snacking!?
  M: "WoW! Is that Tony? Wait here, man"

  Obviously, Milton was severely affected by the shock of finding Ernie's
ear. Jason and Matt of Harmony fronted a crack team of experts, searching
undercover at Vision to find Ernie. After 10 packs of stickers and several
handfulls of gummy worms, their mounting frustration led to desperation,
and Matt got lost in the stalls.
  Members of the Rave Commune have felt that alleged human Captain Yalon of
the SFPD has been less than helpfull at tracking Ernie's captors. He
refused to comment, but at a news conference last week only stated that
"our forensics team believes it may be the ear of a previous victim, Ernie
may simply be missing. He has a history of wandering under a haze of
narcotics."
  Ernie's manager and co-workers claim this unfair and  untrue. "Ernie has
been clean for six months now. He's turned around, man. He wouldn't do
something like this. It's clear the Captain has a hidden agenda, and we
fear that Ernie's witnessing the New Year's bust may have something to do
with it, since Ernie was there, in drag." Bert refused to elaborate,
stating he was at DV8, after Milton refused to lend him a dress for New
Year's.
 The Whining Path still claims responsibility for the kidnapping, and plans
to release pictures of a living-but considerably shaken-Ernie later this
week. This will include a letter by Ernie, asking for cooperation and
asking his friends and fans to stay calm.
  Ethan Miller, club icon and bon vivant, is said to be organizing a
benefit for Ernie, to be televised live world-wide, direct from Richmond
Civic Center, featuring Tracy Lords, Boy George and Wanda Dee. Jeno is
reputed to be booked, although some say that it is actually Christophe with
a baseball hat.
  In the search for Ernie, many hearts stand to be broken. America waits in
tension and fear, shocked that one so loved could be involved in such deep
doo-doo. 

 by P.Ress Van Quished  and Hess Teria, local office, LA Times; David Did,
and Twist N. Shout, SF office.


 News is news, make of it what you will.

Fellow sfravers,

Just got an urge to express myself somewhat as thoughts of dancing 
entered my mind.  Still basking in some afterglow after much dancing this 
weekend, and noticing that I'm still very much dancing, as I'm sitting here.

Looking up dancing in the dictionary, one of the definitions says;
rhythmic movement, usually to music.

When not to music, what are we dancing to?
Is there rhythm in silence?

I can feel it, the life beat, pulsing through my body, vibrating all 
around me.

beat: a habitual route

The continued sence of beingness, ever changing and remaining the same.

Thoughts, feelings, sensations all part of the beat.
 
We may change and grow, but our sence of beingness continues.  That sence 
is something we all share, and as we share it we dance.


peter

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Apr 10 13:56:53 1995
