From: Brian Darkness <brianvan@liberty.liberty.com>
Subject: Re: Bass Test/Sampling (Very Technical, Not for the average reader)
To: Larry Ching <larryc@netcom.com>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com, Sami Khoury <red@hyperreal.com>
In-Reply-To: <199504100209.TAA11859@netcom4.netcom.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9504101151.C29508-0100000@liberty.liberty.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Dear Larry;

	Just a minor note, being a Test Engineer amonst other things, and 
having done a lot of accoustical/vibrational testing, the ideal perfect 
human ear has a frequency range of 20Hz to 20KHz, frequencies above and 
below that cannot be heard by most people, less the exception of the rare 
musician ,, but I feel put to the acid test, even they couldn't hear 
above or below the accepted range, this due to the amount of noise 
pollution out there that damages and derates that frequency range, plus 
ageing. I'm told the average human is limited to about 60HZ to about 
16Khz, being liberal..

	Another note FM radio is only limited to I think, I don't have my 
FCC stuff handy 50Hz to about 15Khz, I'm more sure of the upper frequency 
limit than the lower one. This is due to the nature of FM(Frequency 
Modulation), where the carrier frquency(the one you tune to on the dial) 
is modulated by the audio frequency. Frequencies above 15Khz are blocked 
to due bandwidth restrictions, FCC politics & outdated believe systems, 
about keeping acient equipment still able to receive signals. Frequecies 
above 15Khz create unwanted harmonics which cause distortion of stations 
close to the one doing the broadcast.

	Of course when dealing with humans, these are only guild lines,
and unless you have a calibrated & traceable to NIST or other accepted
calibration frequency measurement source, you don't know what you have for
sure. Devices that can be rented and are accepted for doing this type of
measurement, by the measurement science community are Hewlett Packard 3562
or 3582 Dynamic Signal Analyser, or a Bruel Kajer Real Time Dynamic Signal
Analyser, these devices are only good from DC(0Hz though the audio range
plus I think 100khz). Hewlett Packard has some minor problem will their
power supply, you usually see the 60Hz AC line spike on the screen, but
this usually can be taken care of by either creating or finding a proper
ground, which can be an ordeal in itself. Anyway good luck. 

	Opps almost forgot, as far as virtual PC based instruments, most 
are not real time, or only limited to a very small bandwidth that is real 
time, or sampling rate. To get a true real time, with a usuable bandwidth 
you must get a UNix Based machine. Another note, in the test engineering 
biz if I was digitally measuring a signal say 20Khz, the recommended 
sampling rate for the signal was usually 10x that. So the sampling 
frequency was at 200Khz. 

	I'm very curious that the max audio sampling rate is only 44kHz, I
think this is a compromise based on storage capicity and the cost of
faster devices, and the limits of the human ear. Because it you sample a
signal which is 20Khz say, and you sampling at a rate 200,000 samples per
second or 200Khz, and your sample takes 2 bytes say, this means you taking
data at the rate of 400kbytes a second, just for the frequency
20,000.000hz absolute, and does not include the frequency 19,999.999hz
absolute...etc, which when you do the math is a lot of fuckin data, for
example the average 3 minute song, with a resolution of 1 hz, with a
sample rate of say 50khz, and say 2 bytes per sample, would lay data down
at a rate of 1,998 MegaBytes per second x 60sec * 3(for 3 minute song),
approximately.  Though I told you can define a true sign wave with just 3
data point which is true, but in FM sythn audio you rarely deal with a
pure sign wave, but a rather extremely complex waveform. I would recommend
an intelligent sampling algorythm which sampled at a rate high enough for
each frequency range appropreiate enough to give you the desired
resolution, while maximize storage capacity. When I was doing this type of
work, we used 1 Giga Byte Plasom Optical Cartrige Read Write Drives, it
was really cool work.

From: megatrip@best.com (David Dei)

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I while ago, an audiofile friend of mine gave me a demonstration of the
difference between digital and analog sound.
Playing the same versions of a jazz solo tune, he proved to me that the
analog version has more notes than the digital. What happened was the
sampling rate of digital effectively cut out the highrange, and gave an
aproximation of the inbetween notes. Looking at a sound graph, the digital
showed up as a series of steps, while the harp note on analog showed up as
a continuous oscillation.

A while later, while in an altered and relaxed state, I experienced a
heightened hearing, and found myself listening to the gaps in my cd.
Literally, if you increase your natural hearing by a slight degree (not
uncommon in an altered state) , you can experience the loss of resolution
in digital, or you can mimic this by slowing down the cd itself ( to mimic
the speeding up of your personal sampling rate of reality).

Another thing I've noticed is that some soundsystems at raves, especially
those using digital equipment, often seem to end up with an out of phase
sound. The bpms bouncing off the walls and cancelling out highrange, so
that you lose any semblence of tune, and get  a dull thud thud of negative
aural space that I find exceptionally distressing. I would love to hear any
opinions on this, have others exerienced this?

I have often thought that perhaps DJ's need to include some kind of pilot
light or pilot sound like anything that's not just an on-off or a beat, for
example  wind instrumentation, so as to keep them in tune with reality and
not out of  phase with their audience.

- david dei

At 12:50 PM 10/4/95 -48000, Brian Darkness wrote:
>Dear Larry;
>
>        Just a minor note, being a Test Engineer amonst other things, and
>having done a lot of accoustical/vibrational testing, the ideal perfect
>human ear has a frequency range of 20Hz to 20KHz, frequencies above and
>below that cannot be heard by most people, less the exception of the rare
>musician ,, but I feel put to the acid test, even they couldn't hear
>above or below the accepted range, this due to the amount of noise
>pollution out there that damages and derates that frequency range, plus
>ageing. I'm told the average human is limited to about 60HZ to about
>16Khz, being liberal..
>
>        Another note FM radio is only limited to I think, I don't have my
>FCC stuff handy 50Hz to about 15Khz, I'm more sure of the upper frequency
>limit than the lower one. This is due to the nature of FM(Frequency
>Modulation), where the carrier frquency(the one you tune to on the dial)
>is modulated by the audio frequency. Frequencies above 15Khz are blocked
>to due bandwidth restrictions, FCC politics & outdated believe systems,
>about keeping acient equipment still able to receive signals. Frequecies
>above 15Khz create unwanted harmonics which cause distortion of stations
>close to the one doing the broadcast.
>
>        Of course when dealing with humans, these are only guild lines,
>and unless you have a calibrated & traceable to NIST or other accepted
>calibration frequency measurement source, you don't know what you have for
>sure. Devices that can be rented and are accepted for doing this type of
>measurement, by the measurement science community are Hewlett Packard 3562
>or 3582 Dynamic Signal Analyser, or a Bruel Kajer Real Time Dynamic Signal
>Analyser, these devices are only good from DC(0Hz though the audio range
>plus I think 100khz). Hewlett Packard has some minor problem will their
>power supply, you usually see the 60Hz AC line spike on the screen, but
>this usually can be taken care of by either creating or finding a proper
>ground, which can be an ordeal in itself. Anyway good luck.
>
>        Opps almost forgot, as far as virtual PC based instruments, most
>are not real time, or only limited to a very small bandwidth that is real
>time, or sampling rate. To get a true real time, with a usuable bandwidth
>you must get a UNix Based machine. Another note, in the test engineering
>biz if I was digitally measuring a signal say 20Khz, the recommended
>sampling rate for the signal was usually 10x that. So the sampling
>frequency was at 200Khz.
>
>        I'm very curious that the max audio sampling rate is only 44kHz, I
>think this is a compromise based on storage capicity and the cost of
>faster devices, and the limits of the human ear. Because it you sample a
>signal which is 20Khz say, and you sampling at a rate 200,000 samples per
>second or 200Khz, and your sample takes 2 bytes say, this means you taking
>data at the rate of 400kbytes a second, just for the frequency
>20,000.000hz absolute, and does not include the frequency 19,999.999hz
>absolute...etc, which when you do the math is a lot of fuckin data, for
>example the average 3 minute song, with a resolution of 1 hz, with a
>sample rate of say 50khz, and say 2 bytes per sample, would lay data down
>at a rate of 1,998 MegaBytes per second x 60sec * 3(for 3 minute song),
>approximately.  Though I told you can define a true sign wave with just 3
>data point which is true, but in FM sythn audio you rarely deal with a
>pure sign wave, but a rather extremely complex waveform. I would recommend
>an intelligent sampling algorythm which sampled at a rate high enough for
>each frequency range appropreiate enough to give you the desired
>resolution, while maximize storage capacity. When I was doing this type of
>work, we used 1 Giga Byte Plasom Optical Cartrige Read Write Drives, it
>was really cool work.

iiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiii

Dear All;

	Yes, our bodies are under the influence of many different rythms, and 
harmonics of those rythms. Some are very quick, while others are slow over 
the period of days and weeks, for example:

	Cerebral Spinal Fuild cirrulates at the rate of 6 - 8 bpm, which 
	causes you skull to actually flex/extent at the same rate. If you
	have a partner and you get very still & quiet, you can actually
	feel this by gentley holding the head, its really cool, and I've
	felt it on clients.  Its more noticeable on children because the
	joints in their skulls haven't calcified yet. 

	Pulse rate for adult men at rest is about 70 - 72 bpm, while 
	womyn are at a rate of 78 - 82 bpm

	Cirrculation rate is about 2 - 3 bpm

	Heart Rate is about 72 bpm

	Menstrual Cycle 27 - 28, but can vary as much as 18 - 40 days

	Respiration rate is 15 - 20 cycles or bpm

	Stomach during digestion shakes at a rate of 60 bpm

Acturate Additions Welcomed:

Subject: Re: Bass Test/Sampling (Very Technical, Not for the average reader)
In-Reply-To: <199504102209.PAA07362@shell1.best.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.91.950410154748.8522C-100000@taz.hyperreal.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

On Mon, 10 Apr 1995, David Dei wrote:
> I while ago, an audiofile friend of mine gave me a demonstration of the
> difference between digital and analog sound.
> Playing the same versions of a jazz solo tune, he proved to me that the
> analog version has more notes than the digital. What happened was the
> sampling rate of digital effectively cut out the highrange, and gave an
> aproximation of the inbetween notes. Looking at a sound graph, the digital
> showed up as a series of steps, while the harp note on analog showed up as
> a continuous oscillation.

All digital representations of this kind of information is based on the 
concept that there is actually such a thing as "good enough".  CD's 
sample at 44.1 Khtz, which the Nyquist theorem tells us can represent 
frequencies up to 22khtz.  Usual human hearing drops out at around 
12-15Khtz, while dogs and other animals can routinely hear up to 20 or 
higher.  The argument that "those high frequencies produce resonance
that shows up in lower frequencies" is hot air as the recording equipment 
would have capture those resonances in the lower frequencies while 
recording.  

Now, you talk about "an approximation of in between notes" which is 
something different - that has primarily to do with the bit depth of the 
sample.  CD's sample at 16 bits, which means they can represent 2^16 or 
65536 different levels of amplitude of the wave.  You would have to be 
able to distinguish between those levels of amplitude in a *single* 
sample (1/44 millionth of a second) in order to claim you could hear a 
frequency that CD technology could not represent.  

> A while later, while in an altered and relaxed state, I experienced a
> heightened hearing, and found myself listening to the gaps in my cd.
> Literally, if you increase your natural hearing by a slight degree (not
> uncommon in an altered state) , you can experience the loss of resolution
> in digital, or you can mimic this by slowing down the cd itself ( to mimic
> the speeding up of your personal sampling rate of reality).

Also not uncommon in an altered state is the ability to have your 
perception of reality altered by your conscious expectations of what that 
reality should be like.  Psychoactives can *not* increase the frequency 
response of your eardrums (though they can help you hear things in a new 
light).

> Another thing I've noticed is that some soundsystems at raves, especially
> those using digital equipment, often seem to end up with an out of phase
> sound. The bpms bouncing off the walls and cancelling out highrange, so
> that you lose any semblence of tune, and get  a dull thud thud of negative
> aural space that I find exceptionally distressing. I would love to hear any
> opinions on this, have others exerienced this?

There isn't any correlation between bad sound systems and digital 
equipment that I've ever seen.  It has everything to do with knowing the 
accoustics of the room and balancing (and not overdriving) the right 
parts of the system.  Ethan could probably speak tomes about this.
 
But I'm not a sound engineer nor physicist so believe what you will.

	Brian

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Apr 10 16:42:07 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id QAA13732; Mon, 10 Apr 1995 16:42:07 -0700
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id QAA13717; Mon, 10 Apr 1995 16:42:03 -0700
Date: Mon, 10 Apr 1995 16:42:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: Sami Khoury <red@hyperreal.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Bass Test/Sampling (Very Technical, Not for the average reader)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.3.89.9504101539.F928-0100000@liberty.liberty.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.91.950410162407.10459B-100000@taz.hyperreal.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> 	Opps forgot, I was wondering that if you have say a signal say at 
> 21Khz, and its of enough magnitude that in will produce harmonics up and 
> down the audio spectrum, that could be picked up by the audion equipment 
> and be heard as noise. Just wondering?
> 
> 	Good comments Brian and David. I'll also like to hear from Sami 
> as well, I thing he would have a lot to say about this subject.

Actually, I was trying to figure out why all this has been cc'd to me in 
the first place :)  But I think I can make a brief comment or two.

In answer to your your question, you could probably induce some sub 
harmonics, but I doubt they would sound like noise.  This is *not* like 
undersampling where frequencies below that of the sampled sound are 
generated because the sampling rate is too low.  These "sub harmonics" 
sound like complete crap when played with the original sound.

With regard to what David said about being able to see the interpolated 
steps of the digital waveform, keep in mind that each step you see 
represents 1/44,100th of a second (meaning you have to zoom the scope 
like crazy before it is visible).  So while true that the signal is an 
approximation, its tolerance is far higher than your perception (which is 
the whole point).  And before we get into an analogue/digital debate, 
keep in mind all of the elements between the source material and the 
speakers and how each of these has an effect, in some form or another, on 
the final output.

	Sami


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Apr 10 17:11:14 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id RAA15926; Mon, 10 Apr 1995 17:11:14 -0700

Dear All;

	Also with regard to Nyquist, I image this therory applies to
sinosodial waveforms(please correct me if I'm wrong due to my
non-familiarity with this therory, but most therories are applied to and
for sinosodial waveforms), and should be derated for non-sin/complex
waveforms. 

	Meaning that if Nyquist saids that you can sample a frequency of
interest up to 22kHz, that the highest frequency samplable for a
non-sin/complex waveform would be lower, how much depends on the waveform
and how complex it is, being sampled, I doubt whether the bandwidth would
be decreased by as much as 5Khz - 7Khz, more like 2KHz - 3 Khz. 

	Also, when sampling data for scientific purposes, measuring
unknown signals, I will say it is necessary to sample at a much higher
rate, it just seems that 2x is a little on the low side. But i image as
the $/mega byte of media drops, and faster and faster devices become
cheaper and cheaper, we will see whether or not there is a noticable
difference in what we hear. 

	I wonder with regard to most samplers whether there just doing a
straight sampling at whatever rate, or using it intelligently like I
mentioned earlier. For example if your sampling at 44Khz and your at the
low end, and apply the Nyquist therory/assumtions, your wasting resources,
by sampling to much. At 20Hz with a sampling rate of 44Khz your sampling
at 2200x your frequency of interest. An intelligent algorthym which either
allowed you to set the resolution, or set bands of resolution/s-rate, say
set the sampling rate for 20-200Hz at 400hz, 201-2000hz at 4000hz ...etc
would be a much better use a resources and would proablly net you a higher
overall bandwidth. Of course this adds to the complexity of the hardware
and cost of the device, but lowers the requirements for memory/media which
are also expensive. 

On Mon, 10 Apr 1995, Brian Behlendorf wrote:

> concept that there is actually such a thing as "good enough".  CD's 
> sample at 44.1 Khtz, which the Nyquist theorem tells us can represent 
> frequencies up to 22khtz.  Usual human hearing drops out at around 
> 12-15Khtz, while dogs and other animals can routinely hear up to 20 or 
> higher.  The argument that "those high frequencies produce resonance
> that shows up in lower frequencies" is hot air as the recording equipment 
> would have capture those resonances in the lower frequencies while 
> recording.  

Peace & Love
Brian Darkness

> All digital representations of this kind of information is based on the 
> concept that there is actually such a thing as "good enough".  CD's 
> sample at 44.1 Khtz, which the Nyquist theorem tells us can represent 
> frequencies up to 22khtz.

        I have a question about Nyquist which perhaps someone on the list
can answer.  So its a little off topic, but it's not flamage anyway...
And maybe the discussion will clear up a few other people's mystery
about digital sound.

        The idea of Nyquist, if I understand correctly, is that it captures
enough of the signal that a low-pass filter will get the original back.  To
illustrate, draw a couple cycles of sine wave (in your head if you like).  Put
dots at 90, 270, 450, etc degrees...  ie on the peaks.  Connect the dots,
and you have a triangle wave which if low-pass-filtered will look a lot like
the original sine wave.

        But what if the signal phase is moved 90 degrees with respect to the
sampling clock?  Now the dots are at 180, 360, 540, etc....  on the axis!
Connect the dots and you have a "flatline"...  silence.

        OK, now say you have a signal that is, say, 100 Hz less than 1/2
the sampling rate.  The phase will constantly be changing...  flatline to
triangle and back...  at a rate of like 200Hz.  The amplitude of the output
will be varying at this rate...  sort of a moire effect...  Or you could say
you're beating against a harmonic of the sample clock, I guess, sort of.

        Shouldn't this cause problems?  Like a 200Hz buzz (in this case)?

Andrew
-----------------------------------------
Andrew Knutsen            andrewk@sco.com
Santa Cruz Operation      (408) 427-7538

David Dei said...
>I while ago, an audiofile friend of mine gave me a demonstration of the
>difference between digital and analog sound.
>Playing the same versions of a jazz solo tune, he proved to me that the
>analog version has more notes than the digital. What happened was the
	<etc.> 

	The only believable loss of 'information' I've ever been able to
hear with CD quality sound (44.1 KHz, as Brian B. mentioned) involved two
recordings of a Mahler symphony (10, I think, can't remember), which were
presented to me as 'proof' by a fellow music student that 'spacial resolution'
(the ablity to pick out where the instruments are, directionwise relative
to the listener) could be compromised by sampling technology. This was 
definitely the case with these two recordings, but it could have just
been mic choice/placement, the room, etc., since the recordings were done in
different places.

There may be something to this though, since I had a demo of a thing called
a 'convolvatron' one year at Sigraph'90, and the guy, (his name was Scott
Forester I think, with Crystal River Engineering?) said that some inaudible 
frequencies (high end) were important in spacial resolution.

But this doesn't hammer digital, one could just up the sampling rate.

-Dave I. (<- there, now you know which one :) 

BTW: The convolvatron allows one to compose music with cartesian coordinates,
a virtual enclosing space and 'q' (as in how spread out or focused the
apparent source of the sound is).

As Larry mentioned, DJ Ocean has a nice jungle tape AND also shows up to
play at Ameba fairly often (he actually likes to play a much wider
repertoire including Plus-8 type techno :), as well as being a mainstay
at the Il Pirata jungle night each Tuesday.  

I've been "flavoring" my sets with jungle for a couple of months now,
and played a little bit of a new Bukem track at Liquid Air as sort of
a bridge between what Alex was playing and what I wanted to spin.  
I don't have enough tracks to really consider myself a "jungle DJ" --
which involves some different spinning techniques than for house and
techno, generally -- but I'm all for bringing in the interesting jungle
sounds and helping dissolve the musical and other barriers that excessive
labeling has caused in our scene.  

btw, I also highly recommend DJ Gamall's jungle tape (also available at
Ameba); he's also on the list here.

Umm, I'm worried that I seem to have upset some of you all with some of 
media-sympathetic postings... perhaps I should explain myself as best I can.
See, I kind of like to take a topic and twist it around in my hands and to hold
it up to different lights, to see everything in as many ways that I can. That's
why I tried raving, that's why I subscribed to your guys' list, that's why I
tried e a few weeks ago for the first time.  I think it'sdazzling when everyone
comes together and freely exchanges their ideas and we all try to untangle
the knots of our existence in different ways. Now, this may inevitably result
in some disagreement, but disagreement is okay.  Sometimes it's hard to recon-
cile disagreement with the wonderful, loving, and non-confrontational stance of
rave culture.  If I ever sound belligerent it's not because I'm being hostile,
I'm just stirring the pot of stew, and all the while I'm still smiling.
Remember, though, whenever we discuss anything, we should all try to remember
to always attack the argument and not the person making it.  That's all that
matters.  Love to you all and as someone posted recently, you are all precious.
Pacifiers, lollipops, and shoulder massages to you all,
timothy

and vitamin E--valuable antioxidants which can combat the rare situation where
one's body may react negatively to ecstasy.  With 1000% USRDA of betacarotene
and 400% of vitamin E, it's perfect...(and no, I don't moonlight as an Odwalla
salesman, if there are any cynics out there! :) ).  Given the tragic death
of a raver due to heart failure(?) recently, loading up on antioxidants
before you go raving is easy to do, inexpensive, and could possibly save a life,
I imagine. And it needn't even be via Odwalla; you could just as easily take
some vitamin pills. Hope this tip helps, and of course, as you all learned
in kindergarten (at this point all the little ravers sing in unison) "When we
do ecstasy, we always drink lots n' lots of water, even when we're not thirsty!"

Precedence: bulk

Wow, what is going on with these violent actions by police?
It seems to me that rave culture is growing to the point where it is 
sprouting out more and more from the underground.  As this happens, I 
think it is important to somehow communicate and convey more of an 
understanding of the peacefulness and beauty of the raves.

I enjoy the underground scene very much, and hope it continues.  It seems 
that the scene is becoming much larger than an underground scene.  

Unfortunately known attempts of keeping things hidden very often creates 
suspicions, with the idea; if there's nothing wrong with it, why is it 
being hidden.

Also many people fear what they don't understand.  People may associate 
fear with danger, which can cause a fight or flight response.  
Unfortunately this rave in austraila was met with a fight, probably due 
to alot of ignorance.

It seems obvious that education about rave culture is needed.  I know 
this is happening somewhat, but I think it would be really helpful if we 
started thinking more about how to do this.  I'd really like to hear more 
ideas about this.

Things that I've noticed that have been very helpful with educating has 
been the kind of attitude that is conveyed with people who are exposed to 
the scene.  Bryce gave a good example of this with his last interaction with 
the police.  Taking an interest and caring about someone else (respect), 
is more likely to bring that response back.  Be open to others, and they 
will more likely be open to you.

Helping others feel welcome.  I witnessed this at the last sunset party.  
As people walking their dogs asked what was going on, I saw them welcomed 
to come by and see.  The friendly welcome seemed to tranform their 
confusion towards curiosity.  Rather than just walking by, I witnessed some 
staying a while looking like they were enjoying themselves, having the 
opportunity to take in some of the beautiful vibe.

As much as I like the word rave, I think we probably would be better off 
without it in our education process for a while with the above ground.  I 
think our education needs to focus most of all on the events themselves 
more so than words.  Somehow let everyone feel invited.  

How come so many people feel its ok to celebrate the new year.  Is there 
something we can learn from this that might make it more ok for most 
people to celebrate more often.  Is it that the new year is something we 
all can share.  If thats a big part of it, we ravers know that there is 
alot more in our lives than the new year that we ALL can share.

I'd love to hear any ideas, thoughts opinions on this topic.  I really 
don't want to have to hear about violence at raves.


peter

>think it is important to somehow communicate and convey more of an
>understanding of the peacefulness and beauty of the raves.

I am mobilizing the Aussies into contacting an attorney to help
start the ball rolling for a class action lawsuit.   Similar to
what happened in SOMA on NYE.

>Also many people fear what they don't understand.  People may associate
>fear with danger, which can cause a fight or flight response.
>Unfortunately this rave in austraila was met with a fight, probably due
>to alot of ignorance.

Well,  it wasn't really a fight..  The police just charged into the crowd
who were dancing,   and injured one of the DJ's who tried to protect
one of the ravers.

>
>It seems obvious that education about rave culture is needed.  I know
>this is happening somewhat, but I think it would be really helpful if we
>started thinking more about how to do this.  I'd really like to hear more
>ideas about this.

If I can come up with something,  I'll certainly post it to the group.
Thats for sure...
>
>Things that I've noticed that have been very helpful with educating has
>been the kind of attitude that is conveyed with people who are exposed to
>the scene.  Bryce gave a good example of this with his last interaction with
>the police.  Taking an interest and caring about someone else (respect),
>is more likely to bring that response back.  Be open to others, and they
>will more likely be open to you.
>
>Helping others feel welcome.  I witnessed this at the last sunset party.
>As people walking their dogs asked what was going on, I saw them welcomed
>to come by and see.  The friendly welcome seemed to tranform their
>confusion towards curiosity.  Rather than just walking by, I witnessed some
>staying a while looking like they were enjoying themselves, having the
>opportunity to take in some of the beautiful vibe.
>
>As much as I like the word rave, I think we probably would be better off
>without it in our education process for a while with the above ground.  I
>think our education needs to focus most of all on the events themselves
>more so than words.  Somehow let everyone feel invited.

Down here,  they call them parties.
>
>I'd love to hear any ideas, thoughts opinions on this topic.  I really
>don't want to have to hear about violence at raves.

Well,  I suppose I can refrain from posting bad things,  but I thought
it was important that the SF Scene knew that even down here in a very
lax society,  there is police harrassment.

Crunchman

Precedence: bulk

Crunch says:
> Well,  it wasn't really a fight..  The police just charged into the crowd
> who were dancing,   and injured one of the DJ's who tried to protect
> one of the ravers.

In your initial report, you told us:

|they were making an anouncement asking the crowd to not let the police get
|anywhere near the turn tables.  [...]   Finally the cops backed off,  and
|the dancing continued.  It was short lived though,  as the cops were staying
|back to re-group.   This time, they charged into the group of happy dancing
|folks, 

Sounds like a fight to me.  The whole incident may have been peaceful if 
the ravers had initially respected the police's authority.  Instead of
dispersing like a TAZ, we played *their* game, rightly or wrongly.

Peter asks:
> >It seems obvious that education about rave culture is needed.  
> >[...]  I'd really like to hear more
> >ideas about this.

I'm more in favor of keeping our own house in order, eschewing with the
ego laden approach of having to show the world how "right" we are - that
chest-thumping, us vs. them, your-way-is-wrong message.  Or does our 
culture, like all western power structures, require a common enemy to 
unite against?   If so, then we've morally and spiritually sold out.

Our true power will be the positive influence we have on people who  
participate in the ecstatic dance culture, and on our ability to continue
having such parties, peacefully and in harmony with *all* the forces that
make up our world.     

That said, I certainly hope the aboveground party brokers win the legal
battles in which our mainstream-defined rights have been violated.  
Meanwhile, our scene, and more parties, legal and otherwise, continue...


Lee

At  2:44 AM 11/4/95 -0700, Peter Fogel wrote:
>Wow, what is going on with these violent actions by police?
>It seems to me that rave culture is growing to the point where it is
>sprouting out more and more from the underground.  As this happens, I
>think it is important to somehow communicate and convey more of an
>understanding of the peacefulness and beauty of the raves.
>

Dear Sfravers,

The bigger picture is emerging. These are not isolated incidents, but a
trend WORLDWIDE.
In the UNITED KINGDOM where no bill of rights or written consitution
exists, raves have simply been for all intents and purposes outlawed. Rave
Music itself has recieved specific attention and we all know about the CJA
which defines it as "music with a repetative beat". New Years eve in New
York was NO DIFFERENT from that experienced in San Francisco. Heaven got
busted just like Visual Aid. The problem is this - we are all seeing this
as a local problem. WRONG - it is global, it is comming from up high, and
its aim is to STOP any attempt to hold free, popular, uncontrolled, public
meetings of youth.

In the fifties, Rock n Roll was in the same situation. Mass burning of
records and vilification of rock musicians was the order of the day. BUT
aided by PIRATE RADIO, groups like the rolling stones and the beatles
achieved mass acclaim and acceptance until 1968 and the Summer of Love.
When the entire generation broke out in a wave of love, which to everyones
dismay was eventually crushed by police aided by agents provecateurs,
heroin and speed. If we recall our history you will see that this time was
the first that the ENTIRE WORLD SYSTEM seriously came under question. A
populist evolution very nearly succeeded in dethroning the government and
the war generation itself.

As can be expected, the standing orders of the establishment to this day
are to prevent at all costs
outbreaks of LOVE.  Rock n Roll is now a carefully controlled mechanism for
releasing youthful frustration and making a fuck load of money at the same
time (not to mention selling a load of smack). But as the saying goes, you
can control some of the people for some of the time, but you can't control
all the people all the time. Which is precisely why RAVE has emerged as OUR
NEXT BEST HOPE in getting unbridled LOVE out into the streets and proving
us humans worthy of planetary government.

It is clear what our political goals should be:

TO extend the highest rights guaranteed in the US constitution and the
United Nations Declaration on Human rights - for life, liberty and the
pursuit of happiness, to all members of our society, and that includes
ravers, as well as all citizens of this world.

WE MUST NOT LOSE SIGHT of what is painfully clear - the time has come for
democracy to be extended to the highest political structure of this planet
- the UNITED NATIONS.

We can no longer accept the presence of an elite SECURITY COUNCIL of five
nations having a VETO vote over every other nation on this planet, backed
up by atomic weapons.

After 50 YEARS of a post war solution to world governance, the time has
come to open the debate on HOW we are to RUN this planet for the NEXT
FIFTY.

THE PRESENT SYSTEM DOES NOT WORK - We must rid ourselves of territorial and
colonial competition and recognise what the business & and internet
community already knows - nation states have already become redundent.

The foreign exchange markets alone have a bigger per day trade (in excess
of a trillion dollars) than the entire US budget.

IF WE REMAIN SILENT, the emergence of planetary bodies beholden to no one,
is assured.

LIKE THE PHILOSOPHERS of old, we must take the next step in evolution OURSELVES.

Like some great NARRATIVE, the rave community, this small family of
happiness beings, has been shouldered with the responsibility that our
LEADERS have already rejected.

RIGHTFULLY WE CAN DEMAND TO KNOW WHY THERE IS NO POLITICAL STRUCTURE on the
planet today, that has as its ideals, the extension of basic fundemental
human rights to the rest of the planet - rights like the freedom to dance
whenever and wherever the whim takes us.

THEY HAVE LIED TO US:  24 hours after NATO and US Commander-in-Chief Bill
Clinton authorised the invasion of IRAQ by 35 000 Turkish TROOPS two weeks
ago, the story is still NOT ON THE FRONT PAGE!

ONE WEEK after the de facto collapse of all financial control mechanisms
regulating the dollar, the STORY DISAPPEARS. While Foreign newspapers carry
reports like the following:

"There appeared to be little intervention from the US Federal Reserve -
 something traders attributed to limited foreign reserves because of the
 Mexican Bailout. In Tokyo, the Japanese government braced itself for the
 damage from a high yen. Continued intervention by Japan's central bank,
 which was reported to have intervened in bursts buying US Dollars
 totalling a massive $2 billion, did little to alleviate the situation."

"...investors scrambled into so-called safe-haven harder currencies in the
wake of the Mexican
 financial crisis, the collapse of Barings and concerns over the massive US
 trade deficit.  In the past week alone, the dollar has declined more than
 6 percent against the mark, and 9,6 percent since February."

 "Analysts said central banks were powerless to restore stability because
 of the huge sums of money in foreign exchange markets - in excess of $1
 trillion a day."

WHILE IT IS UNCLEAR, just exactly what will happen, what we do know is this
- THE SYSTEM IS OUT OF CONTROL.
COMPUTERISED Trading has taken on a semblence of cellular automata and
Artificial-life has hit the financial markets. Not even the Rocket
Scientists know what will happen next.

BUT NO NEED TO PANIC - alternative models for governing the world have been
discussed (and tested) for decades.
NOW IS THE TIME TO COME FORWARD - it is we - the rave pangeneration - who
have the skills and knowledge to move the crumbling system over to a
non-violent, non-racial, life-affirming community perspective.

IF we make known our goals, SOON WE WILL BE GETTING CALLS from those
presently in power positions who need our help.  But this can only happen
if we COME OUT with our plans and visions.

SUMMER OF LOVE PART ONE 1968 awoke this planet to the possiblity of LOVE

SUMMER OF LOVE - THE NEXT MILLENNIUM is where we get back on track. for the
RE-UNITED NATIONS - GATHERING OF ALL THE TRIBES - ravers, rainbows,
zippies, cyberpunks, indigenous councils, all nations that desire life,
liberty and the pursuit of happiness.

- david dei



iiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiii
                        DAVID DEI   REALITY TECHNICIAN
               megatrip@best.com    reality@megatripolis.org

     website:http://www.megatripolis.org/dave/html
iiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiiii

I wrote to the Gorbachev Foundation and they sent me a packet of their 
activities and objectives etc.  One of the sections contains information 
concerning the STATE OF THE WORLD FORUM.  This will be held in San 
Fransisco September 28 - October 1, 1995.  I thought that I would relay 
some of the info they sent FYI.

I would appreciate your comments.

MD

Why in the world would Maggie be attending this meeting with this 
bunch of socialists?

{She favors world government!  Just a different style of it--James D}

==========================================================================
			STATE OF THE WORLD FORUM
==========================================================================
OBJECTIVE:
----------
As we enter an era of increasing instability, unleashed by the resolution 
of the Cold War, the Forum will facilitate a collective exploration of the 
challenges we face coming into the 21st Century.

A three-day working conference to be held September 28 - October 1, 1995, 
in San Fransisco, the Forum will include: private, interactive 
discussions, and the creation of educational and historically significant 
print, audio, video materials to further inform and empower individuals in 
this critical debate about the future of the human community.

From: nrg@ultima.org (ethan miller)
Subject: Digital Sound....
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

The other thing to remember about digital sound is that ultimately all
sound is analog -- waveforms propagating through space to your ear. What
this means is that even musical information that is *stored* digitally must
undergo a digital -> analog conversion prior to reaching your ears. And in
fact, discounting feature sets (bells and whistles) this -- the 'quality'
of the DAC chip -- is what really distinguishes CD players (DATs etc.) from
one another (or so I'm told...)

Go into an electronics store sometime and make a comparison of CD players;
you'll be amazed at how different they sound. Sony for instance, uses the
same DAC in all their players so it is the features that differentiate
price. Nakamichi and Onkyo on the other hand scale price in relation to
both the DAC and the feature set.

So to me value of a digital source is mainly the lack of media noise, ie.
tape hiss or vinyl static noise. Though uncompressed vinyl with a great
noise gate is pretty damn awesome :)

Another thing to remember about CDs is that *loads* of them are mastered
from analog and often not very well in relation to both elimination of
noise in the master and in the quality and oversight of the analog ->
digital conversion.

As far as sound at parties goes, IMO, the single biggest factor affecting
quality of sound is the *room*, next being placement of the speakers within
the room and in relation to each other, the absolute key being, no matter
what the size (or shape) of the room, make sure the speakers are working
*with* and reinforcing each other.

A while back I created a visual model for this and learned from it that
given a speaker inclination of 45 degrees (which was clearly the best
choice after graphing all angles from 0 - 50), there is a critical distance
from one stack to another which exists in (relatively) direct proportion to
the power of the amp/speaker pair. Thus with speakers at 45 degrees, at w
feet apart, x watts per side will result in y db over z sq feet.

Increasing w with x remaining constant, results in an increase of z at the
expense of y.

Increasing w and x (proportionally) keeps y constant and increases z

Increasing w and x (disproportionally in favor of x) increases both y and z

Etc. Unfortunately, the math is not nearly as straightforward as it might
seem (there's some weird logarithmic transformm hidden somewhere;), and
indeed, is well beyond me...

take it easy
ethan

some bill to criminalize the handling of subversive messages on
communication channels offered for hire.

Wanna operate a car - get a license.
Wanna operate a transmitter - get a license.
Wanna send on the net - get a license.

'scary how close we are.

Some day I'll go to a rave, meanwhile the love and generally respectful
discussion on SFR warms the heart, keeps kindled the soul and fancies the
imagination.

Dave

Brian B. said...
> Actually, Exon is retiring after this year.  He won't even have to face 
> the heat from the fallout over this.
>
> <URL:http://www.phantom.com/~slowdog/>, for more info...

In his press release, he cited "Polarization of the electorate." as one
of his reasons for calling it quits. Guess who was complaining ... :) 

Pressler and Gorton are still alive and kicking though. 

S314 has morphed into an addition to the comprehensive package referred to
as the 1995 Telecom Deregulation Act (among the monikers I've seen).
There's lots of stuff in there, some good, some bad.

As of Friday, it had not reached the floor of the Senate. 
I was on the phone with one of Diane Feinstein's staff last Friday about 
a different amendment to this legislation called the Snowe/Rockefeller 
amendment, which is actually positive. It calls for having telecoms and
net access providers set aside some 'at cost' bandwidth for schools and
libraries.

Talk ta' yer senators! D.F.'s staff is very polite, and I know B.Boxer is
cool 'cause I saw her at an Art Farmer gig!

The main phone number for the Senate is 202/224-3121  It's cool to have
someone pick up the phone and say, "Hello, the Capitol".

Check out rtfm.mit.edu in /pub/usenet/news.answers/us-govt-net-pointers/

If you don't have ftp, email me, and I'll try to figure out how else you
can get this stuff. 

-Dave I.

P.S. Re: the subject line. Ballistic Bros. + Eccentric Afros sample
Gil Scott Heron, d.i. says check it out!

difference between AMERICAN and TURKISH troops is just an apple pie and a
couple of hershey bars. And why not conduct nato military exercises in IRAQ
with live ammo. But I shudder when I  see the possiblity for a broad

in the US.

Dunno, the press called it "black sunday" when British Finance minister
Norman Lamont lost 6 billion pounds of the UK's foreign reserves in a bad
gamble that saw the pound drop by a dollar or two. Here they call it
business as usual when Greenspan does the same thing with the dollar, yep,
last monday. Now dollar has reached all time low against the yen and my
prediction is it will continue to slide.

Thing is if you look at the figures, the DOW and the NYSE, wall street is
Crashing and Booming about 5 times a week in an out of control fractalling.


Now, I'm not trying to stear this forum off topic again, its just that if
we want to understand why the authorities may be clamping down on RAVEs
worldwide, then we just have to look at what situation  those in control,
find themselves in - DESPERATION. And if people are desperate, they are
usually dangerous.

And its not just Rave thats getting shafted as the recent article on HIP
HOP censorship indicates in the SF WEEKLY

And I find it curious that in Berkeley, a predominantly student community,
there are'nt parties on every block on weekends. Its even quiet by
Californian standards.

dm12, 2 slight apologies.  1. I've slashed around a bit in your thoughts
here - it's not because I don't *like* you, it's just the Rob Roy way they
taught me to present the cut and thrust of Fine Argumente. 2.  I've been
"following" some of these "extra system psychology"thoughts for decades
now.  when you first hear them they can easily sound like some adolesent
rebellion stuff, certainly unthought out, and possibly even on the edge of
sanity.  all I can tell you is that, as Arena magazine said recently, my
"reputation as a prophet is actually quite good." so don't expect to 
agree with me, but try not to reject me just because you don't agree 
with me  >:-) 

On Tue, 11 Apr 1995, D. M.  Ilstrup wrote: 
> 
> Frazer, I respect alot of your ideas, but just thought I'd comment on >

> the guy who was most responsible for military policy during the Vietnam
> War, come out AGAINST the war now in his memoirs? Story on page 7 of 
the > Chron(ically weak news), although did see it on National TV News,humm

good point. imagine if the alernative scene was the dominant culture and
ran the press: the McNamara confession would be front page for days, with
condemnations from the opposition rabble and in-depth analysis and history
and big M would be the darling on ALL he talk shows. nor do I really buy
the idea that putting it on the front page would *not* sell papaers.  TENS
OF THOUSANDS OF YOUNG AMERICANS DIED FOR NOTHING. WAR CHIEF CONFESSES: I
WAS DEAD WRONG - don't tell me that would sell less papers than most
headlines. 
> BRIAN: I believe it was on the NY times front page. Page 7 ain't bad for 
here :)

ain't bad for the queen's of england's and the planet's oldest private
bank going bankrupt?  and where were all the in-depth rep9orts of whether
the Queen herself is bankrupt?  FERGY PAWNS CROWN JEWELS   no, don't think it
will sell? 

 >and why do you say the truth was that the US stood aside whenan 
> >inteligent person like you *knows* that Turkey could *never* do such a 
> >hairraising thing on its own.  are you in denial (as David might say?)
> 
> Actually this is totally wrong. Turkey has a quite substantial military
> force, even compared to Iraq. No one worries about this because Turkey
> is NATO.

miscommunication. I was rejecting the idea that the US stood down in favor
of david's version that the US had *encouraged* the Turkish invasion
(quite possibly to hide the global economic debacle presently impending). 
I was more than tending towards the encouragement scenario, making the US
stand-aside the *minimum* involvement. as you say, in agreement with this:
"no one worries because Turkey is Nato".  but I'll happily abandon Turkey,
it's not the main point. 

>BRIAN: The IRAQI embargo is costing Turkey money. It decided to say
>"screw the US" and go in (I'm not opining on whether that was a good idea
:) And this semi-intelligent (I got three live brain cells :) KNOWS that
>they did it on their own.. without help from US. The US really stood

no, didn't mean to downplay Turkey's balls, no worries.

> >> jaysuzzzz... it's all over the Wall St Journal. And *nothing* collapsed. 

> >c'mon, brian, wake up.  who reads the Wall ST Journal except the people 
> >involv3d in the Game?  the point is that this whole system is based on 
> >confidence (a confidence trick in fact> and newspaper owners are up to 
> >the hilt in the present confidence trick - surely you can see that >:-)
> >forget the myth about newpapers only wanting to sell papers - they have 
> >much higher priorities too, like they want to stay *wealthy* and on top.

> This is dumb, Frasier. I read everything from the Journal to the SF Weekly.
> Read it sometime. If you don't know what 'the other side' is doing, how are
> you going to be effective in underthrowing them anyway?  BTW, I agree fully
> that the Wall Street Journal and the Entire Economic System is about confidence,
> that's the reason stock brokers give for their usefulness to society, they
> agree with you too. There is no use for speculation in my mind to society,
> but people in the financial industry will tell you they are needed because
> they establish what the current confidence level is in various business 
> ventures. The SEC is all about doing things to try and keep these confidence
> barometers stable, that's their excuse for existing, sometimes a questionable
> one.  

miscommunication mostly.  I was poopooing ed's claim that, because they
were covered in the WSJ, they had therefore been "well covered". which is
patently untrue.  would you describe that WSJ coverage plus page 7 in the
Chronicle (which I devour (what litle meat I can find) most days) as 
"likely to produce an elightened informed public."?  didn't think so.. 

I also pick the WSJ etc from garbacge cans as I pass but I'd estimate 100%
of the WSJ's *daily* readership is on one level or another "involved in
the Game".  nor am I saying it's a bad paper, it's often the *only* place
to get information. 

as for stockbrokers, they are the very last people on earth who will tell
you the system is melting down and deserves to.  now please nobody write
in and tell me they know some very nice stockbrokers because all I'm
saying is that they're *never* gonna blow away their entire raison d'etre
until they're forced to exchange the dolloar in their pocket for a piece
of toilet paper.  then they'll probably confess tht they always felt it at
the back of their minds that there was something basically rotten at the
basis of that whole system now gone. 

> Confidence is a major issue that those of us who wish to change the world have 
> to deal with, because any form of civilization must have the confidence of its 
> members on some level, scam or not. 

[scam or not is going too far for me] 
this is one of the most frequent misunderstandings in modern 
conversations.  confusing two quite separate questions.  first: how
*should* a sane and civilised society operate?  two: how shall we operate
during the Struggle to get to that new society?  you might believe money
should be done away with, but you might very well decide to use money to
bring about that change.  in other words:  when a system like todays is
actully strangling us and our planet 'tis not the season of singing the
reassuring delights of the status quo! 
 
> E.G. The internet is nothing if people don't use it. Five years ago my friends 
> gave me empty stares when I told them how cool the net was; they aren't staring
> anymore! The importance of any institution/anti-institution is based on the sort
> of 'critical mass of participation' that can be achieved with it, 
> although I wish more people were involved with healthier ideas, for 
> themselves others and the planet.

total agreement and right on! I get it often enough today for telling 
freinds the state of the planet is *not* cool.  >;-)

> It looks old 'cause it's been in the papers for days...

and nobody's been allowed (or understood) to talk about some of the 
Gigantic Ramifications that might have already started.  let alone some 
imput from others quite outside the system. (witty, educated and 
intelligent a writer as I am yuo're never going to see *me* being given a 
column, and I acually write a lot over the years on this subject.)
what I'm saying is that a whole class of appartchiks has a stake in the 
Game and they're not going to report it objectively if it's going to make 
their own economic situation more insecure than god knows it already is!

>who decided this was not news?

>BRIAN: some kid with an MBA in marketing that figured that the average joe
>wasn't interested in that type of story. The point is Fraser.. it was old

s>hore up the dollar.. in many papers..that's if you were REALLY interested

you sorta missing my point, brian. it's got nothing to do with wherther 
*I*'m interested (I'm FUCKING interested all right) it's got to do with 
whether the citizenry of tis democracy is getting an accurate picture of 
what's of great *interest* to them. and, without straying too far 
off-topic I just don't buy the assumption over here that people wouldn';t 
be interested - not if they realised how important it was going to be for 
them, because it is.  they're not going to ollect their isurance 
policies, the money in their acounts is going to melt away like snow - 
still don't think they'll be interested, naw?

actually this all boils down to this: you're mistaking as cyclical what
is actually fractals getting bigge5 and bigger ... until they move into a 
whole New Game

Hey you guys,   check this out....This is from Grant...

>This is a copy of what was said in a Campbelltown Local Newspaper
>
>* Heading 1 - RAGE OVER RAVE
>* Heading 2 - Police powerless

        <snip>
>* Mr Thomspson said he would discuss the situation with council to see if
>* was any way of preventing another party.
>*
>* "There needs to be some legislation giving police powers to stop this
>* kind disturbance," he said.

        <snip>

>* Council planning and development director Denis Moore said his officers
>* investigate what powers council had to deal with the property owners and
>* organisers.

        <snip>

You know, this is the kind of reporting that *really* frightens me about
the power of the press to miss-inform. Imagine a few reports like this in
the general papers & television reports PLUS a few more officials stating
that "we need better laws to stop this stuff", next thing you know, POW,
Australia has its own CJB and we're in the shit with the general public
convinced that raves are dangerous things that will destroy their children.

It's interesting just how much the public can be brainwashed while thinking
that they're receiving unbiased, balanced reporting. A note was posted to a
list I'm on from back during the Gulf War where a research company
tele-marketed a stack of people regarding why America was in the war, how
it started, etc. No one knew the "real" reasons, no one knew that the US
had ignored the situation until its effect on oil became apparent.
Basically the
y only knew what had been pushed on CNN, that America was
stepping in to aid a weaker "ally" and that the Patriot missle was a "real
cool thing".

Maybe the press in Australia and the US is not as controlled as other
places in the world but we're fucking kidding ourselves if we believe that
television stations and newspapers do not have SOME form of bias on ANY
event ( which NewsCorp held publication wants to run a report slamming
Murdock, huh? :).


Grant

---- end -----

Jeremy Laurance says...

Hi All,

The cops have a lot to answer for. With all this shit going down I haven't
been able to make it to the gym all week. :)

Ok, I get the feeling that Police Internal Affairs have decided on
their strategy to bury^H^H^H^Hinvestigate this whole thing,
so hassling them any more won't get any response except more
misinformation coming back. Thanks go to everyone who phoned them.

There seem to be two issues on-going here (apologies for stating the
bleeding obvious):
1. Response to the naughty things the cops did on Saturday night.
2. Countering mis-information about the rave scene in general.
   Making sure our point of view gets accross to the legislators
   at least as loudly as as the cops' and councils'.

The most constructive next step on (1) is, IMHO, is to make sure
the State Ombudsman's office devotes as much resources
to their investigation as possible. After all, these people
are trained in getting meaningful information from the cops
and other minor miracles.

If you were at Freequency and didn't like what you saw,
make a complaint! This is important. Encourage your non-netted
friends to do this as well.

----- end -----

Crunchman

>From the Miami Herald:

Reports have come in that Ernie was released from captivity, but is now
fleeing the DEA and said to have been captured by Interpol while hiding in
Argentina.

The Sendero depresosso claimed to have released Ernie, this Tuesday, but it
is believed he may have actually escaped during delivery of fresh linen at
the hotel where the terrorist group was reputed to be hiding. The Whining
Path has yet to comment, but a radical splinter group, the Sittin' Fine,
claimed to have Ernie in custody. All these reports proved to be false as
photographs of Ernie in the LA international airport were shown on
Nightlie, tuesday nite.

14 hours after boarding Air-gentina flight 107, Interpol agents stormed the
plane as it landed in Bueno Aires this morning, serving  a warrant for
possesion of sundry amphetamines and  smuggling of acid to Germany and the
UK last spring. Ernie was briefly detained, but Argentine officials refused
to allow his deportation.

The DEA has also requested Ernie's extradition, due to recent comments by a
miffed Bert and recent e-mail recoverd by DEA hackers after seizure of Big
Bird's computer at a NY bust this winter. While only requesting his
presence for questioning, Ernie's lawyers have reccommended the celelebrity
remain in Argentina for the next few weeks.

Argentine President Menem reputedly found Ernie to be a fellow womanizer,
tooter and tripper,according to a close aide, and both appeared in public
this morning, on their way to Victor's Floating Casino on the La Plata
river.

Shooting of episodes for Sesame St. are currenty going on, with splicing of
old anecdotes involving Ernie. Tonight, he is expected to hold a press
conference in the Brazilian border town of Amizade as the floating casino
pulls into port. President Menem has stated that he will not bow to
international pressure to defend laws that he feels are unjust. "Americans
need to cut loose, mijos. Lookit Ernie, he's a good enough chap, he's done
no harm.  Why can't they just go after the real criminals, I mean, the US
and Intepol never came after all those old Nazis here, and Mengele,
whuddabout him? Eh? Sheesh"

Ernie seemed well, and apparently in possession of  both ears. His lawyers
are currently working on his safe, legal return to the states, but in the
meantime, fans can only hope for this to be the end of Ernie's ordeals.

By Arnold Neuz, Amizade, Br.

Greetings all,

Just to let you know about an upcoming party Mother Earth Sound System is 
doing, in celebration of Earth Day, spring, and rebirth!

KIVA

Saturday, April 22

Mother Earth Sound System DJs
Dubtribe
Tony

415.487.7681
510.549.6260

A traditional kiva is an underground ceremonial chamber whose structure 
is symbolic of spiritual emergence. The Hopi people believe that whatever 
transpires within the kiva has a direct bearing on the world at large. 
The songs and dances performed within the kiva ensure the continued 
blessings of our Earth Mother and other universal forces. They remind the 
participants of the Road of Life leading to peaceful coexistence in 
brotherhood with fellow man and all living spirits.


Respect to all,

			MOTHER EARTH SOUND SYSTEM
			*************************
			>>>respect your mother<<<
			*************************
			UNITE  CELEBRATE  SURVIVE

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Wed, 12 Apr 95 13:48:22 PDT
From: peter@island.com (Peter Jones)
To: dhchung@us.oracle.com, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re:  This Week's SFR Calendar

   My son Morgan Jones, a sophomore at the University of California
at Santa Cruz, died on April 1, 1995, after attending a rave in 
San Francisco.

   The coroner has not yet issued a death certificate, but 
preliminary indications we have from a private autopsy are that he had
ingested a small amount of Ecstasy and a small amount of alcohol.
The Ecstasy may have induced a heart arrhythmia which killed him.

   It is my impression that young people regard Ecstasy as an
essentially benign drug.  They should think hard before taking it.

   I am not yet well informed about the drug, but will be researching
it in the months to come.  I would be happy to hear from anyone who
can help me in my research.

   There will be a memorial service for Morgan in the Stanford
Church, Sunday, April 30, at 1:00 p.m., with a reception following
at his grandmother's house on the Stanford Campus.

Peter R. Jones
peter@island.com
(Island Graphics Corporation, San Rafael)
415-491-1000, x2139

April 12, 1995

This bounced as it included the word "svbscribe" in it, with the v 
changed to a u, which I filter for in an attempt to capture people 
unfamiliar with how to add or remove themselves from a mailing list.

To answer your question before you get a chance to ask it, Phred (bad 
form  I know :) I don't want to start a mailing list whose mission 
statement is "everything only remotely tangentially related to the 
discussions that happen on sfraves".  Even I wouldn't svbscribe to that.  
I would sooner make SFRaves a moderated mailing list.

However, I understand best.com allows one to set up majordomo-ized 
mailing lists - David Dei and/or Fraser might find that useful.

In the future, of course, we'll have collaborative filtering, and posts 
of interest to only a few will die by evolutionary forces....

	Brian

check out the dorian gray. it's below the flughafen but above the zug! 
next to the kino! das ist die discotek fur tekno music gehoren. aber, die 
hauptwache (sp?) ist den 'main strip' fur dieses schallplaten 
und 'rave gear' gebrochten. ich hat zwolf jahre in deustchland 
(frankfurt) gewohnen, und die 'rave scene' im 1988-89 was sehr gut! 
mostly in bomb shelters. cool, huh. there was this one called 'bubblegum' 
underneath the main financial district in the summer of '89 or so.
there's also plenty of record stores under the hauptbanhof, so check 
there for info. the hauptwache is 2 or 3 stops from the hauptbanhof and 
the konstblerwache is one more past that. these are the main shopping and 
strolling areas in frankfurt. should have no prob. finding out anything. 
lateness, dj thad

 I recently noticed another post about a death on X ( and alcohol ) and
since TV is showing an expose on deaths caused by using tylenol with alcohol
I was just wanting to mention how we really do need more "information"
in our society on responsible drug use... 
 
  I personally find it "odd" that people feel it is "normal" to take
8 tylenols per day along with 3 drinks PER DAY. From my perspective
unless one has a very serious problem with pain - this pattern of drug
use IS drug abuse. But then I take about 8 aspirin/tylenol or whatever
per Year ! 

  Of course, here I am "preaching to the choir" since it has also been my
experience that some of the most responsible drug users are those that
often take "illegal drugs" - ( and when out of control some of the most
irresponsible also - go figure ). IMHO of course :)

  I just hope that the pain of losing his son will not cause the man who is
going to research X to place all of the blame on this single drug. Especially
when drugs that are perceived to be safe like tylenol can become deadly when
mixed with alcohol. Answers - when they are found - are sometimes grey but
seldom black or white....

Just thinking...

Mike

Subject: Re: RAVING SERIOUS FUN/JUST FUN?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.SOL.3.91.950412231708.15015D-100000@taurus>
Message-ID: <Pine.BSD.3.91.950413020946.20069C-100000@shell1.best.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

it seems to me, a mere newcomer to sfraves and absolutely willing to stick
to the local rules, that there are currently two threads that don't seem
to be connecting in everybody's' minds - almost scizophrenically.  

one is about Rave Culture *not* being about politics etc while the second,
mostly from crunchman in ozland, is bringing into the foreground what has
been increasingly seen here in the Bay Area since at least January 1st,
namely the global crackdown on that very RC. 

now more and more sfravers are writing me privately on these matters -
some say that sfraves *should* be about Rave (which doesn't just mean DJs
if any of you Djs think it does - remember we don't want rock'nroll
"stars"  no more if that's your viewpoint) while others seem to accept
that sfraves *is* meant to be about gig times and djs 'n records 'n 
clothes 'n who I hugged there etc and all that. 

some of these latter are suggesting a Cc list or something.  now I don't
really understand all this bandwidth problem (I personally don't care how
long it is, I care how deep it is) (is it the cost to some people of
downloading it?) I have one suggestion, possibly stooopid.  could this Cc
thing be tried and then released onto sfraves, say, every friday, 30000
long but clearly marked "BORING" or "SERIOUS" so that those who don't 
want it can effortlessly avoid it?  any use?  no?  'spected not.

one other thing to do with all this - I'd like to know how people who have
been putting out the "Raving is just about Raving" thread don't feel some
small element of remorse now that they see how *political* it's all
getting ( actually has been but it just wasn't so obvious) I mean, wasn't
it only a few weeks ago some people were telling us it was all my
imagination and raving had *nothing* to do with all that?! obviously some
high up authorities out there don't agree with you.  anybody like to
recant on that one?  because, believe me this time, RC is only going to 
get more and more "political" (as it affects and therefore begins to 
enter the terrain of "ordinary earthbound poitics" whether it wishes 
to or not) and whether you like it or not.  nothin' to do with me, 
guvnor, I'm just reporting historical developments, not making 'em 
happen. (?)

or do you original first threaders (definitely phred who, I just checked,
has been making vaguely negative remarks about this very point since
almost the first appearance of the zippies on the internet last April, and
several others) still not see the connection?  either you deny there's a
gathering national/global crackdown on RC and that all that Criminal
Justice Balls in the UK we were on about last year has *nothing* to do
with Raving in California (do you?) or you don't see that, if it *is* so,
it can only be because authorities less involved in RC see the power of it
better than you do. 

if that's the case I suggest it's for you to look around at the more
political environment and *notice* the increasing connection. in the real
sense of the word "politics" RC is possibly the *most political*
phenomenon on the planet today - it's outside the "old Game", it's
radically life-altering, it encourages people to "come together", thus
empowering themselves and so on.  and the authorities worldwide (who care
deeply about such stuff) are increasingly noticing it even if you don't. 

and one final question, asked because I genuinely do not know the answer. 
is this post a) off subject b) too long?  could all those who have
complained tell me please. 

fraser

Well,   some interesting events I want to reflect on...  And that is how
similar the rave scenes are between San Francisco and Sydney.  I'm currently
in Melbourne right now.   But two major events took place,  one happened in
San Francisco when a most unfortunate raver passed away,  and the other
event in Sydney when the police got out of hand.    Both events made the
press,  and has given raving some pretty bad press.    It is clear that
we must strive to enlighten the public by informing them of all the good
things about raves.    

In my tracking of BOTH the SF scenes and in Australia,  I've observed this
effort on both sides of this big ocean.    It might be a good idea for each
side to subscribe to each other's mailing list.    I'm on BOTH SFRaves
and AusRaves,  and the messages I'm getting are so similar its almost
uncanny.    

One SFRaver commented...

>Does anyone know of any free park raves put on for earth day next week?

>I think this might be a good chance to bring the press in on it! If we
>show some of the awareness involved with raving and also the love, We
>may be able to start to show our side of the story. We have alot to
>show.

Also,  in SF,  the SFPD busted up a legally permitted party for an AIDS
benefit organization.    The result of which has generated a class action
lawsuit against the SFPD.    13,000 KM away,  on the other side of the
Pacific,   a similar incident took place.   In both cases,  the press
was involved,   but us ravers seem to have no voice or little opportunity
to tell our story.   

Monica and Tom from SF comment...

>the hearing b4 the sf board of supervisors on police brutality and 
>civilian oversight, begun march 28, will be continued this tuesday at 
>10am at the war memorial building (401? van ness, 4th floor).  the public is 
>invited 
>to testify, so if you have experienced or witnessed any brutality at 
>raves and wish to testify, this is an opportunity.

And across the Pacific....  

>So, how many of you called Triple J on Monday? How many of you are still 
>pissed off enough to actually get up and do something about it? Anyone out 
>there going to take responsibility to co-ordinate things so this bullshit 
>doesn't happen again? 

For those who don't know it,   triple-j is the Australian national youth radio
station.

>From Sydney...

>Telegraph-Mirror 10th April, 1995

>Party over for ravers

>SEVEN people were detained when police raided an illegal rave party early 
>yesterday.

>Police from several city stations formed a wedge shape to disperse more 
>than 400 partygoers at the St Peters site.

>A police spokesman said residents had complained about the noise coming 
>from the vacant lot on the corner of the Princes Highway and Mitchell St 
>at 1am yesterday.

>He said a woman at the party had incited the crowd to prevent the police 
from reaching the power generators.  No charges were laid.

Jeremy Laurance from Sydney commented...

>As suggested by Rosie, I've been in touch with Glen Walker at Police 
>"Customer Assistance" (what a great euphemism) on 1-800-622-571.
>If you were at Freequency and were shocked by what happened, give the
>guy a ring: the more people who get in touch with him, the more serious 
>he'll take the issue.

On BOTH sidesof the Pacific,  the police are monitoring our Email,  as
I'm getting indications o such...   If that is so,   then this is GREAT
as we have the tools to prevent that -- IE:  PGP.   As the police are
now well aware that WE NOW HAVE UNITY!!  All over the world.   We have
a powerful tool in our hands.   Our mailing lists...   With this,  we
can instantly communicate.   What we need to do,   is to figure out how
we can use this tool to get out to the world what we are all about.   

The WWW is one such powerful tool.    PICTURES are worth a thousand words.
A picture of a Sunset rave with people smiling and having fun,   or
a picture of a Sydney rave with the same smiling people can certainly
help to show the awsome love and energy that goes on at these events.

Already,  efforts are underway to put together WEB pages for the casual
Internet surfer.

Lets use those tools we got....   

Anyway,   for those in Melbourne,   see Ya all at Land of the Giants...
I'll be the older dude wearing my goofy checkered hat.... I'll certainly
have my well publiized mission in mind,   we all know what that is....  :-)

And or those in San Franscisco scene....  PLEASE KEEP THE SCENE ALIVE...
I'll be back soon enough,  raring to pump in my awsome energy into OUR
scene...

Crunchman

Subject: Re: Digital Sound....
Date: 12 Apr 1995 17:22:18 GMT
Message-Id: <2829045757.487328@macshasta.snowcrest.net>
Organization: Rich Renouf
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello,

Well, quality digital sound is more complicated than that.  There are lot of
factors that have been discovered recently that were not known about 10-15
years:

1) The biggest factor both with digital and with analog is the ability of the
electronic components to consistently stay within their nominal value at all
times.   About a year ago, Mike Moffat (sort of the Richard James of digital
engineers) created an analog-to-digital converter using very expensive
military grade components that hold their value in all conditions.  I have a
couple of CDs that used his converter (called "The Gain System") and they
have that warmth and air that you find in analog, but not in digital.

2) Another factor that has gotten a lot of attention recently is "jitter",
which is basically a time smearing that occurs when the various different
electronic components in the digital chain get out of sync.

3) Power supplies are also a factor in consumer-grade digital components.  If
there is one power supply for both digital and analog components, then when
the servo is "hunting" (trying to maintain the spot on the disc) then
momentarily the analog components (and the DAC is well) will be underpowered,
causing a decrease in fidelity.

Another miscellaneous bit of information is while Technics turntables are
excellent for functionality, they are far from the best current turntables
sonically speaking.  Since the 1200's were introduced, materials engineering
has advanced, eliminating a lot of the resonances that color the sound of
earlier tables and tonearms.  And, none of the best phono cartridges have
versions that allow for back cueing. :-)

respect to all,

Ken
ken@macshasta.com
send bounces to ken.stuart@tigerteam.org

Fraser asks: 
> one other thing to do with all this - I'd like to know how people who have
> been putting out the "Raving is just about Raving" thread don't feel some
> small element of remorse now that they see how *political* it's all
> getting ( actually has been but it just wasn't so obvious)

Raving has always been about many things other than *just* the logistics
of particular parties.  Politics is one.  There are also spiritual,
psychological, technical (ie. sound engineering), sexual and social
aspects to raving.  All these have been discussed on SFRaves since it
was formed.  There is nothing new about the recent political discussions
brought here by you & others.  What's new is this insistance 
you have on making global and national political issues dominate
over all these other interesting and important rave-related topics.

I don't understand why some people cannot fathom the reality that SFraves
is a *regional* list.  BrianB has always allowed us to go off on these
other tangents, but ultimately the main focus here is on more SF-
specific issues.  

I know that both you and David Dei have occasionally posted to alt.raves,
a global Usenet newsgroup that reaches a much wider audience than here.  
Many SFRavers read that newsgroup, too.  Why do you insist on bringing
your global message here instead of there?

Another approach is to have another mailing list that is non-regional.
I bet you can get a greater global participation that is more focused
on politics than alt.rave or any of the regional lists are.  

> or do you original first threaders
> still not see the connection?  either you deny there's a
> gathering national/global crackdown on RC...

Not everyone so readily believes in global conspiracies.  There
have *always* been busts of illegal parties, even before raving.
There is certainly nothing new about predictions of an impending
world apocolypse.  And cultural revolutions?  Considering the track
record of the Industrial, Socailist, and China's Cultural revolution,
I'm glad that there is some skepticism about the "RC" revolution you
seem to be championing.

> and one final question, asked because I genuinely do not know the answer. 
> is this post a) off subject b) too long?  could all those who have
> complained tell me please. 

There has never been anything wrong about an occasional thread like
this one, as long as it doesn't start dominating the general purpose
and written charter of this list (didn't you read it?).  You have
other *better* options for a more in depth exploration of global 
issues.  If these issues are so important to you, why limit them to
such a tiny forum?  You've already made your point here.  Maybe it's
time to enlighten another regional mailing list?  Just don't tell them
that I sent ya.  :)

Lee

lxfogel@pacbell.com   (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )   lee@hyperreal.com

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Apr 13 08:57:37 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id IAA05253; Thu, 13 Apr 1995 08:57:37 -0700
Received: from netcom15.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with ESMTP id IAA05247; Thu, 13 Apr 1995 08:57:35 -0700
