	id IAA21116; Thu, 13 Apr 1995 08:57:21 -0700
Date: Thu, 13 Apr 1995 08:57:20 -0700 (PDT)
From: "Michael E. Clay" <meclay@netcom.com>
Subject: Why Big Events
To: Ethan Miller <nrg@ultima.org>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9504130847.A14620-0100000@netcom15>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


  Just thinking this morning about the possible big filmore show and one
important aspect of it ( in my mind at least )...

 Currently there's been much talk about "crackdowns" and negative press
about raves and/or raving - so much so that people have suggested that
we should abandon the word rave itself....

  It seems to me that one way to "educate" people about the positive
aspects of raving/rave culture is to ( on occasion at least ) come out
from the underground and throw a high profile ( perhaps even media 
covered ) event - that hopefully has the positive vibe associated with
F&F. The position is further strengthened if media "stars" give it their
blessings AND participation. 

  While I can understand some people's position that " we don't need no
stinking badges ", I fear that if we remain totally underground and don't
tap into some of the "staus quo", we will perhaps be so separated that the
crackdowns will increase not decrease until perhaps as in the UK raves will
be outlawed...

  It is in this light that I support the idea of a large event at a space
like the filmore and with "media stars" such as ( but not limited to ) 
mickey hart. If we convinced these people and others that what we do is
worthwhile - then the authorities will back off. If we are "friends to none"
in the mainstream structure - then we will have no friends in the 
mainstream. This will leave us with no support when the police or other
authorities come knocking...
 

  On that note, I see events like Sunset where people actually see the 
positive vibe as "they walk the dog" or whatever does much to educate the
uninformed about the peace and positivity associated with raving. People
need to SEE positive examples of rave culture not read about its "underbelly"
in their local newspaper....


Mike


 meclay@netcom.com          |  Alone & estatic 
 Mike Clay   (415)572-8971  |  A young rainbow learns  to levitate.

Well I'm not going to speak for phred because he does it just fine by himself.
If you read my posts over the last few years I think you will find
that I've believed that there was a global house movement.  I don't have a 
problem with the political nature of raving, what I have a problem with is
the way that you and other people conduct your political lives and bring the
heat down on others.  You forget where you are, this is San Franciscc and this
whole thing from the 60 through the 90's has been raging here and in our
politics for the last 30 years.  Bear in mind that there is a strong psychedelic
community here, many have gone and still are political prisoners held
in some pretty bad federal pens for the distribution of LSD.  LSD and other
psychedelics that supposedly are manufactured here are a major threat
to the State, at least they act like it is.  The DEA has been trying to
crack thisEgg for decades but they can't do it because the Family is really 
tight and they keep their mouth shut.  Sometimes you have the most amazing 
friends in high places. Some of you on the list know what I'm talking about :)
You guys have come here dragging the media with you, totally insensitive to
what's going on here and are acting like you have all the answers where 
all I can see is that you fucked up your little island and now you want
a second chance here.  Well something like the CJB could happen here but
I believe that RC as you call it is more of an EVOLUTIONARY FORCE as
opposed to a REVOLUTIONARY force.  The battle that must ultimately be
fought is one of not even freedom of speech or freedom of assembly but
of FREEDOM of CONSCIUOUSNESS.

 
> 
> if that's the case I suggest it's for you to look around at the more
> political environment and *notice* the increasing connection. in the real
> sense of the word "politics" RC is possibly the *most political*
> phenomenon on the planet today - it's outside the "old Game", it's
> radically life-altering, it encourages people to "come together", thus
> empowering themselves and so on.  and the authorities worldwide (who care
> deeply about such stuff) are increasingly noticing it even if you don't. 
>

yes, you are right it is outside the "old game" in fact I assert it is
outside the whole political spectrum altogether because the political
spectrum involves us vs. them and RC at least in my opinion is more like
expanding your own consciousness and the ones around you to increasingly
include more and more "us" and less and less "them".


 
> and one final question, asked because I genuinely do not know the answer. 
> is this post a) off subject b) too long?  could all those who have

At 8:57 AM 4/13/95, Michael E. Clay wrote:

> Currently there's been much talk about "crackdowns" and negative press
>about raves and/or raving - so much so that people have suggested that
>we should abandon the word rave itself....
>
>  It seems to me that one way to "educate" people about the positive
>aspects of raving/rave culture is to ( on occasion at least ) come out
>from the underground and throw a high profile ( perhaps even media
>covered ) event - that hopefully has the positive vibe associated with
>F&F. The position is further strengthened if media "stars" give it their
>blessings AND participation.

        First a bit of an introduction, i've been on this list for a bit
and am now coming out of my lurking as i've had an experience recently that
has shed a bit of light on the 'representation of raves.'  I live in
Montreal (hope you don't mind me peeking in on what's going on in SF, i'm
thinking of a move soon) and am on NE-raves where we've had MANY
discussions about the term 'rave' and the crackdowns that have been
happening recently.  A lot of ppl want to abandon the term, others want to
're-appropriate it' in the same way that other cultures (people of colour,
women, gays, lesbians and bi's) have taken back word which (for lack of a
better term) the 'media' has distorted.  I'm unsure as to what the best
idea would be.
        Having a 'high profile party' may be a good way to give ppl FIRST
HAND evidence of the beauty that 'raving' can be.
        Another (and this is my story) would be just to TALK to ppl 'from
the outside' as i had to do the other day in my art class.  A lot of ppl
looked at this (lame) sculpture i did and the topic of raves came up, along
with all the preconceptions (everyone is on drugs, it's superficial, you
have to be 'on something' in order to enjoy it, it's a fad, etc.) and all i
did was speak from my own experience, adding that i rarely do anything
stronger than herbal stimulants and i think that THIS is something that can
change ppls ways of thinking, it's just on a grass roots level.  But, i
guess, that's sort of what 'raving' is doing in the
socio-political-cultural arena ANYWAYS, i know that that is what it did to
me.

        just my .02 cents, thanks for reading :)

                peace,

                        brad

---------------Original Message---------------
I think it is amazing that the mother who lost her son  has contacted us and I 
hope she will continue to do so. For the record , I do think we have drug 
abuse problems within our community, as do most groups of young people.
On the other hand, I've never seen young people be as kind to each other as I 
have with young ravers. 

I think the "prophets" are wrong. I see neo - alienation (real alienation and 
revolution is no longer possible) replacing peace/love aesthetics (hopefully 
peace/love will remain the undercurrent). The irony of symbolic difference 
and connectivity will be a greater paradox than the "prophets" now realize.
The media will call it a new-wave/punk revival and they will be partially 
right. Rave culture will be further splintered. The "prophets" will be forced 
into hybernation once again.

        fraser@megatripolis.org
Subject: Re: RAVING SERIOUS FUN/JUST FUN?
Cc: crunch@netcom.com, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Since Fraser mentioned me, I simply want to say I stand 100% with what
Geoff White and Lee Fogel replied.  

I don't want to break this down into polar opposites, but let me suggest
that one fundamental difference in perspective is between the confrontational/
revolutionary/rhetorical/triumphalist strategy pursued under the "zippie"
banner, and the much more modest but in many ways more deeply rooted
adapational/transcendant approach epitomized by Hakim Bey's weird but useful
T.A.Z.  

Where this scene connects to my life at a fundamental level is where it
moves beyond the superficial relations of power, authority, response and
resistance to a more diffuse yet more powerful restructuring of relations:
with ourselves, with each other, with our planet.  I do the slam-bang
political thing every day; I'm on the phone today with our Republican
legislature and the Governor's chief advisor to try and save our global
climate change study.  That's all fine and good.  I don't see what I do
in the r**e scene as disconnected from that at all, it's merely operating
on a different but intersecting plane of activity and reality.  I don't
play loud house music in the Oregon state capitol (yet) and I don't want to
divert too much explicit attention from having good gatherings with music
and art and conversation and inner searching and outer reaching to the
problems of the day, as heavy as they may be (yet).  

The Internet, considered as a whole, is a vast experiment in changing how
we communicate and relate to each other.  One of its key features is the
ability, at a very low system cost, to allow for those conversational
modes that people would like to pursue.  It seems to me that is the reason
sfraves started to begin with, and has been so successful and to me at
least so much of a change agent in my life.  But it cannot BE the entire
net, it needs a limited scope.  So logically it seems to me that if there
is interest in the didactic and goal-oriented discussions that Fraser and
others may want, then, as I suggested recently, another discussion list
should be set up.

I've been pretty didactic and preachy myself over the last few weeks,
friends.  I'
ve learned something from these thrashes, but I'm also prepared to leave
them behind and move on.  The willingness to take in what new arrivals to
the list have to say, and consider it and let it challenge our normal
ways of thinking, is good.  It is also good not to let this process become
an endless distraction or even the primary focus of the list.  I am very
happy to see Fraser Clark and David Dei and others who bring in fresh
perspectives here and offer them respect for their views and request that
they "grant slack" and let all voices be heard in their due time.

see you in the future
phred

"Why make it simple & easy
 when you can make it complex & wonderful!"

page into http://hyperreal.com/raves/sf, so you can get to the calendar
easily from there.  There's also a new map of important sites in SF
now.

a pretty good spring so far); Ex Why Zzz will be the most massive, while
a lot of the others look to be more intimate (esp. Club Freaky, solyluna).

when.

Administrative Notes

If anyone has info on any other events, submit them! I can't possibly hope to
get all the info every week.

This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To svbscribe or unsvbscribe to
the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to majordomo@hyperreal.com with either
the line

svbscribe sfraves-calendar or
unsvbscribe sfraves-calendar

There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to clubs,
parties, house and techno music, etc. To svbscribe, send e-mail to
majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line

svbscribe sfraves

in the body of the message.

Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

*From: Michael E. Clay <meclay@netcom.com>

* Currently there's been much talk about "crackdowns" and negative press
*about raves and/or raving - so much so that people have suggested that
*I fear that if we remain totally underground and don't
*tap into some of the "staus quo", we will perhaps be so separated that the
*crackdowns will increase not decrease until perhaps as in the UK raves will
*be outlawed...

Yes.
I come from a family heavily involved in political discussion (both right 
RIGHT and semi-left(i love them all!!!!)) and have discovered that politics 
become ultimately 
grey and never changing.  You strip people of politics, and you end up 
simply with their personal characters, complex. Public exposure is good and 
the best effort should be put forward, but publicity often dilutes, often
 generalizes.  While simultaneously working to educate "the world" (we are 
music, we are dancing, we are humans, we are life), we should educate the 
individual (the elders to know more, the young kids to think wisely). 
 The best examples i've 
heard so far in breaking out to the "status quo" are Ronan and Galen's 
encounter with the police at the sunset rave, and bryce's encounter at 
Liquid Air. It is the one on one that made a difference. It is the police 
*being* there and talking with them that made a dent.  A lot of small 
dents become....well, you know. Perhaps that is naive, not street-wise, 
but i'm so hopeful....

good luck out from nyc, eugenics

Hello Everyone..:)

	At the last fnf party I attended (the one that got broken up)
I experienced a strange ritual.  A newly acqiured friend of mine,that I 
met at digitaria, introduced to it..I don't know if anyone else has 
experienced this or even heard of it.  Anyway, what the idea was that you 
are supposed to say whatever is on your mind, but not in the usual 
context of speech communication..  Apparently from what I gathered   the 
idea is to verbally express the rythms or thought 
patterns that your brain,soul, heart, or whatever it is inside of us that 
instinctly has rythm in it.  

I guess the easiest way of decsribing what this is that it is a way of 
speaking in tongues
,in a sense,.  Anyhow I found the activity to be a very good release 
method.  At first I was very out of rythm and the patterns that i spoke 
sounded muttled and choppy.  However through a little practice I learned 
to channel this primal form of expression  and have found it quite 
threaputic.

If anyone knows out there what the hell I am talking about please feel 
free to let me know what is up.  Is there an unspoken RC term for this 
ritual or is it simply known to a few people.  Has anybody else out there 
seen this done? I have a feeling that this might be a practice left for the 
more intimate parties...?  Just really curious  .....:)

hugs
Dan

From: Brian Darkness <brianvan@liberty.liberty.com>

To: ken stuart <ken_stuart@macshasta.snowcrest.net>
cc: nrg@ultima.org, sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <2829045757.487328@macshasta.snowcrest.net>

Precedence: bulk

Dear All;

	Regarding Military/Standard Components(MIL/STD), being an 
X-military design engineer of sorts(sub contractor work only), we were 
forced to use components that were tested to the MIL/STD/883 grade. 
Whicjh means to all you cilivians, god bless you all, that the components 
were all tested prior to assembly and after, these components were tested 
in the following ways:

	1. Energized On & OFF
	2. Hi Attitude and Hi Pressure
	3. Drop tested
	4. Vibration(shake)
	5. Temperature(MIL/STD/883 processing was from tempertures range 
	   -55c to +125c)bake
	6. Misc. frost, water proof, stability tolerance +/- .0001%, sudden 
	   temperature change from +125c to -55c in seconds ..etc
	7. Combinations of all of the above

The components that survive are to say the least extremely reliable, and 
very expensive, there are other grades of components which are the following:

	1. Commerical(Yuk)
	2. Industrial(better)
	3. Military(better better), non /883
	4. Military(best) /883 processing

This is done so that components can be rated for levels of reliability, 
this is why a $.30 cent NPN 2n2222a transistor in mil grade is about 
$5.00. Reliability or rates of failure look like a bathtub curve, with 
the highest rates of failure either at infanticy or old age. A CD player 
with MIL/STD/883 components and similar MIL/STD hardware would be able to 
survive EMP/+,- 100g's/function from -55c to +125c/an distant 
thermonuclear attack ..etc, it would be one touf SOB Cd player, but would 
cost like 300% more the a regular one.

There are Military standards for everything, rubbers to peanut butter 
...etc, everything they use has a standard, even toilet paper.

One final note, these components are realily available tp us all, for a 
price, and can be ordered from most large scale electronics supply house, 
you won't findem in Shit Shack though.

On 12 Apr 1995, ken stuart wrote:

> 1) The biggest factor both with digital and with analog is the ability of the
> electronic components to consistently stay within their nominal value at all
> times.   About a year ago, Mike Moffat (sort of the Richard James of digital
> engineers) created an analog-to-digital converter using very expensive
> military grade components that hold their value in all conditions.  I have a
> couple of CDs that used his converter (called "The Gain System") and they
> have that warmth and air that you find in analog, but not in digital.

Peace & Love
Brian Darkness

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Apr 13 23:02:45 1995

From: bradleyg@ix.netcom.com (Bradley Graham)
Subject: Re: S314
To: Monique Ho <myho@ucdavis.edu>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Monique,
All current, pending federal legislation of the 104th congress can be
found on the Library of Congress' Thomas system.  Actually, you can
even find bills from the 103rd congress.  It's pretty cool if you're
interested in laws and how they are created (at least from a political
process standpoint, not a behind the scenes influence pedaling
standpoint). 

To get directly into the Thomas system (104th congress legislation)
go to the following:
    http://thomas.loc.gov/home/c104query.html
under the search by bill number (2nd query option) enter:
    s.314
and voila, all you ever wanted to know about S.314 (communications 
decency act of 1995); all 8391 bytes of it.

Enjoy,
BG

I'm not going to force anyone to change anything, lee, least of all when
I'm at someone else's p[icnic and it has its own whole tradition etc. but
I *am* here in SF and I *do* see california as crucial to the struggle
that the cooperative living meme of RC is now assuming worldwide whether
it's choosing it or not (that's why I'm here) and it's not the cooperative
meme that's choosing an argument, it's the old competitive meme that' s
not going to stand idly by and watch the cream of its youth stolen away from
competition to cooperation - hence the growing problems RC is facing.  would
you like to bet $100 that the whole issue will be even more central
politically, socially, spiritually and even, yes, tecnically a year from
now or even by this summer? 
fraser

On Thu, 13 Apr 1995, Geoff White wrote:

> Ummm Fraser, may I suggest that you download the sfraves archives > (if

>some of the reactions that you are getting. > 

we've had this ongoing debate for 8 years now in the Uk (and that's just
within Rc, never mind Stonehenge, Hippy Fayres and Welsh covens and
Amsterdam psycheleics and all of it) and, until the last 2 years, I've
been getting quite as much"flaming" as here.  that's all changed over
there and is beginning to change here 

now > my question to you is what are *you* going to do about it, given
that > you have this realization.  I don't want to here what *we* should
do > I want to hear what *you* are going to do, and then maybe I'll
deceide > to _join_ you or maybe support you or do something else
entirely. >

I'm sorry if I've sounded like I'm telling you what to do, I didn't mean
to do that.  there are obviously a thousand diferent ways.  as for what
I'm going to *do* the question surprises me.  I'm already doing it and
have been for a decade.  mainly it's "talking* about the importance of RC
for the plznet so that we all see it (and you can't think that everyone
realises that surely) and talking about how little time we actually have -
hence the idea of growing a little scene and maintaining it for the rest
of our lives until our children bla bla is just not seeing the situation.
(you may not agree etc but what am I to do if I feel *convinced* to the
depths of my being then surely my duty is to keep on saying it in new
ways, in funny ways, in more insightful ways etc etc) 

nor do I *only* talk.  I act.  allow me to blow my own trumpet for a
paragraph or two since I obviously haven't done it enough for you.  I've
been putting on raves, wisdom weekenders, love labs, illegal, small, legal
massive raves etc AND publishing magazines like Encyclopaedia
Psychedelica, evolution^, zippy times.  I've released acid house singles
with Tium Leary telling people to "Think For Yourself & Question
Authority", it was my record company which arranged for Terence McKenna to
go on the Shamen track (check the label, phred) and we've released
Shamanarchy In The Uk, the best house album yet IMHO. I've also torn up my
roots in the Uk(successful club at last, good high quality lifestyle,
final social acceptance in my home country etc) to come over here because
some inner voice told me to do it.  I've half starved, been insulted,
misunderstood, reviled etc I've also met great friendships and alliances
and love, support and respect and have garnered large amounts of media
attention to use it to spread the good news about RC (now some on sfraves
are beginning to talk about the importrance (hey great word!) of doing
this before we get isolated (as happened in the UK, which is *exactly* why
I've been doing it, even when most didn't yet realise my intentions.  we
put on the Grand Canyon Mega Rave last year in an attempt to spark a
national identity for RC and we took Rave to the annual Rainbow Gathering
in Wyoming last summer for the first time ever, thus achieving the major
aim of the Zippy Pronoiia Tour - to connect Rainbow wisdom and Raver
enthusiasm to create Zippy in the culture (and met Crunchman on my
dancefloor 300 miles from the nearest town!) etc etc.  as for the
immediate future - the Parallel University is trying to spread RC into
other sections of society, older, psychedleic, middleclass etc) I'm giving
a speech on RC at Stanford University in early May and discussing doing a
regular rave room for their monthly dance.  I've been meeting with
alternative politicos about the UN50 celebrations here in Sf this summer. 
I'm spreading word of the 100,000 Rainbow Lovers celebration festival in
ggpark this summer (of course I had no part in setting it up, that would
be illegal) we're working to finally secure a large legal area just
outside the city where nonprofit NGOs could work with us to provide the
very "safe public idealistic events" that some have started to call for
since the Oz raids (we've been at this since february) AND we're *still*
going through the step by steps to open a permanent club centre in the
city that might provide a home for several posses as the law cracks down on
all the renegade parties this summer.  etc etc etc

> >  I have one suggestion, possibly stooopid.  could this Cc
> > thing be tried and then released onto sfraves, say, every friday, 30000

don't wanna be unravey but some people are telling me that actually it's 
one of the biggest servers in the bay area and easily able to handle it 
all; also many write to me privately that they're glad of what's happening 
etc etc.  sorry if I'm still learning about the technicalities of all 
this.  and, may I repeat, I definitely am not the type to spoil 
somebody's picnic and I mean that seriously.  

> > several others) still not see the connection?  either you deny there's a
> > gathering national/global crackdown on RC and that all that Criminal
> > Justice Balls in the UK we were on about last year has *nothing* to do

oh yes, that's another thing I've been *doing* and, even if you don't see 
a global crackdown (yet) you must surely agree that we were not as loopy 
to warn that what happened in the UK would very definitely have effect 
elsewhere as some thought at the time > > 

> If you read my posts over the last few years I think you will find
> that I've believed that there was a global house movement.  I don't have a 
> problem with the political nature of raving, what I have a problem with is
> the way that you and other people conduct your political lives and bring the
> heat down on others.  You forget where you are, this is San Franciscc and this

> Well something like the CJB could happen here but
> I believe that RC as you call it is more of an EVOLUTIONARY FORCE as
> opposed to a REVOLUTIONARY force.  The battle that must ultimately be
> fought is one of not even freedom of speech or freedom of assembly but
> of FREEDOM of CONSCIUOUSNESS.
> 
couldn't agree more.  we didn't bring the media here, we jumped that wave 
a year early and got out some p0sitive info and vibe to the national press 
BEFORE the word seeped down (or up from the Subconscious if you prefer a 
less conscious conspiracy model) to "DEMONISE RAVING". we did that 
because we'd seen it happen in the Uk, knew the power of the growing 
movement and knew it would happen here.
 
> > true sense of the word "politics" RC is possibly the *most political*
> > phenomenon on the planet today - it's outside the "old Game", it's 
> > radically life-altering, it encourages people to "come together", thus 
> > empowering themselves and so on.  and the authorities worldwide (who care
> > deeply about such stuff) are increasingly noticing it even if you don't. 

> yes, you are right it is outside the "old game" in fact I assert it is
>  outside the whole political spectrum altogether because the political
> spectrum involves us vs. them and RC at least in my opinion is more like
> expanding your own consciousness and the ones around you to
> increasingly > include more and more "us" and less and less "them". >


precisely.  using all the tools available.  but it's not *outside* the
whole political spectrum, it permeates it, includes it because, let's face
it, the lower level is surely the downloading of the higher.  so, I appeal
to you to see that this discussion is one of "downloading strategies" 
(it's great news, it's seeing our vision predominate long after we'd given
up hope) and not all of our generation understsand this:  some appear to
think that meditating off alone is enough when it's actually recuperation. 
we'll be dead and pure spirit soon enough, let's particiapte as free souls
in the apparent plot we find ourselves in - a planet in the final hours of
its ultimate destiny. 

fraser (if this is too long, tell people to stop writing back to me >:-))

agree with everything you said, phred.  thankyou.  fraser.

would like to slightly redraft one of your lines, though.

On Thu, 13 Apr 1995, Fred Heutte wrote:

> that one fundamental difference in perspective is between the confrontational/
> revolutionary/rhetorical/triumphalist strategy pursued under the "zippie"
> banner, and the much more modest but in many ways more deeply rooted
> adapational/transcendant approach epitomized by Hakim Bey's weird but useful
> T.A.Z.  

it is not I/we who are being confrontational.  the competitive meme will 
not sit idly by and see the crem of its youth be seduced by cooperation.  
I wish they would but the proof is starting to lap all around us.  the 
second last magazine I edited was called evolution^ - quite a few people 
here know it. triumphalist, YES!
and let's go for P.A.Z. Permanent Autonomous Zone (as david puts it) if 
we don't move ftom Tazs to PAZ over the next few yers there'll be nothing 
left to be "in many ways more deeply rooted" IN!  >:-(

Hi all

Daniel writes:
> At the last fnf party I attended (the one that got broken up)
>I experienced a strange ritual............experienced this or even heard
>of it.  Anyway, what the idea was that you are supposed to say whatever is
>on your mind, but not in the usual context of speech communication..

>rythms or thought patterns that your brain,soul, heart, or whatever it is

putic.
>
>If anyone knows out there what the hell I am talking about please feel
>free to let me know what is up.  Is there an unspoken RC term for this
>ritual or is it simply known to a few people.  Has anybody else out there
>seen this done? I have a feeling that this might be a practice left for the
>more intimate parties...?  Just really curious  .....:)
>
>hugs
>Dan

Terence McKenna refers to it as Glossolalia (sp?), or the uninterrupted
flow of language.
- from my own experiments is does seem that it is possible to experience
language as a virus, as something we wear like a set of clothing, or
something we channel , like a character on a stage.
In fact, I often find my spoken vocabulary ebbs and flows according to my
state of mind. Extreme Poetry being the hightened speech form of altered
states, and  stumbling, incoherency the state of stuttering speech
normality.

- david

kisses, tents, cold & warm clothes, records(for dj's: there might be a 
slot or two or three open!!!!), and most of all your big ass smiles:)!!

family is throwing a 24 hour, free party!!!!! There are about 12-15 Djs, 
spinning their asses off so go and check it out!!!!!!! Call 
(408)684.6730. The party starts at 4:20pm friday, and goes til 4:20pm on

dancing, music, love, & energy!!!!!

Well, we haven't had any major brainstorms about a pre-party gathering
on Saturday, given the somewhat isolated location of the event at the
Expo Center up by Jantzen Beach and far from downtown Portland.  We could
go to a tavern or brewpub but that doesn't work if you're under 21, and
so on.

So instead I'll just invite anyone who'd like to drop in to visit my office
downtown in Portland on Saturday.  I'll probably be around from 2 pm or so
on.  It's in the vicinity of SW 4th and Washington.

Call ahead to 503/222-9572 or 870-5532 and I'll give you directions.  I've
got turntables, CD player, mixer, amp, speakers and two terminals for
Internet login :-)

See ya'll in the future!
phred

Dear all, i'm sorry for wanking off on your list about other music and 
dance- too much wine Sunday morning, i'll resist the urge next time, will 
find email pals to muse all we want about 80's fabulousness, Siouxsie, 
that icky rawk stuff.

just one last word on dance- tears flowed at the start of the Lambarena 
ballet on some of our faces- not because of the beauty of the 
choreagraphy, the gorgeous orange-yellow flowing kente cloth, or the 
successful mutation of bach and African choruses and drumming, not 
because it was joyful and not watered down, but because there we were 
stuck in our seats or standing room stall, a hierarchicalized audience 
looking up at sublime creatures in another world, stuck in our awkward 
oh-so appreciative, sensitized, but motionless selves
 once again in appreciation of street dance, house, rave, disco, chill 
out or whatever you wanna call it

Well, i dont bother posting anything on sfraves, but i need to vent.

I dont know about any of you people out there, but Ex Why zZz was 
probably, the best rave i went to. really. i personally enjoy driving from 
oakland out to some hick truck stop out in the middle of god knows where. I 
truely love standing in the rain for an hour and half, moving about 10 
feet forward the entire time.  The security guard at the door was more 
than nice. 

This was probably the worst experience i've had at a "rave" (if that is 
what it might be called).  i dont know who the hell fucked up, but they 
did it big time. i will never go to another ZYX party again. someone 
needs to have their balls chopped for this one. 

Did anyone get inside? (Im sure some "special" person that had bought 
their ticket in advance is on this mailling list. let me know how it was.)

I did try to get my ticket at housewares, but they had sold out. oh 
well..never again..never.

yeah i got into XYZ.    


  i donno what to say but to agree that this party definately
bit the big one in having their shit together.  we got there
around midnight and then enjoyed the next two hours waiting 
outside in the rain getting poured on.  luckily i was with some
friends and all and we had a fun time cracking shit up and 
fucking around in the line (if anyone saw me i had this Green
sweatshirt on outside  babbling about NASA kids, and Frankie Bones
and bum-rushing the door;)  but eventually after quite a lot 
of finangling we got in and through the door.  the inside was o.k.
i had an cool time when they finally let the people waiting outside in
sometime after 3:00 am?  i  was in one of those:  why the fuck am
i out here being dumb and getting sick? ?  this whole rave thing is a joke
ive been fucking around being part of
.  call me the cynic raver =)   but when things got going
with Tony there were a lot of smiling faces and people into the 
music and a nice vibe, that i had a good time.  
  i also took some pictures of the people dancing and all but i
dont know how they turned out.  hope theat look ok :) 
   but my ride was tired and it was a long way back to san 
francisco so we left the party before we fully were into the vibe
so i donno what happened next.
   all in all:  a fun night hanging out and all those sorted things, and an 
eeehhh o.k. party 

it wasnt work twenty bucks, hehhehehehehe ;)

doug ) ( dougie@squishy.com

As SqUiShY as we wanna be in 95!!!

Well hearing about EX WHY Zee, I am reticent to post what a good time a 
couple of friends and I had at Evolution. Small, comfortable space, $7, 
nice people, water freely available. Two floors one well, I would say the 
ambient room, except what was being played was anything but. Still cool 
though, heard a Phil Collins cover of a Beatles song and Prince. What 
more could you ask for, hehehe..... Bottom floor was for the serious 
dancing, nothing particularly awe inspiring but good, tight sets from 
what I heard. Boy I have to say I feel REEEAL sorry for you poor folks 
that bought advanced tickets for ex why zee, to find out the party was in 
Stockton. Wonder whose bright idea that was, eh?
 
                                                    Black Adder

actually quite glad i didnt.. Evolution was a nice, small and intimate 
gathering.. a lot of great people were there..and dancing and having a 
ball:) and the music was good too!:))) galen rox..too bad i missed most 
of his set.. oh well.. i met a few people there and had a great time.. it 
was a nice ending to my spring break:))
i want to thank Brian Darkness for picking me up!! waht a sweetie.. 
soooooo nice to meet you!!:) and Bradley.. i was glad u made it and happy 
to say i was the first sfraves person u met! heehe:))
anyways. that's my pitiful scoop.. heeh see ya soon~!

Veronica...DeeGroovy

U GoT ME wrote:

> This was probably the worst experience i've had at a "rave" (if that is 
> what it might be called).

is it a "rave" when hostile security guards in combat boots seem to be the 
only ones running the show outside (BACK UP! OR NO ONE GETS IN) and inside 
(I SAID, NO SMOKING IN THE BUILDING OR WE SHUT THE PARTY DOWN!)


Doug wrote:

> call me the cynic raver =)   but when things got going
with Tony there were a lot of smiling faces and people into the
music and a nice vibe, that i had a good time.

yeah, Tony was inspired. not only his music and spinning and connection with 
the dancers, but he seemed to be the only dj who understood the limits of 
the sound system. the others, from Jon on, didn't seem to notice that their 
extra volume saturated the speakers into a droning buzzrumble, 
smearing over the texture that Tony brought out so beautifully.

too bad most people, including some who had actually arrived at 11 like 
the phone message suggested, were still outside in line in the rain during 
Tony's set. 

richard

Subject: Late Review:Cyberlab 
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

 [ This is a late review of two events that happened last Saturday ]

 On the same night as last week's outdoor Liquid Air, I was invited to
a party that our own John S. Lee was going to spin at. I arrived at the
site , to find that it was Cyberlab. They had to move it tho' , so it
eventually ended up at the same site as the busted Friends and Family -
only the upstairs was used. 

 Setup caused a delay - John was scheduled to be the first up at 9PM,
but he didn't get started until after 10:30PM. He played a nice set of
tasty house , followed by DJ Polliwog. I've never heard her spin before,
and was pleasantly surprised to hear someone who made such an effort to
mix in short pieces. Also an eclectic mixer - as someone said , it doesn't
work 100% of the time , but it's great when it does work!

 I ducked out to Liquid Air , but , despite an excellent acid trance mix
by Joe Rice , the cold made me retreat back to the hot Cyberlab party.
( so , I missed the almost-bust that Bryce averted ). I believe Ernie
Munson (?) was spinning when I got back , and the dancefloor was comfortably
populated - no problem with overcrowding, and a sane line of about 8
people deep at the door. Since the party was word-of-mouth , it probably 
helped to control the crowd size. 

 There was a great vibe! That's all I need to say ... I danced until my
feet got too sore ( gotta get new shoes ). 

 larryc@netcom.com  ( Larry Ching )
 

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Apr 16 15:49:19 1995

Received: from netcom4.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with ESMTP id PAA18830; Sun, 16 Apr 1995 15:49:15 -0700

From: larryc@netcom.com (Larry Ching)

Subject: Wavelength
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Sun, 16 Apr 1995 15:49:04 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

WAVELENGTH at 1015 Folsom
 I usually don't care for Friday events , because I'm usually working
all day Friday and get tired quicker that evening. But I was curious
about Wavelength at 1015 Folsom , because of the great lineup ( Trance
Mission , Ambient Temple of Imagination ) and Shohban and Ocean , two
Jungle DJs . 
 Upon entering 1015 Folsom , I was greeted by Disco! The top front room
was the disco room , while the top back room was for the performance of 
Trance Mission and then DJ music. The top floor had a DJ setup and another
bunch of folks with keyboards and other equipment , but I never found
out who they were. Buzznet on-line magazine had a corner room ( they left
halfway through the evening ).  In the basement was A.T.O.I. and another
DJ setup. 
 Prior to Trance Mission's set, Cheb i Shebah played some great non-western
dance music. Along with this were video projections of non-western 
naked and near-naked non-white people doing exotic non-western stuff.
As you can probably tell , I'm getting somewhat annoyed by now of the
use of documentary material of "tribal" peoples as video wallpaper at
raves and clubs. I can't put my finger on it quite - if anyone wants
to talk about it with me , send me email. ( Why not videos of white
nudists ? ). 
 Trance Mission started at about 10:30PM - nice music , not quite what
I wanted at the time , but I could see getting into it in my living room.
My fatigue got to me then , and at other times during the evening. I sat
at the back of the dancefloor during much of Trance Mission's set. 
( Actually, the semi-sleep altered conciousness I was in played some cool
games with my head ).
 I ducked downstairs to catch a set by Freezer , a duo [ Peter(BPM/0) and
Joshua(Thermal) ] who have done gigs by themselves and with A.T.O.I. 
Mixture of vinyl ( for beats ) and live keyboards and other instruments.
Later , A.T.O.I. played their set. Both were great ( as far as I could
tell between naps! ).
 By the time I got back upstairs , it was DJ music -  nice techno ! While
dancing , I found myself next to DJ Shohban , so I was able to find out
when her and Ocean were going to be spinning downstairs.
 I got downstairs early, and was glad that I did. A.T.O.I. cleared out
their instruments while Freezer did their thing with instruments and vinyl.
There was a bald asian fellow sitting in meditation next to them - one
of the DJs leaned over and talked to him for a few seconds. I turned my
attention back to dancing - after a few minutes , I noticed someone to
my right. It was the bald fellow, but he was now moving to the performance 
area that A.T.O.I. had vacated. He was naked except for a Japanese style
white breechcloth . The light of the candles gave his shaved limbs and
torso a waxen quality. He was a Japanses Buto dancer (I may have the term
or spelling wrong). He gave an intense performance.
 Constant motion - slow and flowing, and more spastic. Moves based on the
postures of fetuses , water , smoke , the crippled , the mad. His face was 
constantly transforming into archetypal expressions of awe , rage ,fear ,
demonic possesion, joy , and ecstacy. 
 He ended the performance as the began it - walking in a trance-like manner
back to his spot next to the DJ booth. 
 Following that were Jungle music sets by Shohban , then Ocean. Such a joy
to dance to! I think I'd like to see one of these Jungle DJs mixing before
or after DJ DRC - that would be a pair of sets to hear!

 I finally conked out with my head on a leopard print pillow halfway through
DJ Ocean's set , and left soon after I woke up. All in all , an interesting
evening! Too bad I was so tired ( and most of the SFRavers I knew by sight
had left earlier in the evening , so I was a little lonely - boohoo! ).

 Hope you folks are having fun at Sunset!

 larryc@netcom.com / Larry Ching

Dear All;

	First my sincerest sympathy goes out to the people who were let
down my the Ex WHY ZZZ thing, wow fuckin Stockton, a minor word of advice,
don't ever buy a ticket to an event where the location is unknown, that
was very slezzey of the people who put it on. I was actually going to go
to EX WHY ZZZ, and like Cool World changed my mind at the last minute,
glad I did. They should have told people up front where the party was. The
recording said a "New Bay Area Location", boy is that pushin it. I guess I
don't understand the point of hiding the location if its legal and
permitted. Unless you have something to hide, like excessive greed. Flame
me if you like, but everyone knows it was a rip, "fool me once shame on
you, fool me twice shame on me." I would really like to hear an honest 
explanation for hiding the event location, when I called the voice mail 
at 5pm they said they would have directions and stuff on there at 7am 
Saturday, I understand why they were late in getting them on. Again this 
is just speculation on my part, and I would really like to hear there 
side of the story, if they have on.

	As far as Evolution went I'll call it the undergroundyest event
that Saturday night short of a private party I wasn't aware of. I like my
events small, house party like and intimate, intimacy over fuckin hype
anyday anytime. An Evolution had it all, and much more, really friendly
people, I wish I had brought me massage table. The music was killer on
both floors. I went with Veronica Degroovy(piedra@rohan,sdsu.edu), it was
the 1st time we met, and she is a sweetie, and "A Cute Little Muchkin",
hope your trip is safe and filled with joy, and beautiful scenery all the
way down, miss ya all ready :). 

	If the space at 7th and Folsum lasts, I feel it will be a great 
place to have small raves at. Its proablly good for about 200-300 people 
comfortabley, anything more than that wouldn't be very nice, but thats 
just a guess. I really hope this space last, because I'll be back, for 
sure. I heard a rumor their going to be doing a monthly, if anyone 
involved with Evolution can verify the validaity of that rumor, please do 
let me know. I had a great time and look forward to going again, please 
soon :).


		Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace

Hey y'll

	First of all thanks for all the cool responses to my post on 
thought rythms.  :)

As far as XYZ goes:
  Can we say "MMEEAAT MARRKET"

excellent music*once inside* 
I only saw one other person with a passafier(sp?)
I tried to hug this one guy that looked cool... he rudely rejected the 
show of affection by pushing me back..That's ok ,I then tried to give him 
 a blow pop and he turned that down..

Oh well in my opinion what a jerk.:(

I brought along to girlfriends that were met with ego inflated freakers 
as soon as they tried to start dancing.  This was their first rave too.
My friend jeff and I were apologetic for having talked so highly of these 
gatherings and then having them see thge reasons that these parties get 
such shitty reputations.  Was quite a downer for jeff and I.

Would someone pleez smack me very hard in the face next time I even 
consider going to a party that requirs "pre-sale tickets"BAAAAAA!

Really cool, lets get every one sick and cold and then let them inside.
YEa that bring em back again next year..

There were some cool people there though..Just took a little 
looking around..
Unfortuanly this party was very sobering in a sense to the reality that 
"raves" that's right "raves"  are pretty sick in most peoples eyes.  If I 
was a concerned citizen I would have called the police long ago on this one.

OOOOOHHH.such an ideal location too!!
When I parked my car in the neighbor hood surrounding the roller rink..
I was approached by some local police.
They drove up to the car and stopped and asked me what was gaoing on.

I politly said" it is a party" ,"No one is excluded""you should go sometime"
he said and kind of grinned,"well thanks but I don't really think so"

I later saw that same cop along with his pals inside wathcing the dancers 
and the whole trip.  I soberly approached him and asked how it was going.
I calmly tried to explain to him a little bit more abstractly the true 
values that these parties represent to many of us.  BUt with the currnet 
example being performed in fron to his eyes he must have thought I was 
completetly full of crap.  That;s what I would have thouhht.

OK I realize that these parties are what you make of them , and I guess 
it was  cool to see people dancing but...When you see that majority of 
the peoples underlying intentions seemed other than what I "perssonally 
see as the perpetuation of the rave spirit" Its a real downer!PLeez skip 
the temptation to flame..I don't mean to offend anyone.:(

HUgs to the warm people.It felt good to go throught the night sober for once.
It just didn't seem like the right place to e bcause You couldn't be 
affectionate to many peolpe with out getting highly raised eyebrows and 
ugly smirks of disapproval.

A definate "TWO THUMBS DOWN"

I heard that hight that xyz just attracted a different crowd.  Well this 
is not the crowd I enjoyed at ALL..

My spirit was torn betwwen the celebations that I knew were happening 
elsewhere in the wolrd that I wanted to experience,that I tried to 
perpetuate at this party, and the tagging ego tipping ,C'mon baby don't 
you wanna, attitude that I couldn't escape from at this party.

Soory for the negativity Folks
it had to be done..

Hugs anyway
Dan

Peace

So, to sum up for the third time, what's up Saturday?  
Have a fantastic week, everyone.

Peace and hugs and starbursts and kisses and good vibes to all 
(except XYZ location-determinators!  :P)
Timothy

Precedence: bulk

Overall, a Wicked's visit to Portland for the FMW (Full Moon Weekend) was
quite a good time.  I had lots of visitors at my office/DJ shop (including
Geoff, Rox and her sister and friend from Eugene), Susie and Collin (of
course), Eli and friends from Seattle, and Randy and Lindsey.  Sorry if
I missed anyone in the course of my ins-and-outs.  

We left my office at 10:15 and stopped at Waddle's for a soso dinner
before going in.  The Expo Center turned out to be a very nice venue
indeed except for the concrete floors which were hard on the ole knees.
The Purple People Pusher did a pretty good job filling the West Hall
but it would have been nice to have another matching setup to do quad
sound -- nonetheless it was fine quality sound.  The outdoor tent/ambient/
chill space (chilly indeed) was set up nicely with rugs and beanbag chairs
and *excellent* music, I only caught a bit of Dervish's set though.  
Inside was Thomas-Markie-Garth-Jeno.  I think things fizzled a bit around
3:30 when Garth started into that typical FMR deep dark vibe, though his
mixing and the visuals were outstanding.  But Jeno came on at 5:15 with
a 90 minute rippingly uplifting set to finish off.

Went to La Luna for the afterparty, a nice set by Dazy and a rare appearance
by Doran, who was unhappy with his set but I thought it smoked and told him
so :-)  Took a bit of a nap and headed down to Powers Park along the
Willamette, but we got there around 5:30 and found the system had been
shut down because of noise complaints around 3.  

The remaining crew is up in the mountains east of Portland as I speak
doing the final benediction for this wonderful weekend.  The weather
was amazingly perfect today, 65 and pure sun.  

I'm hanging in here to type in these few words, gotta get up early and
go to the legislature tomorrow, so more later . . .

c yu
phred

Hi everybody,
I was curious to find out what everyone's favorite words of advice for
raving were. I've met so many people recently, and they always say stuff
like "Tim, just rememeber, when you go to a rave, you MUST..." and some people
say bring a certain candy, some always wear that same hat, some eat breakfast
at the same spot, some always take certain toys, etc. etc. 
What do you guys always do?  My pre-rave preparations are still evolving;
I usually just make sure to a) shower b) bring a pacifier, lotion, and candy
and c) enough $$$.  Boring, huh? 
What are your musts for happy ravers?
PLUR
Timothy

Timothy,
I don't have any major musts or hard fast rules.  I do suggest, if you 
take any sustances to enhance your experience, educate yourself about it 
as much as you can.  I try to make sure I drink plenty of water so I 
don't dehydrate.  Aside from that I like to let love take care of the rest.

From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9504171630.AA27211@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Wavelength
Cc: jlf3@mofo.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

This was one of those San Francisco socially conscious crosscultural
appreciation events for the hip mainstream kind of thing.  Janie & I went 
mainly to see Trance Mission, and we knew that this would in no way
resemble a rave.

Larry:
> I'm getting somewhat annoyed by now of the
> use of documentary material of "tribal" peoples as video wallpaper at
> raves and clubs. I can't put my finger on it quite - if anyone wants
> to talk about it with me , send me email. ( Why not videos of white
> nudists ? ). 

We also found the video to be pretty tacky.  It wasn't presented with any
kind of artistic intent, nor did it foster any kind of connectivity between
us, the observers, and the on screen tribalism.  At most raves I've been
to, this kind of stuff usually gets mixed in with other cultural images,
psychedelic overlays, etc. with everyone dancing along with what's on 
the screen in an overall synergy that usually works for me.  At
Wavelength it basically felt like a form of voyeurism.

In the basement, the socially conscious part was happening with some kind
of puppet show.  Something about a zookeeper beating on a guy in a gorilla
suit.

>  Trance Mission started at about 10:30PM - nice music , not quite what
> I wanted at the time , but I could see getting into it in my living room.

They seemed rather lethargic compared to the last time we saw them.  The
Madonna bleed-through from the disco room didn't help any.   But I highly
recomend their newest CD, "Therefore".  Powerful, uplifting, trancy 
digeridoo based music with fantastic production values.  One of my best 
1994 purchases.

> He was a Japanses Buto dancer (I may have the term
> or spelling wrong). He gave an intense performance.
> Constant motion - slow and flowing, and more spastic. Moves based on the
> postures of fetuses , water , smoke , the crippled , the mad. His face was 
He did his thing during Trance Mission's set as well. It was sort of 
interesting but self-indulgent in that he wasn't really dancing to the 
music or *with* us.  Just something else for the audience to look at.  

I guess one rave-related connection was the herbal "e"(tm) booth, where
for $18 you could get what was basically a couple of smart drinks in pill
form.  The ingrediants were stuff you could get in any health-food store
for about 1/5 the price (unless you care to believe the sales guy who
explained to me that the ginseg was "from Tibet and more 
concentrated" etc. etc...)  He also tried to convince me that this stuff 
gives you "80% of the full effects of MDMA, everything except the 
empathy part." Great.  

I guess this was a good event for a mainstream type party, and the $12 
seemed fair for the variety of entertainment offered.  It just wasn't 
our kind of scene.


Lee
___________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com   (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )   lee@hyperreal.com

Fraser,
I appreciate all your intentions toward saving the world.  It feels like 
your trying to put alot of that responsibility on "RC".
Seeing myself participating in and being a part of "RC", I sometimes feel 
a little overwhelmed with the thought of saving the world.
For me raving helps me open up to myself, which in turn opens me up to 
more of the world.  Being more open to the world lets me be more loving 
to it, and helps keep me from doing anything destructive, including 
things that I might not have realized as being destructive.
Loving the world also helps me respect the world and flow with the pace 
of its change.  Beautiful changes are happening with the help of raving 
as more people join the flow.  Pushing or insisting on the flow seems to 
create resistance imho.
Fraser it seems like you have alot of high expectations of "RC", almost 
sound a little desparate at times for others to recognize the potential 
that you see.  I know I've recognized alot of potential for how raving 
has helped myself internally, and externally with my relationships.
I'd be interested in hearing how it has helped YOU, aside from all the 
awareness of how miserable the world is and how much change is needed.  
Not that I don't want to hear about that, because I do think its 
important to take a look at all perspectives as much as possible.  I 
wonder if raving helps you see as it does me that the world is also a 
very beautiful place, very balanced, where as much misery and suffering 
there is, there is also as much beauty and joy.
Fraser, I must say that I admire your persistance, and drive to make the 
world a better place.  I'm also thankful that there are people like 
yourself, that do want to help change things for the better.  Just hope 
you get some time to smell some roses along the way.


peter

From: fixer@d2.com (Robert Smith)
Message-Id: <9504171757.AA15314@blackhawks.d2.com>
Subject: My weekend and XYZ
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (SF Raves)
Date: Mon, 17 Apr 1995 10:57:25 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23beta2]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 3875      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

By now, many of you have heard of some of the problems at XYZ.  There is
truth in all views here.

>From my understanding, there was a new, Bay area venue planned, but it got
disapproved by the Fire Marshal on Friday night.  So, after scrambling
around, the XYZ people rented a roller rink in Lodi on Saturday morning.
They couldn't get in until 9pm to set up anything, either.  Now, let's
hope they learned the basic lesson we call "back-up space", but let's
move on.  I'll accept their apologies and be glad they did what they
had to do to recover and go on with the party.

Myself and two roommates drove up from LA (we *really* needed to get out
of town for a bit - mini work vacation which you may not fully understan
if you haven't been in motion picture production).  We got in to SF, called
our friends with the directions, only to find we had to turn around and
drive back where we just came from.  Oh well.

We get to the place and got in line.  Seems no one was being let in yet,
due to the aforementioned sound system setup delays.  Slight drizzle called
for the jackets that no native Detroiter would ever be without, no matter
where in the world you find yourself.  I spoke a bit to the main security
guy at the door, and he was friendly and helpful (trying to find a dj friend
that was scheduled to be spinning).

Security was a big deal for the roller rink.  They were bringing four people
at a time into the lobby and doing very complete searches.  Evidence of this
need was shown by all the taggers that bombed the rental truck outside.
The guy at the door was hard-nosed but professional.  The thing they didn't
to was control the line in the sense of people starting at the end of the
line instead of pushing in near the door.  My friends and I waited near the
end of the line for three hours, and we always seemed to be near the end of
the line while the number of people doubled.  I was beginning to get annoyed,
having been on the other end of parties like this and knowing how to control
this kind of problem, and seeing nothing was being attempted.

We finally got in, and took a trip around.  The sound was poorly tuned but
was a nice system.  With another hour or so, that system could have been
top-notch.  I didn't really notice Tony's set, as I was still trying to
cool down from the annoyance of the previous three hours.  Some really
funky beats were going down just as I started to get my body & mind ready,
but then they changed DJ's, and "Energy Flash" came on.  Of course, what
DJ opens his every set with his own old track - Joey Beltram.  I've heard
Joey enough to know I should just spend some more time with my friends
and not worry about dancing for a while.

Due to air conditioning problems and the possible noise complaints if the
doors were open, they shut off the sound for about 20 minutes and opened
all the doors while fixing the A/C.  Then DJ Hipp-E came on, and he was
great!  Some good techno & house, mixed well, that kept me dancing for the
duration of his set.  After that, some other dj came on, but I didn't care
for his style, so I just wandered.  We left soon after and got some breakfast.

Overall impressions:  lot's of kids (emphasis on kids), pretty friendly,
poor dj's & music selection (but remember, I am a cynical Detroiter, so
use salt), and poor business planning on the promoters part.

All in all, at least I got away from work for the weekend and got to hug
a couple of my friends that I seldom get to see!  What more could I really
ask for?


--

   person to circumvent the law or obtain a political favor : one that adjusts
   matters or disputes by negotiation

From: megatrip@best.com (David Dei)

Precedence: bulk

At first sight, the event seemed way too hip with an extremely uptight
crowd. Watching trance form while the full moon rose was kinda cool, but
the dark lighting disturbed me somewhat (no eye contact with anyone).
Anyway, just as I was about to go, struck up a great conversation with
Peter Booth Lee and Michael Mantra and took a break outside until 3am,
whereupon my return, everything seemed totally more ravey. The tribal djs
were doing their thang downstairs, and I couldnt resist dancing and
trancing. Moving upstairs, it seemed like the crowd was a bit stiff, but
after a serious bit of trancedancing, everyone seemed to lighten up and the
vibe accelerated until I was getting free hugs and a lot of those
previously cool coutureculture people were waving their arms in the air and
screeching. Three drummers parked themselves in front of the one speaker
stack and proceeded to do some harmonic navigation.
Have'nt danced so hard in a long while, and by 7 am I was totally bushed
and had to leave to rescue my camero from a parking zone.

Well, i think the event was a success, and certainly introduced jungle
trance to a whole bunch of people who probably had never been to a rave
before. I think they liked it, judging from the smiles and all.

david dei

Hi all,

I heard from a friend recently that the raves in the UK were muuuch more
intense than the raves round here; i.e. many more bpm over there, people
dancing with a LOT more vigour, and less trancey/chill stuff....he was
saying he wished it was more like that over here.  Has anyone raved over 
there?  I'd like a second opinion.
Talk to you guys later,
Rings, Mambas, Taco Bell burritos, pacifiers, and good vibes to all,

Timothy

hey everyone,

 wanted to say that sunset yesterday was as always a fun time :)
i drove with a few friends from SF and got to the site right near
the Richmond bridge. it was a little park by the bay with some rides
for kids.  nice tree's and nice views.  i was a bit tired but once
the sound got going it was cool.  i wasnt in the most friendly mood
when i got there but there were these guys blowing through some PCB
pips making the Digeridoo sounds and they let me blow on one for 
awhile and look at the bay.  it got me in a really good mood and
when i turned around 20 minutes later two hundred more people had shown
up :)  probably like 400 in all.  
  so i went around and ended up taking a lot of pictures and meeting
a lot of people.  the vibe was _very_ nice  and a lot of fun.  and, i
finally met some SFRAVERS! ;)  so that was cool.  
  but thanks to Pacific for getting their sound out and throwing 
another one.  after going to a party like xyz the night before, it was 
good to go to this and remember why i still love raving :)

peace and take care,

doug ) ( dougie@netcom.com

Dear All;
	
	Note, these are my personal opinions not facts, "The World Though 
My Eyes, Mind, Spirit, and Heart." I've said this before and I'll say it 
again, I don't expect or want you to change, I don't want you to follow 
me, and I don't want to lead you, I want you to find and be yourself, and I 
will continue to love you for whomever you chose to be and are. This in 
my opinion is LOVE.

	The only person you can "change" is yourself, and with regard to
the world, all you can do is bring "Awareness" into peoples lives, and
hope and pray(spiritually) that the rest will take care of itself, but any
forced, or imposed change by an outside the self force is violent and
inappropreiate, and most times will be met with prevailing resistance, it
is our nature. I just watched Slinders List for the 1st time last night,
what a statement about the resolve of human beings to, no matter what the
outside forces of the world dictate or do, to still maintain an indenty,
thats different than the current status quo, even at the risk of life, and
lim. 

	We are all fantastic, wonderful beings, uniquely different, all
masterpieces in our own rights. 

	The best way, I think to change the world in a non-violent way is
to unconditionally love and respect people who are different than us, love
them for who they are, and not try and change them, because they have
every right to be whom ever they chose, this is our BIRTH RIGHT and our
nature, and even if someone is preachin hate. This way of being is something
that you never achieve or arrive at, its something that you approach over
life times, Jesus Christ's "NATURE" was about this, less all the religious
bullshit. 

	Pure Love isn't about expectations, or changin people, its seeing in 
ourselves that we are truely wonderful, and when we see that in 
ourselves it shines out of us like rays and enables us to see it, and 
love others for it no matter who they are. I try and work on this 
everyday of my life. Nuff said.

		Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace
		a.k.a Brian Darkness, LMT/BSEE/CET
	       (510)-547-5984 CT Active Voice & Fax

		Internet:	brianv@liberty.com
		Alt. Internet:	brianvan@liberty.com

		 "Come see the world in my eyes"
	     "You never remember how much you forget"

Dear All;

	Drugs, & Doctors, the reason people have to take 8 Tylenols is 
the fact that "addictive pain med's" are doled out by Doctots like there 
diamonds. The med's I'm talking about are Tylenol #3,& 4; Vicodin, Lortab, 
Lorcet, Hydrocet, Talwin, Percodan, Percocet, Demerol, Daladin, Morphine, 
& Darvon/Darvocet.

	There doled out this way because Doctors are afaird of losing 
there DEA licenses, not beacsue there extremely addictive. The fact is 
people suffer from cronic pain can get relieve from these med's, but 
often have to go 1st to pain clinics and try all sorts of DANGEROUS 
experimental drugs, that require almost dailly monitoring of sertate 
bodily functions to make sure these druvgs are not damaging the body. THe 
non-steroidal antiinflamitories, like Motrin, Toradal, Anaprox ..etc, 
supress your bodies immune system, and are contraindicated in people with 
AIDS, and anyone with a depressed immune system, but our ethical doctors 
don't tell you this, plus they are also very damaging to the GI tract.

	In the state of California it is not illegal to go from doctor to 
docotor and get the above mentioned narcotic pain meds, but the 
pharmasist and doctors routinely talk about people over the phone, 
exchanging information about you, violating your right to privancy, my how 
ethical these people are.

	This has happened to me a lot, I remember calling a pharmacy up, 
Payless in Lafayette, and told the pharmasist I was Doctor so so and asked 
what medications Brian had received from whatever doctors they had listed 
on theere computers, I used a doctors name in Florida I used to see, so 
it was not a name or a voice the pharamist would regonize, and she told 
me everything about me, without asking for any id, this is illegal, but 
because of the witchhunt that goes on in our country with regard to drug 
users, your consitutional rights are out the window. I encourage you to 
try this, call a pharmacy you use, say you are a doctor whomever, and ask 
about yourself, make sure you are recording the conversation if you have 
the kind of equipment, and see for yourselfs just what happens.

	If you need to go from doctor to doctor to get relieve from 
cronic pain, which will put you in the grave faster than being addicted 
to narcotic pain meds, and thats a well known medical fact, I have the 
following advice for you. Go to small privately owned pharmacies, not the 
chain stores because they are part of a network/computer, in other words 
the following drug stores have linked computers:

	1.	Walgreens(Nationwide LInk)
	2.	Thifty JR(Not appartent but Linked, they have to enter  
		codes to look at another store)
	3.	Payless(The same as above)
	4.	Longs(Not Linked Yet)
	5. 	Safeway(Linked)
	6.	Lucky's(Not Linked)

Be careful, like I said its not illegal yet, but unfortuately they 
routinely send out faxes with peoples names on them that have received a 
lot of narcotic pain med's. Its really ashame that there are substances  
available and can improve the quality of someones life, but due to the 
conservative, we can't have any druggies out there witchhunt, and I don't 
care what anyone saids its a witchhunt, that people have to suffer.

Eventually there will be a think call PharmNet, were doctors will put 
your prescribtion on a Nationwide computer network, and you will go to a 
pharamcy of your choice, they will call the network up, and get it that 
way. This is being done to prevent prescribtion forgery, and to get the 
druggies.

Peace & Love
Brian Darkness

Date: Mon, 17 Apr 1995 16:16:09 PDT
From: "Diane Tabellija" <Diane_Tabellija@adoc.xerox.com>
Message-Id: <9503177981.AA798162855@beluga.adoc.xerox.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Ecstatic Dancing and Energy Blocks
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     A funny thing happened to me when I attended a rave and I was 
     wondering if anyone has experienced something similiar.  First let me 
     give you some background:  1)  I'm allergic to metals worn against my 
     skin; and 2)  I dance on a regular basis with a dance collective.  
     
     The primary dancing I do is called contact improvisation and it's a 
     blend of modern dance, akido, and sensory awareness (in a nutshell).  
     So being aware of my body and my environment (with the floor, the 
     walls, and people, etc.) is very important.  In some ways, dancing at 
     raves is limiting (physically for me) and in other ways, it opens me 
     up :)
     
     I think I've seen it mentioned in this newsgroup before about the 
     relationship between the pounding bass, tribal dancing, and opening 
     chakras or maybe it's what I've read somewhere.  Regardless of these 
     influences, when I dance at raves I try to loosen my body up and 
     move/shake enough to open up my lower chakras.  When I do this, I find 
     it's much easier to open my crown chakra that brings me into a 
     wonderful state of bliss.
     
     At Wicked, I wore a loose silver double-helix bracelet.  Usually I 
     store my tension below my left shoulder, but for most of the evening I 
     kept feeling tension on my right shoulder.  Aware of the blockage, I 
     asked several people (at separate times) to place their hand over my 
     "wing" so I could concentrate on removing this block.  With no change, 
     I chilled with a friend and while hanging out, I realized that my 
     bracelet was hindering me.  I quickly switched the bracelet to my 
     other wrist only to realize that wearing it was a total mistake and so 
     I had my friend wear it for the remainder of the time.  
     
     After this experience, I started thinking about trance dancing and 
     what others do to get into the state of "ecstatic dance".  For _me_ 
     it's just another realization of how repetition be it chanting, 
     dancing, drumming, etc. allows us to get beyond our personal state of 
     mind and into a group consciousness/awareness.
     
     I'd like to hear from others who may have had a blockage experience 
     (esp. w/metals) as well as others who have their tried and true 
     _natural_ method of getting into a trance state.  If the group wants, 
     I can post what feedback I get.
     
     TTFN,
     Diane

> What are your musts for happy ravers?
> PLUR
> Timothy

toilet paper or napkins, if it's outdoors or a break-in or run by dodgy 
promoters

herbs i may need for the night: echinacia/goldenseal beforehand for 
immune strength, some ephedra combo for energy, maybe bee pollen, maybe 
gingko biloba and gotu kola to wake me up in a.m....

water (i just about always bring my own, and i totally resent ravers who 
don't think to bring any and then expect me to share, and then especially 
when they don't offer to go refill it at the bar)

maybe something to munch on (banana?)

extra $$$ for whatever

and i think that's about it.


monicat

> I heard from a friend recently that the raves in the UK were muuuch more
> intense than the raves round here; i.e. many more bpm over there, people
> dancing with a LOT more vigour, and less trancey/chill stuff....he was
> saying he wished it was more like that over here.  Has anyone raved over 
> there?  I'd like a second opinion.
> Talk to you guys later,
> Rings, Mambas, Taco Bell burritos, pacifiers, and good vibes to all,
n> 
> Timothy
> 

well, i partied in the u.k., and granted it was 2 or 3 years ago, but it 
really seemed like the vibe/energy/musick depended where you went.  my 
favorite parties were outdoor parties with some d.i.y. djs, which were 
pretty housey, as well as Tonka parties, which were also pretty housey 
(but not many divas, thank gaia.  probably progressive house.)  also went 
to a large "RAVE" at school with hard ragga stuff - lots of energy, lots 
of kids, lots of fashion....and then there was club Trade at Turnmills in 
London which was queer (male) and absolutely insane: LOTS of energy, from 
house to hard hard musick at 9am, lots of sweat, and plenty of payoffs to 
the cops to stay open.  

in general, tho', it might be fair to say that there was a lot more 
enthusiasm for raving there, maybe because more people do it, maybe 
because of the criminal justice bill, don't know...maybe too many 
americans are just "too cool" to let loose....?

monicat

>        The best way, I think to change the world in a non-violent way is

>every right to be whom ever they chose, this is our BIRTH RIGHT and our

>that you never achieve or arrive at, its something that you approach over
>life times, Jesus Christ's "NATURE" was about this, less all the religious

WOW, well put.  I only have this tidbit to add: normally we are taught to
view ppl as either bad or good but, after reading some taoist books, i was
introduced to the idea that everyone is a window that has the light of tao
(or energy, or vibe, or the holy spirit, or whatever) that shines thorough
it.  Some people are clear (like they're heavy on the spiritual windex or
something ;)  while others are kinda dusty, the light comes through in
spots but in others it's obfuscated...i guess we should all help each other
wash our windows :)

        peace,

                brad

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: sunset
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Sunset was wonderful as always.  Maybe I'm getting old, but I really don't
need much else.  Once you get used to being able to relax outside and really
talk to people without yelling, it makes it harder to go back to the usual
melee.  And I still get in plenty of dancing in too.  It doesn't matter if
its been a sucky week or even if I'm depressed and have to drive to Sunset by
myself :-(  I always wind up feeling energized and in a great mood watching
the sun set behind Mt. Tam, dancing away to funky electro house beats.  The
music was a little inconsistent at times but you know I really didn't care it
just felt casual.

boogie by the bay,
phuture

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Progress/Celestine Prophecy
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Got a flyer for this party, the first of nine to coincide with the nine
insights of the Celestine Prophecy.  If  you haven't heard of the Celestine
Prophecy, its a very amazing book that I can't recommend enough. Go get it
and read it! It really sums up a lot of things I think and feel, especially
in relation to what I have experienced, felt and learned at the gatherings we
are all so fond of.  Its really accessible too since its disguised as a fun
to read adventure in south america story.  Come to think of it, its not a bad
place to start if you wanted to introduce a non-raver to some of more
meaningful aspects of raving.
  
That said, I really hope the promoters of this party are truly into bringing
the wonderful insights of the Celestine Prophecy to their gatherings in some
meaningul way and aren't just latching onto "whatever the current new age fad
is"

phuture

ecto@python.magnet.ca (ecto):
>WOW, well put.  I only have this tidbit to add: normally we are taught to
>view ppl as either bad or good but, after reading some taoist books, i was
>introduced to the idea that everyone is a window that has the light of tao
>(or energy, or vibe, or the holy spirit, or whatever) that shines thorough
>it.  Some people are clear (like they're heavy on the spiritual windex or
>something ;)  while others are kinda dusty, the light comes through in
>spots but in others it's obfuscated...i guess we should all help each other
>wash our windows :)

And some people are mirrors, some people are diffraction gratings,
generating beautiful rainbows... some people, e.g. my ex-gf, are like
security glass -- you can see right through them but all they can see
back is themselves ... and some people are 4-Way-Window-Panes (U are what
you eat?).

"I'll be your mirror..."
		Nico / Lou Reed (?)

I've raved in Ibiza in 1988 (ok, it's not the UK, but there were plenty
of limeys raving there), and I got some pointers from some of the UK
folks to interesting places to check out in London (e.g. Spectrum,
Schoom (?? or something like that)) around that same time (summer '88).
It was fun, freaky, very different from anything I had dealt with
prior, including SF Clubland. But to tell you the truth, I enjoy the SF
rave scene more. Perhaps simply because I know a bunch of people in it
and it is more familiar to me, musically and socially. Basically, SF,
for me, has a better vibe, and it's more friendly. I didn't find
any of the eenglish ravers I met in London to be very friendly
or vibey...

So i'm sittin' here listening to Fraser Clark v The Irresistible
Force's War N' Peace (CND Edit) from "Give Peace A Dance Volume I"...
and I think I know and agree-with where Fraser's coming from when he
posts the things he posts... (i'm assuming they're the same, though the
CD I have spells the last name "Clarke"??).

Well, whether they're the same people or not, I agree with
either/both... I really don't know or understand why people are
hassling/dissing him on this list so much... 

If anything, this and coming generations need RC's (and I ain't talkin
cola either) big-picture expanded-mind-meets-reality-and-finds-a-god-
worth-woshipping-within-all-nature-man-beast-plant-and-art meme (gaian
if you must) to flourish if we are to survive....

Either that, or we can just party till we puke.

PS: If Clark and Clarke are different, well, uhhh... never mind....

From: "Michael E. Clay" <meclay@netcom.com>
Subject: Raves in Yoga Journal
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
cc: Friends&Family <ff-planners@priscilla.ultima.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9504181701.A12128-0100000@netcom19>
MIME-Version: 1.0
