Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


A student just gave me a copy of June 1995 ( I really hope I haven't skipped
2 months of real world living ) of Yoga Journal and on page 76 is an article 
titled "Sacred Raves"... fairly interesting reading but ..  PG warning: 
last 2/3 devoted to Fraser Clark ( spelled correctly ) and Matthew Fox(more).

Generally, I was glad to see raving get a more "optimistic" focus....

"These all night dance marathons look like hedonistic escape, but raves may
just be the defining spiritual expression of a new generation."

Talks about going to a SOMA warehouse ??? (artistic fact mixing here) 
because these quotes come up :

" I go to raves because I like to dance!" says Ronan Hollowell sitting in a
dimly lit corner of the warehouse where ravers are chilling out from the
dance floor on huge bean-bag chairs..... when he (Ronan) explains ...
" In American culture today kids are suffering from a disconnection from
their roots, their true identity. Ideally raves foreshadow an alternative
social organization, a model for exploring another level of consciousness."

Next paragraph:

  " A Chicano woman with long, dark hair and glitter speckled across her 
cheeks approaches me and politely introduces herself as if we were at a 
small- town church social. " Is this your first time at Friends and Family?
You know this isn't just a party. It's a community and subculture. It's
about taping into something greater than yourself."

 
Article goes on into some history of raves, introducing Fraser (photo)
and the zippies, megatripolis (sf) then into longest section on 9 o'clocks
and planetary mass of both Anglican church and Matthew Fox......

++++++++

So at least from one small published voice comes the image of the "rave" as
something other than "drugged crazed escapists"...... 

this will be an interesting summer  Yes ?   


Mike


 meclay@netcom.com          |  Alone & estatic 
 Mike Clay   (415)572-8971  |  A young rainbow learns  to levitate.

and *intelligent* and likely to give a straighter reporter pause for 
thought.  I'd suggest we all get a copy of this article
and e-zap it off to any bad press that RC attracts over the summer.  it's
"Raving as Spiritual Exploration" - just the ammo we need.

>Got a flyer for this party, the first of nine to coincide with the nine
>insights of the Celestine Prophecy.  If  you haven't heard of the Celestine

>and read it! It really sums up a lot of things I think and feel, especially
>in relation to what I have experienced, felt and learned at the gatherings we
>are all so fond of.  Its really accessible too since its disguised as a fun
>to read adventure in south america story.  Come to think of it, its not a bad
>place to start if you wanted to introduce a non-raver to some of more
>meaningful aspects of raving.
>

        Hi there, this is brad.  I know Jane (the promoter from Next
School) and not only does she beleive in the ideas contained within the
book, she wants to share them with others, but doesn't want to ram it down
their throat.  In a way, this is advertising for this book and, yeah, this
is a capitalist society in which thing are often turned into profit making
machines but i think that, for the most part, she is genuine about her
intentions.  She's the one that introduced me to the book and it's
definitely impacted my life a lot (though i still prefer the Tao Te Ching
which the book, among other eastern texts, has been an obvious influence on
the writing of the Celestine Prophecy.
        I think that she, as well as i, have realized that there are a lot
of ppl that have had their lives altered, if not outright CHANGED, by the
book and this is one way of giving it exposure to a group of ppl who'd be
appreciative of it.

        peace,
                brad

Message-Id: <199504190625.XAA05168@netcom23.netcom.com>
To: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Fwd: Announce of RAVE CULTURE & THE END OF THE WORLD talk
Date: Tue, 18 Apr 95 23:25:01 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

a talk by fraser...
------- Forwarded Message

             RAVE CULTURE & THE END OF THE WORLD

Tuesday morning May 2, 1995     11:00 a.m. in the Roble Studio

          Presented by Friends of Dance at Stanford


Fraser Clark, psychologist and editor, is a social and political 
activist from Glasgow who is most widely known as the founder of the 
Zippy movement, Zen-Inspired Pronoia Professionals, an international 
community which resides primarily in the Internet, with a center in 
Clark*s London club Megatripolis. (Pronoia is the suspicion that others 
are conspiring to help you.) Mr. Clark not only promotes the continued 
spiritual evolution of individuals and communities, but is also an 
advocate for the primary physical expression of the Zippie movement, the 
all-night dances known as raves. 

Fraser Clark's eight-year involvement with raves includes the production 
of both small and massive raves around the world (including last year's 
Grand Canyon Mega Rave), the publication of three magazines on 
alternative lifestyles, the release of acid house singles with 
Timothy Leary, and the seminal house album "Shamanarchy In The UK" with 
the best of the technoshamanic bands, on his own record company. 

A year ago, Clark brought his philosophy, Megatripolis and the Parallel 
University to San Francisco, which he has adopted as his new home.

Mr. Clark will speak on the evolution of the rave culture, the current 
manifestations of this controversial lifestyle around the world, and the 
potential for positive change that an enlightened form of rave culture 
might contain.


This talk is free and open to the public.

------- End of Forwarded Message

> From:          lxfogel@srv.pacbell.com (Lee Fogel)
>
> I guess one rave-related connection was the herbal "e"(tm) booth

Yeah, that crap.  I been meaning to post something about it.  I take 
a lot of the same herbals that go into herbal "e" on my own to just
stay awake and alert.  I decided to take the herbal "e" to see if it 
was any better.  I did feel a kind of rush that was reminicent of E
and not similar to the caffine or ephedrine rushes I'm use to.  It
was pleasant for about 30 mins.  For the next two days though, 
I experienced headaches, nausea, and depression.  

Not worth $18 bucks.  If you want to spend $18 on legal herbals,
try the super dieter "energy" pills or the like.  Take five of those 
and you'll feel a rush and won't feel like shit the next day.  
Guarana is also real nice, I swear sometimes it even makes the
music sound better, but then again it could just be me.

Take my comments with a grain of salt, your milage may 
vary.

Purple Tiger
ptiger@nbn.com (now at a new site) :-)

, where
> for $18 you could get what was basically a couple of smart drinks in pill
> form.  The ingrediants were stuff you could get in any health-food store
> for about 1/5 the price (unless you care to believe the sales guy who
> explained to me that the ginseg was "from Tibet and more 
> concentrated" etc. etc...)  He also tried to convince me that this stuff 
> gives you "80% of the full effects of MDMA, everything except the 
> empathy part." Great.  
> 
> I guess this was a good event for a mainstream type party, and the $12 
> seemed fair for the variety of entertainment offered.  It just wasn't 
> our kind of scene.

just got back from butterfly at the casanova.  had never been before 
(what a shame - it's around the corner from my house!) and wanted to hear 
charlotte (the baroness) and dani.  REALLY NICE party - small, low-key, 
great dance floor, diverse crowd, good music/mixing (very house-y, not 
TOO deep, pretty trance-y) and a $2 cover.  think it goes til 2:00 but i 
could be mistaken.  anyway, it's every tues. at the casanova, valenica 
bet. 16 and 17th.  

one annoying thing, tho: after being at so many parties with 
(tobacco)smoke-free dance floors, i was pretty disturbed at and affected 
by the amount of smoke here.  but, it's a bar...

monicat

What's in Raver Geoff's backpack:

	1) Flashlight
	2) Dry Clothes
	3) Jacket (sometimes)
	4) Spare socks
	5) 1 liter of water (if it's not poured out :(
	6) A plastic zip-lock bag with...
		Carmex
		Rescue remedy (for people on bad trips)
		band-aids
		bactine
		bacatrin
		pen & paper
		toilet paper
		skin lotion
		multi-vitimins
		condoms
		
	7) Random book

        I reccommend looking into getting some Ma Huang (which is a chinese
herb of natural Ephedra).  Look for it either in raw form or, even better,
in liquid tincture which is marketed under the name "ballistic."  Last
summer i tried this
for the first time and i just kept saying "I can't beleive this stuff is legal!"
Of course, the hugs you have to provide for youself but you do get a 'rush'
chills, mucho energy etc..all for $20 CAN for a 1 oz bottle (which lasts me
like 1-2 months of going out every weekend..)

Hello,

I just picked up a new video "Pink Floyd - London '66/'67".

It is 30 minutes with the audio being from their very first studio session.

The video is partially also from that studio session (in sync with the audio)
and partially from the UFO Club in London,  arguably the first psych*d*lic
club ever (Perhaps Fraser was there, yes?).  Other parts of the video imagery
are from a 14 hour rave event, (using the term rave here in a larger sense).

The most remarkable part of the video is that it is crystal clear, both in
audio and video (naturally certain of the live scenes are dark, but so was
the room).

In fact, casual viewers might think the video was filmed recently, since the
fashions have come full circle since 1966.  For example, Roger Waters is
wearing those oval glasses that are all the rage now.

Someone who viewed the video with me said that it was now her favorite
depiction of being on L.

PS The video is an import, so it runs $27.  But, it probably can be rented at
good video places in the Bay Area.

Ken
ken@macshasta.com

Hello,

I keep seeing statements in posts like:

DDei>the dark lighting disturbed me somewhat (no eye contact with anyone).

In fact, Tristan's original post on F&F was critical of the eye contact
there, and another post about UK vs SF mentioned that a particular feature
of UK massives was eye contact.

However, I question whether this is really so important.

Perhaps, since the British are normally so reserved, then eye contact is 
deemed necessary to reassure one of trust and friendship.

Personally, I feel that a darker setting is more conducive to leaving behind
concerns with physical reality and trancing, which can only help the Vibe.

As evidence, I give you this sfr post from a year ago:

-----------------------------------------begin included message-------------

On June 20, 1994, Troy Sheets <tsheets@chaph.usc.edu> wrote:

Basics was simply the best event I have ever been to.  Basics seemed
to have a format, a program if you will.  It was not like a typical 
club where people come and go throughout the night.  Basics was
more like a service.  It had three distinct parts.  

Pat 1:  When I arrived I was a bit surprised that more people were 
not dancing.  But looking around I saw most of the people talking,
socializing, meeting up with friends and meeting new people.  
There seemed to be a feeling o knowing, of anticipation, maybe
the way a family might act before a wedding.  A feeling that everyone was
about to have a really good experience.  The music at
this point was a faster, progressive house.  

Part 2:  Large baners with fluorescent paint were lit up by many
blacklights up until this point.  At about 2:15am, when most people
had started dancing, the blacklights went out, the club fell into
darkness, and a large cheer came from the crowd.  Something was
happening.  The music changed.  I had heard this music a few times
before.  Nothing terribly different, just another step in the ever-
evolving realm of progressive dance tracks.  It was a bit darker,
trancier, almost pagan, but, amazingly, it retained funk and house
elements.  I guess this is "The San Francisco Sound", whatever
that means.  But this was, above all else, dance music.  This was
music that got me moving unlike anythig else I have really
heard.  My mind let go and my body took over.  
I'm not going to try and explain how I felt.  I thought how I would
explain this in a "xxxxxx-raves" post.  The one comment that
came to mind that seemed really appropriate was "dancing
with God".  I was in a state where I could not think of anything
that could possibly make this experience better.  A feeling that
everything within me and around me was in perfect balance.
I was not the only one.  The vibe around
me was unlike anything I have ever experienced, so much so that
the term "vibe" was totally redefined for me.  I could ramble on for
a long time about how I felt for the next 3 hours, but it is one of 
those things that you have to experience to really understand.

Part 3:  At around 4:45 the black-lights went back on, the DJ
poured on the House.  House spun just like I, personally, love it.
It was the perfect music to follow up what we had gone through.
The one word to describe the atmosphere was "celebration".  We
left our euphoric trances to share and dance with each other.
A more perfect sense of acceptance and co-existance I have
never flt.  We had experienced true joy for ourselves, and now it
was time to share it with the people around us.  Morning came,
and the club was over.

There is a either a new generation of raves ("Raves:TNG"?), or the
evolution has passed over Southern California.  Either way, there
is something happening out there, up here, that is wonderful.
I hope to see many so-cal friends visit up here soon!

-------------------------------------------end included message-------------

respect to all,

Ken
ken@macshasta.com
send bounces to ken.stuart@tigerteam.org

> 
> Hello,
> 
> I keep seeing statements in posts like:
> 
> DDei>the dark lighting disturbed me somewhat (no eye contact with anyone).

> 
> However, I question whether this is really so important.

>
> Personally, I feel that a darker setting is more conducive to leaving behind
> concerns with physical reality and trancing, which can only help the vibe.
 
I also find that a dark setting can be more preferable at times, but I 
also like to have times when I can see the people I'm dancing with.
A darker setting sometimes helps me get more centered within myself.  
Once I'm more centered within myself, I'm more open to share that center 
with everyone else.  This is when I like to be able to see others more 
clearly and experiencing that sense of sharing to a greater extent.  
Probably why I usually experience a warm special feeling when the sun 
comes up and I can see the people I been dancing with all night.


peter

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Apr 19 15:19:03 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id PAA23381; Wed, 19 Apr 1995 15:19:03 -0700
Received: from liberty.liberty.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with SMTP id PAA23364; Wed, 19 Apr 1995 15:18:53 -0700
Received: by liberty.liberty.com (Linux Smail3.1.28.1 #10)
	id m0s1hff-002qirC; Wed, 19 Apr 95 13:52 PST
Date: Wed, 19 Apr 1995 13:52:26 -48000
From: Brian Darkness <brianvan@liberty.liberty.com>
Reply-To: Brian Darkness <brianvan@liberty.liberty.com>
Subject: TAGGERS, An Unfortuate Inevitable Part of Our Culture
To: hyperreal <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9504191138.A12505-0100000@liberty.liberty.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; CHARSET=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Dear All;

	I have a love hate relationship with taggers, first the hate part,
it is vandalisum, destuction and deformationm of private/personal
property. It is someone "hurting" someone else in a very selfish,
negative, and egotistical way, no matter how you paint it, no pun
intended. This behaviour has no place in a scene that prides itself, on
love, tolerence, understanding, beauty & above all respect for self and
others. 

	On the other hand I remember the Michele Shocked song about the
graffito artist that was beated to death by the New York city transist
po-lice, and everytime I hear it, it still outrages me. Graffito can be
liberally viewed as a form of free speach. In countries where there is
much oppression, it is often the only safe way a common person can speak
out against the government.  Graffito can also be very beautiful,
especially when its done in the form of a mural. 

	I say that instead of fighting these things, that we provide a
space were these "artists" can express themselves without damaging or
hurting the image of our scene. Because realistically you can't stop them,
but if we provided a space for them to comfortablly express themselves,
the quality of their work will improve, due to the fact that they will not
have the fear of getting caught, and be able to do something meaningful,
we all can enjoy, and something that they can take pride in.  This would
not cost very much, it would validate them, and at the end of the night we
would have a beautiful collage. 

	It doesn't cost that much for some paper, a hard surface of some
type, and a few markers which would be returned to a person in charge of
collecting them, and giving them out, you could do something like take the
persons ID if they want a marker, and don't get it back until they return
the marker. I still say that we should check people at the door for paint
and markers, and strongly discourage this activity outsside of these
asigned areas. Also that we need to get the word out to people who attend
our events that taggers are causing our scene to lose all of the all ages
spaces, a simple flyer program, given out at the door I feel could reduce
the number/damage of incidents caused my taggers. 

	We must target the younger people, because I feel most older 
people don't partake in this type of behaviour. An ironically its the 
younger people who are really hurt by this behaviour ie Richmond Civic 
Center, just another all ages space that we no longer can enjoy. The 
promoters must let people know at the door that it there is graffito that 
we will not be allowed back, I think this will generate some positive 
pear pressure not to tag. Nuff said, anyone else have any ideas or 
positive comments/feelings they would like to share?

Peace & Love
Brian Darkness

> 
>         I reccommend looking into getting some Ma Huang (which is a chinese
> herb of natural Ephedra).  Look for it either in raw form or, even better,
> in liquid tincture which is marketed under the name "ballistic."  Last
> summer i tried this
> for the first time and i just kept saying "I can't beleive this stuff is legal!"
> Of course, the hugs you have to provide for youself but you do get a 'rush'
> chills, mucho energy etc..all for $20 CAN for a 1 oz bottle (which lasts me
> like 1-2 months of going out every weekend..)
> 
yeah, ma huang is fun, but just be careful with it.  it can really work 
your immune system, particularly if you have a more "yin" constitution.  
also, it should not be taken with any MAO-inhibitor.  

from "The Way Of Herbs:"  ephedra is useful for asthma, bronchitis, 
coughs and other congestive conditions.  it should be used only for those 
with a yang constitution and are not deficient, as it is a strong 
stimulant that would debilitate the adrenals of one who is already 
exhausted and low in energy.  it is good for colds and flus and for those 
fevers that are without sweating.  ephedra increaes blood pressure, and 
therefore should not be used by people with hypertension.

mind you, i'm pretty sure i have a yin const., and i often use ephedra, 
but then only if i take some immune system boosters.

monicat

Nutrition News Hotline

Produced by Sheri Zidenberg-Cherr, Ph.D., Nutrition Science
Specialist, Cooperative Extension, Department of Nutrition,
University of California, Davis, Ca. 95616-8669

March 1995

FDA Warns Against Herb-Kola Nut Mix
-----------------------------------

Americans should not consume a dietary supplement that contains
the Chinese herb ma huang in combination with kola nut, the Food
and Drug Administration warned yesterday.

The FDA issued the warning after more than 100 reports of injuries
ranging from heart attacks to hepatitis -- and several deaths --
among people who ate the supplement "Nature's Nutrition Formula
One."

Proponents claim the supplement boosts energy and helps weight loss.
But the FDA said the cocktail of ephedrine, an amphetamine-like
chemical found in ma huang, and the caffeine from the kola nut
poses a danger even when the supplement is used as directed.

When Nature's Nutrition maker Alliance USA refused to recall the
product the FDA issued the consumer warning.  It urged people not
to buy or consume "Nature's Nutrition Formula One" if the
product lists both ma huang and kola nut as ingredients.

Alliance contended that the recall was not needed because that
version of the product is no longer on store shelves.  However,
the FDA received reports of sales last month, and noted that
customers may still have unused "Formula One" at home.

Alliance said it has changed the recipe of "Formula One," now
selling a supplement that contains only ma huang.  The FDA is
not warning against use of the reformulated "Formula One" product.
Consumers can tell the two versions apart by comparing the ingred-
ient lists.

The FDA will evaluate the safety of the new "Formula One" as part
of its review of all products that contain ma huang or ephedrine.

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Land of the Giants review
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Land of the Giants - A Giant rave in Melbourne
==============================================

This last Wednesday,  I headed for Melbourne to visit some friends and take
in a rave on Thursday evening.

I left Sydney early Wednesday morning for a very long 12 hour bus ride to
Melbourne.   While on the bus,   I got a lot of programming done until my
batteries were almost drained on my Powerbook.   

I arrived in Melbourne about a half hour late,   but Martin met me and took
me over to visit some of his friends.   We chilled around for a while,  as
I had opportunity to check my Email and upload queued messages to the net.

Afterwards,   I went to yet another friends place to crash.   

Melbourne is sorta the cultural part of Australia,  with older buildings
having that European look.   Like Sydney,   its spread out and covers a
very large area.   The public transpo system usually has trolly cars
instead of trains.

I meet a few new AusRavers and eveentually head over to the rave,   but
didn't get there until about 12:30.   The rave is in this huge multi-story
warehouse and people were queuing up outside waiting to get in.

Eventually we get all our people together,   and I was able to get two
others on the guest list.    Inside,  downstairs  was the chill lounge
so we check it out first.   The downstair chill area had food
and clothes venders,  as well as other rave related goods.   

I headed upstairs for the main room,   which at the time was playing 
housey trancey stuff,  similar to the SF music.   I stashed my stuff 
near the vidio booth,  and headed out to the dance floor to warm up.   

I head immediatly for the main area and started to get down and
dance.   The vibe in Melboure was amazing,   got lots of smiles wearing my 
checkered hat.    Music was this trancey housey stuff,  not unlike the SF
scene except slightly faster (around 130 BPM or so).  The DJ actually played
the "Wink" laughing song,   but the mix was so seamless that it was halfway
through before I realized what he was playing.  Everyone literally went off,
yelling and screaming.   I think there is a lot more enthousiasm over here
in Australia,  then in SF.

Evetually decided to chill and scope the rest of the place out.    As I was
walking around,   much to my delight,  I discovered yet another room.    
So THIS was where the Hard Trance was located.    I immediatly got into 
the groove,  as the "Ekkie" started to take hold,   and was so intranced 
by the music that I couldn't even think of chilling.   I think I must 
have been dancing for about 3 1/2 hours before my body temperature got 
so high that I HAD to stop.   This must have been the highest trance state 
I've ever been since raving,   and dancing to the faster 160+ BPM's really 
makes a difference.    I only wish they have more of it in SF.  

All evening long,   I was dancing like there was no tommorrow,   getting a lot
of smiles and eye contact with these wonderful people in Melbourne.

As usual,  I get people coming up asking me where I'm from and how Old I am,
and get the usual disbelief when I tell them my age.   They were most eager 
to learn about the SF scene,  and really enjoyed talking to these great people.

I figured there must have been at least 2500 people at this rave,   and my 
friends remarked that it was the biggest rave seen in Melbourne for a very long
time.   The energy was awsome,   especally in the trance room,  which had mostly
Goa style German trance (Absolutly my favorite).   Later on,   the BPM's picked
up to about 200 + BPM and jungle music was played,  mixed in with some pretty
insane breakbeat.

As usual,   I went off BIG TIME,  and danced the entire Jungle/breakbeat
set non-stop.   How!! Jugle is so much DIFFERENT than the stuff they play in
SF.    It's hard to describe,  other then there are fewer breaks,   but when
the beats stop,   it's for a longer time.

When the next DJ went on,   who started playing the slower housier sound,
I left and took a much diserved break from dancing,  and stretched out in
the chill room,  schmoosing around with my friends.   The vibe was totally
insane...  Really high energy...   After taking a break from the german
techno,   which was almost a half hour,   I decided to check out the main
room again.

By this time,  the music in the main room started picking up,  and this wonderful
multi-colored lazer was blowing my mind with this amazing taste of "eye candy"
that really enhanced my visuals,  as I was chasing the lazer beams all over the
dance floor like a crazy idiot.   My energy level literally went off the scale
as I was boogie'ing around the dance floor.    Man!!  There was so much room to
move around.       

As morning approached,  my energy level picked up even more,   but as
I noticed not that meny people dancing,   I started urging the people on the
side lines to get up and dance.    I must have pulled up 20 - 30 more people
from the sidelnes and single handedly pumped in much more energy,  dispite
the slower BPM's.   All it took was eye contact,  a big grin and they would
dance harder.    People really responded when I made eye contact.

Then,  after about 2 more hours of solid un-interrupted dancing in the main
room,  chasing the lazer beams around the huge dance area,   I took another
break and headed outside for a while to cool off and get some fresh air.

I met my other Ausraver friends who were also hanging out,  and they mentioned
that this rave was one of the better raves they've seen in a while,   but
complained that the music was too slow.    I have to agree with that,  as I think
about 70% was mostly housey.   I was also told that the Melbourne scene was
more layed back,   and had less Happy Hardcore then Sydney.   In fact,  I heard
NO happy hard at this rave,  but that didn't mean they had none.

I told my AusRaveer friends I wanted to go in and dance some more,   and one
said "Already?".   I said "Sure!!  - gotta get down and do some serious dancing
some more!".    As I was heading upstairs (about 7 am) lots of people were leaving
but there was enough people to continue the good energy and vibe,  once I started
urging more people to get up and dance,   and danced yet another 2 more hours
until my friends finally pulled me off the dance floor and said "It's time to
go now"  

Totally hosed from dancing,  my AusRave hosts finally pursuaded me that
we should leave,   and was told that things would wind down at 10 am.    So
I reluctantly left with them,   with a big fat grin on my face.    WOW!! Land
of the Giants was one of the best raves I've been to since I came to Australia.

The promoters were most eager to meet me,  as word is spreadng all over Ausralia
about my being here.    The decore had these huge dinosaurs,  and other large
monster creatures all around.   I must say,  for a professional production,  it
had quite a good underground feel to it,   and the venue was huge,  although 
chillout opportunities weren't what I would think was adequate,   but if the
promoters would put in some good floor fans,   this rave would have to be
what I call "rave heaven".    Although no "happy Hardcore" which I'm told isn't
that well situated in Melbourne,  the German hard acid trance more than made up
for it.    So if you're ever in Melbourne and there is another "Land of the Giants"
scheduled,   I would recommend everyone to go.    I had a GREAT time,  an abundance
of energy,   and wonderful music and vibe.    I would have to give the following
score....

  Venue  - 7 (could have used some floor fans)
  Lighting - 9 (wonderful multi-color lazers and black light effects
  Music 8 - Could have been a tad harder
  Vibe  9 - really great,  got lots of smiles and gave out a lot of good energy
  
Crunchman

dear sfravers,

oh, sunset was really wonderful again.  they had it out at a park on  the 
water in richmond, mondo-quirky bay area city.  and to my knowledge la 
police did not once appear.  what is the story with this park, does 
anybody know?  can we possibly have a late-night gathering there w/o 
attracting the notice of anyone who might want to hurt us or merely chase 
us away?

i love the sunset party so much!  this week, perhaps due to the proximity 
to marin, there were larger numbers than usual of marin-y people.  lots 
of awfully glamorous young men and women on E, for example.  my el 
cerrito youth posse tell me they can afford only L.  it's a social class 
thing, i guess.

solar and galen played the SH*T, the best sets i've heard yet from both 
of them, i think.  from the first minute, i was mesmerized.  

the digeridon't people were there, too- at least, there were some people 
playing long tubes.  it was an acoustic treat to be able to hear them in 
one ear and the system in the other ear.  they were cool.

the neatest thing about the  party for me was finally getting to 
re-experience force of one of the  ley lines  that connects marin with
the east bay. 

in case you're curious, one runs under the richmond bridge.  i think it must
make a detour to the park we were at, because there was definitely some 
serious energy going on.  everybody was so happy after a long weekend of 
play play play.  

love,

ann

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com

Brian, Brian, Brian, Brian, Brian...

First of all, let me compliment you on your musical literacy. However the
song, Graffiti Limbo (from 1988's brilliant Short Sharp Shocked), was NOT
glorifying tagging. The song mourned the excessive brutality of the NYPD, and
the clear racial bias demonstrated by the police. The event, graffiti, could
really have been anything...an African American driving through a
predominantly Caucasian neighborhood, etc.

Now, I do agree that tagging can be an expression of free speech, and, in the
best cases, an artistic expression. But you are more than a wee bit over
romantic in your view of tagging. On a day-to-day level, tagging is just
that...the marking of something, mostly territory by rival gangs.
Unfortunately it is more often an act of hubris than an artistic expression.
So your solution of organized tagging would not attract the negative element
that both you and I deplore.

The truly artistic graffiti artists, many times, are donated garage doors or
empty walls by sympathetic members of the community. Unfortunately, the press
covers such artistic expressions most often in the wake of a senseless crime,
where a member of the victim's family or friends create a brilliant work of
graffiti to commemorate the deceased.

Spend a week in good ol' NYC and take the subway into the Bronx. You'll see
the unfortunate reality of what I'm saying.

Peace to you and all in SFRAVESland,

Bone2130@aol.com
Tony in NYC

hello everybody!

well, the new moon is coming up on april 28, and although we have lots of 
ideas about various (renegade) outdoor locations, we are as yet sound 
system-less.

we are as of this time a loose, but warm, collective of friends and 
aquaintances who just like getting together to DANCE and also chill out 
to both hipswiveling house and chilled out ambient, with all the 
gradations in between.  some of my personal fave highlights  of the party 
over the last year include:

(1) tracy ameba's relentlessly energized house music set at the Bolinas 
Mystery School, January 1995. (sound by Pacific, Ronan)

(2) charles uzzel-edwards, bryce and darkhorse ambient stylings at an 
underwater atlantis location in the lower haight, november, '94. (sound
by Bryce, aka MetroVision)

(3) hard trance and italian lessons at the chateau in berkeley, after we 
were chased away from pt reyes.  this was ronan's first dj appearance in 
sf, as i recall.  (correct me if i'm wrong!), july, '94 (sound by MESS, 
MetroVision)

(4) and finally, scott hardkiss' legendary dark side of the moon/sympathy 
for the devil set, followed by Galen of Pacific's Iron DJ set,  on the 
beach at goat rock, a mere three 
hours after glen and heather's new moon wedding. (sound by Pacific) 

anyway, we're not too proud to beg...so if YOU would like to get a little 
sandy, perhaps, or maybe not, pluuleeze give me a call.  also, if you 
have the elements of a system, but not the whole thing, pluuleeze give me 
a call.  we may just kinda piece together what we can and rent the rest.  

the new moon is about music and love and lotsa other cool things and the 
planet is expecting us to do something!  and we certainly cannot afford 
to disappoint Her...she's been awfully patient with us thus far.

if you want to get involved, want directions to the party, or just want 
to put in your evolved two cents,

please do.

love, 

ann
510-525-7780


ps i'll be at 1015 fulsom tonite!

Dear Bone;

On Wed, 19 Apr 1995 Bone2130@aol.com wrote:

Really I never would have guessed(reaking of sacassum).

> First of all, let me compliment you on your musical literacy. However the
> song, Graffiti Limbo (from 1988's brilliant Short Sharp Shocked), was NOT
> glorifying tagging. The song mourned the excessive brutality of the NYPD, and
> the clear racial bias demonstrated by the police. The event, graffiti, could
> really have been anything...an African American driving through a
> predominantly Caucasian neighborhood, etc.

An effective discussion shows both sides, nuff said.

> Now, I do agree that tagging can be an expression of free speech, and, in the
> best cases, an artistic expression. But you are more than a wee bit over
> romantic in your view of tagging. On a day-to-day level, tagging is just
> that...the marking of something, mostly territory by rival gangs.
> Unfortunately it is more often an act of hubris than an artistic expression.
> So your solution of organized tagging would not attract the negative element
> that both you and I deplore.

I have and then some, I helped redesign/retrofit the FL9-AC Locomotives for 
Metro-North and The Long Island Railroad, silly New Yorker, and as of 1.5 
years ago was a New Yorker.

> Spend a week in good ol' NYC and take the subway into the Bronx. You'll see
> the unfortunate reality of what I'm saying.

Sorry(sincerely) for my smug sarcusum, but your response reaks of it, and 
I'm in a bad mood, and it got under my skin.

Sin

From: Kevin Keiper <keiper@itsa.ucsf.EDU>
Subject: Re: uk vs. sf
To: Monica and Tom <litterbx@priscilla.ultima.org>
cc: Timothy McIntyre <timothym@ocf.berkeley.edu>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <m0s14xo-000ILNC@priscilla.ultima.org>

Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I was part of the biggest sound system in Britain up until 1992.  We 
organized parties where at least 2,000 people would show up every week.  
We orgasnized the world's first totally free sound circus where we had 
20,000 people for the whole weekend; all illegal and all totally free.
We played music similer to what they played at "Universe" (see Ameba 
music shop for tapes).  In England we have really good E and people take 
a lot of it and that is all they take so vibes at raves are a lot more 
intense and has rougher edges then in SF.  Your average raver there is 
much more together and knowledgable then over here.  He is older, knows 
all the tunes that he is hearing and can shove an amount of E down there 
throats that would put most people around here in hospital.  In short, 
it's all a lot more hardcore over there.  And that is bassically because 
your average raver there is poor and unemployed, not rich, middle-class 
and white like they are around here.  Also, over there your basic 17 year 
old is much more clued in anyway.  In short, the whole scene over here is 
about five years behind (don't think that this is the best choice of 
word's) and will never get to be as good as London because the whole scene 
here is to small.  In London one could go out every night and never hear 
the same dj twice but that is impossible to do in SF.
I could go on and on and on so what else do you want to know?  But take 
it from me: London kicks arse over SF any day.  

On Mon, 17 Apr 1995, Monica and Tom wrote:

> > I heard from a friend recently that the raves in the UK were muuuch more
> > intense than the raves round here; i.e. many more bpm over there, people
> > dancing with a LOT more vigour, and less trancey/chill stuff....he was
> > saying he wished it was more like that over here.  Has anyone raved over 
> > there?  I'd like a second opinion.
> > Talk to you guys later,
> > Rings, Mambas, Taco Bell burritos, pacifiers, and good vibes to all,
> n> 
> > Timothy
> > 
> 
> well, i partied in the u.k., and granted it was 2 or 3 years ago, but it 
> really seemed like the vibe/energy/musick depended where you went.  my 
> favorite parties were outdoor parties with some d.i.y. djs, which were 
> pretty housey, as well as Tonka parties, which were also pretty housey 
> (but not many divas, thank gaia.  probably progressive house.)  also went 
> to a large "RAVE" at school with hard ragga stuff - lots of energy, lots 
> of kids, lots of fashion....and then there was club Trade at Turnmills in 
> London which was queer (male) and absolutely insane: LOTS of energy, from 
> house to hard hard musick at 9am, lots of sweat, and plenty of payoffs to 
> the cops to stay open.  
> 
> in general, tho', it might be fair to say that there was a lot more 
> enthusiasm for raving there, maybe because more people do it, maybe 
> because of the criminal justice bill, don't know...maybe too many 
> americans are just "too cool" to let loose....?
> 
> monicat

U-ziq is playing this Sat. 4/22 as part of the Ambient Jungle Boat Party. 
Tickets are available at Housewares for $25. It is kind of pricey but it 
ain't cheap renting a boat and there are only 200 tix or so available.

Craig the promoter has tried hard to produce interesting gigs and it is 
rumored that he would like to bring over System 7 if he thought he wasn't 
going to lose a lot of money.

Jonah, Nick Philip and some other good people are playing also. Should be 
a worthwhile show if you've got the cash.

Thanx for alerting me to this article. I remember speaking with the author 
sometime last fall. She did a good job transcribing my words. She was 
truly interested in preseting a positive and insightful position on rave 
culture though she wasn't that familiar with it.

Now for some self promo. I will be publishing an article next month in 
Creation Spirituality Magazine entitled "Raves,Spirituality & the 
Re-birth of Celebration". I  can e-mail a copy of it to people who are 
interested.

This is the mag associated with Matt Fox. Though I consider my-self post 
denominational and not affiliated with any specific religion I will say 
that I am in general agreement with Matt's work. He is one of the most 
open-minded, non-dogmatic and visionary Christian's around.

Hope we can all live a life of celebration and love!

From: "JMRTNKO! please stand by..." <martinko@netcom.com>
Subject: Re: Taggers
To: ezzevvravess <sfraves@hyperreal.com>

Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Tagging has more in common with dogs pissing on trees than it does with 
graffiti art. Barring the few in SF with any redeeming aesthetic merit 
(Probe/Prohibiscus, the early Mr. Element, the running dogs, &c), it's just 
a load of disrespectful homogenous crap waiting to be sniffed and 
overwritten by the next tagger happening by.

Carmen and I started decorating our black and white Valiant three years 
ago with quotes, sayings and pictures that meant something to us. But 
sure enough, nearly every event we went to had us driving home with the 
stank of unwanted tags over our own work. After a couple years of regular 
paint-overs and touch-ups, we finally gave up.

Your suggestions are appreciated Brian, but it's never going to go away 
so easily (I've seen pictures of ancient Pompeiian graffiti). We may walk 
on two legs, but we're still as territorial as nearly any other species. 
And there will always be those without the brains or guts to make a name 
for themselves anywhere other than someone else's garage door.

jmar.

        Monica and Tom <litterbx@priscilla.ultima.org>
Subject: Re: uk vs. sf
Cc: Timothy McIntyre <timothym@ocf.berkeley.edu>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

You know, I promised myself not to respond to Tristan's interminable
patronizing of the SF scene, but his comparison of the UK and SF situations
needs some additional context.

Sure the scene in the UK is different and in some respects may be considered
better . . . but I wonder.  

A brief look at a recent issue of DJ magazine, the flagship of the UK scene,
gives you the flavor of what's happening there.  The scene has turned
relentlessly commercial, and is starting to take on some of the Hollyweird
aspects that rock did in the States in the mid-1970s, when Rolling Stone
stopped being a hippie rag and decided it was cooler to hang out with
the millionaires.  

Here we have a feature on DJ Graham Gold, with three KISS FM slots and
director of the Peach label which is part of the club/house PWL empire.
The feature is a diary of a Day in the Life, and here's one entry:
"12.30 pm.  We pile into Graham's black BMW with its personal plate.
'It's tax deductible' he explains.  Amongst the demo tapes on the floor
in the back is Map Of Britain and a Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles book.
As he reverses full speed back up The Vineyard the phone rings.  'Stupid
cow, I won't be able to drop it off today...'  As we screech across
London he says excitedly 'I'm going scuba diving in Israel next week,
I've been doing a course because I've never been there before.  Apparently
there's a rave scene out there, the Es are 30 pounds each..."

So there's a leading light of your precious UK scene.  All props to those
who maintain the underground and keep it moving and even make ends meet
while not succumbing to the flash lifestyle.

For the punters, it's 10 pounds in the door Friday, shite Es, the Drug
Squad everywhere, CJA killing off all the true undergrounds, and all
the rest.  It's like the US indie rock scene, except the sound is house.

But the money and the greed are the same.

I salute the UK underground, it must be tough keeping going with all that
heavy weight overhead.  We're very fortunate in SF and America in general
not to have that to contend with.  I saw what can happen.  Grunge was
really invented at the Satyricon club here in Portland, not ten blocks
from where I sit.  For years it grew and maintained within our little
Northwest context, suddenly it blew up with Nirvana and all the rest,
and here we are, none the better for it really.  I don't want that to
happen to the house/techno/r**e scene, like it already has in the UK.

Peace out.

phred

> > favorite parties were outdoor parties with some d.i.y. djs, which were 
> > pretty housey, as well as Tonka parties, which were also pretty housey 
> > (but not many divas, thank gaia.  probably progressive house.)  also went 
> > to a large "RAVE" at school with hard ragga stuff - lots of energy, lots 
> > of kids, lots of fashion....and then there was club Trade at Turnmills in 
> > London which was queer (male) and absolutely insane: LOTS of energy, from 
> > house to hard hard musick at 9am, lots of sweat, and plenty of payoffs to 
> > the cops to stay open.  
> > 
> > in general, tho', it might be fair to say that there was a lot more 
> > enthusiasm for raving there, maybe because more people do it, maybe 
> > because of the criminal justice bill, don't know...maybe too many 
> > americans are just "too cool" to let loose....?
> > 
> > monicat
> >

In-Reply-To: <Pine.3.89.9504191138.A12505-0100000@liberty.liberty.com>

ebee/mail/postponed-mail/PLAIN; CHARSET=US-ASCII

I think there is a definite difference between graffiti artists and 
taggers. there are a ton of good, talented, decent (ie they won't do a 
piece on your house) graffiti artists. Taggers, frankly, suck. I could go 
on and on - for a more concrete example - take a trip on the N Judah 
through the Duboce Tunnel - the tunnel itself is gorgeous, with some 
amazing art in it, but when you get to the outskirts of the tunnel at the 
entrances, all it is are really really weak tags, which my tax money is 
used for to paint over. 

Another example: In baltimore, there is a rave 
promoter there named Lonnie Fisher, he runs the Ultraworld crew with 
others...Ultraworld are *fantastic* guys, completely in it for the music 
and the whole of the scene, started as ravers themselves and now throw 
some of the best parties on the east coast - a perfect example of Doing 
It For The Right Reasons, And Doing It Right. Last summer Ultraworld 
threw a big one at an outdoor resort, 4-5,000 people showed up and had a 
*blast*, a magnificent time. tickets were reasonably priced at around $20 
and noone noticed because they had such a good time. Now, when an 
Ultraworld party makes money, it goes into a fund to do *more* Ultraworld 
parties...the promotors haven't gotten any fatter off their scene. You'd 
think with 5,000 they'd have made a profit. But did they? nope - the 
tagging damage done to the buildings and bathrooms, fixtures, 
everything...ran into the thousands of dollars. *thousands*. What kind of 
respect is that? So, Brian...i think i agree with you on this one...i 
just think that one needs to make definite the line between tagging and 
graffiti artists.

I've got some friends in Australia who are artists...and the city council 
where they live (Adelaide) actually put up huge blank billboards along 
the side of motorways for the artists to fill up - a bold statement i 
think, and a good one. Alot of parties on the east coast will have paper 
up covering the walls, so taggers can tag all they want - at the end of 
tthe night, you just rip all the paper down and viola - no damage. Most 
east coast parties will just confiscate markers, though...

well, enough of my rambling. you all get the point. :D

mikebee

<<mikebee@freenet.scri.fsu.edu
<<http://organic.com/~mike 
<<mike@organic.com

Some people think the scene here in California is growing "at warp speed" 
and will lead, very soon, to the beginning of an RC Revolution.  True or
not, I am curious as to how the RC Revolution is progressing in the UK.  
I.e., how has the more widespread and advanced state of raving over there 
influenced UK society for the better?

I don't know about that- I think California has a very diverse amount of 
cultures- With individual music tastes that more then often reflect the 
social and race orientation of that group. England does not have the large 
amount of cultural diversity that we do- If RC in California is to launch 
anything resembling what the UK has- It will have to appeal to many more 
different types of cultures and in our day and age in California it is very 
difficult to get people to drop their prejudice behaviour and join large 
groups of diverse people. Unless they are shopping in a mall together or 
something- And even then take a look around at people that are of a different 
race then you and count the smile to anger face ratio!

<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<UFO The United Fruitcake
Organization<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<

around

have some pretty good works on them.  Sure, alot of writers are idiots lacking 
respect and common sense about where to write, but the real ones deserve some 
respect for creating in an artform that escapes traditional gallery/$$$ 
bullshit....

   Re-Groove-A-Nation - 10PM to 5AM, 18+, $5. 511 Tyler (off Fremont),
   Monterey. DJs Taylor Made (Santa Cruz), Juni, Lonnie, Greg Dean, &
   guests.
   
   BluePrint - 2nd Wed of every month - Quality Time dj's: Jason Boyd,
   Corey Black, YT, Crunch. 10p-6a, $5, 1015 Folsom, 21+

   415.974.1719

   St, SF. 415.673.8181

   174 King st. 415.765.7676
   
   Mystery School - "invoking Mercury, Thoth, Odin, Hermes Communication
   Circle" Come on down and dance with us 11pm-sunrise, 415.337.4905
   
Info Lines

   Be-At Info Line - 415-626-4087. Usually has 5-10 listings, updated
   daily.
   Clubline - 415.979.8686
   Fatline - 415.207.3668
   the Global Party Network - 415.568.1338
   Pre-Rave Warmup Line - Wondering what to do before the music starts?
   Events can happen at any time. Suggestions welcome. Call 415-522-3848
   The Gruv Line - (415) 331-1583 Ext. GRUV(4788)
   
Radio/TV Shows

   Sunday night 12mid-3am - Ambience w/Michael Hayes & David X KWOD 106.5
   (Sac)
   Sunday night 9pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 47 - Progressive
   house, acid jazz and "alternative" music views. (415) 281-3377.
   Sunday night mid-3am - "No UFO's" w/Adam from Silent Records KZSU 90.1
   Stanford
   Wednesday night mid-3am - "Cataklyzmol Pixel" ambient, experimental &
   noize - w/DJ Unknown, KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
   Thursday evening 9:30pm-12mid - Minor Minor KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
   Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF 90.3
   (SF)
   Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix with
   Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
   Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
   10pm-2am Ambient, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, Acid Jazz and
   noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
   Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from SF
   and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
   weeknights ~9pm - the Modern Mix w/Steve Masters KITS 105.3 (SF)
   
Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, submit them! I can't possibly
   hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To svbscribe or
   unsvbscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   svbscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsvbscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To svbscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   svbscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

> music shop for tapes).  In England we have really good E and people take 
> a lot of it and that is all they take so vibes at raves are a lot more 
> intense and has rougher edges then in SF.

honey, i'm sorry but i saw a hell of a lot of speed freak ravers running 
around brighton, as well as acid casualty freak-outs.


  Your average raver there is 
> much more together and knowledgable then over here.  He (HE??!!) is 
older, knows 

> it's all a lot more hardcore over there.  And that is bassically because
> your average raver there is poor and unemployed, not rich, middle-class
> and white like they are around here.  

i really don't think it was poor and unemplyed ravers going to those 20 
quid parties.  undergrounds, yes.  also, please remember that not ALL 
ravers here are wealthy or middle-class and white, altho' the majority 
may be.  

furthermore, while i DID see a thriving underground there, i also saw 
hell of crass commercialism all over the place.

 monicat

From: eugenics <eyh4@columbia.edu>

To: Kevin Keiper <keiper@itsa.ucsf.edu>

        Timothy McIntyre <timothym@ocf.berkeley.edu>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: RC influences
In-Reply-To: <Pine.3.89.9504192252.A65177-0100000@itsa.ucsf.edu>
Message-Id: <Pine.SUN.3.91.950420160523.19622A-100000@ciao.cc.columbia.edu>

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

On Wed, 19 Apr 1995, Kevin Keiper wrote:

> In England we have really good E and people take 
> a lot of it and that is all they take so vibes at raves are a lot more 
> intense and has rougher edges then in SF.  Your average raver there is 
> much more together and knowledgable then over here.  He is older, knows 
> all the tunes that he is hearing and can shove an amount of E down there 
> throats that would put most people around here in hospital. 

I totally respect your opinion about uk raves. But why does the emphasis 
on E-taking such a prerequisite for a good rave? Perhaps I don't know 
enough about origins, but music is my first incentive (it's evolutionary)
--I studied classical music pretty hardcore and this is the first 
contemporary  stuff that reaches the same level of sophistication--second 
is the people (curious, individual, and unpredictable, and definitely 
coming from different backgrounds) and  well, E is always the same. I 
guess i don't insist on as many prerequisites. Everyone has their own 
reasons for why they participate. I do agree that single-minded intensity 
probably does not exist to the same degree as a result. To me, the 
intensity is more individual. (sorry, i'm so hung up on this 
individuality thing and how everything is very personal) As much as I 
love drugs, it is only one path to "intensity". I see a passionate 
violinist get up on stage and perform the Brahms Violin Concerto, and see 
the "knowledgable" audience get wrapped up, and see the violinist go off 
stage sweating like a pig in his tux. I'm not trying to illustrate the 
pompous rich life, I'm just trying to say: people, music, great minds of 
music, intensity. oh, passion too. 
I always love running into ravers that "know their stuff" but if it makes 
someone happy for some unnameable reason, I've got to respect that.

KK: In short, 
> it's all a lot more hardcore over there.  And that is bassically because 
> your average raver there is poor and unemployed, not rich, middle-class 
> and white like they are around here.  Also, over there your basic 17 year 

Are uk raves a greater release? I mean, you seem to think that the 
quality of raving there is a result of STRUGGLE. So are the raves to get 
away from the struggle, or to express it? And I wonder, are sfraves more 
white because of exclusivity or because other ethnic groups simply like 
other kinds of music (hiphop, acid jazz, plain ol' rock)? I've noticed in 
NYC, it is more mixed, even tho' they advertise in such a way to ward out 
stereotypical gangs and such. And all my hip hop friends simply "don't 
like techno and all that cr*p!" And they don't like the "drugginess," 
they want to have a "couple beers and get down on the dance floor."

cheers,  eugenie

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, submit them! I can't possibly
   hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

Subject: ERNIE linked to bombings
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>From the Miami herald:
Ernie, of Sesame St. fame, currently in a legal brouhaha in Argentina,
negotiating the terms of his return, is in big trouble. Already under
scrutiny by the Interpol and the DEA, due to various drug charges, he is
recovering from a harrowing kidnapping by the Whining Path. But there is
more, and he seems to have been an unwitting pawn a blistering ploy by
terrorists, in an Fleming-esque international espionage crisis worthy of a
James Bond tale.

His escape seems, apparently, to have been a carefully orchestrated ploy by
various terrorist groups. Apparently, while unconscious, the Whining Path
inserted into one of Ernie's molars a microfilm of the federal building, as
was discovered early this sunday when he suffered an absess and went to the
dentist, who x-rayed his teeth. The film was discovered and removed, but
The CIA/FBI apparently felt it was a hoax and did not respond to his plea
for swift action.

It seems that the terrorists hoped Ernie would return to his east coast
barrio, and there he would recaptured by other terrorists and the tooth
removed in a mock mugging. Ernie, however, was under enourmous pressure, as
the DEA was already on his heels. He fled to Argentina instead.

Currently treating a case of the clap, contracted on Victor's floating
casino, Ernie said that as a sesame st. actor, he is often not taken
seriously and that the FBI contact felt that he was only trying to buy into
amnesty with "this absurd plan." CIA agents O.P.Ress and Knot Surv said in
a press conference today that they could not take Ernie's story as true.
"he's a schizophrenic, due to long term drug use. You can't rust him. He
may come up next month with a story about the japanese gas attacks!" But
Big Bird, in an exclusive phone interview, said that this was
insensitive,untrue, "an outright lie. Ernie may have his excesses, but he
has never been unstable. We  have our differences, but I know he's a good
man." Bert backed him up on this one: "a real good one" said the yellow
house mate and Jesse Helms target. 

Ernie, wearing his trade-mark "kill Barney" tee, and sipping a beer, was
seen on the deck of the floating pleasure palace by media hounds and fans.
He waved a "V for victory" sign and gave the crowds a thumbs-up. But for
many, the only thing up are eyebrows around the world, as many wonder if
the US government refused to follow his passionate plea this sunday, and
averting disaster.

Reported by Juan Motime, from the APS wire office, for the Miami herald.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Apr 20 18:44:01 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id SAA29659; Thu, 20 Apr 1995 18:44:01 -0700
Received: from ix2.ix.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with ESMTP id SAA29641; Thu, 20 Apr 1995 18:43:56 -0700
Received: from  by ix2.ix.netcom.com (8.6.12/SMI-4.1/Netcom)
	id SAA15779; Thu, 20 Apr 1995 18:43:03 -0700
Date: Thu, 20 Apr 1995 18:43:03 -0700
Message-Id: <199504210143.SAA15779@ix2.ix.netcom.com>
From: bradleyg@ix.netcom.com (Bradley Graham)
Subject: Re: taggers
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Tagging is wrong.   There is NO excuse for it.  Tagging has no socially 
redeeming value as it shows a blatant disregard for other people and
their property.  When I hear about or see taggings at raves I just have 
to shake my head because it is so hypocritical.  Tagging simply runs
counter to everything that RC has grown to mean (e.g., peace, love, and
harmony).  It's sort of like writing an email that says "you're an
irrelevant piece of garbage" and concluding it with "Peace and Hugs."

I guess what bothers me most is that tagging destroys the beauty of our 
habitat.  There is nothing worse than waking up, especially after an
excellent night of dancing, to see the outside of the building you live 
in covered with tags.  BTW, cleaning off tags are a great way to spend a
cold Sunday afternoon in SF.  I don't wantonly deface my (or others') 
property or neighborhood.  I don't want anyone else to either.  I'm sure
our friendly taggers would be more than a little upset if I tagged their
property (home, car, 49ers jacket, and so on).  What has happened to the
golden rule?????

Someone in an earlier posting to SFR mentioned that dogs (or maybe it was
animals in general, I can't remember) pee to mark their territory.  They
used this as an anology for tags.  Good point, but the fact is that dogs
are driven by primal instincts and not capable of higher order reasoning.
 I'm sure that most taggers are smarter than animals (but maybe not!)
and, therefore, they know right from wrong.  They simply don't care.  

What to do about tagging?  That's a toughie because it is indicative of a
larger social and political problem.  Tagging is just one step in a
vicious, degenerative cycle.  The cleaning of tags steals money from 
other programs that endeavor to break that cycle such as education, job 
training, or maybe even art programs that help taggers develop their
artistic potential.  As a volunteer for the SF School district, I can
say that the schools need every penny they can get their hands on.  It's 
really bad.  I wish I could spend more than five hours a week at the
school.

I don't believe governments should spend tax money to put up walls or
billboards as a way of letting taggers perform their craft in a less
harmful way.  Murals are different.  Murals are art and readily 
distinguishable from tags (which are not art).  Perhaps Singapore's
approach isn't so far off the mark?  I'm wondering if Michael Faye is 
still into in tagging?

BG

"profound .sig not include!"

Hey All,

Just got word that the Guardian is starting a local network, and they 
need beta testers to help them wok out the bugs.

Looks like a good system. All graphical, icons, the works.

The plan is to archive the Guardian from now on so ANY article from 
past issues can be researched quickly.

Their big deal is conferences. They want as much chatter as possible to 
be going on so a local community of people can be created, discuss local 
issues, inform each other of local events, situations, etc.

Send a note stating your interest to :	info@sfbayguardian.com

and they'll tell ya what to do.


Don't mean to sound selective, but they do want Bay Area people as 
testers, though perhaps you can persuade them if your out of the area.

This network might be a nice way to the "integration" thing with 
other like minded people in the area.  

Should be interesting. Later...

-Jonas

Hey check this out!

I was sitting here watching CNN after taking a shower. They were doing a
story on SHEITE MUSLIMS(SP) and lo-and-behold, there is ernie way in the
backround. He was for sure in cognito. He grew a beard and had downed a
white full cloth indicative of the middle east for clothing.

When the camera crew zoomed in on him he opened his cloth and revealed a
shirt with the quote:

                         BOMB SUDDAM

Although his attire and new found facial hair seamed to keep him
disguised very well, distinguishing marks were his halfmoon ears and
that toothless-clothy gumline of his. After he flashed the camera some
shots were fired and he fled to the sandbags.

I called and talked to JANE PAULY-SHORE. They are trying to do a
recovery-computer graft on the footage to see what food he had sticking
to his mouth. This will give them a clue as to where he has been in the
last week. That is, if someone didn't first wash,spin,rinse, and cycle
him. I asked PAULY-SHORE if he (ernie) had been linked to the terrorist
bombing in OK. The reply:" With advances in computer and
telecommunications, anything is possible. Heck even my 13 year old son
can do his homework now without even getting out of bed. Our world is
changing. The better we get with communicating orur problems and solving
them, the worse the crimes can become."

I then proceeded to try and contact Milton of the "Militia Of Ernie" but
my RJ11 analyzer beeped and showed that his phone was tapped. I
imediately hung up in fear of the FBI.

I know ernie would never do anything to harm anyone. I also know that
none of his discedents(SP) would either. If anyone knows how to contact
him. Please do for I fear for his saftey, and the security of all our
activities.

SIGNING OFF:
Andrew Dressler(Cheif of non-related security)

SOUNDGOD@iccse.com

All events and persons depicted in this story are fictional(exept ernie,
JANE PAULY-SHORE and myself). Anything resembling real life events is
purely coincidental and has nothing to do with real life ecept for the
stories described above.

my contradiction monitor started bleeping and i had to respond to this
remark from bradleyg:

>  Perhaps Singapore's
>approach isn't so far off the mark?  I'm wondering if Michael Faye is
>still into in tagging?
>

if capital punishment doesn't stop murder, do you really think caning will
stop tagging?  get real.  if you think you have an answer, fine.    if you
care so much, why don't you make an attempt to understand why people do
what they do instead of making generalizations like "it's counter to
everything RC has come to mean".   RC means a lot of different things to a
lot of different people,  after counting yourself in maybe you should count
in others too.    is caning along the lines of  what "RC has come to mean",
as far as you're concerned?  is judgement/punishment Singapore style
something you'd like to contribute to the RC culture that "means" so much
to you?

what are you talking about exactly?

 all you seem to be saying is that you don't like taggers  and you don't
understand tagging.  that's a long way from doing something about it or
understanding what a solution might be.

--Jim

Jim wrote: 
>
>my contradiction monitor started bleeping and i had to respond to this
>remark from bradleyg:
>

>>approach isn't so far off the mark?  I'm wondering if Michael Faye is
>>still into in tagging?

will
>stop tagging?  get real.  if you think you have an answer, fine.    if 
you
>care so much, why don't you make an attempt to understand why people do
>what they do instead of making generalizations like "it's counter to
>everything RC has come to mean".   RC means a lot of different things to 
a
>lot of different people,  after counting yourself in maybe you should 
count
>in others too.    is caning along the lines of  what "RC has come to 
mean",
>as far as you're concerned?  is judgement/punishment Singapore style
>something you'd like to contribute to the RC culture that "means" so 
much
>to you?
>
>what are you talking about exactly?
>
> all you seem to be saying is that you don't like taggers  and you don't
>understand tagging.  that's a long way from doing something about it or
>understanding what a solution might be.
>
>--Jim

Jim,
I appreciate your comments but I think you should go back and read my
posting again.  You're right in that I don't like tagging.  Tagging is
a form of vandalism and is wholly unproductive.  I am, however, very
openminded so if you can provide a convincing explanation of its
virtues I'd be interested.

I do have a pretty good sense of what tagging is all about.  So your 
assessment of my ignorance or lack of awareness is unfounded.  I also
have a good sense of social issues and priorities.  I can see the
homeless, the poor state of public education, the inadequate and 
overburdened medical services available to those with limited or no 
financial resources, etc.  In fact I *do* *more* than just observe it
and hypothesize about reasons why these things have come to pass and
ponder possible solutions.  I am involved in community service projects.

Frankly, I have spent alot of time cleaning up after taggers and I am
tired of it.  Every time someone has to clean tags from a school, a
muni bus, a library, or even the building you live in, it takes away
valuable time (and money) that could be used for more productive 
purposes.  That's an undeniable fact!

As for the solution, I indicated in my first posting that it is a 
tough problem that can't be solved without addressing some broader 
issues.  I could easily argue both sides of the capital punishment 
issue and Singapore's approach to crime.  Singapore's solution
works for Singapore because of its unique circumstances (culture, 
government, size, etc.).  I am pretty certain it is not extensible to 
the US.  My comment was intended to be more ironic than serious.  I 
don't think we should put a bandaid on the problem by creating places 
where taggers can perform their "art" with impunity.  It not only sets 
a false expectation for the way the real world works but it does
nothing to resolve the problem.

Finally, regarding tagging and RC.  I agree that RC means different
things to different people.  My comment was not an indictment of the
entire RC (sorry if it came across that way). I was just commenting on a
contradiction that occurs periodically within the rave community.  Are
these types of contradictions unique to the rave community?  No.  But
that doesn't they're not worth talking about.  It's, in fact, more
important to talk about this type of issue you are interested in
perpetuating your philosophy or attitude.  For example, in the course 
of discussing how the internet will (or is) changing society, then it
is probably worthwhile to talk about how it promotes anti-social 
behavior; a fundamental contradiction of what the internet is supposed
to be about (i.e., uniting people without regard to geographical 
location).  An instance of how anti-social behavior is emerging as a
result of the internet is that people are more aggressive in their
communications when using impersonal mediums such as email; much more
so than they would be when communicating face-to-face.  I mean, if you 
were speaking to someone in person, would you tell them (especially if
someone you don't know) to ridicule their beliefs and tell them "get
real?"

Bradley

"profound .sig not included!"

Hi everyone:
About my recent, um, UK vs. SF post...I didn't mean to start arguments about
the transatlantic rave differences, and sure, there is a difference between
the two, I'm sure, and all I wanted to find out was what those differences
were.  Thanks to Saira for her thought-out reply and everyone else who mailed
me and posted, and I can assure you all that I had no underlying intention
of implying that SF was inferior by perhaps being physically slower.  I am in
love with this delicious collection of gatherings around the bay--don't 
forget that!  
Thanks to all, again, and if any of you go to KIVA (or I might be at Progress,
actually...haven't decided) tomorrow and you see a brown-haired kid with 
a pacifier in his gob, that's me!
Bye (wave)
Timothy

> 
> well, can you still tell where it is?
> 
I can now tell you where it was, as it was last night and this morning.  
Now it continues within me, as well as for those that were there.
I made the trip down with a friend toward bonnie doon.  After a bit of a 
search, we found the secluded beach underneath a sky full of stars.
There weren't many people at this party, which I found to be a nice 
change, because I felt I got to know everyone there.  On arrival I handed 
out lollipops to everyone and I recieved a very warm response  from 
everyone I approached.  With the warmth of this small intimate party on 
a  beautiful 
beach I found it easy to let loose and feel that sense that when I danced 
I shared the feelings that we all had.  The beat of the music and the 
sensations of the beautiful surroundings took me to a sense of 
enlightenment that let me feel extreme joy as I allowed myself 
to let go and dance with no inhibitions. 
After the music was done, it was nice to bask in the afterglow on the beach 
with  the remaining ravers.  It was nice to get to talk to some people 
I've seen on the dance floor from past partys.  
After grabbing some brunch in santa cruz and checking out some of the 
sights, headed back to sf to rest a bit before the boat party.
In closing I want to say that I had a great, great time, and I still am.  
For those of you going out tonight, enjoy that groove, and where ever we 
are we will be there together.  That goes for those of you not going out 
tonight as well.


peter

Man, we're all sitting here in Berkeley waiting for the KIVA line to be updated
and we're getting the unpleasant initiation that all ravers experience at some
point: sometimes, I guess, promoters forget to update the message line, and
some raves just don't happen or get shut down or just suck.  *sigh* but as
you need downswings to make upswings noticeablr, I guess this will just make
the next rave I go to that much better, since it will be compared to tonight.
Hopefully, the rave will happen, I guess, but it seems a little late to this
newcomer to the scene.  Oh well.
Anyone go to Progress?  Some people at my house got back from there after
staying for about ten minutes, and then leaving because it was lame...but, as
Vincent Vega said in Pulp Fiction, "That's just what I heard." 
Well, I had all this energy bundled up inside me, ready for an amazing night,
but I can't use it, so I send it through these fiberoptic wires to all of you
in equal-sized and carefully-wrapped packages.  Swallow it down, smear it across
your bodies, and enjoy!
Hopefully everybody had a better evening than me,
Timothy

Phred, you are totally correct in what you say.  I have not lived in 
England for two years.  But even when I lived there their was always this 
element of mainstream v. underground.  I was only ever involved in the 
underground scene.  But what ever side of the UK dance scene you are 
looking at one thing is true that was not true when I was working in the 
scene: it's now all run by black gangsters called Yardies who are evil 
corrupt people.  I hope the same fate does not befall the scene in SF.
     And, as any self-respecting UK raver will tell you, anybody that now 
works for KISS FM and thinks that this is cool is nothing but a complete 
wanker anyway.
See ya! Love Tristan.

On Thu, 20 Apr 1995, Fred Heutte wrote:

> You know, I promised myself not to respond to Tristan's interminable
> patronizing of the SF scene, but his comparison of the UK and SF situations
> needs some additional context.
> 
> Sure the scene in the UK is different and in some respects may be considered
> better . . . but I wonder.  
> 
> A brief look at a recent issue of DJ magazine, the flagship of the UK scene,
> gives you the flavor of what's happening there.  The scene has turned
> relentlessly commercial, and is starting to take on some of the Hollyweird
> aspects that rock did in the States in the mid-1970s, when Rolling Stone
> stopped being a hippie rag and decided it was cooler to hang out with
> the millionaires.  
> 
> Here we have a feature on DJ Graham Gold, with three KISS FM slots and
> director of the Peach label which is part of the club/house PWL empire.
> The feature is a diary of a Day in the Life, and here's one entry:
> "12.30 pm.  We pile into Graham's black BMW with its personal plate.
> 'It's tax deductible' he explains.  Amongst the demo tapes on the floor
> in the back is Map Of Britain and a Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles book.
> As he reverses full speed back up The Vineyard the phone rings.  'Stupid
> cow, I won't be able to drop it off today...'  As we screech across
> London he says excitedly 'I'm going scuba diving in Israel next week,
> I've been doing a course because I've never been there before.  Apparently
> there's a rave scene out there, the Es are 30 pounds each..."
> 
> So there's a leading light of your precious UK scene.  All props to those
> who maintain the underground and keep it moving and even make ends meet
> while not succumbing to the flash lifestyle.
> 
> For the punters, it's 10 pounds in the door Friday, shite Es, the Drug
> Squad everywhere, CJA killing off all the true undergrounds, and all
> the rest.  It's like the US indie rock scene, except the sound is house.
> 
> But the money and the greed are the same.
> 
> I salute the UK underground, it must be tough keeping going with all that
> heavy weight overhead.  We're very fortunate in SF and America in general
> not to have that to contend with.  I saw what can happen.  Grunge was
> really invented at the Satyricon club here in Portland, not ten blocks
> from where I sit.  For years it grew and maintained within our little
> Northwest context, suddenly it blew up with Nirvana and all the rest,
> and here we are, none the better for it really.  I don't want that to
> happen to the house/techno/r**e scene, like it already has in the UK.
> 
> Peace out.
> 
> phred
>

Any scene that results in a Government passing laws where it is illegal 
for anybody to gather together in groups of ten and where the right of 
silent upon being arrested by the cops is seen as admission of guilt can 
only have been a scene that was getting so big and fundemental that it 
scared the British Governemnt into taking this action.  Can one ever 
imagine the same thing happening over here?  I think not.
Anyway: nuff said on this subject.  See ya! Love Tristan.

On Thu, 20 Apr 1995, Atherton, Darren wrote:

> Some people think the scene here in California is growing "at warp speed" 
> and will lead, very soon, to the beginning of an RC Revolution.  True or
> not, I am curious as to how the RC Revolution is progressing in the UK.  
> I.e., how has the more widespread and advanced state of raving over there 
> influenced UK society for the better?
> 
> I don't know about that- I think California has a very diverse amount of 
> cultures- With individual music tastes that more then often reflect the 
> social and race orientation of that group. England does not have the large 
> amount of cultural diversity that we do- If RC in California is to launch 
> anything resembling what the UK has- It will have to appeal to many more 
> different types of cultures and in our day and age in California it is very 
> difficult to get people to drop their prejudice behaviour and join large 
> groups of diverse people. Unless they are shopping in a mall together or 
> something- And even then take a look around at people that are of a different 
> race then you and count the smile to anger face ratio!

whole underground scene is being run by poor unemployed classes people.  
In SF it's all being run by cynical English ex-pats or young white trash 
kids who have not got a clue.  Guess which one has more authenticity going 
for it?
