I've avoided this issue, even though I predicted before xmas that Raving
and Tagging would be the 2 big social issues ths summer.  the reason for
avoidance was pretty much to not make big threads that not eveybody would
want to go int. however, now that we've largely taken the heavier RC stuff
of-line, sfraves seems to me to be suffereing a lack of rlevance and
interest to anyone interested in more than "dancing and hugging". so hre
goes. the reason I thought these 2 issues would be lrge this summer is
that, as with RC, urban grafitti (as I prefer to call it) is about the
suppressed imagination and creativity busting out of an overcontrolled
culture). in NY where this stuff has gone much much further it often
seemed to me as if, every night, a whole wave of peoples' imaginations
would flood up from the cellars of the culture and spread itself to a
height of 7 feet across the whole city. 

none of it is selling anything - Art Unchained?  a healthy dose of it is
quite political.  undeveloped egos were getting a chance to address the
public (and be listend to?) and much of the "art" is quite good.  I'm 
absolutely certain that this school of art will be recognised in a few 
years and even actual walls (or fotos certianly) will be on sale in fancy 
Manhattan galleries.

art is revolutionary.  it should *always* offend the powers that be.

one last point, especially for Bradley who seems an intelligent, 
fair-minded chap:  perhaps you have fallen for the official Unholy Roman 
Empire hype that large expanses of boring, deadly grey concrete somehow 
sums up the mightiness of our armed forces and multinationals and must 
therefore be accepted as "Beauty"?  NOT!  those large aonymous planes of 
concrete *should* inspire rebellion, rather than passive acceptance and 
apathy (I mean if there are to be only 2 choices).

personally I definitely view grafitti as healthy signs that the human spirit 
is not yet smothered to death beneath grey concrete planes. it might piss 
me off if I had to clean them up every time - but do we?  actually?  why 
is the "brochure" look better than when adorned with some real people 
creativity?
fraser

On Fri, 21 Apr 1995, Bradley Graham wrote:

> Jim wrote: 
> >
> >my contradiction monitor started bleeping and i had to respond to this
> >remark from bradleyg:
> >
> >>  Perhaps Singapore's
> >>approach isn't so far off the mark?  I'm wondering if Michael Faye is
> >>still into in tagging?
> >>
> >
> >if capital punishment doesn't stop murder, do you really think caning 
> will
> >stop tagging?  get real.  if you think you have an answer, fine.    if 
> you
> >care so much, why don't you make an attempt to understand why people do
> >what they do instead of making generalizations like "it's counter to
> >everything RC has come to mean".   RC means a lot of different things to 
> a
> >lot of different people,  after counting yourself in maybe you should 
> count
> >in others too.    is caning along the lines of  what "RC has come to 
> mean",
> >as far as you're concerned?  is judgement/punishment Singapore style
> >something you'd like to contribute to the RC culture that "means" so 
> much
> >to you?
> >
> >what are you talking about exactly?
> >
> > all you seem to be saying is that you don't like taggers  and you don't
> >understand tagging.  that's a long way from doing something about it or
> >understanding what a solution might be.
> >
> >--Jim
> 
> Jim,
> I appreciate your comments but I think you should go back and read my
> posting again.  You're right in that I don't like tagging.  Tagging is
> a form of vandalism and is wholly unproductive.  I am, however, very
> openminded so if you can provide a convincing explanation of its
> virtues I'd be interested.
> 
> I do have a pretty good sense of what tagging is all about.  So your 
> assessment of my ignorance or lack of awareness is unfounded.  I also
> have a good sense of social issues and priorities.  I can see the
> homeless, the poor state of public education, the inadequate and 
> overburdened medical services available to those with limited or no 
> financial resources, etc.  In fact I *do* *more* than just observe it
> and hypothesize about reasons why these things have come to pass and
> ponder possible solutions.  I am involved in community service projects.
> 
> Frankly, I have spent alot of time cleaning up after taggers and I am
> tired of it.  Every time someone has to clean tags from a school, a
> muni bus, a library, or even the building you live in, it takes away
> valuable time (and money) that could be used for more productive 
> purposes.  That's an undeniable fact!
> 
> As for the solution, I indicated in my first posting that it is a 
> tough problem that can't be solved without addressing some broader 
> issues.  I could easily argue both sides of the capital punishment 
> issue and Singapore's approach to crime.  Singapore's solution
> works for Singapore because of its unique circumstances (culture, 
> government, size, etc.).  I am pretty certain it is not extensible to 
> the US.  My comment was intended to be more ironic than serious.  I 
> don't think we should put a bandaid on the problem by creating places 
> where taggers can perform their "art" with impunity.  It not only sets 
> a false expectation for the way the real world works but it does
> nothing to resolve the problem.
> 
> Finally, regarding tagging and RC.  I agree that RC means different
> things to different people.  My comment was not an indictment of the
> entire RC (sorry if it came across that way). I was just commenting on a
> contradiction that occurs periodically within the rave community.  Are
> these types of contradictions unique to the rave community?  No.  But
> that doesn't they're not worth talking about.  It's, in fact, more
> important to talk about this type of issue you are interested in
> perpetuating your philosophy or attitude.  For example, in the course 
> of discussing how the internet will (or is) changing society, then it
> is probably worthwhile to talk about how it promotes anti-social 
> behavior; a fundamental contradiction of what the internet is supposed
> to be about (i.e., uniting people without regard to geographical 
> location).  An instance of how anti-social behavior is emerging as a
> result of the internet is that people are more aggressive in their
> communications when using impersonal mediums such as email; much more
> so than they would be when communicating face-to-face.  I mean, if you 
> were speaking to someone in person, would you tell them (especially if
> someone you don't know) to ridicule their beliefs and tell them "get
> real?"
> 
> Bradley
> 
> "profound .sig not included!"
> 
> 
> 
> 
>

the Rave Spirit is wild, involves more sponataneity, it allows more
craziness and "possession" and so on.  I noticed very clearly how RC was
affecting the UK culture a few years ago when I noticed that I was having
no problems taking my dog (unleashed as always throughout its life but
that's a whole other story, probably not related to sfraves, althoug she 
attended as many raves as some people on here!) onto the bus, and just 
generally, at cafe tables, crossing the equivalent of Market St etc
.  
when I thought about it I realised what had been happening and later
noticed many similar examples.  RC was spilling more"craziness" out into
the streets of the surrounding superculture.  until it got to a point that
there was just so much lovely human diversity and craziness everywehre
that authoritarian personalities who feel its their duty to stomp out such
things had ben forced to give up.
that's also my reason to people who worry too much about government 
surveillance and so on.  the only real answer is to spread this new 
tolerant, cooperative culture so widely that all their equipment becomes 
useless since they don't have the manpower to even *observe* their 
findings, let alone *do* anything about it.

and, as usual, RC seems to be pivotal in playing this "seeding" role.
fraser.

From: Marc Pfister <mjpfister@ucdavis.edu>
X-Sender: ez045207@dale
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: doin' Lawndree
Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.3.91.950423145318.13455C-100000@dale>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Precedence: bulk

Despite many early setbacks (unavailable generator, voicemail crash), 
Lawndree Went Off in Davis last night. The party cost only a quarter and 
was outdoors and went till sunrise. At its peak ouround 1 am, there were 
over 100 people dancing in the oak grove. DJs were Marcone (me), Jeyson, 
Glowboy and surprise guest DJs Pepe and Tom (I hope I got your names right), 
who showed up with crates and proceeded 
to tag-team out a excellent deep house set. This, combined with my 
eclectic trip-hop/acid/conga house set and Jeyson's hard acid and jungle 
sets gave the mixed crowd all sorts of wonderful music to dance to. The 
crowd varied from ravers to local punk-band members. At oround 4am all 
that were left were about 5 breakdancers, maybe 10 raver types, and three 
drunk alumni that had been wandering around playing golf in the dark and 
had heard the thump of the speakers and decided to hang out and dance 
with us for a while. As the sun rose the remaining few 
were treated to a beautiful ambient set by Glowboy. The lighting varied 
throughout the night from the glow of the stars and rising crescent moon 
to an acid bubble light projected on hanging parachutes. 
In summary, we had an incredible party. Everyone loved the location and 
the low cost. The mostly unknown DJs (though you might have seen Jeyson 
spin at F&F) provided great, enegetic sets. There were no bad vibes and 
everybody got along like they were old friends, sharing water and food.
Everyone was incredibly cooperative with parking  somewhere else and 
walking in. We are so amazed that the party went so well that I can 
hardly express it.
 And we didn't get busted.  :)
 
Marc

On Sun, 23 Apr 1995, Kevin Keiper wrote:

> Any scene that results in a Government passing laws where it is illegal 
> for anybody to gather together in groups of ten and where the right of 
> silent upon being arrested by the cops is seen as admission of guilt can 
> only have been a scene that was getting so big and fundemental that it 
> scared the British Governemnt into taking this action.  Can one ever 
> imagine the same thing happening over here?  I think not.
> Anyway: nuff said on this subject.  See ya! Love Tristan.
> 
got to disagree on this one, kevin.  indeed I'd say from some of the 
stuff we've been hearing about authroty actions nationwide, and some of 
the bad press, that RC must *already* be starting to discombobulate a 
few people who feel they have something to lose from society changing. 
 (they're wrong, they'd be much happier, but try telling someone who's 
never been how good a rave will be!) 
I mean, when you compare reactions to the first zippy warnings last year 
over the Criminal Justice Act to, at most, a discomforted silence and 
general agreement today it's pretty clear.  (and this is whether you 
agree it's a good thing or not.)
fraser

are interest in going. The trip will include a van ride up to portland

would leave Fri may 5 early morning and come back sunday night. If
anyone has the slightest chance on going I highly recomend it. Seating
is limited so please get a hold of me in advance. I will be the one who
is driving(I'm a really good driver and I'm really good at finding my

van and 5 spots are already taken. The people in portland are very nice,
kindof reminds me of the closeness I feel with the people I know in the
city but with perfect strangers! The "SCENE" is different there but very
dancy. I like the "new look" about the scene up there. Drop me a note if

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Apr 23 21:49:32 1995

i sent this to my friend david and realized it might make some extra
happiness if i posted it; this is the sort of stuff that keeps me reading
this list.  all about people and beauty and lovE!  hope you enjoy.

*****

david i know i've said this before but i want to say it again:  thank you
so incredibly for everything you've given (me) this past year!  this
trajectory i'm on was largely instigated by your brilliant examplEmpathy
and your guidance and love continues to push great shit through.  last
night i felt for (almost?) the first time that i was giving back some of
the wondErful lovE i've received from everyone here; the kids i drove home
thanked me so much for providing the lovEmpathy and i said "don't thank
me!" and they said "we *are* thanking you!" and i said "it's not me" and
they said "yes it is!".  funny, so i'm learning to feel good about giving
and being recognized for giving.  and how i receive so much by giving that
it feels hardly worth commendation, you know?  the kiva party (w/dubtribe)
didn't happen so i went to Progress which turned out to be really kickin';
i had my second mind-blowing WOW experience (the first was with the doc
w/you & brandy) during john howard's set; i was absolutely transfixed,
fucking incredible.  the feeling is like being disintegrated by the music,
like a zillion acupuncturist's needles running me through at once, one for
every cell in my body, and each cell reunited with the air/earth/fire/water
all around.  the WOW is really like the WOW of the Transcendent Other in
the psychedelic experience, of any ecstatic experience, i suppose.  like
"Ahhh, --here--we--are--!"  we are now HERE.  the nutrition of the
situation is so deep, i continue to be amazed.  and i continue to be amazed
at how amazed i am by the entirE Environment, i mean the insanely bEautiful
hills, bridges, trees, faces, birdsongs, white breakers (went to Progress
afterparty at ocean beach today!), gorgeous sUn, deep surgical bass, tribal
groups that promote these things (Pacific, Friends & Family, Cloud Factory,
Harmony, Mother Earth Sound System, etc.), i'm so overwhelmed by the depth,
breadth, stunning bEauty and wisdom of it all, it's like having a continual
ecstatic expEriencE as long as i can avoid the concerns about myself as
individual, i.e. a thing to be marketed, protected, possessive (of things
as well as people), a consumer, loyal to god and country.  helen wonders
how i can feel good about having this stuff as the focus of my energy and
work; it seems so "unproductive", i'm not writing, i'm not sculpting, i'm
not creating.  but here's my take:  just a day or two ago i started
thinking of all this as my current work, and what i'm working on/creating
(collaboratively with the comE/unity) is a new piEce of art to transcend
all artworks, one whose components are human consciousnesses and
lovEsources, and this is happening on many levels:  global (species), local
and everywhere in between.  i'm sure someone has pointed this out before,
but in addition to these raves being TAZes, they are like mandalas made of
sand; transcendently gorgeous and Eternal works of "art" which are created
collaboratively with great lovE and comE/unity and then returned to the sea
rather than placed on display in someone's living room; a dynamic thing,
not static like western art.  wow, i feel like i just hit on another little
profundity; the way we make art in the modern western world as an attempt
to stop the world, solidify something essentially ethereal, the brilliance
of lifEforcE.  so the ultimate "art" is an endlessly morphing culturE of
lovE, and we are all making it together!  cool.

Subject: Re: taggers (fwd)

My comments to a recent post ...
( Anybody on SFRaves who has graffiti and/or tagging experience, I'd
appreciate hearing from you via personal email ... )
 
Forwarded message:
> From: Fraser Clark <fraser@megatripolis.org>
> Subject: Re: taggers
> 
> ... the reason I thought <raving and tagging> would be lrge this summer is
> that, as with RC, urban grafitti (as I prefer to call it) is about the
> suppressed imagination and creativity busting out of an overcontrolled
> culture). 
 From the beginning of this post , there is a problem with terminology
that may make the rest of the post irrelevent to "tagging". The term 
tagging is the practice of leaving personal trademarks ( "tags" ) 
symbolizing the tagger or a group the tagger is advertising. It is a
subset of the whole world of graffiti.  Compared to the beautiful , rude,
colorful graffiti which is most obviously an example of "Art Unchained" ,
tagging is a minimal , monochrome , selfish statement which sole purpose
is to say "here I was/we were" .   
 I must say that there is a echo of calligraphy in tagging , as taggers
probably practice a long time to develop a unique yet readable (?) tag.
However , I prefer my graffiti with more pictorial elements in it .
And the artistic aspects of their tags seem to be the last element in
the minds of taggers. 
> 
> none of it is selling anything - Art Unchained?  a healthy dose of it is
> quite political.  undeveloped egos were getting a chance to address the
> public (and be listend to?) and much of the "art" is quite good.  I'm 
> absolutely certain that this school of art will be recognised in a few 
> years and even actual walls (or fotos certianly) will be on sale in fancy 
> Manhattan galleries.
 I can't quote any showings or books from memory , but good graffiti has been
recognized as such - most public libraries should have at least one  
book from the 1980's about the subject , when the interest in the more
pituresque version of graffiti peaked here in the United States.
> 
> ... the official Unholy Roman Empire hype that large expanses of boring, 
> deadly grey concrete somehow sums up the mightiness of our armed forces 
> and multinationals and must therefore be accepted as "Beauty"?  NOT!  

 Hmmm - it'd be nice to see references that document the connection between
"large expanses of boring, deadly grey concrete" and "mightiness of our armed 
forces" . There is a definite connection between the look of a building
and the amount of narcissism the building's would-be owners have. Look at
the TransAmerica Pyramid. It seems the bigger the corporate ego, the 
wilder and less boring the building design. 

 Actually all that gray concrete probably has more to do with it being
cheaper than large expanses of painted concrete. The look of corporate 
USA has at lot to do with the collision of the dreams of architects crashing
against the customer's budget. 

> those large aonymous planes of 
> concrete *should* inspire rebellion, rather than passive acceptance and 
> apathy (I mean if there are to be only 2 choices).

 However ... tagging is mostly done in locations where other taggers can see 
the tags  - including neighborhood "mom and pop" grocery stores , delivery
trucks, library walls , fences , and ( most annoying to me ) art murals 
created by local artists. Tagging as an offensive act against the territorial
asperations of other gangs is carried out in the neighborhood of the
enemy - these are the folks that are probably defacing the art murals. 
If in "neutral" territory , tags are purely advertisement.
   
> personally I definitely view grafitti as healthy signs that the human spirit 
> is not yet smothered to death beneath grey concrete planes. it might piss 
> me off if I had to clean them up every time - but do we?  actually?  why 
> is the "brochure" look better than when adorned with some real people 
> creativity?

 Ironically, tagging is rarely seen on gray , corporate buildings , because 
zoning laws seperate these buildings from the homes and schools and libraries
that mostly catch the worst of tagging. 

 Any grafitti done on billboards ( except public service bill boards ) usually
gets some anti-advertisement approval on my part - maximum points if the 
grafitti actually comments on original advertisement. 

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

[ Group mailing to SFRaves list ]

Some "alternate" opinons follow - the only excuse I can give ahead of time
is that I'm on antihistamines and feel a sore throat coming on ... :-) 

 Raves as AntiSocial Selfish Rudeness

 I appreciate the beauty of a great vibe when it blossoms and spreads like
a fire flower - I've felt blessed to see the sun rise and set with the 
beat of techno/house moving my body and soul. I say this up front to 
try to establish to you folks that I like raves ....

 Raves are not the salvation of the nation or the world - that's my opinion.
They may be the salvation of sub-sets of the USA or the world. But if you
find yourself screwing somebody over to get yourself raving , don't use
the higher purpose of "Rave Culture == Soul Salvation/Cure for Modern
Civilization" as an excuse. 

 So far as I know , I've never broken into a place to hold or attend a
rave, and I'm proud of it. Bent some laws - sure , but I never concioussly
wanted to rave if doing so would screw up someone's right to a decent 
night's sleep . Other things I would never want to do is trash the land
and property of others for the purpose of raving.  

 We've heard the "ends justify the means" line before , and most of us
wouldn't accept it as a valid excuse in a non-rave context , so why do
so in a rave context?

 I feel like writing more along this vein , but can't get the ideas and 
words to align here on screen via my keyboard. I will appreciate any 
comments on what I've already written here ...

Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Apr 23 22:31:28 1995

Subject: Raves In Society
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Sun, 23 Apr 1995 22:31:09 -0700 (PDT)

Another point I wanted to bring up in my "raves as Antisocial Selfish
Rudeness" post was that RC should be humble enough to co-exist with 
other "ways of life" - tolerance should go from ravers to the world
in the same amount that we want the world to tolerate us. And - maybe
the more antisocial aspects of raves ( tresspass , property damage , 
noise pollution  ) should be modified or transformed in order to
form " a more perfect union" ???

	Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Apr 23 23:08:11 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id XAA09393; Sun, 23 Apr 1995 23:08:11 -0700
Received: from saclink1.csus.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with ESMTP id XAA09387; Sun, 23 Apr 1995 23:08:08 -0700

	(1.37.109.14/16.2) id AA049083620; Sun, 23 Apr 1995 23:07:00 -0700
Date: Sun, 23 Apr 1995 23:07:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: Amy R Starkey <sac41673@saclink1.csus.edu>
Subject: what does it all mean?
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9504232257.A3796-0100000@saclink1.csus.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Something happened to me that hit me really hard.....have you ever just 
*known* that you were with the right person - trusted them with your 
soul, shared every little thing in your life with him or her, had a 
blissful dream of always being together and most of all *loving* them in 
the most pure and undiluted form that can be possible - then to have it 
severed instantly?  How do you deal with it?  I am in such a state of 
shock right now and thank god I have my inner strength and incredible 
positive energy continuously flowing around me and through me thanks to 
my incredible friends.  But I have to unsubscribe to this list for 
awhile to get myself back together - I know I don't post all that 
often, but I consider you all my friends, and I don't leave without 
saying goodbye.  I'm strong, I'll be back in full force soon enough, 
but I need this time to heal myself.  If any of you still wish contact 
with me, my email address is below and I'll get into contact with you.  
I will definately be at Sunset this Sunday if it's happening, and 
probably Wicked in May.  Thanks for listening.

with much PLUR,
Amy

Subject: Re: Raves In Society
In-Reply-To: <199504240531.WAA02081@netcom10.netcom.com>

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

hmmm.  in the valley of the blind, the guy with the large sound system is
KING! but you might run into continuous problems with yur light shows.
what I'm trying to say is that, if you take the view that we live in a
*seriously* repressed and almost somnolent culture, then you'll be
continuously running afoul of a whole plethora of laws which have no moral
standing at all but are just more or less the side-effects of general
intolerance.  I don't know exactly how things are here, but I do know in
England, as the System runs down, huge areas of formerly industrial bdgs
can lie vacant for years as they crumble.  not because the owners don't
care (many of them would *love* to hire them out) but becuse zoning laws
and all the rest of it won't allow anything to happen there.  meanwhile
thousands of ravers (for example) who just want somehwere to dance can
find nowhere legal.  so what to do in this situation?  the most famous
rave in history was at Castlemorton in England a few years ago.  and you
shaould have read the press that said it was antisocial.  complete with
interviews with people living nearby who couldn't sleep all weekend.  then
I did some enquiries.  and it turned out that Castlemorton is actually
"public land"  meaning that the king had granted them in perpetuity to the
people for the holding of fayres etc.  but a few yuppy types (4 I think )
had managed to fiddle the local rules and had managed to build private
houses on the common land.  and it was *they* who were doing all the
complaining!  they had 360 days a year to live on "our" land but when we 
poor city types came once a year to party they complain like crazy.
now, to bring things home a bit:  if ravers were allowed to hold raves on 
common land here - after all we pay for its upkeep - there might be less 
reason for using warehouses or even keeping some poor wage slave awake 
for once in his lifetime (why not just join in with the ravers, eh?  
would that really be so bad?) 
so before we start talking about tolerance let's be more sure how much 
tolerance the overculture is giving us.  which is as close to zero as it 
can make it!  with a lot worse to come as RC expands.
or should the concentration camp prisoners have been more "polite and 
tolerant" to the wage-slave guards as they were led to the incinerators?
>:)   fraser

On Sun, 23 Apr 1995, Larry Ching wrote:
> 
>  We've heard the "ends justify the means" line before , and most of us
> wouldn't accept it as a valid excuse in a non-rave context , so why do
> so in a rave context?
> 
I dunno who you're quoting here but I'd like to correct it anyway.  I am 
certainly not saying that the ends justify the means.  a Rave *is* the 
end.  in a slightly more sane culture young people (and older ones too, 
like in an unrepressed place like Africa, say) would do a lot more 
dancing.  and a sane culture would encourage it by making lots of space 
available.  why the hell NOT??!!
so I doubt if anyone's putting that case forward.  such a case might 
involve killing someone to bring about peace.  VERY UNLIKELY!  but that's 
not my argument.  I defend *some* rule-bending from an inner conviction 
that such things would be allowed and enouraged by a sane culture and so 
we're only doing what should be allowed in the first place anyway.
fraser.

In-Reply-To: <Pine.BSI.3.91.950423094132.24439A-100000@taz.hyperreal.com> from "Sami Khoury" at Apr 23, 95 09:42:04 am

For those who are still confused about Kiva, I have some
information, although perhaps an official Mother Earth Sound
System representative can say more.  After losing their site,
they looked desperately for a new site, and after considering
all the options and their desire to make this party happen,
they decided to try a break in.  An old warehouse going unused...
Ethical issues aside, some police noticed some activity and found
what was going on as they were setting up, and a small number of
people were arrested and put in jail for, I assume, breaking
and entering.  As far as I know these people will be in jail
until thursday, or until $10,000 bail each is posted, and then
they will have to deal with the charges.  So, obviously, the
party didn't happen.  Whether these people deserved this or not
is up to you... regardless of that, the Mother Earth Sound 
System could use all our support and love right now.  We can
also be thankful that the bust didn't happen after the party
was already going, as a lot more people could've been arrested
or many confused people would've suddenly have had to deal with
getting home, similar to the problems after Friends and Family.  
Do the ends always justify the means?
It's a very difficult question.  We need to be very much aware
that as much as we beleive in our cause and the goodness of
our love, there is a whole other side to the world out there
that demands our responsibility and awareness.  We won't change
them overnight and we can't simply ignore them.
But we can't stop beleiving, either.

My love to all,
and wishes for an ever improving tommorow.

-john.

ps.  I had hell of a lot of fun at Organic on Friday.
good sound... *grin*

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: vibe spreading
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Hi everybody!
Guess what I did last night?  Well, okay, 2 nights ago I was supposed to go
to KIVA with a bunch of friends, but when the party fell through, I was kind
of bummed, so my roommate Niki and I and her friend Kelly went to Larry
Blake's in Berkeley, which is a bar/r&b club, and we went to dance.  We
got downstairs to watch the band, which was playing some jazz/freeform/hip-hop
fusion stuff, and the crowd was extremely chill.  Grad students sitting at
smoky tables, sipping beer, frat guys with their arms crossed, leaning against
walls, etc.  No one was dancing at all, even though there was a space for it
in front of the stage.  Determined to spread the vibE, we told the singer to
tell people to get up and dance, and he was excited by our energy and made
an announcement.  Nothing happened.  Then the trumpet player came over to
our table and told us to dance, so we did!  Just the three of us at first,
but as we jammed others started doing it too... then I broke out my blow pops,
and started passing those around the club.  People were a little taken aback at first, but it was heartwarming to see their faces light up when they got offered
candy.  Then I unwrapped a package of stickers, and slapped them on all the
very grateful bandmembers as they played, and on the dancers, too!
Soon we were all having a fabulous time, and everyone there seemed to be
fasci9nated by our limitless energy.  A couple of tourists from 'dee-own undah'
(sydney, I think it was) asked what we were doing, and I said, 'you ever been
to a rave-up?' and then they realized what we were doing!  OHHHH! they said...
and then they caught the good vibes too.  Try this sometime, you guys!
Pick a non-ravey environment and enjoy the challenge of introducing the fun
that we all know so well.  If the daylight people won't come to raves, well,
then take the rave to them.

Stickers and blowpops to ya,
Timothy

Yeah, well it should have made you nervous.   

4-24-95 Los Angeles Times 
            Bomb information on the internet sets off debate

Only hours after the bomb that shook America, someone posted instructions 
for a repeat performance on the Internet.

It was all there--even a diagram: Mix two widely available chemicals, 
slap on a "booster," attach a detonater, and almost anyone can have a 
bomb like the one being callled the deadliest in U.S. history.

"Democratization and dissemination of the techniques of terrorism," says 
University of Southern California terrorism expert Richard Hrair 
Dekmejian, "is going to breed more violence."
<snip>
************************************************************************

You should be able to guess the rest; "Clamp down on The Internet."

So if you enjoy the right to free speech, you might want to give a fling 
or two of it to the list, or other places.  The terrorism bill that is 
going to roar through congress like a fire through a haystack, most 
likely will assign someone to watch out for our ilk with loose lips.





----- End Included Message -----

For a look at taggging & bombing & piecing and other urban art forms,
check out the book "Bomb the Suburbs" by Upski.  He's a guy who grew up
in downtown Chicago, deeply rooted in hip-hop & graffiti culture.  It's
a good look at many aspects of inner city life.

Precedence: bulk



*** Pure Space
I went to this long running Thursday night party
for the first time a week or two ago.  Also, made it to
the 1 Year anniversary where everything was more expensive
instead of cheaper.  The Sound Factory isn't as bad as one
might gather from rumor and secondhand party chat.  It does
seem thoroughly 'imitation' - the decor, I suppose.  The 
soundsystem is kinda brutal in spots.  Despite any of
this minor stuff, I had a great time.  Lotsa fun 
cute people at this party.  In fact, (and this is
hard to explain) both the dj's and the people here
made for some moments that were very True.

a Ringing feeling.  
one touched - body, mind, and soul.

I wonder what it takes for this to happen?  (how innocent)
I'm reminded of a flamboyant and extremely energetic aquaintance
of mine who, at a small house party, expressed his desire "to give".
Charitable and greatly entertaining.  I think, maybe, any
further elaboration might somehow spoil it all.


*** Eighth House
In all honesty, I kinda avoided this club.  I'm not sure why.
Just going on my instinct.  Anyway, my friends' momentum carried
me there last Thursday.  It was nice.  Sorta what I expected.
On the brainy side of things.  Music and people.  Very social at
the same time.  I could see this kinda club being potentially
sinister - but perhaps not in San Francisco.  If anything, the
people were in complete contrast to the subvert and mutate 
Overtones.  Any of you twitchy acid trance popcorn types 
shouldn't miss out on the dancing that starts up later in 
the evening.  The music is good (and I'm told) quite
hard to find in this town.


*** DV8
I went to some URB party in the basement of DV8.  Dubtribe 
played and they were pretty good.  (They were *really* good at
the 4 yr CU party awhile back)  Anyway, the party was ok.  The
basement is nice.  But, having never been to this nightclub
before, I really wanted to check it all out.  The sfdisco
party was completely separate and I was only allowed to 
look thru some doors into the first floor room.

As luck would have it, I got invited to "Dwight's birthday party"
this Saturday.  Dwight is a semi-famous hairdresser at some posh salon
in the city.  This got me on the guest list and into a private party
held on the second floor.  So many enclaves.  Inner sanctums.  How
many velvet ropes, elevators, doorman, and secret passwords must 
I shuffle thru before feeling Completely and Totally Swank?  Aaahhh,
granted access to the innermost private room with complimentary 
Oysters.  I have Arrived!  Under the false impression that there was
also supposed to be a Diva Fashion Show I was a little disappointed
that my friends and I were among the most dressed up.  Again, this was 
minor and momentary as I now had access to the entire club.  Well ...
anyway, happy birthday Dwight!  Thanks for the invitation.


*** that Sex Party (zippie fundraiser)
I am aware of at least two people who went there and, of course,
had sex.  Now I also recall some people having sex at one of those Evolution
parties awhile back.  And a few weeks before that there was a couple not
so discretely occupying themselves in the basement of 1015.  What is 
the story here?  Also, I met a guy who chomped down an entire Yohimbe
root (no mere extract punch for him) and he claimed to have had a
hard-on for 36 hours straight.  There is no moral to this story.


Dave

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Apr 24 21:19:14 1995

[ broadcast to SFRaves list ]
 I know of one pagan who is organizing an effort to buy land within a
few hour's drive of the San Francisco Bay area , for the purpose of 
having a communally owned site for pagan observances and rituals. Has
this been considered by the Northern California rave community?

 Has this idea been tried in other parts of the USA?

 Has this idea been tried in Britian? How do the new laws affect the
holding of raves on private property , with the permission/participation
of the land owner?

	Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Apr 24 21:23:04 1995

From: larryc@netcom.com (Larry Ching)

Subject: Raves Be Kind ...
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Mon, 24 Apr 1995 21:12:59 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0

Precedence: bulk


[ Group mailing to SFRaves list ]

[ Never get Larry Ching on downers or antihistamines ... he gets sappy 
  and posts strange things ...]

( I want to say ahead of time that when I made my original posts, I had 
  not read about the KIVA folks getting arrested for doing a break-in. I hope 
  they don't get charged too hard for it. )

 This is a combination followup on my recent posts about raves' antisocial 
 aspects.

Fraser Clark described the warehouse situation in England :
> I don't know exactly how things are here, but I do know in
> England, as the System runs down, huge areas of formerly industrial bdgs
> can lie vacant for years as they crumble.  not because the owners don't
> care (many of them would *love* to hire them out) but becuse zoning laws
> and all the rest of it won't allow anything to happen there.  meanwhile
> thousands of ravers (for example) who just want somehwere to dance can
> find nowhere legal. 

 A nice by-product of industrial decay - too bad the empty warehouses around 
here have too many working warehouses ( with security guards ) nearby. 

 A lot of raves' problems with the surrounding human environment come
from not having a true space to be .

 I said:
> ...<I've> bent some laws - sure , but I never concioussly
> wanted to rave if doing so would screw up someone's right to a decent
> night's sleep . Other things I would never want to do is trash the land
> and property of others for the purpose of raving.

To which Fraser replied:
> ... if ravers were allowed to hold raves on
> common land here - after all we pay for its upkeep - there might be less
> reason for using warehouses or even keeping some poor wage slave awake
> for once in his lifetime (why not just join in with the ravers, eh?
> would that really be so bad?)

I know that Fraser actually wishes all the best for our Hypothetical Would-Be
Sleeper ( HWBS).  I hope that the vast majority of SFRavers wishes our HWBS
the best too, and would be pleased if HWBS came to dance.
However, let's imagine the possibilities  for what kind of person the HWBS 
 is -

1. An able-bodied wage slave who could possibly tell a convincing tale 
   of illness over the phone to the boss the next day - most likely to be 
   able to join us.
2. A farmer who put in a hard day's work and will do the same tomorrow.
3. A soul with bad memories of disco who hates any music with a beat. Will
    definitely call the cops on us.
4. Some obnoxious assault-gun toting neo-nazi survivalist hiding out in the 
   woods ( yikes! ).
5. A performer ( artistic or otherwise ) who needs their sleep to give the 
   best possible performance the next day.  Due to fatigue on the performer's 
   part, our rave results in a sub-par performance , harming the performer 
   and the audience.
6. A severly ill person who needs their sleep - so , our rave is acting to 
   shorten their life.
7. A true wage-SLAVE who needs the $$ the job brings. This unfortunate 
   situation can arise for various reasons ( legal debts , family obligations 
   , the medical needs of others , etc. ) , but it's a sure bet that our 
   rave next door holds no direct solution to his problem  - can we give him 
   the alertness he needs to do the job he NEEDS to be at the next day, after 
   we've vandalized his sleep?

 I think that most of the folks I list above have a right to a good night's 
sleep - who are we to take it away from HWBS ?

[ by the way - just for fun , imagine all the above persons as male , then
  female. Does it change/affect your point of view ? ] 

   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

When I talked about ends NOT justifying the means -
>  We've heard the "ends justify the means" line before , and most of us
> wouldn't accept it as a valid excuse in a non-rave context , so why do
> so in a rave context?

  ... I wasn't refering to anything Fraser Clark said, nor was I consciously 
refering to any one person here on SFRaves. I think it was an extreme phrase 
to use in the context of holding and attending raves.

 My point , however overstated , remains - can we as ravers use the "justi-
fication" of being victims if/when we victimize others in pursuit of the vibe?

-------------------------------------------------------------------------

 Back to my antihistamine haze ...

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

At 11:07 PM 23/4/95 -0700, Amy R Starkey wrote:
>Something happened to me that hit me really hard.....have you ever just
>*known* that you were with the right person - trusted them with your
>soul, shared every little thing in your life with him or her, had a
>blissful dream of always being together and most of all *loving* them in
>the most pure and undiluted form that can be possible - then to have it
>severed instantly?

Yes. But it is my opinion that we live in an ultimately just and good
universe, where love is not unrewarded.
Sometimes, one has to allow the tides to change, so perspective can be
gained on what it is that you value.

  How do you deal with it?

You nurture yourself, and learn to allow the universe to love you. then
when you are feeling good again, and in tune, without a need for another in
your life, love and all that warm fuzzy stuff settles quietly on your
shoulder.


a good rule - follow your bliss

hope this helps

david dei

as far as I understand the new CJA (Criminal Justice Act) in the UK such
decisions are now in the hands of the police who can go right over the
head of the owner. an attempt was made some time back to buy a parcel of
land and divide it up into square meters, each held by a different "owner"
so that a rave or festival could move from one "site" to the other. 
sounded good intheory, not sure if cops are "interested" in such fine
points. fraser.

it's "*we*" who are being (quite consciously in most cases) victimised.  
the HWBS is *not* being victimised in this sense ie nobody consciously 
*sets out* to keep others awake.  it's just that there's so little space 
in the city and they won't let us take it to the country.  maybe we 
should just stay home and watch TV like they want us to?

AND, Larry, I'd like to see you construct a List of Ten Ravers whose
entire lives might be changed by holding the rave.  maybe some of them
will even help the poor HWBS change hir life some time later - mysterious
ways indeed, Hir wonders to perform. 

fraser  >:-)

On Mon, 24 Apr 1995, Fred Heutte wrote:

> I know I'm in a small minority on this, and I know my opinion has even
> less value since I haven't been to Burning Man myself, but my honest
> view of it is that the desert deserves more respect than this event
> basically allows.

total nonsense!  we're talking of a square mile at most of, what, several 
hundred thousand square miles of desert.  now Desert Storm is a whole 
other matter. (and every record you bought this year, phred, helped *pay* 
for that)

the press (a few hostile idiots) used this on us last year, namely raving 
in the forest squashed the grass.  my answer then and now is:  how the 
hell are urban kids ever going to learn to app[reciate our natural 
resources if they don't get out there to experience them?  and if urban 
kids don't start appreciating nature soon the *real* urban hooligans will 
have finished polluting the oceans, the atmosphere, aand will probably 
have "tagged" the city till it looks like a manic blackboard jungle on 
acid (besides big the only jungle we have left!)

sorry, phred, but this sort of nitpicking really infuriates me.  for a 
moment.  >:-)

PS  we've been invited to help organise a festi-rave on the weekend 
following the Rainbow Gathering in Taos, New Mexico (peaks on July 4th) 
where we shall also be doing a small but intense rave like last year at 
the Rainbow Gathering in Wyoming (where I first met the Crunchman - see 
you there again, cap'n?)  it'll be in the same area so there will be 2 
wonderful festi-raves in the same week, say between July 2nd and July 
10th? more on this as the facts coalesce.  bring a tent and p[repare for 
wilderness survival but the true meaning of Zippy is Rainbow Raver and 
there's nothing the world needs more right now than a coming-together of 
these two cultural strains.

I'm inviting you here and now, phred, to come play with us at the Rainbow 
GatherRave.  then, if you still feel as you do about the Burning Man, 
well ....

fraser.

Fred,

Absolutely the desert deserves respect and MOST desert areas would not
allow the burning man event... but the area they have it in is actually an
ancient salt lake flat... imagine an area flat and basically devoid of 
plants for miles and miles.... of course, this does absolutely nothing to
hold down the dust...

  At first I had imagined the event in the "typical" desert area where the
impact of hundreds of people would be devastating on the plant life ( some
cactii only grow less than 1" per year so knocking down an 8" cactus could
be destroying a 10+ year old growth effort ). The actual area is basically
a no growth area since the soil is so hard and mineralized.

  The Cacaphony Society put this event on ( it started with the first burning
man on a beach near SF some 10 years or so ago ). They are a great bunch
of "alternative types" and do such events as Kill Your TV and the SF
sewer walk ( in formal attire and sneakers ). I videoed the Kill Your TV this
Fall ( the TV killing segment I have shown at F&F's ) and may very well
attend and video the Burning Man over Labor Day... it's a very unique and
pagan event - and the Cacaphony Soc. are definitely not trying to be 
disrespectful to the desert any more than ravers celebrating with loud music
on a beach are being disrespectful to nature. Although some people would
say disrupting the quiet of nature is disrespect :-)

 Mike


 meclay@netcom.com          |  Alone & estatic 
 Mike Clay   (415)572-8971  |  A young rainbow learns  to levitate.

On Mon, 24 Apr 1995, Fred Heutte wrote:

>I know I'm in a small minority on this, and I know my opinion has even
>less value since I haven't been to Burning Man myself, but my honest
>view of it is that the desert deserves more respect than this event
>basically allows.  
>
>phred

I had this concern last year but the event is very kind to the desert.
I stayed through Tues. to help with the clean up and basically all that was
left was a few scorched areas in the playa. (The playa is 400 square miles
of dry alkaline lake bed which contains no life except what we bring - not 
even micro-organisms.)

The energy there is intense and very primal.  I think one of the reasons the
playa is there is for events and spiritual happenings like this.  

On Tues, 25 Apr 1995 Fraser wrote:

>my answer then and now is:  how the hell are urban kids ever going to learn 
>to app[reciate our natural resources if they don't get out there to experience 
>them? 

I also have to agree with fraser on the eye opening this event does for many
as to the beauty and wonder of the desert and the need to perserve it.  (Many 
people who are into saving the trees and rivers aren't as concerned about the
desert as they buy into the barren wasteland theory.)

The Newt King

I hope that you, un-like me, were fortunate enough not to be at Porgress 
on Saturday night.  Despite a good set from Mark Farina this was with out 
a doubt the most badly organized party I think that I have ever been to 
in SF.  There was no chill-out room and all the deco and effects looked 
like they had been bought at safeway.  They also were well into their 
philosophy tip to the p[point where you got bombarded with new way of 
thinking weather you wanted to or not.  If you feel you have to think a 
a certain way in order to enjoy a party and the organizer's also take this 
attitude then they are looking to exclude rather then include and, to me, 
this defeats the whole purpose as to why one throws parties in the first 
place.
If you need help on how to have a good party at a nightclub, and you do, 
talk to the Zippies because they certainly know how to throw a good party 
in that space.  Also, get off this celestian prophacy tip as soon as 
possible because all it is doing is alienating people rather then making 
them feel more comfortable.  I know the people who organized this party (I 
love you Clair but Saturday night was a complete fuck-up) and they do, I 
am afraid to say, confirm all my fears as to what happens when you have 
young middle-class white kids trying run a club: it does not work.
Please make your next party free because I am sure that all the people 
who paid $10 wished that they stayed at home.  Next time they will so 
heed my warning.  And Clair (or anybody else for that matter) go and talk 
to Frazer from the Zippies: he REALLY knows how to throw a good party and 
he could teach you a lot.
Also, stop playing mundane techno, we've all had enough of that music 
because it was shit when it came out and it has not got better threw time.   

Better luck next time.  Love Tristan

Indeed I am!

On Tue, 25 Apr 1995, Fraser Clark wrote:

[ad and other stuff deleted]

> total nonsense!  we're talking of a square mile at most of, what, several 
> hundred thousand square miles of desert.  now Desert Storm is a whole 
> other matter. (and every record you bought this year, phred, helped *pay* 
> for that)

[stuff deleted]

> the press (a few hostile idiots) used this on us last year, namely raving 
> in the forest squashed the grass.  my answer then and now is:  how the 
> hell are urban kids ever going to learn to app[reciate our natural 
> resources if they don't get out there to experience them?  

How about by participating in environmentally beneficial activities 
like: restoring streams, wetlands and other habitat; clearing out 
invasive plants and replacing them with natives; cleaning up 
beaches; monitoring creeks and rivers; planting trees in wildlife 
preserves; etc. etc.???  All these opportunities and more are available to 
urban kids through school curricula, neighborhood outreach programs, 
and a wide variety of interest groups. 

My group and others sponsor specific hands-on programs 
that get urban schoolchildren out into the natural environment where they 
can see direct improvement in the world as a result of their work and 
where they take ownership and personal responsibility for their environment, 
i.e., their own neighborhood. By extension, they become stewards of our 
earth. These urban kids describe wildlife as "rat" and "cockroach." They 
think the Bay they see out at the Berkeley Marina is the ocean. These 
urban kids are not the ones who have $25 plus travel and expenses to go 
to Burning Man, unless there's some scholarship program I'm not aware of.
So if you're arguing that Burning Man is going to raise urban kids' 
environmental consciousness, I don't think the argument makes sense. 

I agree with Phred. The desert, every square mile of it, deserves our 
respect. The world no longer has the luxury of considering any wilderness 
area expendable, as you seem to suggest, Frasier. The desert is an 
incredibly fragile ecosystem. What looks like a 
barren stretch of sand can host a diverse array of plant and animal life. 
Walking, driving and indeed dancing on it can threaten the soil structure 
and lead to ongoing and irreversible erosion. Raving is not necessarily an 
environmentally benign activity, particularly at outdoor events where 
some people leave trash, use the world as their own personal ashtray, stomp 
around on sensitive wetlands and marshes and yes, squash the grass. And 
if the press calls us on it, they're not necessarily hostile idiots. If 
the impression we leave is that of careless disrespect for our Mother 
Earth, what else can we expect?

Kathryn

sorry, fraser, while i've agreed with most of what you've said up to this 
point, i've got strongly disagree here...

the idea of 800 ravers keeping someone awake all night and getting away 
with it because "they're the majority" is ridiculous.  this is just mob 
action, even violence if you will (if someone needs to sleep because they 
are sick or get sick as a result of their lack of sleep.)  you may say, 
well, join the rave!, but not everyone can just up and take off of work 
all the time, or, as larry suggested, some people need sleep for 
different reasons.   (however, i will concede that people who build 
estates on common land really shouldn't have a say in the matter.)

granted, there are not enough places for us to celebrate, but i still 
think we must minimize our (physical) impact as much as possible, for our 
own sake (to avoid getting busted), AS WELL AS for the sake of people 
around us.  some people just don't like techno all the time and that does 
not mean they're "unenlightened."  

and while it may be true that "nobody consciously *sets out* to keep 
other people awake," not taking care to ensure that you don't is 
negligent and irresponsible.  it's like, oh, i didn't MEAN to shoot you, 
sorry!  (to use an extreme example)

and i am most definitely NOT suggesting we stay inside and watch TV!  
there ARE ways of minimizing our impact regarding sound:

- set up the speakers so the sound does not travel far outside the 
building, or if outside, face them towards somewhere unpopulated.  do 
sound checks.

- invest in some sound blankets - they're cheap!

- the sound does not always have to be turned up to the maximum volume.  
this DOES cause hearing damage.  (what?)   (imho, the sound should be 
loud enough on the dance floor that people cannot easily carry on a 
conversation, but soft enough so that away from the dance floor they can.)

- IF AT ALL POSSIBLE, let neighbors know you'll be having a party.  


granted, sometimes we may step on people's toes (like, i'll assume every 
time we have a party outside where homeless people live we wake them up), 
but again, this should be avoided at all costs.  


with love and @,
monicat

ah, dear tristan, time to take issue with you again...

> 
> I hope that you, un-like me, were fortunate enough not to be at Porgress 
> on Saturday night.  ....
 They also were well into their 
> philosophy tip to the p[point where you got bombarded with new way of 
> thinking weather you wanted to or not.  If you feel you have to think a 
> a certain way in order to enjoy a party and the organizer's also take this 
> attitude then they are looking to exclude rather then include and, to me, 
> this defeats the whole purpose as to why one throws parties in the first 
> place.

got to disagree here...people throw parties for different reasons.  some 
of us throw mega-parties where (almost) anything goes, anyone 
comes...others of us throw parties for ourselves and our friends and 
maybe anyone who is interested, and this may include parties with 
specific philosophical, spiritual and political ideas highlighted.  there 
is nothing wrong with that; if you don't like it, don't come.  this does 
not mean the party is "exclusive."  focused perhaps, but not 
exclusive.  of 
course, i would hope that on their flyers they might have 
mentioned taht the party was about the celestine prophecy, etc. (i didn't 
see any flyers so i don't know)... that way, people know what they're 
getting into. 

> If you need help on how to have a good party at a nightclub, and you do, 
> talk to the Zippies because they certainly know how to throw a good party 
> in that space.  Also, get off this celestian prophacy tip as soon as 
> possible because all it is doing is alienating people rather then making 
> them feel more comfortable.  

again, there is room for just about everyone in the rave 
scene/movement/whatever.  while you may not like the celestine prophecy 
stuff, others may.  are you saying that there's only one way to throw a 
party - the zippy way?  it sure sounds like it.  

(and may i remind you that your zippy parties are full of ideology which 
some people may not agree with, but whatever!  it's your right to throw a 
party the way you want to.)

  they do, I 
> am afraid to say, confirm all my fears as to what happens when you have 
> young middle-class white kids trying run a club: it does not work.
> 

please, tristan, get over your guilt-tripping and race-baiting and 
assumptions about 
people based on their backgrounds.  it's not where you come from, it's 
what you believe and how you act in the world.  

granted, there may be aspects of some raves that are very 
"middle-class" - e.g. the price, the location, maybe the attitude - 
and are exclusive.  but that does not mean that things can't be 
changed and that "middle class white kids" can't run a club.  (and may i 
remind you that megatripolis was quite exclusive price-wise.)

> heed my warning.  And Clair (or anybody else for that matter) go and talk 
> to Frazer from the Zippies: he REALLY knows how to throw a good party and 
> he could teach you a lot.

my dear, frazer is NOT god.  megatripolis had its ups and its downs, as 
do most parties.

> Also, stop playing mundane techno, we've all had enough of that music 
> because it was shit when it came out and it has not got better threw time.   
> 
umm... shouldn't you have learned by now not to go to parties with techno 
if you hate it that much?  


better luck on your next post,

monicat

Okay guys, listen--if the desert involved in Burning Man is as desolate as 
Brian describes, and I'm sure it is, there's no need to lose sleep over 
environmental impact.  Goodness, when we drive to raves around here nobody
frets about CO2 emissions, or I haven't heard of anyone rearranging blades
of grass after a sunset rave, or anything like that.  And stomping on dirt
DOES NOT cause erosion when it's not on an incline... and erosion, on a cosmic
perspective, is no big deal anyway.  It changes things, but it just reallocates
soil, that's all.  One area loses dirt, another area gains dirt.  The soil
doesn't evaporate, guys.  There's no net loss, you know.  This planet is going
to be around for quite a while, and while we should be environmentally responsible, we should also remember that the universe will still glide along without
bothering to stop and read the scientific journals.
Peace and lollipops,
Timothy

Besides which, thermodynamically, raves are very non-universe-friendly! 
By expending so much energy irreversibly, we only increase the entropy of 
the universe, thus moving it ever closer to its eventual perfectly random 
death. Maybe we should all just sit in our rooms and hold our breath:-)

Hello,

I am writing this on behalf of the Mother Earth Sound System, to offer an 
explanation of what happened Saturday night, and our most sincere 
apologies for all of you who were inconvenienced in any way.

After losing our space on Friday, we tried to find another permitted all 
ages location without success, and Saturday night were informed of a space 
in SF that had been used several times before for break-in parties.  
Around midnight, without actually having entered the building, myself, Brad, 
Eric and Danielle were picked up by the SFPD and charged with attempted 
burglary, possession of burglary tools, and conspiracy (a felony 
charge).  Our combined bail was set at $41,000, and we thank those of you 
who were prepared to help us with it, but fortunately, on Sunday evening 
our charges were dropped (except one citation) and we were released.

Once again, Mother Eath Sound System would like to offer its deepest 
apologies for any inconvenience caused by Saturday's events.  Due to the 
volume of calls between 12-6 am, we could not even change our voicemail 
message, an unforeseen problem that we are looking into.  A number of 
things led us to attempt to do KIVA despite the risky circumstances 
we faced, and basically our desire to have an all ages gathering that 
night blurred our judgement, and we are fortunate that we escaped as we 
did, and that no partygoers were involved in what could have been a much 
worse situation.  

Much as we may disagree with and dislike the legal restrictions imposed 
on the simple human right of gathering and dancing, 
going up against the Man in such a direct way doesn't seem to be the 
answer, even though it can make a pretty powerful symbolic statement.  
Can we make the same sort of statement at a legal party?  People like 
Spiral Tribe or DIY, throwing free outdoor parties in England in defiance 
of the Criminal Justice Bill, might say no, the power of creating a truly 
autonomous zone for ourselves is worth the risk of jail, but then again, 
the relationship of the rave community and the rest of society is 
becoming an increasingly political one over there.  Over here, until 
things (may they never) get that confrontational, it looks like we'll 
try to work with the System just enough to make the party go off, which 
is what we'll be doing in a few weeks, hopefully.  We've located a legal 
indoor space which we'd like to use to do a make-up party for KIVA, and 
we'll keep you all posted on that as it develops.  In the mean time, 
we're doing a party at Le Chateau in Berkeley this Saturday 29th,  
benefitting Latin American refugees, more details as we sort it out, and 
if you're interested our info #s are: 415.487.7681 and 510.549.6260.


Much respect,

			MOTHER EARTH SOUND SYSTEM
			*************************
			UNITE  CELEBRATE  SURVIVE

>Received from various individuals:
>
>>----- Begin Included Message -----
>>
>>There is a computer virus that is being sent across the Internet.  If
>>you receive an e-mail message with the subject line "Good Times", DO
>>NOT read the message, DELETE it immediately.  Please read the
>>messages below.
>>
>>Some miscreant is sending e-mail under the title "good times"
>>nation-wide. If you get anything like this, DON'T DOWNLOAD THE FILE! It
>>has a virus that rewrites your hard drive, obliterating anything on it. 
>>Please be careful and forward this mail to anyone you care about--I
>>have.
>>
>>The FCC released a warning last Wednesday concerning a matter of
>>major importance to any regular user of the InterNet.  Apparently, a new
>>computer virus has been engineered by a user of America Online that is
>>unparalleled in its destructive capability.  Other, more well-known 
>>viruses
>>such as Stoned, Airwolf, and Michaelangelo pale in comparison to the
>>prospects of this newest creation by a warped mentality.
>>
>>What makes this virus so terrifying, said the FCC, is the fact that
>>no program needs to be exchanged for a new computer to be infected. 
>>It can be spread through the existing e-mail systems of the InterNet. 
>>Once a computer is infected, one of several things can happen.  If the
>>computer contains  hard drive, that will most likely be destroyed. If 
>>the
>>program is not stopped, the computer's processor will be placed in an
>>nth-complexity infinite binary loop - which can severely damage
>>the processor if  left running that way too long.  Unfortunately, most
>>novice computer users will not realize what is happening until it is far 
>>too
>>late.
>>
>>Luckily, there is one sure means of detecting what is now known as
>>the "Good Times" virus.  It always travels to new computers the same
>>way in a text e-mail message with the subject line reading simply "Good
>>Times".  Avoiding infection is easy once the file has been received - 
>>not
>>reading it.  The act of loading the file into the mail server's ASCII 
>>buffer
>>causes the "Good Times" mainline program to initialize and execute.
>>The program is highly intelligent - it will send copies of itself to 
>>everyone
>>whose e-mail address is contained in a received-mail file or a sent-
>>mail file, if it can find one.  It will then proceed to trash the 
>>computer it is
>>running on.
>>
>>The bottom line here is - If you receive a file with the subject line
>>"Good Times",  delete it  immediately!  Do not read it!  Rest assured
>>that whoever's name was on the "From:" line was surely struck by the
>>virus.
>>
>>Warn your friends and local system users of this newest threat to the
>>InterNet!  It could save them a lot of time and money.
>>
>>
>>
>>
>>----- End Included Message -----

 ------------------- A - T - T - E - N - T - I - O - N -------------------
|  CIAC is available 24-hours a day via its two skypage numbers.  To use  |
|  this service, dial 1-800-759-7243.  The PIN numbers are: 8550070 (for  |
|  the CIAC duty person) and 8550074 (for the CIAC manager).  Please keep |
|  these numbers handy.                                                   |
 -------------------------------------------------------------------------

Welcome to the fourth issue of CIAC Notes!  This is a special edition to
clear up recent reports of a "good times" virus-hoax.  Let us know if you
have topics you would like addressed or have feedback on what is useful and
what is not.  Please contact the editor, Allan L. Van Lehn, CIAC,
510-422-8193 or send E-mail to ciac@llnl.gov. 

  $-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$
  $ Reference to any specific commercial product does not necessarily   $
  $ constitute or imply its endorsement, recommendation or favoring by  $
  $ CIAC, the University of California, or the United States Government.$
  $-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$-$

THE "Good Times" VIRUS IS AN URBAN LEGEND

In the early part of December, CIAC started to receive information requests
about a supposed "virus" which could be contracted via America OnLine, simply
by reading a message.  The following is the message that CIAC received: 

 ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
| Here is some important information. Beware of a file called Goodtimes.    |
|                                                                           |
|  Happy Chanukah everyone, and be careful out there. There is a virus on   |
| America Online being sent by E-Mail.  If you get anything called "Good    |
| Times", DON'T read it or download it.  It is a virus that will erase your |
| hard drive.  Forward this to all your friends.  It may help them a lot.   |
 ---------------------------------------------------------------------------

THIS IS A HOAX.  Upon investigation, CIAC has determined that this message
originated from both a user of America Online and a student at a university
at approximately the same time, and it was meant to be a hoax. 

CIAC has also seen other variations of this hoax, the main one is that any
electronic mail message with the subject line of "xxx-1" will infect your
computer. 

This rumor has been spreading very widely.  This spread is due mainly to the
fact that many people have seen a message with "Good Times" in the header. 
They delete the message without reading it, thus believing that they have
saved themselves from being attacked. These first-hand reports give a false
sense of credibility to the alert message. 

There has been one confirmation of a person who received a message with
"xxx-1" in the header, but an empty message body.  Then, (in a panic, because
he had heard the alert), he checked his PC for viruses (the first time he
checked his machine in months) and found a pre-existing virus on his machine.
 He incorrectly came to the conclusion that the E-mail message gave him the
virus (this particular virus could NOT POSSIBLY have spread via an E-mail
message).  This person then spread his alert. 

As of this date, there are no known viruses which can infect merely through
reading a mail message.  For a virus to spread some program must be executed.
Reading a mail message does not execute the mail message.  Yes, Trojans have
been found as executable attachments to mail messages, the most notorious
being the IBM VM Christmas Card Trojan of 1987, also the TERM MODULE Worm
(reference CIAC Bulletin B-7) and the GAME2 MODULE Worm (CIAC Bulletin B-12).
 But this is not the case for this particular "virus" alert. 

If you encounter this message being distributed on any mailing lists, simply
ignore it or send a follow-up message stating that this is a false rumor. 

Karyn Pichnarczyk
CIAC Team
ciac@llnl.gov


------------------------------
Contacting CIAC

If you require additional assistance or wish to report a vulnerability, call
CIAC at 510-422-8193, fax messages to 510-423-8002 or send E-mail to
ciac@llnl.gov.  For emergencies and off-hour assistance, call 1-800-SKY-PAGE
(759-7243) and enter PIN number 8550070 (primary) or 8550074 (secondary). 
The CIAC Duty Officer, a rotating responsibility, carries the primary
skypager. The Project Leader carries the secondary skypager.  If you are
unable to contact CIAC via phone, please use the skypage system.

        Well I hate to contradict someone when they're 99% (maybe)
right, but a false sense of security can be dangerous (where have we
heard this before).

        One of the earliest "viruses" around exploited a "feature" of
some DEC terminals (this is in the pre-PC days).  They allowed some
function keys to be programmed via escape codes over the serial line.
They also allowed the function keys to be activated via escape codes,
if I recall correctly.  The result was that it was possible to send a "mail
bomb" which would result in the terminal sending commands back to the
system -- masquerading as the recipient.  "DELETE *.*" quite possibly.

        Now call it coincidence but AOL also has a front-end which runs
on the customer's PC and can be activated by escape codes.  I've only
spent a few hours in AOL chat and I've seen it exploited (for amusement 
only fortunately).

        The recent email that has been floating around re "good times"
is obviously off the deep end -- not restricted to AOL anymore and including
a bunch of gobbledygook intended to create FUD (fear uncertainty doubt).
However, like many urban legends, it may be rooted in reality.  And as
MIME and other "active" mail formats become more popular, there will be
more opportunities for unpleasant/immature people to find ways to make
"mail bombs".  As they say, the only perfect security is a good backup.

Andrew
-----------------------------------------
Andrew Knutsen            andrewk@sco.com
Santa Cruz Operation      (408) 427-7538

> >>the
> >>program is not stopped, the computer's processor will be placed in an

> >>novice computer users will not realize what is happening until it is far 
> >>too
> >>late.

> >>way in a text e-mail message with the subject line reading simply "Good
> >>Times".  Avoiding infection is easy once the file has been received - 
> >>not
> >>reading it.  The act of loading the file into the mail server's ASCII 
> >>buffer
> >>causes the "Good Times" mainline program to initialize and execute.
> >>The program is highly intelligent - it will send copies of itself to 
> >>everyone
> >>whose e-mail address is contained in a received-mail file or a sent-

> >>computer it is
> >>running on.

ARGHH!!! I hate these hoaxes. There is NO virus that will damage a 
processor. The only machine that had an actual command that you could 
enter to damage it was the PET by Commodore in the early 80's. There are no 
viruses that are started because you simply read a message(except MAYBE, 
under very specific circumstances ANSI BOMB's which are not the same thing.)
A similar "warning" with the same subject (supposed "Good Times" virus) 
was posted here a few months back, only now the story has been 
embellished slightly with the FCC issuing the warning. Look at the AC for 
the supposed author. Alabama is AC 205. Relax, this warning is B.S. 

                                                Black Adder

> > > total nonsense!  we're talking of a square mile at most of, what,several

> > hundred thousand square miles of desert.  now Desert Storm is a whole
> > other matter. (and every record you bought this year, phred, helped
> > *pay* for that) 
> > [stuff deleted] 

> > > the press (a few hostile idiots) used this on us last year, namely 
raving 
> > in the forest squashed the grass.  my answer then and now is:  how the
> > hell are urban kids ever going to learn to app[reciate our natural 
> > resources if they don't get out there to experience them?  

 > How about by participating in environmentally beneficial activities 
>  like: restoring streams, wetlands and other habitat; clearing out 
> invasive plants and replacing them with natives; cleaning up 
> beaches; monitoring creeks and rivers; planting trees in wildlife 
> preserves; etc. etc.??? All these opportunities and more are available to 
> urban kids through school curricula, neighborhood outreach programs, 
> and a wide variety of interest groups.
> I agree with Phred. The desert, every square mile of
it, deserves our > respect. The world no longer has the luxury of
considering any wilderness > area expendable, as you seem to suggest,
Frasier. The desert is an > incredibly fragile ecosystem. What looks like
a > barren stretch of sand can host a diverse array of plant and animal
life.  > Walking, driving and indeed dancing on it can threaten the soil
structure > and lead to ongoing and irreversible erosion. Raving is not
necessarily an > environmentally benign activity, particularly at outdoor
events where > some people leave trash, use the world as their own
personal ashtray, stomp > around on sensitive wetlands and marshes and
yes, squash the grass. And > if the press calls us on it, they're not
necessarily hostile idiots. If > the impression we leave is that of
careless disrespect for our Mother > Earth, what else can we expect? > >
Kathryn

good work, kathryn .. but about what percentage of urban kids do
you think these sorts of programs actually convert?  RC has the
possibility to convert a whole generation, to make it *fashionable* (dare
I say it?!) to *care*. it's all been seen in the Uk for the last few years
- older rainbow types moaning about "all these urban types who won't clean
up after themselves"  and eg break dwon trees to make fires that won't
even light 'cos the wood's green.  BUT, after a while, they *get* it. 
just like each of us did, presumably.  and then they turn on others and so
it goes - now it's *ver* very "fashionable for lioterally thousands of
raver kids to go out and try to stop motorway building and all the rest of
it. truly, they do get radicalised by being out there - and they're not
going to go in large numbers for "replanting ceremonies".  that's just a
fact.  to make a fuss about the damage while thery're learning is to miss
the point that it's *corporate vandalism* that's 99% of the problem.  and
the only real way to stop *that* is for a "peoples movement" demanding it. 
and how do you create that if most urban kids, as you point out, think the
Bay is the Ocean.  you gotta get 'em out there to *experience* it.  we're
on the same side.  we're arguing about tactics.  and if, as you seem, you
know how fragile the balance is and how late the hour is, then you have to
realise that the methods you describe just won't do it. IMHO
and think much bigger and much more determinedly
fraser

Well, I didn't think I would be back so soon - what 2 whole days?!?!?  I 
wanted to say a hearty *thank you* to all who responded to my post on 
Sunday evening.  If I didn't respond to you personally, I am doing it 
now.  I was nearly overwhelmed at all the love and support I recieved 
from so many.  It gave me such hope and faith in this whole thing called 
a rave community.  You all showed me it exists *fully* and I am 
***PROUD*** to be a part of it!! :)  My heart is now 
stronger than ever, although I'm still quite sad at what happened - time 
heals that.  And so do great people and great music - which is why if 
Sunset is happening this weekend I am going to be there *for sure*!!
I've just got to meet you all - especially those who gave me such warm 
words these last few days (and you know who you are:) Thank you again.

live with PLUR 
and it will come 
back to you......
luv,

hey all,

  in my photojournalism class today i was showing some of the pictures
i had been taking for my photo essay about  raves and stuff and my
teacher asks me "what are raves?"

  before i can respons one lady says "everyone is on drugs there."
and then another person is like "yeah they all do ecstacy there."
  and yet another person is like "when i went to one all thes people
were touching me."

  i tried to break in and give a explanation about raves "you know
they are big dance parties where people can come together no matter 
who they are and just dance and have fun without attitudes and fights
and all that."


  which someone replys "yeah, cause everyone is on x (ecstacy)


  needless to say the encounter as a whole pissed me off and leads me
to ask:  "What can i say or what can i do to make raves sound like
something to check out?"

  i mean  the stuff about everyone together dancing and having a good 
time must sound to someone who hasent been to one like some stupid
joke or something, but its true.

  ive been in the scene for awhile and have gone through my cynical
cycle on how raves are a joke, but i keep coming back cause i like
the openess, the ability to walk up to someone and say "hi" and 
to dance my ass off smiling and having a good time.


  why is that so hard for a lot of people to understand??

doug ) ( dougie@netcom.com

fine, monicat, there would be something wrong if we agreed *all* the 
time.  >:-)

I take *all* your points, but I just think we're being far too 
apologetic.  if we were living in a close-to-paradise culture and a whole 
bunch of rude kids showed up ... well, sure, *BUT WE'RE NOT*. hell, it's 
even illegal to walk around *naked*, for Goddess' sake!!!  see my point?  
this culture is so repressed that even the naked body upsets people.

how about the following for a general policy:  turn people ON, don't turn 
them OFF.  but don't let's turn *ourselves* OFF either because that won't 
ultimately help *anyone*.
fraser

> > area?  I make it:  800 YES and 6 NO.  "sorry, lads, the NOs have it!"???
