> > > fication" of being victims if/when we victimize others in pursuit of the vibe?
> > > 
> > it's "*we*" who are being (quite consciously in most cases) victimised.  
> > the HWBS is *not* being victimised in this sense ie nobody consciously 
> > *sets out* to keep others awake.  it's just that there's so little space 
> > in the city and they won't let us take it to the country.  maybe we 
> > should just stay home and watch TV like they want us to?
> 
> sorry, fraser, while i've agreed with most of what you've said up to this 
> point, i've got strongly disagree here...
> 
> the idea of 800 ravers keeping someone awake all night and getting away 
> with it because "they're the majority" is ridiculous.  this is just mob 
> action, even violence if you will (if someone needs to sleep because they 

I was suggesting a democratic vote, not mob action.  rephrase what you 
said and you get this:  the idea of someone making 800 others stay home 
and keep quiet because they're the minority is ridiculous. and a lot worse.
 
> - the sound does not always have to be turned up to the maximum volume.  
> this DOES cause hearing damage.  (what?)   (imho, the sound should be 
> loud enough on the dance floor that people cannot easily carry on a 
> conversation, but soft enough so that away from the dance floor they can.)

totally agree.  at the ChemicaSutras (last friday's one was amazing) we've
been keeping the volume probably half what you'd normally expect and it
works (actually) even better! 

> > > granted, sometimes we may step on people's toes (like, i'll assume 
every > time we have a party outside where homeless people live we wake
them up), > but again, this should be avoided at all costs.  >

interestingly tangential point, monicat.  wonder if larry gives them the
same weight he gives the wage slave.  oh and BTW when I say wage slave I'm
not being hostile to that person.  I *care* very deeply that hir whole
life is being shafted by the current system.  *nobody* should be forced by
a lifetime of hypnotic propaganda and financial controls to be a wage
slave.  we and the planet need a lot *less* "busyness", a *lot* less. and
a lot less consumption. nor am I telling anyone how they should live
(before the flames start).  I'm not holding a gun or a new law to stop you
doing anything.  but I *am* sugesting very stronlgly indeed (and shall
continue to do it - it's the planet that makes me do it!!) that maybe
others have been doing that to you and you should start deconditioning
yourself.  look at it beyond the kneejerk reaction of "aw, but then I
couldn't buy that neat new whatever I thought meant life and death to me!"

let the flaming begin. 

fraser

On Tue, 25 Apr 1995, Michael E. Clay wrote:
> attend and video the Burning Man over Labor Day... it's a very unique and
> pagan event - and the Cacaphony Soc. are definitely not trying to be 
> disrespectful to the desert any more than ravers celebrating with loud music
> on a beach are being disrespectful to nature. Although some people would
> say disrupting the quiet of nature is disrespect :-)

I was once at an all-night rave in Somerset and, when we'd finally danced 
the sun up, pagan style, we realised that the entire fenced-off dance area, 
 was surrounded by literally hundreds of curious looking cows, all 
gazing at us.  they didn't look "victimised" to me.  
rock'nroll music kills plants.  but plants thrive under house music, and 
it's well established (in the UK anyway) that house music helps a baby 
fall asleep. (not asleep yet?  turn up the volume!)   certainly I can sleep 
thru house music - if the spirit moves me, or, rather, doesn't.
fraser

On 25 Apr 1995, Amy Esken wrote:

>                       RE>>Technoerotic expedition                  4/25/95
> 
> thank you for the wonderful party. 
> I enjoyed
> I think I am still a little confused. Was there something going on there that
> I was not privy to. People kept dodging in and out of rooms. Did I miss
> something. How is this party planning to go on the road. Will it remain
> intimate. How were the people who attended this party interrelated. What made
> that teaspoon of green liquid so soul warming. Who had the inspiration ( and
> the time ) to create the Museum of the erotica. Why are you involved with
> this. 
> I may be bothering you, you seem to have a lot of people demanding your
> focus, but I am merely curious. It never hurts to ask. Well, sometimes it
> hurts... I guess I like the pain.
> Please send my warm thoughts to Dan. He is a heart winner.
> Thanks, 
> Amy

amy, 
certainly there were things happening that you missed.  me too.  one of 
our main aims in throwing a party is definitely to leave everyone with 
the feeling that they missed plenty.  I love that feeling personally.  we 
even used to put up confusing signs in Meatripolis/London to make sure 
people were even more lost than before (in the nicest possible way, of 
course!)  lost as in an eastern bazaar.
as for going on the roae and keeping it intimate.  not entirely sure on 
this one yet.  I think we cold esily go up to 300 people andkeep the 
intimacy.  above that I'm not sure.
and here we segue into your next question.  the people who were there 
were drawn from all walks of life as I'm sure you noticed.  the way 
through to your last question is probably to build this "family" of 
people (maybe let 'em in free next time) so that the "intimacy"  alreaddy 
outnumbers the alienation.  see what I mean?
the lovely green liquid has been used among certain african tribes for 
their fortnight-long sexual initiations.  as for the "scientific" reason, 
ask Dan, or get the book andfind out about some of the other totally 
legal Romance Drugs (as I prefer to call them):
[ Better Sex Through Chemistry - A Guide to the New Prosexual Drugs.  It's 
available from us for $14.95 (plus $3 postage)  cheques to Megatripolis - 
BOX 12, 3288 21st St, SF, CA 94110) ]
I'm involved because the author asked us to organise a book rave launch, 
having attended our book rave for Leary's new book last november.
the museum was put together by John Wickett, the handsome sparkly-eyed 
old guy who was bustling about.
don't mind you asking questions at all!
don't miss the Cyberlab 7 Safari on May 12th.  get the digital camera 
booked now!
>:-)   fraser.

        bmcgonig@pacific.abbotthpd.com, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Mime-Version: 1.0

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Don't you DARE lecture me, Fraser Clark, about environmental issues, or
about the Gulf War for that matter.  I've been an energy consultant for
well over 15 years.  I marched in *three* cities -- San Francisco, Seattle
and Portland -- against the war.  I know all about oil and vinyl, my friend.

So it's "only one square mile" of the desert being used by Burning Man.
Well, you could have mentioned that two-thirds of the desert West is
basically used primarily by the US military -- ask any of the ranchers
about fighter jet overflights.  And of course Nevada is the home of
the underground nuclear test sites and numerous other environmental
insults.

Which is the *very* reason I object to what I perceive as the basic
approach to Burning Man, which is to practice pseudo-mystical self-
indulgence in the extreme environment of the desert.  Quite frankly,
though I have considerable trouble with the social climate of the
Rainbow tribal scene, I have much more respect for their approach to
the land.  

In the most pure and extreme of environmental zones, whether it's the
high desert, rainforests, arctic tundra or seashores, we must tread the
most lightly.  The marks of Rommel's tanks can still be found in the
North African deserts, and the same for maneuvers practiced by the US
Army in the south of California *before* World War I.  I wonder what
residues Burning Man leaves behind?  

I do not insist that everyone follow my way of thinking on this.  I'm
only saying this is what my heart tells me about the Burning Man event.
Others' mileage may well vary.

phred

X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.2.0 06sep94)
To: geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White), phred@well.com
Subject: Re: Burning Man
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Several people have asked me to elaborate on my responses about Burning Man.
As I said, this is purely a personal view.  I've read some of the newsletters,
some of the reportage, and talked with quite a few participants.  I get
the sense it's well organized, has a serious purpose as well as a sort of
let-it-all-hang-out-attitude, and most people who've gone really had a 
good time.

All the same, I guess it's the environmental purist in me rebelling against
some of the reported aspects of the event.  And you know, I really can't
put my finger exactly on what it is that bothers me.  I know that will
upset those who like the event, but please understand me -- it's not that
I want to take away from anyone's enjoyment, it's that my heart stronglyu
tells me this is NOT the event for me.  

We all make choices about what things to do in this life.  I'm sure there
are people we know would *love* to go to our rave-type events, and just
can't bring themselves to do so.  As in my case with Burning Man, they
may not have *valid* or *well-informed* reasons for this from our point
of view, but we have to respect decisions like that which are not reached
lightly.  

So rather than turn this into an extended riff, I'll just leave it at that.

see ya
phred

The so-called "alert" about the "Good Times Virus" has *itself* become
a nuisance meta-virus of a sort.  It keeps circulating on email systems
around the world (this is, what, the second year of this?!) and seemingly
cannot be eradicated.  It even showed up in a corporate email system
where I'm the sysadmin.  Sigh . . .

Rave Culture (since the first week the Zippies appeared on the net) about
which I knew more than you know today on the day you first discovered it.
I didn't complain, I took it on the chin - and still do.  I marched (and
puffed) against the Vietnam War when you were still in diapers.  I put on
a Rave Against the Grave (of Desert Storm) at the Fridge in Brixton the
night your president ordered your possibly future president to launch the
invasion.  And I've never yet made a penny off my efforts, mi amigo and
fellow conspirator, let alone get paid a salary for it. So just grin/smile 
and bear it.   >:-)

[ to SFRaves mailist ]

 I'm afraid that raves have spoiled me , as I now find the average annoyances
of rock concerts much more annoying.

 Tonight , I actually lost my temper at someone - the first time for me at
a rock concert or rave . Near the last half of the concert I went to tonight,
a gal came up behind me ( I was at the edge of the stage ) , and started
in with derogatory words and gestures aimed at the singer. This was somewhat
alarming , but she would also YELL at the singer while her mouth was
4 inches from my left ear. Also lunging towards the stage whenever the singer
got close to our side of the stage ( which was often ).

 Unfortunetly for me, the pitch of her scream was just at the frequencies
where my hearing HURTS, so , finally , I lost it and shoved her in front
of me in order to avoid her YELLING in my ear one more time. Needless to
say , her friends were alarmed , and things were tense for awhile. Things
got back to semi-civilized level ( for the middle of a rock concert ) - 
I later learned that she was a tour guest of the band , and a friend of the 
singer. All the shit she was yelling at him was meant in fun ( sheesh ...).

 People don't yell in my ear at raves , although it's happened most times
I can remember when I'm in the pit at a rock concert. The closest thing was
that dreadful whistle blowing fad - glad that's gone. I had the same problem
with whistle frequencies being in a bad, hurtful frequency range for me. 
When people yell at raves , it's with their heads tilted upwards in communal
howl.

 Such nic(er) people at raves ... 

   Larry "Eh, whatca' saying? Speak up!" Ching

 [ to SFRaves mailist ]

 I checked out ( for a short time ) the Jungle music at Il Pirata on
16th . Nice folks , and a lot more black folks that at most recent
raves I've been to ( I think I was the only asian there for the hour
and 20 minutes I was there ). The door guy was friendly , and warned me
about moving my vehicle before the meter maid tagged it ( street cleaning ).

 The dance area had an aggresively placed strobe light that blasted your 
eyes if you didn't look away ( hard to do , since it was placed at one corner
close to the speakers ). The speaker cabinets had a hard time with some
of the dub-style low frequencies , "doubling" with a horrible baritone
squawk every time it tried to do them low notes. The speaker cabinets
had pink(?) fake fur on them - I've seen them before , but I don't
know where ...

 Music was great! Jungle is such fun to dance to , once you give up the idea
of twiching to every damn sound in the mix ( or even more fun if you try
to! ). I recommend trying it out some Tuesday night ( just be sure to park
your car carefully ...).

  Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Apr 26 05:39:53 1995

Date: Wed, 26 Apr 95 22:42 EST
From: crunch@sysx.apana.org.au (John Draper)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Burning man and other things
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Been reading all this stuff on Burning man,  and as last years attendee,
for those who haven't been there,  it's a real enlightening experience.

Frazer says...  

> The Burning man, woman and child (dog) event I regard as an opportunity
>to > throw yourself into a hostile- to- life environment and try to
>experience > catharsis. The desert can be very unfriendly and I think when
>Phred sez more > respect, he means "don't take it lightly"!As It sez on
>the brochure "people > have died".The rave is a side show to a
>neo-primitive Road Warrior meets > Rocky Horror survivalist vaudville.  >

I can say for those plannng to go this year,   is that the environment is
hostile... And if you don't plan or observe certain things,  you die!!  It's
simple as that.    It's really easy to just wonder off away from camp,   and
get over 3 1/2 miles out...  The camp literally dissapears below the horizon.

If you don't pay attention to things like direction of travel,  or take your
bearinge before you strike out (Should you ever want to),   you could easily
lose your bearings and wonder in the wrong direction.   Especially at night!!

USE the STARS as reference,  learn how to use them to navagate...   Out there,
it;s just like navagation on the ocean.   It's FLAT FEATURELESS dirt.

Bring plenty of water...  It's HOT in daytime,  freezing cold at night...
COME PREPARED!!   But some with NO EXPECTATIONS!!   You will really dig it
to the max...

If you set up camp,   establish some sort of unique "Beacon light" for your 
camp.   Or before you leave your camp,  take a bearing on where you are in
relation to the "Man".

There are really great hot springs nearby,  bring plenty of sunscreen,  chapstick
and anything else to deal with very dry conditions.

Usually,  the rave will be about a mile or so away from the main camp.  People
usually drive aimlessly out there,  and often don't look for people when away from
the camp.   It's possible to aim the car in any arbitrary direction and drive
for hours without hitting anything.

I remember when I first got there,   from the road,   I could only see this tiny
blue dot...   But from down on the flats,  it was not visible.   As I approached
it became visible...   Always giving me the impression that it was a few hundred
feet away,   But after 15 minutes of driving,  it became evident just how far
away it REALLY was.    Distances are extremly deceptive out in the desert.

On the lighter side,  tommorrow I fly to Adelaide to go to yet another rave
in yet another Australian city.   Be looking for a great report in a few days.

Later....
Crunchman

ps  in the words of beck, "everyone's out to get you, muther-fucker..." ;)
-------------------------------------------
I agree with sig in the sense that we as a society overuse the term 
"victim" to the point of meaninglessness. However, there are victims.

Someone who's pushed off a cliff on the evil whim of another is a victim. 
Someone who ignores warning signs and slides off a cliff cannot claim to 
be a victim because there were no guard rails installed.

When the police bust a permitted party operating within legal noise 
limits because one person calls up and complains, the police victimize 
the party organizers and participants. The police changed the rules to 
accommodate their whims.

Party organizers arrested for breaking into a warehouse are not victims. 
Everyone knows it's illegal. Expect to be caught.

You might consider them activists practicing civil disobedience, however. 
Pleading civil disobedience in court seldom causes charges to be dropped 
(though lately it seems the charges aren't even pursued). The act itself, if 
done forthrightly and frequently, can and does motivate government to 
change its laws. 

Of course there are lots of gray areas - local governments rarely provide 
coherent, much less feasible, procedures for obtaining permits or 
complying with ordinances - but I think similar principles can always be 
applied.

...still thinking about it,
nate

I find your experience "interesting" but what is says to me is :

 1) most of our society has NO COMMUNITY (or at least a common shared one)
 
 and as an outgrowth of 1) most of us

 2) don't REALLY listen or HEAR each other

These people were NOT responding to what you were trying to say because
they weren't hearing you - instead they were listening to their "media
feed voices buzzing inside their heads"... there was no attempt to connect
with you or what you were saying  --- frustrating isn't it?

  On the other hand when I tell a "close" friend about my experiences with
raves they become interested - because they value me (and my thoughts ) and
if they know me, they know that I am not a destructive person so they
re-evaluate the media lines about raves... On the other hand, I often warn
them that yes there is indeed a very high incidence of drug use but I
always go on to say : 1) most of it is within the realm of "responsible"
drug use and 2) doing drugs is NOT necessary to partake of the scene so
each person can make their own decisions about that issue... that usually
defuses the drug issue - at least for most of my straight friends who have
a brain and actually choose to use them :-)
 
Mike

 meclay@netcom.com          |  Alone & estatic 
 Mike Clay   (415)572-8971  |  A young rainbow learns  to levitate.

i had a bit of hardware architecture in college; my impression was

  that the registers of all CPUs are made VERY indestructable, kind of
    like the way first and fifth gears of manual transmissions are made
     of extra-tuff steel;

basically, the accumulator and primary registers can take millions of
  times more accessing than RAM before they fail; maybe billions...

so go on, use and ABUSE that accumulator!

Dave Scruton

gentleman and a scholor and has got more intgreaty then most of the other 
people on the SF rave scene put together.  He has a very positive energy 
and knows how to get people motivated for the good.  A genuine catalyst 
in every sense of the word.  Any bad press that he does get are by people 
who are merely jeolous aboiut his abilities and his vibe.  He is as 
responsible as anybody for making the UK scene the world-wide force that 
it has become and for this he deserves nothing but absoloute respect.

about matters that they know nothing about.

 Oh, ya...?                  RE>>Internet Virus (fwd)
According to the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory Computer Advisory Team
the "Good Time" virus is a hoax.  It was found to be a collage student prank
that got out of hand.  

I received this information from the Livermore Laboratory yesterday.  

-rick

PS.  Computer Viruses normally invade executable applications/programs.  The
virus will lay dormant until the application is executed.  At that time the
virus generally propagates or sets itself up to perform some action(s),
generally attacking your computer's hard disk.  The virus, a string of computer
code, being apart of an executing application allows the virus code to 
directly instruct the processor.  This generally does not occur with
documents/data files.

Games are a big target for viruses.  Everyone play them and no one knows what
to expect during execution.  We would not think that anything is wrong with a
three headed green monster starring out of the screen laughing, while a
background process scramble your File Allocation Tables.

Sorry for being long winded.....
---------------

> >Received from various individuals:

> >>----- Begin Included Message -----
> >>
> >>There is a computer virus that is being sent across the Internet.  If
> >>you receive an e-mail message with the subject line "Good Times", DO
> >>NOT read the message, DELETE it immediately.  Please read the
> >>messages below.
> >>
> >>Some miscreant is sending e-mail under the title "good times"
> >>nation-wide. If you get anything like this, DON'T DOWNLOAD THE FILE! It
> >>has a virus that rewrites your hard drive, obliterating anything on it. 
> >>Please be careful and forward this mail to anyone you care about--I
> >>have.
> >>
> >>The FCC released a warning last Wednesday concerning a matter of
> >>major importance to any regular user of the InterNet.  Apparently, a new
> >>computer virus has been engineered by a user of America Online that is
> >>unparalleled in its destructive capability.  Other, more well-known 
> >>viruses
> >>such as Stoned, Airwolf, and Michaelangelo pale in comparison to the
> >>prospects of this newest creation by a warped mentality.
> >>
> >>What makes this virus so terrifying, said the FCC, is the fact that
> >>no program needs to be exchanged for a new computer to be infected. 
> >>It can be spread through the existing e-mail systems of the InterNet. 
> >>Once a computer is infected, one of several things can happen.  If the
> >>computer contains  hard drive, that will most likely be destroyed. If 
> >>the
> >>program is not stopped, the computer's processor will be placed in an
> >>nth-complexity infinite binary loop - which can severely damage
> >>the processor if  left running that way too long.  Unfortunately, most
> >>novice computer users will not realize what is happening until it is far 
> >>too
> >>late.
> >>
> >>Luckily, there is one sure means of detecting what is now known as
> >>the "Good Times" virus.  It always travels to new computers the same
> >>way in a text e-mail message with the subject line reading simply "Good
> >>Times".  Avoiding infection is easy once the file has been received - 
> >>not
> >>reading it.  The act of loading the file into the mail server's ASCII 
> >>buffer
> >>causes the "Good Times" mainline program to initialize and execute.
> >>The program is highly intelligent - it will send copies of itself to 
> >>everyone
> >>whose e-mail address is contained in a received-mail file or a sent-
> >>mail file, if it can find one.  It will then proceed to trash the 
> >>computer it is
> >>running on.
> >>
> >>The bottom line here is - If you receive a file with the subject line
> >>"Good Times",  delete it  immediately!  Do not read it!  Rest assured
> >>that whoever's name was on the "From:" line was surely struck by the
> >>virus.
> >>
> >>Warn your friends and local system users of this newest threat to the
> >>InterNet!  It could save them a lot of time and money.
> >>
> >>
> >>
> >>
> >>----- End Included Message -----

ARGHH!!! I hate these hoaxes. There is NO virus that will damage a 
processor. The only machine that had an actual command that you could 
enter to damage it was the PET by Commodore in the early 80's. There are no 
viruses that are started because you simply read a message(except MAYBE, 
under very specific circumstances ANSI BOMB's which are not the same thing.)
A similar "warning" with the same subject (supposed "Good Times" virus) 
was posted here a few months back, only now the story has been 
embellished slightly with the FCC issuing the warning. Look at the AC for 
the supposed author. Alabama is AC 205. Relax, this warning is B.S. 

                                                Black Adder

As many of you know, I'm going through a trying period right now. I found 
a way to sort of "escape from the present" for a little while and dive 
into fond memories of the past.  Today I popped in Tony's *The Ultimate 
Seduction* from way back - was it '92? - when I very first got into 
raving.  Oh the wonderful sweet memories! :) Just hearing how the music 
was a little different gives me an escape - especially when it has been a 
long time since I heard the songs on the tape.  What kinds of things do 
you all feel when you do this?  Of course I love just about all the new 
stuff coming out too....always anxious to hear something new and deep, 
but boy, sometimes those old tapes work wonders just when you need it! 
(gonna have to break out my *Vision* collection now..)

livin' the PLUR,
Amy

I'm sorry your classmates steamrolled you like that. Regardless of what the
subject is, it's not considerate or constructive.

Personally, when I'm asked "what are raves?", I try to be open and honest about
the drug aspect, and in doing so emphasize that taking drugs is not a prerequisite
to enjoyment. Still, I've more or less given up trying to dispel the
characterization of raves as "drug parties." Rather, I try to leave the
impression that they're "nice drug parties." While the word "drug" immediately
conjures up negative images of dark alleyways, guns, and derelicts, it's not so
hard to remind people that the rock (n' roll) scene they grew up with wasn't exactly
clean and sober, nor was it the exclusive domain of pushers and addicts.

I by no means try to portray it as something _everyone_ should check out. Anyone
who shows interest (or even just intense curiosity), though, I offer to take
them along to a rave. I've taken people who loved it and wanted to go to every
event thereafter. I've also taken people who thought it was really interesting,
were honestly glad they came, but still prefer to spend their evenings (and
mornings :-) in other ways. So far, I've been successful in judging who not to
take (i.e., if you really hate to dance, you'll probably get bored).

Though others might strongly disagree, I don't think there's anything wrong with
bringing "tourists" to raves (as long as they're not the "ugly American" type,
of course :-). Not only is it good PR for our community, but I think it
genuinely enhances the tourist hirself in terms of experiencing the diversity of
human expression. Raves, you know, aren't the only way to celebrate life -
people have been doing it for thousands of years in as many different forms.

take care!
-nate

(flame retardant on)

when peeple ask me whut a rave is i usually say:

  "have you ever watched laugh-in?"

    'laugh-in?whutzthat?'

  "you know, the comedy show from the 60's; now its a cable staple"

    'um, ohyeah, now i remember'

  "well, do you remember the scenes where there's this crazy party
    with everyone in costumes, dancing, and they stop for jokes now
     and again?"

    'yeah, sure ... i think'

  "that's kinda like what a rave is, except for the computers and stuff"


Dave SCruton

(major IMHO)

  regarding the clobbering of life in the desert; if there was only
    a way to get ALL of mankind's destructive acts to occur out in
      the desert (INSTEAD of forests, reefs, wetlants, etc) we'd all
        be better off.

  let's not forget that the major chains of life and the highest densities
    of critters per square inch occur in rainforests, reef flats, wetlands,
      coral reefs, etc;

  as time progresses and we wipe all the forests off the face of the
    earth, THE WHOLE PLANET will become a desert.

  at that time, there will be PLENTY of real estate for the cacti,
   mesquite, and other arid scrub to eke out a living, because we will
    all be GONE.

Dave Scruton

Newt King sez:
"I enjoyed myself, tho I would have liked a bit more energy."

True it wasn't out of control massive crowd energy, but I really enjoyed the
intimate vibe -- you can tell what this energy is coming from what person.
  Energy comes from within, but I can't believe how often I still forget this
simple truth.  I'll still arrive at a party and think the energy is kinda low
and blame the crowd size(too big, too small, I don't see many people I know)
or the music(too fast, too slow) or the space(too smoky, too dark) -- you get
the idea.  Of course thats usually not the problem, its just me not putting
any energy out so only a little ambient energy comes back rather than a
full-blown two-way transfer.  After relaxing a little and dancing a while in
the middle of the crowd I lighten up and start sending out positive energy
and good vibes because I'm happy and suddenly there's SO much more energy.  I
just need to find a way to get around that initial transition phase.


phuture

> full-blown two-way transfer.  After relaxing a little and dancing a while in
> the middle of the crowd I lighten up and start sending out positive energy
> and good vibes because I'm happy and suddenly there's SO much more energy.  I
> just need to find a way to get around that initial transition phase.

Try concentrating on how *you* feel - or how you want to feel.  If you 
*want* to feel good vibes, send them out enthusiastically.  There have 
been times at a party where the vibes are okay, if not nil, and one or 
more people come join the crowd with such energy and enthusiasm, the rest 
of the place catches on immediately.  Many people just need an extra 
"boost" to gettem going.  Enthusiasm and good vibes are *CONTAGIOUS*!!

love to all,
Amy

Precedence: bulk

Dear All;

	An assembly language program that will "kill" a PC. From the book 
80386/80286 Assembly Language Programming, authors Murray & Pappas.

This program switches into Protected Virtual Mode, changes the display 
attribute to reverse video, and returns to Real Mode to exit to DOS. 
Modifed for collor monitor and card.

----------------> Assemble as a COM file <---------------------------------

WARNING: This program will "kill" a PC. It should only be run on an AT.*

PAGE	,132

bios_data_seg 	SEGMENT at 	0040h
		ORG		0067h
io_rom_init	dw ?		; dword var. in BIOS data segment
io_rom_seg	dw ?		; used to store dword address
bios_data_seg	ENDS

descriptor	STRUC
seg_limit	dw 0		; segment limit (1-65536 bytes)
base_io_word	dw 0		; 24 bit physical address
base_hi_byte	db 0		; (0 -(16M-1))
access_rights	db 0		; access rights byte
		dw 0		; reserved_386
descriptor	ENDS

cmos_port	equ 070h
code_seg_access equ 10011011b	; access right byte for code seg
data_seg_access equ 10010011b	; access right byte for data seg
disable_bit20 	equ 11011101b	; 8042 function code to de-gate A20
enable_bit20 	equ 11011111b	; 8042 function code to gate A20
inta01		equ 021h	; 8259 Int Controller #1
intb01		equ 0A1h	; 8259 Int Controller #2
port_a		equ 060h	; 8042 port A
shut_cmd	equ 0FEh	; cmd to 8042; shut down AT
shut_down	equ 00Fh	; CMOS shut down byte index
status_port	equ 064h	; 8042 status port
virtual_enable	equ 0001h	; LSB=1: Protected Virtual Mode

There is more, but this should be enough to "kill" a PC. Partially 
reprinted courtesty of Brian Darkness

> ARGHH!!! I hate these hoaxes. There is NO virus that will damage a 
> processor. The only machine that had an actual command that you could 
> enter to damage it was the PET by Commodore in the early 80's. There are no 
> viruses that are started because you simply read a message(except MAYBE, 
> under very specific circumstances ANSI BOMB's which are not the same thing.)
> A similar "warning" with the same subject (supposed "Good Times" virus) 
> was posted here a few months back, only now the story has been 
> embellished slightly with the FCC issuing the warning. Look at the AC for 
> the supposed author. Alabama is AC 205. Relax, this warning is B.S. 
> 
>                                                 Black Adder

Sin 
Brian Darkness


ps This is not a virus by itself, and the only intention I had by posting 
this was to say that there is more than one way to "Kill" a PC :)

From: misssig@ix.netcom.com (sigrid hafstrom)
Subject: feeling wordy tonight  (something about victims)

fraser wrote: 

>
>in fact I was comparing larry's description of the HWBS being 
victimised >with *us* being victimised.  I agree with you, up to a 
point, sig.  
>*they* (?) are trying to victimise us.  but we shouldn't get into that 
head >space (while not fooling ourselves with what we think 
spirituality is 
>telling us that it's not happening and ,even if it is, it's all 
illusion 
>or karma or something.)  I'll settle for evolutionary love guerillas.
>fraser. 
>

i think i may be need to clarify my point a bit, not because you didn't 
"understand" it exactly, but because i don't think i was too clear in 
the first place.  i'll be as brief as i can.

this is true to me:  we are all free, always.  in order to be vicimised 
we each have to choose freely to take the roll of victim.  this is 
really difficult to articulate, but basically i can give this one 
example of not doing the victim thing when the oppertunity to do so was 
present:  a friend of mine was arrested a while back for tresspassing.  
she wanted to play in the forest at night (like we all can't relate to 
that!), but it was against the law.  so she was brought to the police 
station and that whole ritual.  now, we all could rant about this 
injustice, about not being given the basic right to play with nature 
anytime we felt moved to do so.  but good old jess, she didn't rant, 
she smiled.  she smiled for her mug shot.  and the man (or who ever the 
hell "they" are) couldn't take that away from her and he can't take it 
from us; even if he cuts off our lips, we can always find ways to 
smile.  do we want play victim to the will of someone else or do we 
want to find a way to coexist with conflicting ideas, even when its 
sometimes uncomfortable take responsability and commit to bringing 
about this coexistance?  i choose to smile and to be responsable

there are of course times when it's extremely difficult not to give up 
responsability.  torture, and i mean extreme physical and psycological 
torture, is a prime example.  but we're not being tortured.  we as a 
movement and as individuals are free to dance, we're free to sing we're 
free to hug and to kiss and even to take illegal drugs and to 
tresspass.  we must be free to do so, at least to some extent, because 
we do it.  and anyone who doesn't want to dance and sing and so forth 
is free not to. 

again, i'm feeling rather boxed in with words at trying to explain what 
exactly i mean.  if i'm getting too unrave related (yes, sig, you    
are ;) this thread should by all means stop, but i'd like to discuss 
the subject still with anyone at all who's interested by private mail, 
etc.

and for further information on not being a victim, please consult your 
nearest nest of saws reprsentitive (you know who you are, my blessed 
sisters :) 

love from all over the universe,
sig

> we each have to choose freely to take the roll of victim.  this is 
> example of not doing the victim thing when the oppertunity to do so was

yes, but, smiling and lipless or not, she wasn't dancing in the woods no
more.  and if some poor psyhopathic wretch (driven crzy by this crazy
system) guns me down in a supermarket before I have time to smile, what
then? 

I'm slightly teasing.  I agree absolutely that we must avoid victim 
psychology.  but I don't take the next (new age?) step that I create the 
problem in the first place. lastly (because we're probably off-subject) 
if you go too far dwon the road you're pointing at, sig, you can end up 
blaming yourself and, like many a "spiritual" hippy end up doing nothing 
about the state of the world because you'e not pure enough or ready.  
we can be love warriors, we're not required (or expected) to be saints.
fraser.

On Wed, 26 Apr 2000, Brian Darkness wrote:

> Dear All;
> 
> 	An assembly language program that will "kill" a PC. From the book 
> 80386/80286 Assembly Language Programming, authors Murray & Pappas.
> 
> This program switches into Protected Virtual Mode, changes the display 
> attribute to reverse video, and returns to Real Mode to exit to DOS. 
> Modifed for collor monitor and card.
> 
> ----------------> Assemble as a COM file <---------------------------------
> 
> WARNING: This program will "kill" a PC. It should only be run on an AT.*
> 
> PAGE	,132
> 
> bios_data_seg 	SEGMENT at 	0040h
> 		ORG		0067h
> io_rom_init	dw ?		; dword var. in BIOS data segment
> io_rom_seg	dw ?		; used to store dword address
> bios_data_seg	ENDS
> 
> descriptor	STRUC
> seg_limit	dw 0		; segment limit (1-65536 bytes)
> base_io_word	dw 0		; 24 bit physical address
> base_hi_byte	db 0		; (0 -(16M-1))
> access_rights	db 0		; access rights byte
> 		dw 0		; reserved_386
> descriptor	ENDS
> 
> cmos_port	equ 070h
> code_seg_access equ 10011011b	; access right byte for code seg
> data_seg_access equ 10010011b	; access right byte for data seg
> disable_bit20 	equ 11011101b	; 8042 function code to de-gate A20
> enable_bit20 	equ 11011111b	; 8042 function code to gate A20
> inta01		equ 021h	; 8259 Int Controller #1
> intb01		equ 0A1h	; 8259 Int Controller #2
> port_a		equ 060h	; 8042 port A
> shut_cmd	equ 0FEh	; cmd to 8042; shut down AT
> shut_down	equ 00Fh	; CMOS shut down byte index
> status_port	equ 064h	; 8042 status port
> virtual_enable	equ 0001h	; LSB=1: Protected Virtual Mode
> 
> There is more, but this should be enough to "kill" a PC. Partially 
> reprinted courtesty of Brian Darkness

So what, it kills it, you turn the computer off and then back on. It 
would not damage the processor. I have seen a couple of viruses that can 
destroy a couple of types of monitors, and one that attempts to 
destroy(physically) your HD. But nothing to date that will destroy your 
processor, except the Intel Virus(OOPS I mean the Intel public relations 
people. :)

>True it wasn't out of control massive crowd energy, but I really enjoyed the
>intimate vibe -- you can tell what this energy is coming from what person.
>  Energy comes from within, but I can't believe how often I still forget this
>simple truth.  I'll still arrive at a party and think the energy is kinda low
>and blame the crowd size(too big, too small, I don't see many people I know)
>or the music(too fast, too slow) or the space(too smoky, too dark) -- you get
>the idea.  Of course thats usually not the problem, its just me not putting
>any energy out so only a little ambient energy comes back rather than a
>full-blown two-way transfer.  After relaxing a little and dancing a while in
>the middle of the crowd I lighten up and start sending out positive energy
>and good vibes because I'm happy and suddenly there's SO much more energy.  I
>just need to find a way to get around that initial transition phase.

i couldn't agree with you more, both about the energy at the Progress party
and about energy in general; and this has application/relevance well beyond
the dance floor!  that little ITP (initial transition phase) rears its ugly
head in *so* many areas...

CRUSH THE ITP!!!  RADIATE POSITIVITY WITHOUT HESITATION!!!

nEil

          id AA06934; Thu, 27 Apr 1995 15:37:40 -0400
Date: Thu, 27 Apr 1995 15:37:40 -0400

To: Doug Zimmerman <doug@hyperreal.com>

Subject: Re: stereotyping raves

Precedence: bulk

At 10:42 PM 4/25/95, Doug Zimmerman wrote:
>hey all,
>
>  in my photojournalism class today i was showing some of the pictures
>i had been taking for my photo essay about  raves and stuff and my
>teacher asks me "what are raves?"
>
>  before i can respons one lady says "everyone is on drugs there."
>and then another person is like "yeah they all do ecstacy there."
>  and yet another person is like "when i went to one all thes people
>were touching me."
>
>  i tried to break in and give a explanation about raves "you know
>they are big dance parties where people can come together no matter
>who they are and just dance and have fun without attitudes and fights
>and all that."
>
>
>  which someone replys "yeah, cause everyone is on x (ecstacy)
>
>
>  needless to say the encounter as a whole pissed me off and leads me
>to ask:  "What can i say or what can i do to make raves sound like
>something to check out?"
>
>  i mean  the stuff about everyone together dancing and having a good
>time must sound to someone who hasent been to one like some stupid
>joke or something, but its true.
>
>  ive been in the scene for awhile and have gone through my cynical
>cycle on how raves are a joke, but i keep coming back cause i like
>the openess, the ability to walk up to someone and say "hi" and
>to dance my ass off smiling and having a good time.
>
>
>  why is that so hard for a lot of people to understand??
>
>doug ) ( dougie@netcom.com

        I have gone through the very same experience here, though it was in
my sculpture class wherin i did a project that was BARELY rave-related.
People started talking about the superficiality of things and emotions
present at parties, the massive drug use, the 'faddish' nature of this, the
fact that one HAS to be on drugs to 'get it' (whether that's the music or
the feeling in the air, etc).  It really got me down, i'm used to being
around open-minded people and it's funny but we're always given this
stereotype of "ARTISTS" as being the one's who are 'out there' and live in
a context in which 'anything can happen.'  THAT, in my experience, is a
complete fallacy.  I've met more ravers who were math students, genetic
biologists, commerce students, whatever, who were open to new ideas.  A lot
of "artists" (at least at my school and in my experience) would rather sit
around and complain about how shitty things are, sit self-righteously on
their priviliged upper middle class throne and hand down platitudes to the
masses trying to get them to change rather than taking a hard look at their
own behaviour, and trying to set an example for others.  IMHO, making
objects will not change the world.  Being involved in group experiences and
LIVING with core beliefs such as PLUR might be one of the few things that
can change the present societal structure.
        My response to the class was that 'raves' have different impacts on
different people, for me they have irreconcilibly changed my life for the
best.  I didn't get angry at the class or the 'doubters' but only said, i
understand your opinion but maybe you should give 'raves' a second thought.
To be hostile and exclusionary (IMHO) would be antithetical to PLUR-ish
beliefs and THEN they would be right in saying that 'ravers' are just a
bunch of confused kids with some half-digested spiritual mumbo-jumbo in
their heads that is preached and not lived.  I guess what i try to do is
set an example as best i can.

        peace,
                brad


ps-->I also told them that i go completely straight to parties and dance
all night, some didn't beleive me but oh well, there will always be
doubting thomases :)

/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\

        ---->   ectographics, montreal  <---
        ---->      ecto@magnet.ca       <---
		
        You're #1 with us! Smile and have a nice day :)
/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\/\



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Apr 27 13:43:45 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id NAA05131; Thu, 27 Apr 1995 13:43:45 -0700
Received: from saclink1.csus.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with ESMTP id NAA05121; Thu, 27 Apr 1995 13:43:40 -0700
Received: by saclink1.csus.edu
	(1.37.109.14/16.2) id AA182155338; Thu, 27 Apr 1995 13:42:18 -0700
Date: Thu, 27 Apr 1995 13:42:18 -0700 (PDT)
From: Amy R Starkey <sac41673@saclink1.csus.edu>
Subject: gathering of the minds: summer '95
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9504271342.A14960-0100000@saclink1.csus.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Okay everybody - I have a brainstorm thundering in my head and I *must* 
share it with you.  

Some friends and I in Sacramento have been thinking about getting out and 
doing some camping this year.  I remember last year going to Muir Woods 
and on the way, my friend and I noticed an incredible camping site.  It 
has a small parking lot, lots of room for tents and best of all: an 
ampitheatre type place with a BON FIRE in the middle.  I thought to 
myself, what a place to have a gathering of many friends!  

Now that summer is drawing near, that same idea came into my head.  I've 
been sharing a real connection with people lately and I want it to 
continue even more.  I had originally planned on just a few close 
friends, but the more I think about it, the more I'd like to connect with 
friends I don't know as well: my friends on sfraves and their friends!  

What this would be is a weekend in mid to late summer and it would not be 
a rave, but simply a gathering of people to come together to share ideas, 
experiences, and dreams.  All of us could bring drums and other 
instruments, and maybe a portable stereo & mix tapes.  The campsite is 
walking distance from the ancient redwood forest of Muir woods, and that 
night we could all come together for an incredible learning experience 
and inner growth for all.  Then maybe top it all off with a sunset party 
on Sunday......  Am I being idealist, or does this sound like just an 
incredible idea of people coming together to SHARE with one another - to 
connect?  I want your imput, thoughts and comments on this because I'm 
gonna do it!  

makin' that
PLUR occur! :P

Amy

Looks like a cool weekend for a few (sunny?) outdoor events - Positive
Society and Golden Gate Park on Saturday, and hopefully Sunset on Sunday.
Kundalini, Stompy and Diverse City should all be OK too, and then
Come-Unity on Wednesday.  Too bad I'll miss all of them since I'll
be out of town.

Caught Dust last Friday - Ethan spun a good set, and I liked the
intimate environment (a fresh space, at least for me).  Simply Done
last night was pretty good too, with Suiki and Mark Farina, the crowd
was a bit weird but entertaining.  You'll have to go sometime to see
what I mean (unless it was a freak occurence).

Also, I've gotten more images into the web pages.  Promoters (or
anyone, really) can send me little uuencoded GIFs if you want them
included in the web page.  Otherwise, you'll have to rely on me liking
your flyer enough to scan it in...

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, submit them! I can't possibly
   hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To svbscribe or
   unsvbscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   svbscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsvbscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To svbscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   svbscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com - 415.506.6195

[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[[
     THE NEXT CHAPTER OF TAPE COMPILATIONS FEATURING ELECTRONIC MUSIC
                           FROM OHIO AND BEYOND

(ed. note: categories are useless but give a general idea :])

FUSION 0.3 FEATURES:

joy (euro hard trance)
titonton (2 smoov bleepy techno compositions)
raumgeist (bleepy techno)
version 1.0 (breaks)
evolution control committee (experimental cold wave techno)
9th circle (dark breaks)
excess (old-skool ambient/industrial)
fuzzy logic (old-skool revival)
cro2 (smoov techno)

FUSION 0.4 FEATURES:

raumgeist (bleepy techno)
monochrome (smoov breaks)
kingsize (ragga breaks)
elliptical (trance)
sonik (smoov house)
tempest (experimental techno)
citizen (experimental breaks)
.xtrak (bleepy minimal)
fuzzy logic (breaks)
ihannoa (experiental tribal)


ALL TAPES ARE HI-BIAS 60 MIN CASSETTES WITH COLOR COVERS AND COST $6
POSTAGE PAID.  THE 21/22 CORPORATION ****MAKES NO MONEY FROM THESE
TAPES*****

THESE COMPILATIONS ARE INTENDED TO HELP SPREAD THE WORD ABOUT NEW AND
UNKNOWN ARTISTS, FOR YOUR LISTENING PLEASURE, ***NOT FOR PROFIT***
(we mean that)

PLEASE MAIL CHECKS/MONEY ORDERS TO:

CHARLES NOEL
286 E 13TH AVE
COLUMBUS OHIO 43201

BE SURE TO TELL CHARLES WHERE TO SEND YOUR TAPE!!!

for more info or anything else you might need!!!

That's about right. Psychic TV were in LA to do a show (that got cut
short, incidently, when Genesis passed out on stage 45 minutes into the
set) and were invited to stay at Rick Rubin's mansion by Love and Rockets,
who were recording an album there. Early Monday morning the mixing board
(the fire department speculates) sparked and set the studio on fire. All
of the people in the house woke up in time to get out except for Genesis,
who had to jump through his window to get to safety. I left LA on Sunday
night so I didn't see any of this, but I hear he has a lot of broken
bones. Poor guy--what an unlucky weekend. 

Lee

I am taking the liberty of forwarding this reply to my inquiry about
the Fraser Clark lecture - be forwarned about the room capacity! Also note 
the warnings in Alethya's post and here about the serious lack of
public parking ...

Forwarded message:
> Date: Fri, 28 Apr 1995 09:19:52 -0700 (PDT)
> From: Richard Powers 
> To: Larry Ching <larryc@netcom.com>
> Subject: Re: May 2 Fraser Clark :details?
> 
> Hi Larry:
> 
> Actually, I was a little surprised to see the announcement posted on 
> sfraves (I didn't post it). Yes, the talk is open to the public, but the 
> reason why I'm not doing large publicity is that the room has a fire 
> marshall "capacity" of 300, and I have 400 students this quarter, and 
> another 500 from past quarters this year. I don't know how many of them 
> will come, but we probably have too much interest already.
> 
> But feel free to come. We'll just see what happens. I suppose it would be 
> ironically appropriate if a TALK about raves gets busted by the police.
> (actually, we just let in the first 300)
> 
> 
> Here are the directions: 
> 
> Take I-280 south
> 
> Take the Alpine Rd. exit (the one after Sand Hill)
> 
> Turn left onto Alpine and go a winding half-mile or so to the first light
> 
> Turn right at this first light (Junipero Serra)
> 
> Proceed to the first light (Campus Drive) and turn left
> 
> Go to the first stop sign (Santa Teresa) and turn right
> 
> We are the first large gym-like building on the left, after the open
> athletics field: Roble Studios, on the corner of Morris Way.
> 
> Public parking on campus is almost non-existant! Permits-only for miles.
> Try to find meter parking down by Tressider Center, at the very dead-end 
> of Santa Teresa.
> 
> 
> richard
>

Subject: conversations and raving
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Sat, 29 Apr 1995 13:34:59 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 1367      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I was wondering if others can relate to this.
I enjoy having conversations with others at raves, but sometimes find it 
to be a bit of a struggle, especially when the music is really good.  
When the music is really good, I sometimes find it difficult to be more 
consciously present with that person.  The music can sometimes cause my 
consciousness to start to merge with the music and overall surroundings, 
making it more difficult to focus on the conversation.  At this point I 
find it more natural to converse through dance, rather that with words.

Last week I went to a beach party near bonnie doon, and enjoyed having 
conversations with the people that remained after the music stopped.  I 
found it much easier to be more fully present with the verbal 
conversations.  This is one of the things I appreciate about net.  We get 
to converse in an enviroment that we can create for ourselves that makes 
it most comfortable for our verbal conversations.

One of the things I love about raves, is the amount of communication that 
takes place, which seems to happen in many different ways and on many 
different levels.  Sometimes after a raves I think about some of the 
different interactions and connections through communication.  Some 
through a look, a movement, sound, many different expressions.  
Oooohhhh, the joy of making connections.
:)

peter

 Looking at some old SFRaves mail , I read again Peter Fogel's mail 
about dancing apart from music. It reminded me about something I 
occasionally wonder about. 

 Only twice can I remember seeing someone at a rave who didn't have
the use of his legs - both times in a wheelchair. One of the times
was Malachy , and he doesn't count because his was a temporary
condition ( I hope ). The other fellow seemed to be have been
brought by his friends , and he seemed to be having a great time.

 Can raves be a place for those who can't dance with their legs?
I can't remember when I've seen someone in crutches or a wheelchair
at a rock show , but maybe raves? They have sports for folks in
wheelchairs - basketball, skiing (!). I think it'd be cool to see
a floor full of folks bopping away in their wheelchairs! And , since
they have racing wheelchairs now - zip!zip!zip!  

 Larry "Another Wacky Idea" Ching
 

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Apr 29 21:21:37 1995
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id VAA02429; Sat, 29 Apr 1995 21:21:37 -0700
Received: from shell1.best.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with ESMTP id VAA02123; Sat, 29 Apr 1995 21:11:00 -0700
Received: (fraser@localhost) by shell1.best.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id VAA09255; Sat, 29 Apr 1995 21:10:24 -0700
Date: Sat, 29 Apr 1995 21:10:23 -0700 (PDT)
From: Fraser Clark <fraser@megatripolis.org>
X-Sender: fraser@shell1.best.com
To: Larry Ching <larryc@netcom.com>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Raving Without Legs
In-Reply-To: <199504300310.UAA12422@netcom8.netcom.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.BSD.3.91.950429210319.5457D-100000@shell1.best.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

at Megatripolis/London we have a regular wheelchair raver in the form of 
Greg Sams, an american actually.  he gets right up on his wheels and 
wheels about.  great to watch!
I also once came across a miracle rave cure to do with a cripple.  I 
can't remember why or how he was injured but he was paralysed from the 
neck down.  anyway his freinds noticed that he did show some kind of 
response to rave music and took him to a rave.  there this friend of mine 
noticed that he was kind of bopping his eyes and head to the rhythm.  
almost a year later my friend bumped into him again at a rave and this 
time he was functioning from the waist up and really going for it in his 
wheelchair.  another year after that, my friend (Sequenci, my alltime 
favourite DJ as a matter of fact) was DJing when this raver came up to 
him, jumping about in an ever so slightly spastic way:  "you don't 
recognise me, no?  I'm that guy in the wheelchair, remember?"  anyway he 
claimed (and I believe him) that raving had saved and cured him.
zip!zip!zip!
fraser.

Dear All;

	Before I go further, I'm just posting an idea, not a fact, and am
looking for feedback on it, in the group forum. The tone of this post is
happy:), curious:), relaxed:) ...etc:), please to do infer anything else
about my writing, unless you are unsure of its meaning and then first ask
me in private to carifiy what you thought I wrote, or wrote so poorly 
that you couldn't understand it, before publically frying me butt, :). Ok 
nuff said. 

	I was thumbing though the SF Guardian, and came across an ad for
DJ/VJ Master Mixer, Doug Wendt, and his exclusive "All World" Music &
video dance Party. I thought about how nice it would be for an average
person, non-raver, non-lurker, earth ...etc, to be able to go to the
community section and have SFR Calendar in what ever form the paper would
except it, there along with the rest of the community happenings like Art
Shows, Rock & Roll ...etc. What follows are the PRO's & CON's as I see
them, please do make additions, rebut respectfully, and lavishly praise
where deserved. I'm looking for all and welcome them always:

  PRO's

	1. It would bring in a much greater diversity of peoples both
enomically, intelectually, and racial. With this increased diveristy, more
raves will be held, at bigger & better venues. R-Culture would be more
widely accepted, and tolerated, and finally we as members of this 
subculture would have many more allies/help/recourses. The benefits 
mentioned would go to peacefully defend ourselves against the police, help 
out local & nation charites ...etc. 

  CON's

	1. With the increased diveristy and public awareness, comes the 
negative/destructive elements of society, also more commerializum.
               
	2. Events would seem to big, & lacking intimacy, but most of our 
large scale events do that anyway.

	3. No more underground theme/feel, with an ocassional renage private 
party for our scene elders.

	4. Cost to put them in the paper each week if any, and would they
even let us do it. 

		_____________________________________________

	Ok theres a start, personally I'm all for keeping things as low
keyed as possible, I get my calendar every week and am just happy as a pig
in shit. I have no trouble keeping our scene nice & usually comfortable
the way it is, I prefer intimacy over hype anyday. I like my raves small,
either indoor or out, house party like. Being selfish isn't always negative.

	But we talk about the fact that diversity/acceptance/tolerence are
some of things were about, and that thats important to us. But the fact is
that most of the people in my circles when I talk about "RC" they think
I'm talking about Reevaluation Counseling, which is like AA, but very
different. With the numbers of people who show up so our events sometime,
the word is definately out there on the streets. Word of mouth adversing
is one of the most effective forms there is, and offers each person with
the knowledge the opportunity to filter it to "kind" people. 

	So I quess this comes back to an age old ?, why are we here, and 
what do we want rave culture to be, today, and in the future(only *YOU* 
can answer that one). Or is it just here so we can have a good time, 
right now(: no negative images meant :)? God knows I need a good time:)

	I would like to see R-Culture(ew ew a pun silly me) as an
**active** force, for spreading fun, positivity, peace, love, tolerence,
"awareness", and trust, though out our world, while having a great time.
But that's just my opinion. I would like to hear your PRO's & CON's about
publically posting our parties and your vision, (a few sentences to save
bandwidth please) of R-Culture. I just ask that they be your own honest
clear thoughts, not your parents, not your friend the DJ ...etc.
Feel/Thing(Phinking, B. Darkness Word) about what it really means to you,
what you would like see changed today, and where you would like to see
R-Culture in say 5 years, maybe 10, and please take your time. 

	No matter what we all say here R-Culture has its own path and
destiney, just like you and me. I just want to see whats on peoples
minds and in their hearts, with regard to our scene, a groups energy, 
their intentions, and dedication can acomplish great things. If you 
want to write more than that send it to me privately, cool. 

		Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace
		a.k.a Brian Darkness, LMT/BSEE/CET
		(510)-547-5984 CT Active Voice & Fax
		  (510)-885-5387 CT Active Pager

		Internet:	brianv@liberty.com
		Alt. Internet:	brianvan@liberty.com

		  "Come see the world in my eyes"

ps Personal disclaimer, I do not want you to follow me, follow yourself, I
do not want to lead anyone, unless its helping someone facillate finding
their own identity, and even then I don't like the responsibility. I'm
just happy being 100% pure ME!!!!(joyful), and hope you all find peace &
love for yourselfs with yourself. 



From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Apr 30 09:33:18 1995

From: Sami Khoury <red@hyperreal.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Public Newpaper Post, of Our SFR Calendar /Opinion
In-Reply-To: <Pine.3.89.9504300452.A8393-0100000@liberty.liberty.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.91.950430091651.19395B-100000@taz.hyperreal.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Brian:

> 	1. It would bring in a much greater diversity of peoples both
> enomically, intelectually, and racial. With this increased diveristy, more
> raves will be held, at bigger & better venues. R-Culture would be more
> widely accepted, and tolerated, and finally we as members of this 
> subculture would have many more allies/help/recourses. The benefits 
> mentioned would go to peacefully defend ourselves against the police, help 
> out local & nation charites ...etc. 

At first, I thought posting the SFR Calendar in the newspaper would be a 
really bad idea.  Your pro's though suggest otherwise.  The diversity 
issue is not one I pay much mind to simply because it is too hard to 
gauge fairly.  However, the public's perception of rave culture may be 
given more credibilty if it sees rave events being publicized in so 
public a forum.  With credibilty comes respect, and perhaps this would 
lead to less trouble with the cops.

> 	1. With the increased diveristy and public awareness, comes the 
> negative/destructive elements of society, also more commerializum.

There are many raves that are already quite commercial.  With more 
events, you'll be able to pick and choose--thus avoiding ones you know to 
be more "corporate".

> 	2. Events would seem to big, & lacking intimacy, but most of our
> large scale events do that anyway.

Some events would be huge and unintimate, and others would not.  You 
can't really apply this argument to the entire scene.

The possibilty exists that this could backfire horribly.  The fact is 
that there *are* some people who choose to use drugs at raves, and 
allowing the "public" (whoever that is) to evaluate our parties expects a 
certain amount of objectivity.  Many people's minds slam shut at the 
first sign of anything out of the ordinary, so...

Inconclusively yours,

	Sami

One of the concerns I have about throwing raves into the mainstream 
public with big commercial parties is that these may not turn out to be 
what I consider raves. 
I could be wrong about this, but it seems that alot of the mainstream 
public uses alcohol to reduce their inhibitions.  There very well may be 
alot of alocohol use at a big commercial party.  This doesn't have to be 
a horrible thing, but with big numbers of people drinking the chances go 
up of people not be able to deal with the high energy vibe in a peaceful 
loving manner.  The media will probably focus more on the negative 
aspects like people being out of control and getting into fights.
Actually techno and house music is played in mainstream clubs now.  Are 
these raves because of the music?
Does calling a PUBLIC event with techno and house music a RAVE make it a 
RAVE?

Sorry if I sound a little pessimistic this morning, haven't had my 
morning coffee yet. 

peter

Last night we went to 1015 to hear Andrew astralmatrix's new song he wrote 
for Terrence Toy. Saturday night at 1015 is very far from being a rave, it is 
very much a pickup scene. They are listening to much of the same music but 
they mostly dance as couples. Terrence Toy is one of my Favorite House DJ's 
and he has been spinning for as long as house music has been around. He 
has been to Come/Unity and Stompy and he would love to play a party where 
the vibe is so strong and the music loved. (Terrence even played the song first 
so we could get out of there)

In-Reply-To: <Pine.3.89.9504300452.A8393-0100000@liberty.liberty.com>
Message-Id: <Pine.SUN.3.91.950430140106.11134C-100000@ciao.cc.columbia.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

i can't help but to think that a subculture is a subculture is a 
subculture. And it must follow it's nature as that, even at the expense 
of dying out in years to come. I stumbled upon techno/trance/ambient 
music, and thus _found_ raves. It is something that people discover and 
arrive at. I don't expect it to survive indefinitely, and that is why I 
love it so much--it is * our zeitgeist *, everything about it is born from 
the conditions we are living in. I believe it must follow its natural 
course. One or two events of the year can probably afford to be public, 
and certainly we as individuals should not lose touch with mainstream 
america--mainstream _is_ America after all, but leave it be.
A flower grows through a rock because it was its destiny, not because  we 
forced it to.

love and evolution,
eugenie

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Apr 30 11:27:54 1995

In reaction to an original post from Brian Darkness:
> From: Brian Darkness <brianvan@liberty.liberty.com>
> Subject: Public Newpaper Post, of Our SFR Calendar /Opinion
> 
> ... I thought about how nice it would be for an average
> person, non-raver, non-lurker, earth ...etc, to be able to go to the
> community section and have SFR Calendar in what ever form the paper would
> except it, there along with the rest of the community happenings like Art
> Shows, Rock & Roll ...etc. 
> 
 It would be an interesting experiment. Some recent posts worry about
alcohol and the events getting too vibe-less - if the "cart is kept
BEHIND the horse" - i.e. , the raves listed in the SFRaves calender
keep the goals as vibe first , "mainstream" acceptance & alcohol sales
secondary , then I see no trouble.

 [ Imaginary ideas for making raves more "mainstream" -
   1. WET T-SHIRT NIGHT!
   2. Jaegrmeister shots only 75 cents before 11PM!
   3. WET BOXER SHORTS NIGHT!
   4. "Rave" dance contests!
   5. Arm wrestling night! ]

 BUT - With the overcrowded F&F event of recent times as an example -
some of the parties mentioned in SFRaves may not be set up for crowds
of folks showing up. Select "publicity" to keep crowd size down is
deliberate in those cases. Some editing of the weekly calender would
be required before it could be sent to the paper.

Dear All;

	Thanks for all the great responses to the idea about posting our
SFR Calendar to a newpaper like the Guardian, and keepem coming. I agree
with what most of you have said to varing degrees. 

	Eugenics point that techno is here to stay I feel is an acturate
one. Though I do feel there can be a laspe in popularity, for example I
was a part of the punk rock scene in Philadelphia, PA during the late 70's
early 80's. After about 83 - 84 the scene kinda died out due to no more
Hardcore Halls, & Clubs caring not to want to deal with the uppity nature
of the clientel(great spirit bless their narly little hearts, the punkers
everywhere that is). But the more people I meet who are about 10 years
younger than me are all into that music, so its kinda weird, that it took
another 10 years of listening to the same old super groups, before
mainstream radio, back east, to finally recogized them. 

	When I was heavily into it, punk rock I couldn't even image what a
Dead Kenneys CD would look like, today you can get the complete
collection, in a boxed set no doubt. Very similar to the way techno is
today, everything being primarilly or vinial, or cassette. I hope they
don't make the same mistake they did with "new wave/punk rock". Because 
the real shame there is that a lot of the really ggod bands are either 
MIA, dead, insane. or just out of the biz, or doing other thing musically.

	I'm a little disappointed that no one I've read yet, has told me 
about what their vision of our scene is today, and 5 - 10 years what they 
would like it to look like. I'm sincerely interested in your ideas, the 
scene belongs to everyone, so I feel everyone should have a say. I 
promise I won't flame you, invalidate you Phinking, or even laugh; unless 
you intented it to be funny, promise, cross my cpu, and hope for an 
electrostatic discharge. If your still shy, send it to me privately.

	As far as the alcohol think goes, I don't like booze, booze
doesn't like me. But I do understand that a lot of people enjoy the
comsumsion of booze, and do it responsibly. My response is that there are
penty of places to go to drink booze & listen to house, techno ...etc, why
do we have to be like everyone else who serves alcohol, R-Culture prides
itself on being different, I think in our world, that we as a race of
beings we should be able to go to an techno event, and not have booze offered
to us, or accept it, and just ask the people who drink to bring there own,
its cheaper anyway, it saves the booze consumers money, and we make a
statement to the General Public that alcohol is a dangerous drug, much
more dangerous than some of the illegal ones, especially in the hands of a
Fratt person, on testostrone OD, with a 5.0 liter. I think thats 
what a lot on Con Alcohol ravers would like to see happen, anyway. 

	Of course most of the promoters would have a shit fit, not 
allowing them to serve alcohol at a big big event, try some other 
night to make your 200% profit, and on another group of people.

	There some reasonable, aware promoters in the bay area, what 
little dealing with Martin of Communion, I've had has always been open 
for neogiation. Opps and need I not forget Ethan of F&F, whos crediabilty, 
and dedication to our scene speaks for itself. I can't speak for him, but 
I'm sure if you had a reasonable political agenda you were bringing with you 
to a big event that he would definately here you, or do something like 
makings the booze proceeds go to things like, Ravers Defense Fund, or 
MADD ...etc

	So please respond to the 2nd set of ?, it gives me a lot of
information about how people feel about techno & raves, and what they want
to do with all this wonderful positivity & love, today and in the years to
come. But its still ok to want to keep it all for yourself, any change is
scarey, and somethings can happen as a result of change that make it
impossible to go back to the way things where.

Guess what me found today?  I found a nice little list of upcoming Orb 
U.S. concert dates.  I just received the latest keyboard magazine, 
complete with Orb cover story.  I opened the mag to read the article, and 
lo and behold, found the following list.  And away we go!

May 30 - Masquerade, Atlanta, GA
June 2 - Venus de Milo, Boston, MA  <---------------***
June 3 - Roseland, N'yawk, N'yawk
June 4 - The Trocadero, Philly, PA
June 6 - TBA, Montreal, Quebec
June 7 - TBA, Toronto, Ontario (my kinda town)
June 9 - Phoenix Center, Detroit, MI (bring your combat gear)
June 10 - The Metro, CHITOWN, Land of Wonder, IL (fuck yeah!!!!)
June 12 - The Bomb Factory (NOT in Oklahoma), Dallas, TX
June 16 - Warfield Theatre (NOT in Bosnia), San Fran, CA <----------***
June 17 - The Shrine (wear your Fez), Los Angeles, CA


There you have it, folks.  Hope you're all within driving or flying 
distance to these shows.  

**Special disclaimer.  I am not, repeat NOT to be held responsible if 
something happens like the whole damned tour being cancelled like the 
last one.  Also, the jokes were meant to be jokes.  I don't want any 
E-mail bombs being sent to me.  I'm too young to die (plus who would be 
uncool enough to hurt a girl anyway.  PS - I also wear glasses too).

Mistress ov Groupie News

> Does anyone know the copyright laws about making mix-tapes?  How can DJ's 
> make tpaes with published music on them, without paying royalties?  Or do 
> they pay royalties?  Any ideas?

A while back, Spun released a mix cd.  The liner notes did not reveal so 
much as a tracklisting, indicating that he is not paying royalties (I am 
not certain about this, though).  It's a really complex issue, but if 
you plan on releasing a mixtape, you should at least include a track 
listing (credit where it's due...).

	Sami

	id PAA29126; Sun, 30 Apr 1995 15:37:01 -0700
Date: Sun, 30 Apr 1995 15:37:01 -0700
Message-Id: <199504302237.PAA29126@ix4.ix.netcom.com>
From: bradleyg@ix.netcom.com (Bradley Graham)
Subject: Re: Public Newpaper Post, of Our SFR Calendar /Opinion
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

What makes raves so distinctive is not the music (I can hear the same
music at home or in a club) but rather the culture and community.  I
like the fact that at a rave I see people that I know, get hugs from
people I don't know, as well as talk and dance with women who know my
motivation is not to pick them up.   To a great extent this is not
possible at a club.  A private party yes.  At a club no because the
underlying dynamics are different.

The ranks of the rave community will expand and contract as people pass
through various stages in their lives.  This isn't, of course, to say 
that all people will eventually enter (and ultimately exit) the rave
scene.  Some people never will.  My sense is that this is more an issue 
of personal preference.  It is really unrelated to age, ethnicity, 
socioeconomic status (at $20 a pop it is pricing some people out of the 
market!), sexual orientation, political affiliation, religion (ok,
maybe not religion though I once heard about an all christian rave but
perhaps it was a joke??), body piercing, tatooing, etc.  Did I cover 
everything??? :>)  I see a great deal of diversity at raves.  In fact,
it usually seems more diverse than regualr clubs.  Adverstising isn't 
necessary to reprofile the demographics of the rave community.

As with most anything in life, if you want it bad enough, you'll put
forth the effort to find/get it.  This is certainly true of all illegal
or non-mainstream things (I am not associating these two things)
such as drugs, automatic or semiautomic weapons, alcohol if you're
underage, non-English language films, topic specific publications, and
raves.  Let's think about it for a second.  How hard is it to find a 
rave???  I mean, you can find posters or those little cards advertising
raves all over.  They're in record stores, clothing stores, hair 
salons, etc. (haven't seen them in the grocery store though)!  Sheesh! 
I mean, the only thing other they could do is put up a billboard
on the 101 and a full page ad in the WSJ.  And, don't forget that
hyperreal provides space to publish the weekly sfrave calendar on the
internet or that there are newsgroups and irc channels for raves.  That
makes it available to the millions of people with a pc and a modem (and
internet access).  I think raves are as a result becoming too 
popularized, too impersonal, and too mainstream.

Rave culture is on the outskirts of the mainstream.  That's where it
belongs.  That's how it differentiates itself from the establishment.
Why?  Because major elements of RC fall outside what is generally
accepted by society at large including but not limited to the use of
drugs or other intoxicants (illicit or otherwise), staying out until
very early in the morning (even on weekdays!), and so on.  There's much
more but my poor brain is still not fully operational after last night!
 
It seems RC is having an identity crisis.  One the one hand, people 
want to keep it underground and "exclusive" while on the other hand it
is being thrust into the mainstream by promoters who want to profit
from it.   I mean some of these guys (and the venue/concession owners)
are major profiteers.  Does RC encompass charging $.50 for a swig of 
tap water (like they were doing last night at Diverse City)??  No sign
of peace, love, unity, etc. in that as far as I can see!  I am not sure
advertising will get us where we want to be.  RC has to evolve but
it should evolve in its own way, at its own pace while maintaining its
original raison d'etre and spirit.  The risk of expanding too quickly
is the loss of those special qualities that are missing or not equally
evident in the mainstream.  To push RC unmercifully into the mainstream
by advertising raves more broadly will have a profound and irreversible
impact on RC (sorry for the meladramatic wording).  Then, a rave would
simply be another *club*.

Bradley


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Apr 30 15:41:25 1995

I was having some thoughts earlier in the day of Web sites and the such.
I've not been on this list for much more than a month but I've found that

philosophies and thoughts of my own.  I'd like to compile works from others
and post it as an extension to one of my pages.

thoughts and feeling of me, yet I'm addressing the entire population of rave
culture...

Subject: Re: Public Newpaper Post, of Our SFR Calendar /Opinion
To: bradleyg@ix.netcom.com (Bradley Graham), sfraves@hyperreal.com
X-Mailer: AIR Mail 3.X (SPRY, Inc.)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I want to say that I really appreciate Bradley's post.  I must say that I 
agree that we need to evolve at our own pace and not be forced into an 
evolution that is not necessarily our choosing.  If we want to go mainstream 
than that is *our* decision and that is also a probability of more promoting. 
 Though, I am not suggesting that we will become mainstream, things like 
publishing all of our gatherings for anyone and everyone to join allows and 
invites people in large numbers who may not understand us and may not promote 
the community we have developed.  And let me say...It is the *best* thing 
going and probably the neatest thing I have ever experienced! :)  We have the 
opportunity to introduce people that we meet in the "mainstream world" to this 
community, as others have said, who may appreciate and promote our values.  We 
have an opportunity, and to some degree and obligation, to take what we have 
out there and find a way to integrate it into our mainstream lives.  Those who 
understand, are interested, or relate should be invited to join us and they 
will in turn bring people who have responded to them in the same manner.  We 
can evolve collectively, ever promoting what we believe in rather than being 
forced to adapt to new environments which we already know we definately do not 
want to be part of.

I don't want to sound too exclusive.  We take what we have, this incredible 
since of community which shares core values promoting -peace, unity, 
tolerance, love, etc. - and we share it with as many people as we can.  There 
are enough of us, growing larger every day to make an impact...I just don't 
want to see the door open and mainstream society, many with dominator vales, 
come crashing in.  There are no distinctions, as I see them, in our community 
- we are all wonderful people.  I would like to see us evolve in a manner that 
promotes and rewards this.

"Take a ride on the rhythm of love....:)"

Love Anais
bliss@rain.org
