>equally evident in the mainstream.  To push RC unmercifully into the 
>mainstream by advertising raves more broadly will have a profound and 
>irreversible impact on RC (sorry for the meladramatic wording).  Then, a 
>rave would simply be another *club*.

What do I want the San Francisco rave scene to be like in 5 to 10 years?

That is a very difficult and easy question to answer.  Difficult in that 
the scene has changed alot since it began. It is always changing, it 
seems.  So many complain bitterly because "it ain't what it used to be."  
Well, change is the only constant - it's how you *deal* with the change 
that makes a difference.  Who knows what the scene will be like in 5 to 
10 years.  The music and attitude are a reflection of what is happening 
in the world at that time and what people *want* out of their scene.  
That could change drastically for all I know. We have no way of knowing.

The part that is easy to answer in what I want out of the scene in 5 to 
10 years is that I still want that incredible music, wonderful people and 
most of all - that Peace, Love, Unity, and Respect.  I still get that 
today, even if the rave scene is quite different than from when it 
began.  It is all what you (as in everybody involved) decide to make of 
it.  There is my 2 cents for the evening.:)

love,
Amy

Hi JC!
There's jillions of people out there making illegal copies of copyright
protected music.  That's what most of the big DAT player debate was all 
about.  That's why to prevent pirating the movie industry has started to
scramble portions of the video stream on pre-recorded videos.  Of course,
the video industry has also considerably reduce their prices whereas the
music industry has not.  Music has only got more expensive even they are
using a much cheaper medium.  Figure that one out!  Net, net of it all is
that while jillions are doing it, I would hate to be the person they made
an example of!  :>)

Bradley


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Apr 30 22:14:36 1995

Date: Mon, 1 May 95 15:17 EST
From: crunch@sysx.apana.org.au (John Draper)
To: adrave@box.apana.org.au, ausrave@smug.student.adelaide.edu.au,
        sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Soundscape review
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


SoundScape Review
-----------------

Well,   at the request of the Adravers,   I took my trek to Adelaide this
weekend and arrived at the airport on Thursday afternoon,  and was picked 
up by Cris and Barry at the airport.

I was immediatly taken to the Uni and given a tour of some of it's more
interesting places,   checked my Email,  then taken over to Simon's place.

While over there,  we hung out,  and listened to some really good trance
music played on a pair of 1200's.   After that,  I tried my hand and spinning
a few tunes,   but my unfamiliarity with the records got the best of me,  but
I did lay down some fairly well beat matched sets until I got bored.   I
would rather be at the business end of the turntables    :-)

Adelaide was much smaller than I expected,  but fairly spread out over a 
large area.    The Uni was situated near the Botanical gardens,  the
zoo,   and one of 4 very large parks surrounding the city.

Later that evening,  we went to a small club called "Heaven" to hear a 
DJ from Detroit,   but we got there while the line was still fairly 
long.   Instead we head over to another place and hung out before going 
back to check out "Heaven" again.

Eventually,  we get there,   but I was turned away at the door because of
strict dress code.   I eventually had to go over and pick up acceptable
threads and return.

WARNING!! Adelaide clubs have strict dress codes just about everywhere,
and there is NO SPECIFICATION for what is acceptable.   

I finally get in...  and discovered that the venue was very big.   One of
the biggest clubs I've been in in a ling time.

Mostly house music was on the menu,   but when the Detroit DJ finally went
on,   I wasn't that impressed.    Shortly afterward,   I was pulled away
by my host,   who wanted to go home and sleep.

I did the same (because i've beeen awake 2 days already),  and wanted to
to try and sleep so I can do a "no sleep" weekend.

On friday,  we go over to the venue to check it out...   The venue is an
old boat house,  where the Uni rowing team stores their rowing boats.

Upstairs,  it's used as a gym for weights,   rowing machines (of course),
and other athletic gear.    Downstairs was where the boats were stored.
It looked like it was going to take a long time to get the venue spruced
up for the rave,  but after a lot of hard work from everyone in AdRave,
the place was really done up excellently.

During the day,  I was running around giving interviews,  and meeting people,
as well as helping clean up the venue.   I also met the Mind Virus people,
and had long talk with Nick,  met a lot of Hacker types,  before heading
out to check out the local Adelaide club scene.

Friday evening...  was Discovery,  and Cargo Club.   By the time I got to
Cargo club,   things had fizzled out...  As usual,  we had a hard time with
the door goon.   He said "We are closed.." when we arrived,  but inside,
it was clear that at least 30 people were in there.   Aventually,  one of
the DJ's finally came out and insisted that we be let in...  The door goon
pointed accusingly to us and said "The only reason why I'm letting you in,
is because Adrian (the DJ) said it's ok".

As we go in,  the DJ was playing house,  but nobody was dancing.   So soon
after that,  we head over to Discovery.

At discovery,  we get the same treatment...   only this time,  Mr Steriod
head said "Can't let you in here... Improper attire".   All the while,
other people,  wearing even more grungery attire were coming and going.

That dude was either stoked up with Steriods,  or had a very bad day,  and
no convincing would make the asshole change his mind,  so we left.

I head back to Simon's place and did some net surfing,  using Nick's account
which is connected DIRECTLY to AARNET.   OmyGad!!  what a difference a fast
link makes....  As daylight approaches,   we go off for breakfast...

Later that morning,  we head over the boat house,  and started cleaning it
up for the party tonight.   I had another inerview with Adrian (the DJ I met
last night) who's working on a Techno magazine.   Did a lot o yoga and stuff
that afternoon before the party,  tuning myself up for a long evengings worth
of dancing.

Early in the evening,   it started to rain,   but evenutually made it back to
the venue...  Omygod!!  What a change...   The chill room was nothing short
of amazing...  Now THIS is a chill room.   Plenty of foam matresses,  and a huge
bean bag over in the corner.  Chairs all around the sides,  and a 400 watt
black light really made this a visual experience.  Although no music (which
would have been impractical,  due to close proximity to mai room),  it
didn't really matter.  What mattered was the abundance of nice soft places
to flop down on.

The main room had really good lighting...  with the sound system at one end,
provided plenty of dance space dispite is smallish size.

At first,  the crowd size was very small,  and I was asked to quickly go
somewhere for a short time,   but got back before nobody noticed me missing.

When I returned,  about 60 people had arrived,  and the vibe picked up 
considerably.   Some awsome german trance was on,  so I wasted no time in
getting on the dance floor.   WOW!!   my mind completly left my body
as I was wildly moving around.   Eventually they broke into Jungle,  so
took opportunity to take a break and schmooze around with the AdRavers
for  while.    But it didn't tke me long before I was out there on the
dancefloor again,  groovin to some pretty awsome jungle/breakbeat stuff.

The place was packed,  and those that arrived during that time,  got
turned away,  or were told to come back later.   There were times it
got fairly hot,   but the fans kept things cool and made it tolerable

After that,  Hardcore,  and I mean HARDCORE!!  Really fast.  hi energy
hardcore...  WOW!!  I went insane.   All evening long...  Fast Hard 
Hardcore.   I would have liked more Acid Trance,  thats what my biggest
complaint was.   Also,  the MC sort of spoiled my head space on some
tracks.   I remember hearing tapes of the Universe raves in the UK
with MC's but this is the first one I've been to that has them.   I don't
think I would like to hear MC's oll the time...   Its sort of distracting
at times.   I mean of they had something useful to say,   I suppose that
would be allright.

I would say it was 80% hardcore with a little bit of house towards the
beginning and the end.   

The rave went on well into the morning.   Even as we started to clean
up afterwards,  the music was going.    I danced al the way to the end.

So,  in summary...  Soundscape WENT OFF!!   Was really good!!   Hi 
energy,  great vibe...  And for me,  was well worth the flight and the
effort I made to get to Adelaide to meet the Adravers.

Venue - 9
Music - 8 (Could have more variaty)
Vibe - 10
Visuals - 8 (Chill room was INSANE)
Chill room - 10  (It even had a fan)

This compares very favorably with the SFRaves Friends and Family parties
and I sure hope there's more to come.

Congrats go to the Adravers for putting on such a wonderful party..
Sydney,  now it's YOUR TURN!!

====
Crunchman

Hi SFRaves.  I'm trying to think of some interesting things about last 
nights party at King st...
VIsual screen: I think it was Synergy and Pure or something and they had 
the usual multi layer thing but this was like everything!  At one point 
there was a computer generated landscape rotating and mirrored so you had 
this sense of travel forward, with a slide of a guys face in sunglasses 
flanked by a film loop of a pair of ducks flapping in place and some kind 
of pulsating glowy thing for his brain.  Whoa momma!
Maybe it was due to the fact that I haven't been out in a few months but 
I couldn't find the vibal energy on the dancefloor, just a whole lot of 
people dancing.  Not that there's anything wrong with that! better 
dancing than drunk driving.  One thing you gotta like is saying "stompy 
stomp" .  outside a young girl with I believe a new zealand accent asked 
me if I had been in "stuwmpy stuwmp" and if she could copy my hand 
stamp.  "What hand stamp?" I ask. Door people dissed me on that one. and 
I continued my stroll down the embarcadero reciting "stuwmpy stuwmp" over 
and over and over again...

I've been a lurker for some time now on sfraves, but finally feel the need to
add my 2 cents worth to the Mix Tapes question. 
This is part of a much larger controversy which came about when cassete tapes
first allowed a person to record published music without the artist getting
credit. It is still an issue and is getting more attention since  DAT tapes
now make it possible to reproduce without tape generation loss. As far as I
know it is officially illegal to record a published work even if you bought
the original copy yourself, if no royalties are paid to the artist. We all
know that is not enforced or we'd all be in trouble. Now I am definetely not
an expert so please inform instead of flaming if I got something wrong
(little sensitive me may go back to lurking if it gets too hot). What follows
is my own personal opinion.
Regardless of the legality issue which you may choose to ignore, there is a
moral one. 1/3 of my income in 1994 came from publishing royalties due to
being in the first version of a little known band called Counting Crows (she
name drops shamelessly). Now I am as guilty as any of buying and even dubbing
copies (double whammy) of mix tapes, and it is always with a pang of guilt
since I know that I am cheating some hard working Songwriter/DJ out there.
Publishing Royalties are a Songwriter's bread and butter. Since techno music
gets alot less airplay  and thus fewer Performance royalties than pop music,
I imagine Publishing royalties are alot more important to a Techno/Dance
music songwriter. in response to Jesus Chrysler's Post, as far as I know it
is not illegal for DJs to be playing published or copyrighted works, but they
are supposed to pay a licensing fee of some sort to ASCAP or BMI which are
the organizations responsible for keeping track of and distributing
Performance Royalties to the artist whenever their song is played (there are
changes going on in congress in regards to all this but I won't elaborate.
Anyone interested can Email me privately and I can send them info that BMI
sends me regularly). I believe that most nightclubs do pay this fee but
because of the nature of raves the artist never gets compensated as far as I
know. The first post regarding mix tapes mentioned the fact that song credits
are rarely included. I feel this is a shame for two good reasons. The first
is that if I like an artist I hear on a mix tape I would love to go out and
buy their CD therefore indirectly supporting the artist with publishing
royalties. The second reason is that if there are no credits, the artist
doesn't even get any recognition for the offspring he worked so hard to
create and was so proud of. Most artists I know feel this way about their
creations, as if it were a part of them. Where would we be without all of
these beautiful songs that move us so much (no pun intended). Let's put the
word out to all the DJs that we can, that we would like credits on the Mix
tapes so that we can at least give praise in our hearts (if not $ in the
pockets) to the creators of all this wonderful music.  
So take this for what it is worth, but whatever you decide let it be an
informed decision and one you feel comfortable with.

Love Lydia
(what is a rocker doing on this list anyway?!)
 

P.S. I'm almost always at sunset so come say Hi if you spot me (long black
hair- bright red on top with a little black and white dog tagging at my
heals)

Happiness is only a smile away!
